fields.headline: Keegan sees the tide turning
fields.trailText: After 34 years of hurt, self examination, navel gazing, inferiority complexes and frustration, Kevin Keegan believes the tide of German superiority over England has turned. 'We're fed up of hearing they've got something on us and we play them again soon. I hope we make them pay as we've had to pay.'
fields.body:
After 34 years of hurt, self examination, navel gazing, inferiority complexes and frustration, Kevin Keegan believes the tide of German superiority over England has turned. 'We're fed up of hearing they've got something on us and we play them again soon. I hope we make them pay as we've had to pay.'

The fighting talk didn't stop there. It was put to the England coach that this was a sweet moment for his goalscorer, Alan Shearer, the man in whom he has never lost faith even though he has been so bitterly maligned by a few people lately. 'A few people? Alan Shearer has answered his critics again. Just give him two or three days before you knock him again. You have knocked him, pummelled him, questioned his right to be in the side, questioned his right to be captain. He has never, ever given less than 100 per cent. A boxer couldn't take the knocks he has.

'He's a man amongst men - that's why he's my captain. And I'd have him as my captain if he changed his mind for the World Cup qualifiers starting in September.'

Shearer himself was more subtle in his sense of personal vindication. 'A few people had stories written concerning myself and I'm very pleased to have scored and very pleased to have beaten Germany. You can see by our reaction at the end that we have to come down in the dressing room and realise we have won a game. But now the hard work starts again.'

But briefly, surely, it is simply a time to relish. 'People say it's not the best German side but they gave us a really tough game, which is what I expected. What made the difference was spirit and togetherness, and that want to put something behind us. The committment was tremendous. It was a real man's game tonight,' purred Keegan. No-one gave you anything - you had to earn it. Our destiny is in our own hands now and you can't ask for more than that.

'A lot of people have waited a long time for this and I am so proud I was in charge when it happened. It wasn't the most classic game I have been involved in but it was the most important.' And with that he was off with a playful farewell to all and sundry, in his best Deutchse accent: 'Auf Wiedersehn.'

fields.headline: Man for man marking
fields.trailText: England - how they rated
fields.body:
England - how they rated

David Seaman 8

Securely smothered the first shot of the game, a long range fizzer from Hamann. Settled England's early nerves, and later, an excellent reaction block from Kirsten prevented a certain equaliser. This was his most comanding international performance for a long while..

Gary Neville 8

A reasonably solid performance, full of heart, which didn't let England down.

Sol Campbell 7

Had his work cut out coping with the gargantuan handful that is Jancker. Needed to be a giant - and was.

Martin Keown 8

Recovered from an early knock to be an uncompromising, unyielding presence. Stood for no nonsense, his brave display compensated amply for the absence of Tony Adams.

Phil Neville 5

Exposed in the back four, he struggled to cope when Germany advanced down the England right. Too often he lost his man, Scholl, in the danger zone but luckily the Bayern playmaker shot first weakly and then wide.

David Beckham 8

You could sense German anxiety with every raid down the right flank - one visionary cross picked out Scholes brilliantly. The arch-creator made the difference with yet another indefensive delivery, bullishly converted by Shearer. How many more times does he have to produce the killer ball before the numbskulls get off his back? Booked for an unnecessary hack at Kirsten.

Paul Scholes 8

A mature performance from England's most creative force in the heart of midfield. Drifted all over the park to shrewd and dangerous effect. Looked the most likely to unlock the door, and desperately unlucky to see a vicious dipping volley beaten away by Oliver Kahn just before half time. Made way for Nick Barmby after running himself into the ground.

Paul Ince 8

Sufficient in the water carrier role - not as commanding as he once was - but job done. Grew in stature as the game went on.

Dennis Wise 7

Supremely diligent filling in on the left flank. Under the circumstances proved himself the right man for the job on the night.

Alan Shearer 7

This could have been billed as the day the captain went down with his sinking ship. For 51 minutes, with all the will in the world, his contribution lacked the pace or power to upset the Germans. Just as it was looking a tournament too far he gave us a flashback of the potent predator of Euro 96 with a jubilant header. One nil to the Eng-er-land.

Michael Owen 8

Ploughed a desolate furrow against a well-manned German defence. England seldom have the ingenuity to play to his strengths. Inspired the first signs of belief with a splendid header which Kahn clawed out. Still looks short of match fitness, and was replaced by Steven Gerrard, who was outstanding, on the hour.

fields.headline: Survive the junk jungle
fields.trailText: • Keep your email alert switched off when you are busy; check for mail at particular times each day.
fields.body:
 Keep your email alert switched off when you are busy; check for mail at particular times each day.

 Use a holding email to acknowledge a message, and promise to get back later with a detailed reply.

 Send your emails on a strictly 'need to know' basis; don't include everyone on a mailing list unless it is really necessary.

 Don't ask questions when sending email, unless you really want to get a reply.

 Prioritise your incoming mail.

 Avoid registering on dozens of websites so you keep your junk mail to a minimum.

webTitle: Are you suffering from PMS (post mail syndrome)?

fields.headline: Are you suffering from PMS (post mail syndrome)?
fields.standfirst: An unruly inbox is a major cause of stress and wasted time, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: An unruly inbox is a major cause of stress and wasted time, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
'You've got mail.' Those three words are increasingly a cause of dread, as the massive growth in emails becomes yet another source of anxiety for the nation's stressed-out office workers.

For most people, email is a wonderful invention - an efficient way of communicating that is instant, direct, and costs virtually nothing. The problem comes when those emails start building up in your in-box and you become a victim of information overload. It is stressful trying to respond to hundreds of messages, and the danger is that a really vital one will get lost.

A recent UK survey found that users are now spending three hours a day reading and composing emails - twice as long as a couple of years earlier. It is believed that in the US, more emails are sent every day - some 300 million - than letters.

On this side of the Atlantic, a study by the Institute of Management earlier this year found that email is now identified as the tenth-greatest cause of stress in the workplace. The most stressful aspect of email is, most would agree, the sheer volume of it. One journalist, returning from a two-week holiday in Cuba recently, found 400 emails awaiting him in two inboxes. It took him a day to work his way through them, deleting many without even opening them. Receiving 20 or 30 emails a day is now commonplace, and some peo ple - particularly at hi-tech companies such as Microsoft - are used to receiving hundreds a day.

Elizabeth Lank of IT services company ICL, says: 'I would guess I get 30 or 40 a day. But when you really feel the pain is when you've been out of the office for more than a day, and they start mounting up. The thing I find really stressful is that I feel very bad if I don't respond to somebody - it doesn't seem very professional.'

As a result, she says, she often spends time on Sunday evening going through the previous week's unanswered emails, to avoid starting the week with unresolved mail. She finds the best way to cope with large numbers of emails on a daily basis is to automatically prioritise incoming mails according to colour.

'Anything I've been copied on is probably for information purposes only, so in the email program I have set up that is in yellow, while emails sent only to me are in blue. Anything I get from the chief executive is in red, to ensure important messages don't get lost.'

Mark Hastings, policy director at the Institute of Management, says it is not just the volume of emails that is a problem; their instantaneous nature also causes stress. 'People think they need to respond instantly, so they get involved in a kind of corporate tennis match, where they are lob bing messages backwards and forwards over the net,' he explains. One tactic he suggests is sending a 'holding' email, which acknowledges the message and promises to get back with a more detailed response later.

'You need to schedule dealing with emails into your working day and stick rigorously to the time you have set aside,' he says. Perhaps the greatest culprits in the proliferation of emails are people who copy their messages to all and sundry, when this is simply not necessary. Why do they do this? Imogen Daniels, an adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, says: 'It's largely an anxiety thing: wanting to make sure that everyone has all the information.'

Emails are also a convenient way to cover your back in an environment where office politics are rife, but in some cases the proliferation is simply the result of thoughtlessness. Lank says: 'Ask yourself who really needs this information.' At ICL, she has taken charge of the 'global' email facility, so anybody who wants to send a message to everyone in the company has to ask permission first. Most can quickly be persuaded that there is a way of targeting the message more efficiently, she says.

Hastings at the Institute of Management suggests that if companies really want to get the best from their employees, rather than making their lives more stressed, they should have an explicit policy advising people on how to use the email system. Many companies do have an email policy, but it tends to focus on issues such as security, viruses and material, rather than email etiquette. Hastings says the policy should outline the types of messages that should be sent by email, and the acceptable time in which somebody should respond. He adds that companies could also provide staff with basic training on how to manage their inbox.

With WAP-enabled mobile phones becoming more common, and broadband communications being introduced by airlines later this year, getting away from email will become almost impossible. 'Psychologically, the feeling that you are constantly accessible can be very stressful in itself,' says Hastings.

Nevertheless, according to Winston Fletcher, communications director of advertising agency FCB Europe, some people make themselves a martyr to their inbox. He says: 'You hear about people who, even if they get an email when they are out on a Saturday night, will answer it promptly when they get back. It shows that you are wanted, that you are loved, and to that extent it is flattering. But you should only reply when you are ready to do so.' For all its undoubted advantages, email is, in any case, not always the best way to communicate. IPD's Daniels says:

'I seriously wonder whether it's the best way to consult with somebody, because you simply end up going back and forth. Sometimes it may be simpler to just pick up the phone and talk.'

webTitle: Beware: they may look friendly but...

fields.headline: Beware: they may look friendly but...
fields.standfirst: Many pension companies are embracing stakeholder schemes, but some investors will face ludicrous charges, says  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Many pension companies are embracing stakeholder schemes, but some investors will face ludicrous charges, says Jill Insley
fields.body:
Pension investors could lose hundreds of pounds by investing in so-called 'stakeholder-friendly' schemes before the launch of the new pension scheme in April.

The stakeholder pension is a new low-cost scheme designed to encourage people earning between £9,500 and £21,600 to save for their retirement, although those earning more will also benefit. The new scheme will be introduced in 10 months, but several pensions companies are marketing their current personal pension schemes as stakeholder-friendly or stakeholder-compliant by offering to switch policyholders from their personal pension to their stakeholder scheme free of charge.

However, a survey by Money Management magazine this month shows that the charges levied by these personal pension plans will consume a large proportion of investors' contributions. Janet Walford, editor of Money Management, says: 'Some of the charges are so high that, ignoring the loss of a year's potential growth and the tax relief, consumers would be better off putting their money in the building society until April.'

Money Management compared the amount that would result from investing in a personal pension now and transferring the premiums to a stakeholder scheme in April with the amount that would be built up if you were able to invest the same premiums in a stakeholder scheme over the same period.

Only five of 48 pension companies surveyed - Equitable Life, Friends Provident, Marks & Spencer, Standard Life, and Virgin Direct - offer penalty-free switches from their personal pension to their own or other companies' stakeholder pensions. Two more - Legal & General and Nationwide - offer penalty-free switches to their own stakeholder plan, but switches to other companies' plans would involve penalties in the form of a lower transfer value.

Twenty of the companies surveyed - including Norwich Union, Royal Sun Alliance, Scottish Amicable and Scottish Widows - would provide transfer values worth less than 93 per cent of the premiums invested. In the case of the example used, 93 per cent of the £650 paid in premiums would be £605. These companies would not only fail to match stakeholder standards, but would also 'materially disadvantage' the investor, according to guidelines issued by the Association of British Insurers last year.

Scottish Widows, which is marketing its personal pensions as 'stakeholder standard', would charge the Money Management investor £101 for a transfer into its own stakeholder scheme; Scottish Equitable, which describes its plan as 'stakeholder-friendly', would charge £99; and Edinburgh Fund Managers, which intends to implement changes to fit in with the new rules when stakeholder plans are finalised, would charge a staggering £181.

However, Mark Birks of Royal & SunAlliance says there is a danger that pension investors will become so obsessed with pension charges, they will forget about investment performance. 'Of course charges are important when assessing different schemes,' he says, 'but the difference that a good investment management team can make to the overall return you can expect will dwarf charges over the long term.'

Stakeholder pensions: the facts

 Stakeholder pension plans are available to employees who do not belong to an occupational pension scheme, the self-employed and, for the first time, people with no earned income.

 You can contribute the higher of £3,600 (irrespective of earnings) or a proportion of your relevant earnings. The amount is determined by your age and level of earnings - from 17.5 per cent for people aged 35 or under to 40 per cent for those aged 61 and over.

 Total charges on a stakeholder pension will be limited to a maximum of 1 per cent a year - with no upfront fees.

 All stakeholder schemes must set their minimum contribution level at £20 or less.

 You will not be penalised for contributing irregular amounts, missing or stopping payments.

 Firms with five or more employees must offer a scheme for their employees if they do not already provide an occupational scheme or group personal pension for all their employees.

 They must deduct employees' contributions from payroll. However, they are not obliged to make contributions to the stakeholder scheme on behalf of their employees.

 Contributions will be paid net of basic-rate tax. Higher-rate taxpayers can claim higher-rate tax relief through their annual return. People who pay no or lower rates of tax will receive relief at the basic rate.

With so much at stake, your money could be better spent

People aged 40 or more with little in the way of savings could be better off spending their spare cash rather than investing it in a stakeholder pension, according to draft advice issued by the pensions and investment watchdog, the Financial Services Authority.

The FSA has drawn up draft 'decision trees', to help people decide whether they should invest in a stakeholder scheme or not. A decision tree entitled 'How much should I save for when I retire?' indicates that people aged 40 or more, who can only afford to save £20 a month, could receive a monthly pension of less than £47. This, combined with the basic state pension, is not enough to exceed the minimum income guarantee, a means-tested benefit which currently ensures that a single person receives at least £339.95 a month.

In guidance notes accompanying the decision trees, the FSA says: 'Particularly if you are over 40, have little pension or other savings and cannot afford to save much, the little you are able to put into a stakeholder may not be enough to bring your total retirement income above the MIG. It would then be wasted.'

Some pension providers and independent financial advisers fear this information will discourage the over-40s from saving. But Martin Campbell of Virgin Direct does not think the FSA has gone far enough in clarifying the situation: 'We would like the Government to state a minimum funding level for people of different ages - a clear benchmark showing whether it's in their interests to save in a stakeholder, or whether they should be considering an alternative form of saving.'

Someone saving a small amount in an Isa, for example, could use their savings to pay off part of their mortgage and thus prevent the money counting against their means-tested benefits after retirement.

In contrast, the low charges and flexibility of stakeholder schemes should prove advantageous to investors on average or higher earnings. The 1 per cent cap on annual charges is expected to become the industry norm for personal pensions, and the lower profit margins and increased competition between pension providers is likely to result in a flood of mergers and takeovers, making the choice of a specific stakeholder scheme easier.

However, Nick Bamford, of independent pensions adviser Cranleigh Informed Choice, says that even wealthier investors would benefit by keeping part of their savings outside of a pension scheme. He said: 'While the tax advantages of pensions are undoubtedly attractive, you cannot access any of your money until you reach retirement age. As you never know when you might need some capital, it's a good idea to put some of your money into an Isa or some other accessible investment scheme.'

 A new Trades Union Congress webpage contains information and can answer questions about stakeholder pensions.

 For the FSA's draft decision trees, visit www.fsa.gov.uk click on publications, followed by discussion papers and download PDF 1.23MM.

But Martin Campbell of Virgin Direct does not think the FSA has gone far enough in clarifying the situation: 'We would like the Government to state a minimum funding level for people of different ages - a clear benchmark showing whether it's in their interests to save in a stakeholder, or whether they should be considering an alternative form of saving.' Someone saving a small amount in an Isa, for example, could use their savings to pay off part of their mortgage and thus prevent the money counting against their means-tested benefits after retirement. In contrast, the low charges and flexibility of stakeholder schemes should prove advantageous to investors on average or higher earnings. The 1 per cent cap on annual charges is expected to become the industry norm for personal pensions, and the lower profit margins and increased competition between pension providers is likely to result in a flood of mergers and takeovers, making the choice of a specific stakeholder scheme easier. However, Nick Bamford, of independent pensions adviser Cranleigh Informed Choice, says that even wealthier investors would benefit by keeping part of their savings outside of a pension scheme. He said: 'While the tax advantages of pensions are undoubtedly attractive, you cannot access any of your money until you reach retirement age. As you never know when you might need some capital, it's a good idea to put some of your money into an Isa or some other accessible investment scheme.'  A new Trades Union Congress webpage contains information and can answer questions about stakeholder pensions.  For the FSA's draft decision trees, visit www.fsa.gov.uk click on publications, followed by discussion papers and download PDF 1.23MM.

webTitle: Changed contracts work only one way

fields.headline: Changed contracts work only one way
fields.standfirst: My employer is about to force new working practices on us in the form of shift patterns, much to the chagrin of the workforce. New contracts will be forthcoming. How can a company get away with this when a contract is supposed to benefit both parties?
fields.trailText: Agony aunt
fields.body:
Yes, a contract is in place to benefit both parties. If your employer unilaterally introduces changes without your agreement, it is in breach of the contract. In theory, you could then walk out and claim constructive dismissal. However, very few employees do so. Constructive dismissal cases, heard by employment tribunals, are notoriously hard to win, and few employees will give up their jobs for just a hope of compensation.

The law does allow an employer to change working practices if this is for very serious economic reasons - if the business might otherwise fold, for example.

There is a middle way: negotiating. If you have a union, it should be talking to your employer. In any case, the firm should be consulting staff and trying to accommodate anyone who would find the new shifts difficult. If it cites 'serious economic reasons', it is obliged to consult.

Ask the local office of the Arbitration, Conciliation and Advisory Service (Acas - the number should be in Yellow Pages), about the form these consultations should take.

 Legal advice: Pinsent Curtis

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Add-on policies: why take pot luck?

fields.headline: Add-on policies: why take pot luck?
fields.standfirst:
Lenders will sell all sorts of insurance with your mortgage - but you may not need them, writes Virginia Wallis, and they can cost an arm and a leg
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lenders will sell all sorts of insurance with your mortgage - but you may not need them, and they can cost an arm and a leg.
fields.body:
It's not often that you feel sorry for insurers. But it does seem a little unfair that they are having to shoulder the whole of the expensive administrative burden of sorting out the endowment mortgage mess. After all, if lenders and other mortgage advisers hadn't been quite so keen to pocket the commission from helping to sell endowments, the insurers would not now be having to write to thousands of policyholders to tell them whether or not their endowments are on track to pay off their mortgage loans.

As well as not helping out with the costs of all that extra correspondence, many lenders - including nine of the largest 10 - are adding to insurers' woes by refusing to put any more endowment business their way. And there's little comfort to be had from the endowment-friendly lenders that are left. Now that they have to prove that an endowment is 'demonstrably better than a repayment mortgage' the chances of them making a sale are slim. It's a shame isn't it? But don't get your hankies out just yet. There is still plenty of other mortgage-related insurance that lenders are happy to sell. And they're pretty good at it.

Even though many lenders have moved away from insisting that borrowers buy house insurance from them, they still manage to sell nearly 40 per cent of all household insurance in the UK. How? By 'capitalising on customer inertia and the point-of-sale advantage of mortgage provision,' say the market analysts at Datamonitor.

But it's not simply that mortgage customers are sitting targets. According to Patrick Bunton of London and Country Mortgages, in such a fiercely competitive mortgage market, 'you can take it as read that lenders will be pushing as hard as they can to sell peripheral products'.

Lenders are going to have to try harder if they are to meet their target of selling mortgage payment protection insurance (MPPI). Also known as accident, sickness and unemployment benefit, MPPI pays your mortgage for up to a year if you lose your job or your earnings suffer as a result of illness. The aim is to get at least 55 per cent of borrowers to buy it by 2001. But despite Government help with the marketing of MPPI, lenders are still less than half way there.

Making its purchase compulsory would increase the take-up but, because compulsory insurance now has to be included when calculating the Annual Percentage Rate, that would make mortgage rates look less attractive. It also wouldn't be fair on those consumers for whom MPPI is unsuitable.

An alternative would be to follow the example set by the small Market Harborough Building Society, where 76 per cent of customers have bought MPPI. Recognising that insurance which can help to prevent mortgage arrears benefits both borrower and lender, the Market Harborough sells MPPI at cost. This society, despite its lack of financial clout, has negotiated a deal with CGU which enables it to charge customers £1.50 for every £100 of cover. This is nearly four times cheaper than the average £5.45 charged by other lenders. Over the 25-year life of the loan - assuming a monthly mortgage payment of £500 - that difference could represent nearly £6,000 profit.

There are also healthy prof its in selling lump-sum mortgage protection in the form of life and critical illness insurance. And there's an added bonus from persuading customers to buy these products for lenders who want to sell endowment mortgages or those backed by life insurance Isas.

Because life and critical illness insurance can be cheaper when bought as part of this sort of package, it is much easier for a lender to show that recommending an endowment (or life insurance Isa) rather than a repayment mortgage was reasonable advice.

If a customer didn't want life and critical illness cover, a lender would be hard-pressed to show that the investment-backed mortgage was 'demonstrably better' than a repayment version.

As well as costing more, that customer would be tied to buying life insurance he or she didn't need. However, once life and critical illness insurance are brought into the equation, the investment option can be made to appear to be as good - if not better - than the repayment option.

Must haves, and the rest

Lenders would be failing in their duty if they didn't tell you about all the different types of insurance they can sell you, because it's a requirement of the Mortgage Code. But unless - as they are also required to do - they tell you the insurance is a compulsory part of the mortgage package, it's up to you whether you buy what's on offer. So which of the following do you really need?

Buildings insurance
This is a must. Without a suitable policy, you won't get your mortgage. If you're allowed to arrange your own insurance, make sure that it's in place from the date you exchange contracts, and that you insure for the 'reinstatement' value of your home (usually given in the lender's valuation) rather than for the purchase price. If you don't, you risk having the lender's policy foisted upon you.

Contents cover
Existentialists may not agree, but cover for your possessions is worth having if you would prefer someone else to pick up the bill for replacing , or repairing, your belongings if they are lost, stolen, damaged or destroyed. If you are moving, you'll need a fresh policy for your new home. While you arrange this, it's worth checking whether your belongings are covered while in transit. If they are, it's unlikely that you'll need the insurance that your removal firm is bound to offer you.

Your life
Lenders like you to have life insurance because it pays off the mortgage if you die, and saves them the bother of having to sell the property to get their money back. Paying for life insurance is unavoidable if you choose an interest-only mortgage backed by an endowment policy, or the more flexible alternative of a life insurance Individual Savings Account (Isa). But with other sorts of interest-only loans, or a repayment mortgage, you usually have a choice. If you are unattached and dependant-free, you don't need life cover. If you have a joint mortgage and/or children, you probably do.

Critical illness pay-outs
What do you sell the single person who won't buy life insurance? The answer is critical illness cover, or serious illness insurance. Widely regarded by the industry as even more important than life cover, critical illness policies pay out a lump sum if you are diagnosed as having one of a defined list of life-threatening or seriously debilitating conditions, such as cancer, a heart attack, multiple sclerosis and loss of limbs, eyesight, hearing or speech. Whether you need it or not depends on several factors: the likelihood of serious illness striking before your mortgage is paid off; how it would affect your household's finances; and what other resources you have.

Life and illness insurance
One of the main drawbacks of critical illness insurance is that, typically, it will not pay out if you die within 28 days of the diagnosis of a serious illness. To plug this gap, many lenders sell policies which combine life and critical illness cover. If you decide you need both types of insurance, combined cover tends to be cheaper than buying separately.

Mortgage protection cover
Lenders have government blessing to push this type of insurance, but if your ability to meet your mortgage repayments would be unaffected by illness or unemployment, you don't need it.

If you're self-employed, having cover that pays out if you're too ill to earn could be useful, but you're unlikely to benefit from unemployment cover unless you're prepared to close your business.

If you are an employee and your boss offers a decent sick pay scheme, you probably don't need the sickness cover. You are unlikely to benefit from it, either, if you are over 64, already out of work, do fewer than 16 hours a week, have not been in continuous employment for at least six months or are a contract worker.

Reassuring your lender
If you need to borrow a higher percentage of the value of your home than your lender thinks is wise, they may be prepared to go ahead only if you pay a high fee for an insurance policy, called a mortgage indemnity guarantee. This protects the lender from the risk of not being able to recover the full loan if you fall into arrears and the place has to be repossessed.

You won't face this fee if you borrow less than 75 per cent of the valuation (unless you borrow from Paragon Mortgages which starts charging if you borrow more than 70 per cent). Many lenders don't levy it until you borrow more than 90 per cent of the valuation (although Barclays makes you pay if you borrow more than 80 per cent). Once you go over the lender's limit, you face a charge of between 5 and 9 per cent of the difference between 75 per cent of the valuation and the amount of your loan.

With a mortgage of £95,000 on a property valued at £100,000, paying for your lender's peace of mind could cost anything from £1,450 to £1,790. If you can't pay it up front, the fee is added to the loan, so you end up paying interest on it too.

This is 'totally unfair', says Melanie Green, senior Researcher at Which? 'Consumers have no option to pay in instalments, you can't shop around for a cheaper policy and you're unlikely to get a refund if you move after a few years, even though the policy covers the full mortgage term.'

If you don't have the cash to put down a sufficiently large deposit to avoid the fee, the only other way of dodging this unwelcome cost is to take out your mortgage with one of the increasing number of lenders which don't charge.

webTitle: How to avoid getting into a WI-style pickle

fields.headline: How to avoid getting into a WI-style pickle
fields.trailText: Don't think you are too clever, try out ideas first and always, always check your facts
fields.body:
1: Don't follow the Tony Blair-Alastair Campbell model of thinking that you are clever enough to know everything yourself. If they had asked their mothers - or sought out some members of the Womens Institute - the Prime Minister could have avoided his slow hand-clapping debacle at the WI earlier this month. Being clever is no protection against gaffe-making. Even if you can prove Fermat's last theorem without pen and paper, you need to listen to a few boy scouts if you want your address to them next week to go down well.

2: 'Always have friends or colleagues who will play devil's advocate,' says Elizabeth, a political adviser. 'Have someone who will tell you your ideas are mad. And don't jump down their throat when you disagree with them.'

3: Try out new ideas with trusted confidantes or small groups of colleagues - before you run the risk of launching a dud in public. Many corporate gaffes are caused by lack of consultation.

4: Check your facts before making controversial statements. Gordon Brown, regarded as one of the cleverest in the Cabinet, clearly put his hoof in his mouth when he jumped into the Oxford elitism debate. Had he made a few discreet inquiries first, he would have protected his reputation.

5: Build up some brownie points to store against future gaffes. Princess Diana made some howlers - not least by becoming entangled with the Fayeds - but stayed popular because of her track record. This cannot always save you, however: Prince Charles' press secretary Sandy Henney had seven years of top performance behind her - but it was not enough to compensate for the gaffe over Prince William's eighteenth birthday photos.

6: Recognise that many gaffes are about clothes, appearance and protocol. The gaffe-prone Japanese prime minister Yoshiro Mori - who bowed twice, not the customary three times, at his predecessor's funeral - is in for a tough time in the polls tomorrow. Gaffes, even minor ones, are seen as indicators of poor judgment.

7: Work out the nature of your Achilles' heel. Most of us have a blind spot to our worst weaknesses. If you lack a sense of humour, you are unlikely to see it as a serious failing. If you listen positively to the criticisms of your friends, you will be able to deduce a pattern in what they say. When you hear for the fourth time that you can't take a joke, you know you need to go out and buy yourself a sense of humour.

webTitle: Now get back to work, all you oldsters

fields.headline: Now get back to work, all you oldsters
fields.standfirst: The Government wants to curb our desire for early retirement, says  Pamela Atherton
fields.trailText: The Government wants to curb our desire for early retirement, says Pamela Atherton
fields.body:
Young people dreaming of an exit from the workforce in early middle age should prepare themselves for a shock. The Government is conspiring against you. Even if you save in a pension scheme, you may not find it worthwhile retiring early if plans to restrict the tax advantages to over-55s go ahead.

These proposals to curb early retirement have met with a mixed response. Although the rationale for encouraging later retirement is generally understood, those contributing to pension schemes like to know that they have the option of retiring early if they so wish.

'One of the great carrots we wave in front of people to encourage them to save for retirement is the prospect of being able to retire at 50,' commented Alan Pickering, chairman of the National Association of Pension Funds. 'If it withdraws that option, the Government may find that younger people are less inclined to save for their old age.'

But the Cabinet Office report, Winning the Generation Game , which examined the effect of early retirement on the economy, found that more than 50 per cent of the 2.8 million people out of work between the ages of 50 and 65 were on sickness or disability benefits, which cost the taxpayer between £3 and £5 billion a year.

The overall cost to the Exchequer of having so many economically inactive people is estimated to be £16bn a year in lost tax, national insurance and social security benefits.

So the Government wants to reverse the trend, seen over the past 20 years, of early retirement, with companies using pension schemes and redundancy packages to get rid of millions of older workers.

Furthermore, individuals who retire early are facing a two-pronged erosion of their financial well-being in retirement. People are living longer: a 60-year-old man can expect to live to 84 and a woman to 87 - a far cry from the 1950s when the average 60-year-old man could expect a retirement span of only 10 years.

Add to this the low annuity rates being paid in return for pension funds and you have a recipe for long-term poverty for millions of retired people.

The Government intends to gradually raise the minimum age for tax benefits to apply to occupational and personal pensions from 50 to 55 between 2010 and 2020. This will coincide with the planned equalisation of state pension ages for men and women to 65.

For civil servants the retirement age will move from 60 to 65, with part- time work allowed in the later years. A number of retailers such as Boots, Dixons, Tesco and Sainsbury's are also encouraging more older employees to remain in work.

Their reasons for doing so are generally related to skills shortages. But the Government wants older workers to remain in the workforce so that they can continue to contribute to the economy.

But it may find it has a struggle on its hands. Banning redundancy on the grounds of age will require anti-discrimination laws, and Inland Revenue rules will have to become more flexible to allow older workers to work part-time while drawing a pension.

Sainsbury's pensions manager, Geof Pearson, who gave evidence to the report, says: 'Inland Revenue rules prevent an older person from drawing a Sainsbury's pension while working part- time for us and contributing to the same pension scheme - even though the same person could draw a Sainsbury's pension and work part time for Tesco and join its pension scheme.'

Pearson adds that what people really want is the opportunity to work fewer hours as they get older while drawing their company pension in order to bridge the gap in income.

Still set on putting your feet up early?

If you want an early departure from the nine-to-five, you will have to save. Figures from Scottish Equitable show that a 20-year-old man should be saving £300 a month in a personal pension to retire on the equivalent of £20,000 a year. At 30 the figure is £635. At 40, it will be too late to start a pension and hope to retire at 50. Even if you have the income, the limits on annual contributions do not accommodate the required level of contributions: Scottish Equitable calculates this at £1,765 for a 40-year-old to get £20,000.

Amanda Davidson, of independent adviser Holden Meehan, advises those who are already in a company pension scheme, to get a forecast for the penalties they could suffer for taking a pension early.These can be swingeing.' If your normal retirement age is 60 and you want to go at 50, you could have 40 per cent sliced off your pension.'

You can top up a company pension by contributing to an Additional Voluntary Contribution Scheme. This form of saving is attractive if your employer will contribute money to an AVC.

Davidson says: 'The golden rule for retiring at 50 is that you are not going to do it on pensions alone. You are looking at Isas, share portfolios, whatever.'

For younger people though, the reality will be that retirement, in the sense that it is known today, will disappear.

So the Government wants to reverse the trend, seen over the past 20 years, of early retirement, with companies using pension schemes and redundancy packages to get rid of millions of older workers. Furthermore, individuals who retire early are facing a two-pronged erosion of their financial well-being in retirement. People are living longer: a 60-year-old man can expect to live to 84 and a woman to 87 - a far cry from the 1950s when the average 60-year-old man could expect a retirement span of only 10 years. Add to this the low annuity rates being paid in return for pension funds and you have a recipe for long-term poverty for millions of retired people. The Government intends to gradually raise the minimum age for tax benefits to apply to occupational and personal pensions from 50 to 55 between 2010 and 2020. This will coincide with the planned equalisation of state pension ages for men and women to 65. For civil servants the retirement age will move from 60 to 65, with part- time work allowed in the later years. A number of retailers such as Boots, Dixons, Tesco and Sainsbury's are also encouraging more older employees to remain in work. Their reasons for doing so are generally related to skills shortages. But the Government wants older workers to remain in the workforce so that they can continue to contribute to the economy. But it may find it has a struggle on its hands. Banning redundancy on the grounds of age will require anti-discrimination laws, and Inland Revenue rules will have to become more flexible to allow older workers to work part-time while drawing a pension. Sainsbury's pensions manager, Geof Pearson, who gave evidence to the report, says: 'Inland Revenue rules prevent an older person from drawing a Sainsbury's pension while working part- time for us and contributing to the same pension scheme - even though the same person could draw a Sainsbury's pension and work part time for Tesco and join its pension scheme.' Pearson adds that what people really want is the opportunity to work fewer hours as they get older while drawing their company pension in order to bridge the gap in income. Still set on putting your feet up early? If you want an early departure from the nine-to-five, you will have to save. Figures from Scottish Equitable show that a 20-year-old man should be saving £300 a month in a personal pension to retire on the equivalent of £20,000 a year. At 30 the figure is £635. At 40, it will be too late to start a pension and hope to retire at 50. Even if you have the income, the limits on annual contributions do not accommodate the required level of contributions: Scottish Equitable calculates this at £1,765 for a 40-year-old to get £20,000. Amanda Davidson, of independent adviser Holden Meehan, advises those who are already in a company pension scheme, to get a forecast for the penalties they could suffer for taking a pension early.These can be swingeing.' If your normal retirement age is 60 and you want to go at 50, you could have 40 per cent sliced off your pension.' You can top up a company pension by contributing to an Additional Voluntary Contribution Scheme. This form of saving is attractive if your employer will contribute money to an AVC. Davidson says: 'The golden rule for retiring at 50 is that you are not going to do it on pensions alone. You are looking at Isas, share portfolios, whatever.' For younger people though, the reality will be that retirement, in the sense that it is known today, will disappear.

webTitle: How to stay ahead if you're getting behind...

fields.headline: How to stay ahead if you're getting behind...
fields.standfirst: Borrowers in arrears are being squeezed by Government and lenders, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Borrowers in arrears are being squeezed by Government and lenders, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
You may not realise it, but if you are one of the country's 11 million mortgage borrowers, life is getting riskier for you. The legal and practical situation of homeowners who get behind with their loan repayments is becoming more precarious.

In theory the lot of homeowners has improved since the height of the negative equity crisis in 1991, when 75,000 homes were repossessed. The mortgage code, for instance, which came into force three years ago, requires lenders to deal 'sympathetically and positively' with borrowers who get into arrears.

But, speaking about the bad old days of 1991, Sue Edwards, London money advice adviser for the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux (Nacab), says: 'If the same situation were to happen again, we'd have a lot more repossessions.'

There are two particularly worrying developments. Most lenders are accused of being harsh in their repossession policies. And, for its part, the Government is about to reduce the financial support it gives to indebted homeowners.

In a highly controversial move in October 1995, the Conservatives lengthened from four to nine months the period in which homeowners claiming state benefits would still have to make their own mortgage payments after they signed on.

The Labour government, in housing legislation which could be introduced this autumn, plans to extend the period before Income Support for Mortgage Payments (ISMI) becomes payable to 14 months. The proposal was recently outlined its housing green paper. The 14-month period was chosen because, the government says, homeowners should all buy mortgage payment protection insurance (MPPI) and this will cover them.

Although Nacab has serious concerns about MPPI, it is recommending that homeowners buy these policies - because you will almost definitely be repossessed if you cannot continue your mortgage payments for this period. However, citizens' advice bureau files are littered with examples of people whose MPPI claims are turned down by insurers.

There are major obstacles to claiming: if you are self-employed, for instance, and your business gets into trouble. You can be excluded if you become unemployed soon after starting the policy, and if your difficulties are caused by some sort of mental breakdown, you will also have trouble claiming. If your spouse or partner leaves you - a very common cause of arrears - you cannot claim for that. And since MPPI can easily cost over £15 a month for a £50,000 loan, many homeowners are choosing to go without.

But lenders are now taking a very strict line on borrowers who get into difficulties. By law, you cannot have your home repossessed within two months of falling behind - but your problems can start quickly after that.

Debt advisers are seeing may people appearing in court after the six months. Edwards believes the buoyant housing market is encouraging lenders to sell properties quickly when they think they can do so at a profit. If, by contrast, we were in a time of widespread negative equity, lenders might be slower to repossess, as a profitable sale would be unlikely.

In particular, lenders appear to be ignoring the landmark Cheltenham & Gloucester v Norgan case in 1995 in which it was held that borrowers who were in arrears could repay their debts over the remaining period of the mortgage rather than in a shorter timeframe. Paul Scannel of the Bow County Court Advice Service - a free service for people in court - says: 'In my experience, a lot of the big lenders - especially demutualised ones - want the money repaid in very short periods.'

Judges, however, apply the law Norgan case law. Research by Nacab in London last year showed the average repayment schedule requested by lenders was 1.8 years. The average offered by borrowers was 4.4 years - and the average granted by judges was 4.3 years.

Lenders deny they are being unduly harsh. Many plead that borrowers do not discuss their problems with them. A spokeswoman for the Woolwich says: 'On arrears, we pursue customers to make an arrangement based on their individual circumstances. We will go to court only if the customer doesn't co-operate.'

Repossession may not hit the headlines often at the moment, but it is still common. About 30,000 homes were repossessed in 1999, according to the Council of Mortgage Lenders, and another 180,000 homeowners were more than three months in arrears.

What to do if you fall into arrears

1: Talk to a debt adviser as soon as you get into difficulty. Your mortgage lender - and particularly its solicitor or bailiff agents - may take you more seriously if it knows you have someone sensible on your side. Citizens advice bureaux provide help for free.

2: Start talking to your mortgage lender. Many repossession orders come about because the borrower has ignored letters from the lender. The sooner you speak to the lender, the more likely you are to reach a compromise. If the matter has been sent to the litigation department - or to an outside firm of lawyers - you also have a bureaucratic battle to fight to stop a summons being issued.

3: Ensure you get all the basic information you need - statements and schedules of sums outstanding, in particular. Confusion over administration is a common feature of arrears and repo cases. This is partly caused by the fact that your file is passed on between different departments - from branch to head office, perhaps, then from arrears to the legal department to litigation. Insist on getting the name of the person who is dealing with your case. You now have a chance of being able to negotiate with them.

4: Recognise your own areas of flexibility. Consider whether you could meet the payments if the life of the mortgage were lengthened. Consider whether you could make regular payments if your debts were 'capitalised' and added into your mortgage debt. If the house price has gone up, you could still sell at a profit and pay off your liabilities. (Mortgage lenders are often wary of this route - but a court will sometimes give you a stay of execution if you have proof that the property is on the market.) Although you should not cash in an endowment policy if you have one, you could sell it through the second-hand endowments market (for a higher price than surrendering to the insurer, in many cases) if you really need the money.

5: Understand that both lenders and judges will want strong indications that you will eventually repay the debt. You increase the chances of repossession if you say you cannot meet your normal monthly payments and do not see how you can increase your income. At minimum, you should be chipping away at the arrears as well as meeting the basic payments.

webTitle: Byers ties minimum wage to average earnings

fields.headline: Byers ties minimum wage to average earnings
fields.trailText: The Government is poised for a radical overhaul of the minimum wage - linking it to rises in average earnings in a move that will be seen as a step towards an annual upgrading of the rate.
fields.body:
The Government is poised for a radical overhaul of the minimum wage - linking it to rises in average earnings in a move that will be seen as a step towards an annual upgrading of the rate.

Trade Secretary Stephen Byers is ordering the independent Low Pay Commission to take movements in average workers' salaries into account when it considers an increase next year.

This sends a clear signal that the Government has listened to unions, and to its disgruntled 'heartlands' supporters, who have campaigned vigorously for annual increases in the level, and a link to pay packets.

Public service union Unison has led the campaign, demanding a £5-an-hour minimum - compared with £3.70 reached at the last upgrading earlier this year, following threats of rebellion from Labour backbenchers. Unions, however, reacted angrily when the Government nudged up the initial rate of £3.60 by only 10p.

Unions argue that an annual uprating would mean that 2 million poorly paid workers keep pace with those at the top.

However, business is concerned that any such move could spark inflation: wages jumped by 5.9 per cent in the first quarter of this year, although partly fuelled by extra-high millennium bonuses, well outstripping inflation.

There would be no fixed link with earnings; the rate at which the minimum wage followed any rise in earnings would be left to the discretion of the low-pay commission, made up of academics, economists and others.

The Trade Secretary has also ordered an investigation into whether the lower rate for under-22s - now £3.30 - should be scrapped, letting them collect the full adult rate. Both of these instructions have been agreed with the Treasury.

The Treasury has resisted making annual rises in the minimum wage automatic. But unions want an annual uprating because of fears of a new form of poverty trap. Linking the wage to earnings takes Ministers one step closer to this.

Byers has already asked the Commission to look again at whether a further rise is necessary next year. The Commission will report in July 2001, which means any increase would be unlikely to come into effect until the autumn.

Critics have argued that anxious bosses will respond by laying off young people if they suddenly become more expensive to employ.

Unions point out, however, that dire predictions about the adult minimum wage causing mass unemployment turned out to be empty. The Conservative Party have agreed not to repeal it.

fields.headline: Seer of cyberspace symbols
fields.standfirst: Manuel Castells understands the internet economy.  Simon Caulkin  reports
fields.trailText: Manuel Castells understands the internet economy. Simon Caulkin reports
fields.body:
In the hype-filled internet world, those with the ability to tell virtual wood from the trees are as rare as dotcom companies that make profits. One respected wood-watcher is Manuel Castells, professor of sociology at the University of California and author of the trilogy The Information Age: Economy, Society and Culture (Blackwell) - a work which, in one admiring view, does for the internet economy what Max Weber's The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism did for the industrial age a century ago.

Like Weber, Castells is European, a graduate of the anti-Franco movement in Spain and the May 1968 upheavals in France before he moved to Berkeley in 1979. He is also a social theorist. Both these lenses provide useful correctives for the simplistic, US-centric way in which the web is usually viewed.

At a series of lectures organised last week by Oxford's Said Business School and Oxford University Press, Castells emphasised that the 'new economy' - an investment-led, high-growth, low-inflation process destroying the past and powered by the most extraordinary technological revolution in history - is already here, transforming social, economic and productive relations as it goes. 'There's no industry sector which won't be affected,' he says. 'Within a few years, if it isn't an internet business it won't be a business at all.'

Yet it is striking how much the internet owes not to business, but to its origins in the academic world and the libertarian hacker culture.

From these roots the internet draws its awesome flexibility and ability to reconfig ure itself around obstacles, and its self-regulating nature outside government control. By contrast business failed to see the possibilities (both AT&T and the UK Post Office turned down early prototypes), while many firms, including Microsoft, persevered with inferior proprietary online services well after the internet was the only game in town.

It is to the hacker's culture, not business, that Castells attributes much of Europe's vibrant internet and mobile start-up scene.It is this that links it to Silicon Valley.

One of Castells' emblematic figures is Linus Torvalds, inventor of the free Linux operating system now beat ing Microsoft in some areas. Torvalds is a hacker and a Finn; and Finland is 'the first true information society in the world', says Castells, with one website per person, internet access in all schools, a buzzing IT sector - and a welfare state.

Ironically,Torvalds has elected to live in Silicon Valley. This now represents the cutting edge of the new economy, with its culture of risk, extreme individualism, flexible capital and stock options; its totem company, Cisco, is as representative of the networked era as Ford was of the industrial age.

Yet that will change. Within five or 10 years, Castells believes, a subtly different model will have emerged around a new tech nological impetus - new network applications, genomics, or the mobile internet.

'Mobile internet leadership will be shaped by Nokia and Ericsson, and its norms, usages and customs will be European. These are the ones which will be taken into the US,' he says - a positive development because, while all new applications in the US are driven by commerce, in Europe the possibilities will be defined also by public services and even social movements, allowing a wider range of uses to appear.

Can the Old World take part in and share the benefits of the virtuous 'new economy' of which Silicon Valley is the symbol? Castells insists it is not only possible but inevitable. Europe may not yet match the astonishing, unprecedented 5 per cent productivity growth racked up by the US in the last quarter of 1999. But that's partly because of inevitable lags and the failure of unreformed statistics to reflect the improvements.The main point, says Castells, is that the new economy's methods and techniques are spreading through Europe at amazing speed - that's what happens in global info-capitalism. Indeed, that's what globalisation is .

In a relatively short time, therefore, Europe will converge on the US both in internet diffusion and usage and in pockets of productivity growth. Already the European labour force, except in Germany, is much more flexible than it is often given credit for. The Netherlands, notes Castells, is the employment miracle of the world, with a jobless figure lower than in the US. France, despite opposite rhetoric, is going the same way.

Castell's internet is also a deeply unsentimental place, as underdeveloped socially as it is overdeveloped technologically. Weber would recognise it at once. Thus it excludes unwanted elements as ruthlessly as it embraces what's valued.

'There is no value judgment in electronic networks, except for assessing value - which is increasingly measured in terms of prospective capital growth rather than profit rates,' Castells writes in On the Edge: Living with Global Capitalism (edited by Will Hutton and Anthony Giddens, Cape). An example: Amazon.com at $25 billion is worth twice as much as all the companies quoted on the Russian stock exchange.

Moreover, in this perspective Castells insists it is meaningless to talk of an internet 'bubble'. Turbulences and extreme volatility are endemic to the new economy. He speculates that 'at the core of our economies, conditioning our lives', is a man-made 'automaton' - a radically decentralised, increasingly unpredictable electronic system of financial transactions - which thrives beyond the control of individuals, corporations or governments, simultaneously inducing growth and wealth and triggering disinvestment and crisis.

'It's not a bubble, it's fizzy water,' advises Castells. Get used to it.

Simon.Caulkin@observer.co.uk

Wasim Akram yesterday joined a highly exclusive club - with three previous members - when the Pakistan spearhead dismissed Russel Arnold in Colombo to glean his 400th wicket in tests, the first southpaw so to do, then warned of his intention to keep going "for another year and a half".
fields.body:
Don't look now, Courtney. Wasim Akram yesterday joined a highly exclusive club - with three previous members - when the Pakistan spearhead dismissed Russel Arnold in Colombo to glean his 400th wicket in tests, the first southpaw so to do, then warned of his intention to keep going "for another year and a half".

Not that the all-rounder's pooping of Sri Lanka 's 100th test celebrations stopped there. Earlier he had made 78 as a last-wicket stand of 90 with Arshad Khan lifted Pakistan to within seven of the hosts' first-innings 273.

His message to would-be heirs? "If you go through rough patches then just hang in there and God will help you."

Meanwhile his fellow Pakistani Saqlain Mushtaq and the former England spinner Ian Salisbury shared 19 wickets at the Oval as Surrey crushed Somerset by an innings and 207 runs.

Salisbury's match haul of 12 for 91 included eight for 60 in the second innings, a career best.

webTitle: In-form Chanderpaul needs to up the ante

fields.headline: In-form Chanderpaul needs to up the ante
fields.trailText: Relief and partial celebration must be very much in the mind of Shivnarine Chanderpaul. Personal problems, a loss of form and sickness followed one after the other, with low scores the result.
fields.body:
Relief and partial celebration must be very much in the mind of Shivnarine Chanderpaul. Personal problems, a loss of form and sickness followed one after the other, with low scores the result.

After a miserable series against Zimbabwe this year, he was diagnosed with fatigue syndrome and sat out the one-day series with Zimbabwe and Pakistan. A grafting 89 in the first innings of the third test against Pakistan in Antigua signalled a possible return to form, which was confirmed with two tour centuries in England. Yesterday he came to the rescue with another half-century, his 20th in 43 tests.

Just when he appeared ready to blossom, having hit 12 fours, his innings ended and another hundred, which seemed very much there for the taking, was lost. He has only two test centuries to his name.

One of the 11 teenagers to play for West Indies at test-match level, Chanderpaul made his debut in 1994 against England at Bourda, Guyana, when he was 19. In 1997, at the Kensington Oval in Barbados, he scored his first test century, an unbeaten 137 against India. The second came the following year against England in the Caribbean.

It was thought then that the tide had turned and the conversion rate from half-centuries to hundreds would increase. This, however, has not been the case. So, though he will be pleased with his continued form, he may also want to re-examine some facets of his batting. Strength and stamina are the obvious areas for consideration, but he may have some totally different solutions to the problem.

He has immense powers of concentration and relishes being out in the middle; his triple century for Guyana against Jamaica in 1996 is one of the best examples of this appetite. Though he is known as a somewhat dour, purposeful player, he can explode for short or long periods. When he does, he cuts, pulls and drives the fast bowlers and uses his feet to the spinners. He can select and place his shots with intelligence, and occasional impudence as well. At other times he adopts the counter-puncher's gambit, deflecting, pushing and nudging out singles and twos.

All of these qualities were present in his fine innings of 73 in 119 balls yesterday. He batted tremendously well before his dismissal, which he rather orchestrated himself.

He had, however, done what West Indies would have wanted. He ensured, along with the other middle-order batsmen, that a familiar collapse did not occur, a crucial factor on a pitch already showing some signs of wear and on which West Indies may have to bat last. They will be even more delighted to see this Guyanese left- hander figure out the formula to up that conversion rate. What a welcome addition that would be.

webTitle: Soccer pundits line up for clash of the day

fields.headline: Soccer pundits line up for clash of the day
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 BBC and ITV at full strength for head-to-head
fields.trailText: As England and Germany prepare for the clash of the Euro 2000 tournament, Britain's top television pundits are limbering up for a fixture that has almost as much riding on it as the match itself.
fields.body:
As England and Germany prepare for the clash of the Euro 2000 tournament, Britain's top television pundits are limbering up for a fixture that has almost as much riding on it as the match itself.

For the first time since the battle over television rights ended in blood-soaked carpets on the executive floor at Broadcasting House, the two main television networks tonight get the chance to prove their worth.

In the ITV corner Des Lynam is waxing his 'tache in preparation for a marathon five-hour broadcast beginning this afternoon. Over at the nation's broadcaster, Gary Lineker is topping up his tan on the BBC health club sunbeds. But don't let their smooth exteriors fool you: this fight is dirty.

ITV appears to have a strong front row. With Lynam on the pundit panel are three of the last four England managers: Bobby Robson, Glen Hoddle and Terry Venables. (Not even the BBC wanted Graham Taylor - the corporation has lined up Alan Hansen and Mark Lawrenson to spar with Lineker.) The commercial network also has the advantage of exclusive rights to the Romania v Portugal fixture which precedes the England game.

It was the BBC which landed the first punch, though - and it was a low blow. Just before the deadline for television listings magazines, the corporation announced it was to counter ITV's scheduling advantage with an afternoon of must-watch family television. Against ITV's first match it has pitted the blockbuster animation movie Babe. And if a talking pig is not enough to woo the viewers there's a 45-minute EastEnders special in the run-up to the main event.

The BBC's strategy is clear: there is no way that parents with young families could risk a weekend bust-up by banishing Babe to the black-and-white in the back room: nor could soap-watchers be denied their fix. ITV is seething. "There are not many blokes who could get away with watching two football matches one after the other on a Saturday," one ITV source said.

ITV is banking on the Des factor. Lynam said at the launch of ITV's coverage recently: "I have done it before on the other side, it has always worked rather well for the BBC and this time I hope it will go well for ITV."

But the network stresses that traditionally it does not do well on head-to-head football clashes with the BBC. "We are under no illusions. We face a very stiff test. Des has said he doesn't believe he can overturn viewing habits overnight but he hopes that some of those people who used to watch him on the BBC will switch over."

For the BBC it will be a tough show too. The corporation is still reeling from the loss of rights to English Premiership highlights, and Lineker's profile at the corporation will take a serious knock from the scaling back of Match of the Day.

But the former England striker, who has won acclaim for his performance at the BBC since Lynam defected to ITV, said he would be staying with the corporation. "I have no aspirations to go anywhere else," he said.

"We are all really deflated, but I am perfectly happy with the BBC. It's a great place to work, with a fantastic team."

It needs to be.

BBC1 :

5.05pm : Babe. Hit family comedy with a talking pig who is adopted by a sheepdog

6.30pm: EastEnders. Albert Square prepares for the big match

7.15pm: Euro 2000: England v Germany, presenter Gary Lineker

ITV

4.15pm : Euro 2000, presenter Desmond Lynam; Romania v Portugal (5pm), England v Germany (7.45pm)

fields.headline: Another football defeat for Dyke
fields.trailText: ITV and OnDigital yesterday secured the rights to screen the Football League and Worthington Cup after the BBC's plans for a bid fell apart.
fields.body:
ITV and OnDigital yesterday secured the rights to screen the Football League and Worthington Cup after the BBC's plans for a bid fell apart.

BBC chiefs had been working on a joint offer with Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB but the two failed to submit a final bid by a Thursday deadline imposed by the league.

"The structure of the deal required a subscription TV partner and only OnDigital was interested in bidding but they wanted ITV as a partner," a BBC spokeswoman said. "We understood the league was quite keen for us to do it but as there wasn't a partner there was nothing we could do."

OnDigital and ITV secured the three year deal for £315m.

The debacle capped a wretched week for the BBC's director general Greg Dyke who made sport a priority when he started.

On Wednesday it was outbid by ITV for Premiership highlights. Its subsequent success in winning rights to the FA Cup was soured by a row with Premier League officials. Mr Dyke said throughout the week that he was hopeful of adding Football League and Worthington Cup games to the BBC's reshaped Match of the Day.

Football officials, however, have hauled in £2.4bn over the past three days through the successive broadcasting rights deals. The Football League agreement is worth £105m a year, four times higher than the existing £25m a year contract with ITV and BSkyB.

The BBC has found it increasingly difficult to compete with its wealthier commercial rivals. It has lost the rights to Formula One, Test cricket, England's home rugby internationals and golf's Ryder Cup.

The Football League rights will offer some consolation to pay-television company OnDigital which competed against BSkyB and NTL in the battle for live Premiership and pay-per-view rights.

The business which is owned by ITV companies Granada and Carlton Communications intends to launch a premium sports channel before the league contract starts in the 2001 season.

It will show a minumum of 88 First, Second and Third division and Worthington Cup matches per season as well as pay-per-view matches. ITV will broadcast live 15 regional matches and will show the play off for promotion to the Premier League and the closing stages of the Worthington Cup across the network.

Brian Barwick controller of ITV Sport said: "It's been quite a week for ITV Sport."

OnDigital chief executive Stuart Prebble said he aimed to raise the profile of the Football League.

fields.headline: Wonder Walsh's final fling
fields.standfirst:
England 179 and 125
West Indies 397
West Indies won by an innings and 93 runs
fields.trailText:
England 179 and 125
West Indies 397
West Indies won by an innings and 93 runs
fields.body:
For those uncomfortable with the idea of change, Edgbaston was a reassuring place to be yesterday afternoon, but for every other English man or woman it was all infinitely depressing - and familiar. England have been humbled by West Indian pacemen for the last three decades; for half that time Courtney Walsh has been hounding them. At the age of 37 he still is.

Bolstered by a massive first-innings lead of 218, Walsh despatched the first three English batsmen in half-an hour to register Test wickets 455 to 457. He had the decency to do much of the damage while Channel 4 were at the racing to save patriotic viewers from enduring yet more humiliation.

It's tempting to say that Walsh ripped through the English upper order because that's what we always used to say about him, but that is not strictly true. He has made some concessions to age; his bowling now clocks in around the 80mph mark. No matter; he's still too much for England. By tea they were crumbling on 71 for 5 and yet another blank Birmingham Sunday was in the offing.

Nowadays Walsh rarely terrifies - he could in the past- but especially when he discovers a pitch where the ball grips, where the bounce is uneven; he flicks his wrist, the ball lands on the seam and it moves. He doesn't bother to try to bowl fast. Bumpers are a waste of energy, only to be used when the wicket is 'sleeping'.

In this match England have bowled far more bouncers than their opponents and it's obvious why. The wicket 'slept' when Gough and Co were in the field. It was wide awake for Walsh. Unlike Curtly Ambrose, Walsh has not promised to retire after this series. Who knows? England go to the Caribbean in 2004. He'll only be 41 then.

Walsh and Ambrose, who has also bowled superbly with the ridiculous reward of only one wicket so far, have shown that class and know-how are more important than youth and pace. They have exploited the conditions expertly. The surface at Edgbaston is not ideal. As is often the case Edgbaston has produced a truncated Test which has cost the ECB and the English game a lot of money. They are good at marketing here; the ground has been just about full for the last two days; they are not so good at preparing a decent Test pitch, something the ECB should consider a lot more seriously when they allocate their internationals.

This is not to excuse England's performance or to deny the West Indies absolute superiority in this game. England have been outplayed in every area - except perhaps catching (the West Indies put down a couple yesterday afternoon).

The tourists have made rapid progress since Roger Harper and Jimmy Adams have taken the helm. Before arriving at Edgbaston they had lost 10 consecutive Tests away from the Caribbean. No wonder they all look forward to coming to England. All the signs of a cohesive and committed side are there: the batsmen down the order grit their teeth and hang in; the fielders dive here, there and everywhere and the old lags, eager to help, have a spring in the step. The West Indies are coming back

England were supposed to travelling a similar journey. That was the spin after the victory at Lord's against Zimbabwe. Since then they have stalled and here they looked stagnant, their batsmen hesitant and too easily cowed by the old names on the opposition scorecard, their bowlers innocuous - with the exception of Darren Gough in a couple of spells on Friday.

It took them all morning to take the last three West Indian wickets. Gough's inswinging yorker accounted for Franklyn Rose, whose 48 was skittish and highly entertaining.

But Reon King was able to last 40 balls in support of his captain Adams, who scented a hundred. King was finally undone by Robert Croft, who had bowled tidily throughout, when he dragged his back foot out of his crease much to Alec Stewart's delight.

So Adams needed 11 for his hundred when Walsh appeared. The expert number 11 could not be moved (this was his 56th Test not out - a world record) but Adams' innings ended two short of his century thanks to a stunning catch by Andrew Flintoff at cover. Adams cracked a drive off Gough and Flintoff flung out his right hand. To the satisfaction of both parties the catch was held (it wasn't so obvious from the TV replays).

This was the last time the English team smiled in the oppressive Birmingham heat. For Walsh set to work in the afternoon session. His first wicket was an easy one. Mark Ramprakash, stuck on the crease to a straight ball, missed it and was lbw. It was not obvious why he missed it; it did not appear a devilish delivery.

Nasser Hussain might have been out twice before groping against Walsh. First the ball took the shoulder of the bat from a rearing delivery from Ambrose and then sped through the hands of Brian Lara at first slip, who might have caught it. Then Hussain mistimed an on-drive against Walsh into and out of the hands of King, who most definitely should have caught it. Then the edge to Ridley Jacobs who made no mistake; this was not the pitch nor the attack for Hussain to recover his form.

Now Graeme Hick registered his first pair in first class cricket. He may have been unlucky on two counts. He received a snorter from Walsh, which pitched leg and sailed over the top of off stump; moreover the ball was deemed to have brushed Hicks's bat or glove on the way through, which was not obvious. Stewart bristled as usual while acquiring his eight runs, but was out in similar fashion to the first innings forcing away from his body and dragging the ball on to his stumps.

Mike Atherton was bloody-minded enough to see off the spells of Walsh and Ambrose; so was infuriated when an attempted cut shot against King ricocheted onto his stumps.

When Flintoff was bowled by King and Croft caught at short leg the score was 83 for 7, the contest was over.
