fields.headline: Party poopers learn to chill
fields.standfirst: The success of the tournament owes much to the men in black, writes Roy Collins
fields.trailText: At previous major championships, referees have been forced to spend their non-working days sitting in darkened rooms watching endless videos of matches while being encouraged to criticise one another for not flourishing more red and yellow cards.
fields.body:
At previous major championships, referees have been forced to spend their non-working days sitting in darkened rooms watching endless videos of matches while being encouraged to criticise one another for not flourishing more red and yellow cards.

Here, if they have been spending any off-duty moments in darkened rooms, one can only assume it is because they have been sinking gallons of Samson-strength Belgian beer or puffing on Dutch wacky Woodbines. To a man, they have officiated in a more laid-back style than Dishy Des, and at the risk of losing all terrace cred, one has to hail them as the catalysts of a surprisingly entertaining first week of the tournament.

After the first 10 games, only three red cards and 23 yellows had been flashed, which is not far above the match average of Paul Danson when he was a Premiership official. And Hugh Dallas of Scotland should write to the Guinness Book of Records after failing to dip into his top pocket once during the Italy-Turkey game.

So relaxed have referees become that England will not be as frightened as they might have been by the appointment, for today's game against Germany, of Italy's Pierluigi Collina, the man who sent off Paul Ince against Sweden in the opening match of England's qualifying campaign.

Collina made one of the most contentious decisions of this competition by awarding the penalty that allowed Holland to beat the Czech Republic. But mirroring the new philosophical approach of the men in black, he says: "The most important thing to accept about football is that it is not perfect.

"People make mistakes, whether it is the player missing an easy goal, the coach making a bad substitution or the referee giving the wrong decision. We have to accept that there are two kinds of football, the real kind played on the pitch and televised football, where every mistake is shown repeatedly."

Collina was a member of the panel of experts that drew up the refereeing guidelines for Euro 2000, which for the first time included former players in Michael Laudrup and Andoni Zubizarreta, and managers in Roy Hodgson and Scotland's Andy Roxburgh, now Uefa technical director.

This was a bit like inviting motorists to have their say at a traffic wardens' convention. But the result is that referees no longer have a Pokemon- style "gotta book 'em all" mentality but are allowed to assess the intent of any transgressor and take other mitigating circumstances into account.

The referees have used this discretion wonderfully and the players, unlike those in the Premiership when a similar relaxed approach was introduced, have responded by reducing their own level of cynicism. This has produced a series of matches in which the football, rather than the cards, has flowed.

Although Collina says that diving is the only growing crime statistic among players, referees here have even taken a novel approach to that by simply ignoring it, leaving the writhing player looking utterly ridiculous as the game goes on without him.

Before the past two World Cups, in France two years ago and the United States in 1994, referees were issued with zero-tolerance instructions, which led to a rash of cards and the farcical situation where, come the final stages, many of the top stars were suspended.

Philip Don, England's only referee in '94, says: "We were told in a seminar a few months before the tournament that every foul tackle from behind was going to be a red card and we said, no way. Luckily Fifa eventually watered that down, otherwise it would have made a mockery of the game.

"But during the tournament we had to watch reruns of controversial incidents. They would freeze-frame the video and ask: 'Was that offence a yellow card or a red? Should that yellow have been red?' We were under constant pressure."

At France 98, where Paul Durkin was England's only representative, organisers were so worried about the pressure on referees to punish the slightest indiscretion that they provided a team of counsellors for them.

If referees here request counselling, it will be only to help them cope with their unfamiliar popularity, which has even led to outrageous claims that some of them have parents. webTitle: Keegan's cast adds new twist to familiar script

fields.headline: Keegan's cast adds new twist to familiar script
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: Lacey looks forward to a massive day for English football.
fields.body:
A pity about Match of the Day, for which the FA Cup deal is a devalued consolation, but at least the Beeb will not be squandering extra millions on football at the risk of having to cut back on one of the things it does best, period drama, a point proved by the excellence of the present serial going out on BBC1.

Millions of viewers have become captivated by the latest revival of that English classic in which a group of wayfarers find themselves isolated in a foreign hotel and surrounded by hostile forces waiting to pounce on their every move.

The leader of this expedition, though remaining true to the Scouts' motto by smiling and whistling under all difficulties, is at odds whether to man the gates in fours or threes. Already he has been caught out by people sneaking up the middle of the drive during a supper break.

Opinions on what to do next vary from digging trenches to lobbing mortars. Periodic gas attacks from bystanders bearing notebooks and ballpoints do not help. The ordeal could be over after another day but it may yet be prolonged.

The sheer predictability of England's latest fraught foray into a European Championship does not lessen the awful fascination with what is unfolding on the northern fringe of the Ardennes. Already the more strident headlines are engaged in a battle of the bilge.

David Beckham's single-finger response to the foul-mouthing he received from a few demented English fans after Monday's 3-2 defeat by Portugal in Eindhoven struck some familiar nerves back home. An article labelled Why This Man's a National Liability appeared to offer Roy Hattersley's thoughts on Beckham. Or was it the other way round?

All right, Beckham should have known better but at least he did not launch himself at his tormentors feet first, an old Manchester United custom.

Reports of a players' revolt have come earlier than usual. Normally England play at least two games before rumours leak out concerning discontent with team selection, tactics, the quality of the video films, the loudness of the morning birdsong and the media's obvious lack of patriotism.

Remember the players' deputation to Bobby Robson, supposedly led by Bryan Robson and Ray Wilkins, after England had taken one point from their opening two matches, against Portugal and Morocco, in the 1986 World Cup? Naturally it was all denied but Robson still brought in Peter Beardsley, Peter Reid and Trevor Steven against Poland in Monterrey, and Gary Lineker's hat-trick did the rest.

In Italia 90, after a particularly banal draw with the Republic of Ireland, Robson surprised everyone by switching to a sweeper system, saying he had planned this all along. England drew but still gave a performance, inspired by Paul Gascoigne, that ignited their hopes.

In the 1988 European Championship there were reported rumbles from the troops as England lost to the Republic of Ireland, Holland and the Soviet Union, the last defeat marking the end of Glenn Hoddle's fitful international career.

Four years later Graham Taylor took his team to Sweden saying that if England flopped again he would be blamed for picking the wrong team and employing the wrong tactics. They did and he was.

If England are eliminated from Euro 2000 by Germany tonight or the Romanians end it all on Tuesday Keegan will doubtless suffer a reprise of the criticisms about his coaching abilities which were being voiced even before he chose his first team, let alone watched his first match.

This would surely be an idle and pointless exercise. Keegan has never pretended to be something that he was not. He is part cheerleader, part agony aunt and relies otherwise on his players to sort things out on the field.

In being prepared to listen to a senior committee of Alan Shearer, Tony Adams, David Seaman and Sol Campbell he has shown a refreshing sense of democracy. Unfortunately one of the points at issue after the Portugal defeat is whether Adams, Campbell, Seaman and Shearer should have been on the field.

Certainly Adams was always going to be a gamble because of his uncertain fitness, and Keegan's insistence on strapping Shearer to the tiller no matter where the ship is heading was bound to limit his attacking options. But Monday's defeat was brought about not so much by Keegan's tactics as his most experienced players forgetting the basics amid their unaccustomed joy at taking an early two-goal lead.

The England coach has been pressed to switch from 4-4-2 to 3-5-2 against Germany today. But though the reasons for advancing such an argument are sound enough, no tactics will work if those involved give the ball away in their own half and then fail to defend space in the approaches to goal.

In Brussels on Wednesday night there was scarcely a murmur among the Italian media when it became clear that Dino Zoff had gone the other way, playing four at the back against Belgium after using five in midfield against Turkey. The difference is that whereas Zoff switched things to utilise his strengths, Keegan would be altering systems to hide his weaknesses.

And in the present England squad there are plenty of those.

webTitle: Flak flies but Sir Erich remains a gentleman among players

fields.headline: Flak flies but Sir Erich remains a gentleman among players
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 front
fields.trailText: How traditional virtues have deserted Germany's coach.
fields.body:
He is the most courteous of enemies. "I'm looking forward to seeing Kevin Keegan again," Erich Ribbeck said yesterday, "and I'm happy that he, too, is going to contribute to making this a football match and not a war. It's vital that those responsible don't lose control and keep this as what it should be, a sporting encounter."

Most of Ribbeck's recent wars have been of the civil variety, in which he has been opposed by those among his compatriots - sometimes even from inside his own squad - who disapprove of his tactics and his selection policy. Handsome, tanned, silver-haired, the 63-year-old coach also has a nice line in civilised irony, which came in useful this week when deflecting criticism of his side's first appearance in Euro 2000, a limp, error-strewn 1-1 draw with Romania. But the sense of humour momentarily drained away when he was invited to say whether, despite the outside world's judgment that this is the worst Germany team in living memory, he still believes that there is a great, or even a good, side within his squad - and, if so, to speculate on the conditions under which it might emerge.

After the question had been translated, there was a pause of fully 10 seconds, at the end of which he drew a deep breath. "Sometimes it's a great advantage if people underestimate you," he said quietly, looking down. A five-second pause, and he raised his eyes to his questioner. "We played our qualifying matches, and we came first in the group. We lost just one match, in Turkey. Other nations only came second in their group. So when I make those comparisons, I realise we can't be that bad."

Point taken, most of all by the English, although it hardly explains his offer to resign after the 3-0 defeat by the United States in Florida in February 1999, when he was only six months into the job, or the 2-1 defeat by Holland in Amsterdam last February, Germany's first reverse on Dutch soil in 75 years, or the dreadful performance against Romania. The questions wouldn't go away, most of them dealing with the cacophony of complaints surfacing from within the squad, usually to do with his loyalty to the 39-year-old Lothar Matthäus. But the coach, a relaxed Rhinelander whose fastidious manners long ago earned him the nickname "Sir Erich", kept on giving answers, always realistic and interesting, occasionally diversionary, sometimes cleverly conciliatory while refusing to give ground.

For example, how did he respond to the demand of his centre-half, Jens Nowotny, for more responsibility - a coded plea for the removal of Matthäus? "I don't blame him for saying that. I expect players to want responsibility. I don't need also-rans in the team. And responsibility covers all areas - be a good team member, don't lose your one-on-ones, don't pass the ball to the opposition. You can inter pret responsibility in a thousand different ways. Some people interpret it as criticising your team-mates, which is not the right way."

Internecine warfare is hardly what we expect of Germany. The once-envied system which produced a seamless succession of respected coaches appears finally to have broken down. But is Erich Ribbeck the problem, or he is merely the victim of a shallow pool of footballing talent?

Yesterday he announced the selection of the 20-year-old Sebastian Deisler on the right flank, and felt forced to make a joke about it. "How old was Michael Owen when he made his first start for England? Eighteen? Well, I hope you won't reproach me by suggesting that I've left it two years too late to pick Deisler." And then he turned serious. "We should be happy to have a young player with such potential. By giving him an opportunity to play in such a crucial match, I hope to set a trend for the whole of German football. If back home there are kids of 12 or 13 who see that you don't have to wait for a chance with the national team until you're 26 or 27 or 29, it might give them the incentive to keep on trying to realise their dream."

Ribbeck was by no means the first choice of the Deutscher Fussball-Bund when Berti Vogts, the man at the helm when Germany won Euro 96, stepped down after his team crashed 3-0 to Croatia in the World Cup two years later. In fact he was in semi-retirement. An undistinguished defender with Wuppertal, his coaching career started under the wing of Hennes Weisweiler at Borussia Mönchengladbach in the mid-60s before he moved on to Rot-Weiss Essen, Eintracht Frankfurt, Kaiserslautern, Borussia Dortmund, Hamburg, Bayern Munich and Bayer Leverkusen, with whom he won the Uefa Cup in 1988, his only major honour.

Team spirit

It was not long after he took over from Vogts that the internal cracks started to appear. "I think it was easier in the past to create an absolute team spirit," he said rather wistfully this week, "but with the media interests becoming ever stronger, the egoistic side of the players comes through more clearly. I spoke to Uwe Seeler and Horst Hrubesch, who represent two generations of German international players, and they both confirmed that in their time things were different and easier to handle."

To his critics inside Germany, the fact that the coach has managed to hang on to his humanity and his realism is of little interest. "We will try to erase as many mistakes as possible," he said this week on the subject of his team's new habit of giving the ball away. "On the other hand, football lives off its mistakes. They are part of the game." And when challenged on his team's dispirited play against Romania, he responded: "I don't know whether you can increase players' motivation. It has to be strong anyway." He is right on both counts, of course. And yet not quite right enough for some people.

The problems he faces were exposed when Oliver Kahn, his goalkeeper, talked about the defensive lapses that forced him into several one-on-one contests with onrushing Romanian forwards. "This isn't only a problem in defence," Kahn said. "Defensive work begins further up front. You just have to play with more commitment and, let's face it, with more heart in midfield. Because if these guys do their work properly, the defence and I aren't put in so much difficulty."

Conceding an early goal, Kahn said, had given the team "a serious mental problem. It destroys everything that you planned for. But having said that, if you put your national team shirt on it should be clear to everyone that you must fight for your country, run for your country, and give your all for that shirt. Playing with more heart and with your country in mind would already be a big step forward."

Just imagine that - a team in the shirts of Germany playing without pride, and one of their players admitting it. But Keegan and England would be unwise to count on benefiting from the same phenomenon this evening.

"Our next opponent," Ribbeck said yesterday, rather pointedly, "is a team that is proud of its tradition. And we must not lose."

fields.headline: Chelsea agree Sutton's Boro deal
fields.trailText: All the other news including: prize money for the FA Cup; a new contract for Gerard Houllier; a suspension for Alex Rae; and Leeds give Manchester United Gala go-ahead.
fields.body:
Chelsea have agreed a £6m transfer fee with Middlesbrough for Chris Sutton, although they are hoping to recoup the full £10m they paid to Blackburn Rovers for his services last year.

Boro will now speak with the 27-year-old striker, who managed only three goals last season, in an attempt to persuade him to move to Teesside.

"It's true we have agreed a £6m deal with Middlesbrough," said the Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchin- son. "The package is such that it's possible if they have reasonable success over the coming year then we can recoup all our £10m."

The Football Association is to consider introducing prize money for the FA Cup as part of an attempt to restore the competition's prestige.

With BSkyB and the BBC securing a £400m television deal for the competition, the FA has promised new marketing initiatives, including prize money, to challenge the threat posed by the Champions League.

The FA chief executive Adam Crozier said: "It is the first time that the FA have had the funds available to make a huge difference to the game from the grassroots up."

The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier, 52, has signed a new contract committing him to the club until 2005. The deal is believed to be worth about £1m a year.

The Sunderland midfielder Alex Rae has been given a four-match suspension after his red card for elbowing David Ginola in the 3-1 defeat at Tottenham on the final day of the season.

Manchester United will face the Turkish champions Galatasaray in a pre-season tournament to celebrate Bayern Munich's centenary. United consulted the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale before accepting the invitation. "I told them that the sooner sporting links with Turkey are re-established the better," Ridsdale explained.

The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier, 52, has signed a new contract committing him to the club until 2005. The deal is believed to be worth about £1m a year. The Sunderland midfielder Alex Rae has been given a four-match suspension after his red card for elbowing David Ginola in the 3-1 defeat at Tottenham on the final day of the season. Manchester United will face the Turkish champions Galatasaray in a pre-season tournament to celebrate Bayern Munich's centenary. United consulted the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale before accepting the invitation. "I told them that the sooner sporting links with Turkey are re-established the better," Ridsdale explained.

fields.headline: England 1 - 0 Germany
fields.trailText:
Teams
England: Seaman, G. Neville, P. Neville, Campbell, Keown, Beckham, Scholes, Shearer, Owen, Ince, Wise.
Substitutes: Martyn, Wright, Southgate, Barry, Gerrard, Barmby, Heskey, Fowler, Phillips.
fields.body:
Teams
England: Seaman, G. Neville, P. Neville, Campbell, Keown, Beckham, Scholes, Shearer, Owen, Ince, Wise.
Substitutes: Martyn, Wright, Southgate, Barry, Gerrard, Barmby, Heskey, Fowler, Phillips.

Germany: Kahn, Babbel, Nowotny, Scholl, Kirsten, Matthaus, Hamann, Jeremies, Ziege, Deisler, Jancker.
Substitutes: Lehmann, Butt, Rehmer, Linke, Bode, Haessler, Rink, Ballack, Wosz, Ramelow, Bierhoff.
Referee: P Collina (Italy).

1 England kick off. After all the expectation, we're finally under way. Playing from right to left, the first England attack is a long ball to Shearer.

2 Germany have their first foray forward. Mehmet Scholl, the furthest forward of the German midfield, tries to find Ulf Kirsten with a looping pass, but Sol Campbell beats Kirsten to the ball comfortably.

4 How to make Alan Shearer look pacy: put him up against Lothar Matthaus. The England captain slips the ball outside the German veteran and races past him, only to be brought down for a free kick that David Beckham fails to make much use of.

6 Another aerial challenge for Campbell, this time with Jancker, but the German comes off better, and wins a free kick which Christian Ziege can only send over the bar.

9 A long throw from Markus Babbel, 10 yards from the goalline, produces the first half chance of the game. But Carsten Jancker's dangerous flick misses his teammates and Seaman scrambles to the ball first.

10 An England corner which David Beckham decides strangely to send to the far post where only Campbell, and close friend Jancker, are waiting. The ball is cleared.

11 Campbell comes to blows with Jancker again, and gives away a free kick. Scholl takes the kick and a flicked header from Jens Jeremies lands on the roof of Seaman's net.

14 A long throw from Gary Neville finds Shearer's head. His flick-on runs across the six-yard line untouched, but Paul Scholes salvages the ball, scoops it back into the box and England win a corner off Nowotny. Again the corner ends up at the feet of Sol Campbell, who loses the ball and fouls Jancker again into the bargain.

17 Sebastian Deisler displays the game's first piece of skill, jinking past Dennis Wise on the right wing and firing in a low cross beyond the outstretched Phil Neville. Campbell clears for the corner.

18 More German pressure ends with a long shot from Dietmar Hamann - which forces Seaman onto his knees to save. No real danger for England as yet, but the Germans have certainly started the game better. And Matthaus appears to be playing well too.

19 Michael Owen is called offside, chasing onto a through-ball from Alan Shearer. A violent scream of disagreement can be heard to emanate from the young Liverpool striker.

23 Jeremies slices open England's flat back four and releases Scholl into the box. But, with only Seaman to beat, Scholl fires tamely into the ground and Seaman saves. More worrying signs.

24 Scholes beats Jens Jeremies wonderfully, dragging the ball around and past the Bayern Munich man. He then finds Michael Owen on the right wing, but Owen's cross is poor.

25 Another striking chance for Germany, and again it's easy for Seaman. But England are both sitting off the German midfield as they attack, and defending in numbers - not an ideal combination.

29 Another cross from Scholl forces Scholes to head out for a corner.

32 Another German corner. Cleared this time by Keown, but with only two men upfield, the ball heads swiftly back into German possession. England are seeing less of the ball than they did against Portugal - but still no chances for either side.

34 Correction. A hopeful long ball from Dennis Wise is cleared for an England throw. The throw goes to Phil Neville whose right-footed cross (natch) finds the head of Michael Owen. Owen connects with both power and positioning, and Kahn can only push the ball onto the post. Thankfully for the Germans, the ball bobbles to safety.

35 Scholes drives from 30 yards. The shot, reminiscent of his goal against Middlesbrough for Manchester United, just dips too late to sneak under the bar.

39 England's best movement of the match. Wise plays a crossfield pass to Gary Neville, who feeds Scholes, who passes to Ince, who releases Alan Shearer into the box. Instead of shooting however, Shearer opts to lay the ball back square to Ince. The ball is easily intercepted by Nowotny, but this is better from England.

40 Hmmm. David Beckham is booked for retaliating to a wild challenge from Kirsten. We can all probably remember a similar event a couple of years ago.

41 1-1. In yellow cards that is, as Jeremies is booked for a foul on Ince.

42 More good play from England. Wise makes a great tackle on Scholl, and Scholes picks up the ball. Scholes then plays a one-two with Beckham which covers half the length of the field, and results in a half-volley from Scholes which again forces Kahn into a good save. This is the sort of play that worried the Portuguese.

45 Which means that the next notable event has to be a lucky escape for England. Two successive corners German corners find Seaman flapping, and Dietmar Hamann just misses the target after firing in off a rebound.

48 Half-time.

45 Germany re-start. Germany advance immediately and Phil Neville clumsily brings Jancker down on the edge of the box. Ziege whips in the free kick which drifts just over the bar.

48 The half has begun with a series of free kicks, mostly given away by the England midfield. As in the first half however, the opportunities rarely come to anything.

49 A scramble in the German box ends with a shooting opportunity for Michael Owen. But the ball stubbornly refuses to come down and the opportunity passes.

50 Which is what Paul Ince should have done, rather than blazing the ball over Kahn's bar after being set up by David Beckham.

532 GOAL! England 1 - 0 Germany Can you guess what happened? That's right, a beautifully deceptive free kick from David Beckham screams past the German backline and onto the head of a diving Alan Shearer. His header finds the far post, and England are up.

54 England's goal is swiftly followed by Germany's best chance of the game. Jancker eludes the attentions of Campbell and gets to a Scholl cross first. He spins and shoots, but the ball - which could have gone anywhere - goes over.

58 Germany are really going at England. Scholl comes even closer than Jancker with a shot inside the box that only just trundles wide of Seaman's far post. There weer six England defenders back inside the area too. A lucky break.

60 England substitution - Gerrard for Owen. Unlike on Monday, Keegan is looking to close up shop.

62 Beckham, who has been dropping deep to pick up the ball throughout the game, is now finding spaces into which he can deliver the ball. One such attempt finds Shearer who heads the ball across the box towards Scholes, playing further forward in the absence of Owen. A hasty clearance from Nowotny clears the danger.

63 Gerrard makes his first contribution of the game, robbing Scholl of the ball in the area just as the German was about to strike. Germany win a corner

64 Another let off for England. The corner is whipped in by Deisler and headed down by Kirsten. Seaman can only clear the ball into the path of Jancker who, falling backwards, somehow conspires to miss.

65 A rare moement in footballing history as Phil Neville produces a Giggs-ian stepover and leaves Deisler for dead. The resulting cross is too long, but we'll pass over that.

68 Another German corner causes a few hearts to flutter but a foul by Jacker curtails any real danger.

69 Germany substitution: Rink for Kirsten.

71 England substitution: Barmby for Scholes.
Germany substitution: Ballack for Deisler
Scholes appears to be limping as he comes off for Everton's Barmby.

73 These last few minutes are going to be tense. Germany are piling forward, and England appear to lose possession before they even get it. Still though, Germany appear unable to get a real strike on goal (wood is being touched at the time of writing).

76 Although England aren't seeing much of the ball, the arrival of Gerrard and, latterly, Barmby appears to have settled the midfield a little, allowing Wise and Beckham to come inside freely and giving England several options when breaking upfield.

77 Germany substitution - Bode for Jeremies. Germany's best player leaves the field.

79 Alan Shearer is felled in the German box and, clutching his hip, hobbles off-field.

80 Shearer comes back on the field, with Germany enjoying ever greater possession. Still they fail to do anything constructive with it, but England cannot rely on the failings of the opposition.

82 Marco Bode tries to scoop the ball over the English defence one-by-one, and almost succeeds. A fortunate toe poke from Martin Keown eventually brings an end to another worrying moment.

84 A decent shooting opportunity for Paolo Rink, after Paul Ince sells himself with a sliding challenge. Sadly for the left-footed Rink, he shoots with his right foot and the ball goes well wide.

86 A long spell of German possession ends in Barmby giving away a dangerous free kick. Scholl sends it into the danger zone and Seaman is forced to punch, quite weakly, to keep the ball off Jancker's head.

88 Markus Babbel is booked for protesting after a flailing Alan Shearer wins a free-kick. The Liverpool-bound defender better get used to it.

89 Beckham sets up Gerrard for a shot on the edge of the area which bobbles into the arms of Kahn.

91 England supporters, who have been far the more vocal all night, sense victory. What better way to celebrate than a quick round of the Great Escape?

93 It's over! England, despite never playing as well as they did against Portugal, have won three points in Euro 2000, taking them into second place in the group. And, oh yeah, they've beaten Germany in a competitive match for the first time since 1966. Come on.

webTitle: NHS 'should use best breast cancer drugs'

fields.headline: NHS 'should use best breast cancer drugs'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Two expensive modern breast cancer drugs, which are widely used overseas but have been available in the UK only in the few health authorities that would pay for them, should be available on the NHS, a government advisory body said yesterday.
fields.body:
Two expensive modern breast cancer drugs, which are widely used overseas but have been available in the UK only in the few health authorities that would pay for them, should be available on the NHS, a government advisory body said yesterday.

Taxol (paclitaxel) and taxotere (docetaxel), which cost up to £6,000 a patient, should be given to all women with advanced breast cancer once other chemotherapy has failed, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) ruled.

The decision would cost the NHS an extra £16m to treat the 4,000 patients a year who are currently being denied the drugs. Only 1,000 women are getting the drugs.

Health minister John Denham welcomed the institute's guidance which follows a recommendation last month to allow the taxanes, as this group of drugs is known, on NHS prescription.

"The fight against cancer is one of our top priorities in modernising the NHS," he said. "We set up Nice to provide authoritative guidance about which drugs and treatments are most clinically and cost effective.

"Today's announcement means thousands of women suffering from advanced breast cancer can look forward to effective treatment wherever they live."

The decision on the taxanes was keenly awaited by cancer support groups, which have been lobbying for the end of what has notoriously become known as "postcode prescribing". While they were pleased at the result, they had concerns that health authorities would still not want to pay for them. They also pointed out that the UK still lags behind other countries in Europe and the United States in the introduction of new cancer drugs.

Professor Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: "At last we have got some action, but we expect money to follow that action. There's no point Nice making statements if health authorities can't afford to pay for the drugs."

Delyth Morgan, chief executive of Breakthrough Cancer was even less enthusiastic. "This is the first step towards ending postcode prescribing. The next crucial step is for doctors to make all women who might benefit from these drugs aware of them. But for some women this decision is too little, too late."

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: Days eight and nine

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: Days eight and nine
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. So what should you bet on this weekend?
fields.body:
Well, a week of reckless gambling has passed, and the standings look like this:

Scott Murray: £106.67
Mike Hodgkinson: £58.73
Sean Ingle: £49.36
Paul MacInnes: £28

Another week? Yeah, why not...

Scott Murray

Saturday
England v Germany: Goals scored 4 or more 9/4 (£10)

I can't remember England being involved in a "big clash" in a major tournament without it being incident-packed. Strange thing is, these matches always seem to end up one-all, despite about seventy or eighty near misses at each end. Something tells me a punt on 2-3 goals scored sounds good, then, but as both defences are particularly useless this time, I'll take a chance on seeing at least four.

Sunday
Norway v Yugoslavia: First goalscorer Vegard Heggem 40/1 (£5)

Yes, I know Spain should trounce Slovenia. But for some reason I am disinclined to touch them, even with an overly long bargepole fitted with a bargepole extension. Instead, I'm taking a pop on Vegard Heggem, who had a solid game for Norway down the right flank against the Spanish.

I expect Heggem to trouble a Yugoslav defence weakened down the left by the loss of smilin' Sinisa Mihajlovic, who got his marching orders against Slovenia. The Liverpool defender can finish well - he's popped in the odd goal in the Premiership, and if he can breach defences like Middlesbrough's and Bradford's, he can breach anything.

Mike Hodgkinson

Saturday
Portugal v Romania: Draw 11-5 (£10)

Romania will go into this game knowing that, however gifted Portugal's attacking stars, their defence is not an impenetrable fortress. So long as they're not unnerved by the bizarre appearance of Abel "Bigfoot and the Hendersons" Xavier, they should score. But Portugal will hit back - so the draw looks likely.

Sunday
Norway v Yugoslavia: Draw 11-5 (£10)

A tight game in prospect and it's hard to find this one ending in anything other than stalemate. Norway would quite happily settle for shared points so if things are tight with 20 minutes to go, the game may clam up. Yugoslavia may not miss Mihajlovic that much, but will still find it hard to break Norway down.

Sean Ingle

Saturday
England v Germany: Double - goals scored 2 or 3 goals 10/11 and Portugal to draw with Romania 11/5 (£5)

England to shock the world with a stunning 3-0 victory, with Michael Owen scoring the first goal! A 100-1 shot! "That's a bargain!" says adventurous Sean. !Don't be silly," interrupts rational Sean - "It'll end 1-1, just like it always does." Either way the 2 or 3 goals option has it covered. But it only pays a measly 10-11 which is why I've combined it with a Portugal v Romania draw. Hagi's boys won in Lisbon, and drew in Bucharest, which is why a draw is not as stupid as it sounds. And if both results come off I'll win £30.

Sunday
Spain v Slovenia: First goalscorer Raul (£10) 3-1

Despite their woeful performance against Norway, even the Spanish should beat Slovenia. Surely?! But the 1-3 on a Spain win doesn't offer any value. Raul to score first does, which is why I've gone for it.

Paul MacInnes

Saturday
England v Germany: England to win 6/4 (£5)

Never let your heart rule your head when it comes to gambling. That's what Howard Keel once told me, and it's advice I was loathe to spurn. But Howard Keel is now a has-been so he can stick his advice and I'm going to put an emotional fiver on Kev and the boys to bring us home some glory. [Stumbles off humming Great Escape theme to himself]

Sunday
Spain v Slovenia: Goals scored 4 or more 11/8 (£10)

Thanks to the vagaries of Uefa's ticketing system I am going to this game. So how better to jinx my chances of watching a good match by betting on there being loads of goals? A great decision, even though I say so myself, albeit one that does have a bit of logic to it (stung Spain v defensively-sloppy and attackingly-gifted Slovenia). If I lose this bet, it should leave me pretty much broke. Hurrah.

But the 1-3 on a Spain win doesn't offer any value. Raul to score first does, which is why I've gone for it. Paul MacInnes Saturday England v Germany: England to win 6/4 (£5) Never let your heart rule your head when it comes to gambling. That's what Howard Keel once told me, and it's advice I was loathe to spurn. But Howard Keel is now a has-been so he can stick his advice and I'm going to put an emotional fiver on Kev and the boys to bring us home some glory. [Stumbles off humming Great Escape theme to himself] Sunday Spain v Slovenia: Goals scored 4 or more 11/8 (£10) Thanks to the vagaries of Uefa's ticketing system I am going to this game. So how better to jinx my chances of watching a good match by betting on there being loads of goals? A great decision, even though I say so myself, albeit one that does have a bit of logic to it (stung Spain v defensively-sloppy and attackingly-gifted Slovenia). If I lose this bet, it should leave me pretty much broke. Hurrah.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Tel Aviv

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Tel Aviv
fields.standfirst: Linda Grant
fields.trailText: Linda Grant
fields.body:
Why? When I went to Tel Aviv two years ago, I spent the first 24 hours thinking it was a horrible place. It seemed a city filled with crumbling 1960s buildings. Then I looked at them again and realised it was genuine Bauhaus architecture. Tel Aviv was founded in 1909 but most of it was built in the 1930s by refugees from Germany, so it is very much a 20th-century city. I love Tel Aviv for being secular and very young. It is not beautiful and has nothing in the way of charm - or at least charm which is immediately visible -but it has a wonderful vitality. Unlike Florence, Venice or Paris, which you see through the eyes of other people, Tel Aviv has not been written about. But if you want to understand what makes Israel tick, you have to go there.

What's the best thing? There is a fabulous museum of the Jewish diaspora but, for me, it is wandering the streets, eating in the fish restaurants and seeing the liveliness of the place. Two of my favourite places are Carmel Market and Shenkin Street. When you visit Carmel Market, your idea of what a Jew is goes into complete meltdown; there are Jewish pimps, prostitutes and drug dealers, and Shenkin Street on a Friday afternoon is like Camden market. It is a magnet for young Israelis.

My advice: You have to appreciate that Tel Aviv is not a resort; it's a city that happens to be on the Mediterranean and you have to regard it as a city holiday with the sea as an extra.

How do I get there? British Airways (0845 7733377) flies to Tel Aviv from £159 up to July 15. From July 16 to Aug 15, the price is £299. Taxes are £36.80 from Heathrow, £35 from Gatwick. KLM (0870 5074074) offers return flights from Heathrow from £456 excl tax.

 Linda Grant is the winner of this year's Orange Prize for her novel When I Lived In Modern Times, published by Granta at £9.99.

webTitle: How I fell in love with a square society

fields.headline: How I fell in love with a square society
fields.standfirst: Julie Burchill has been a reluctant traveller. Her first love was the Caribbean. Then came Las Vegas. This time, with the boyfriend's mother, she flirted with an island stuck out in the Mediterranean...
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill has been a reluctant traveller. Her first love was the Caribbean. Then came Las Vegas. This time, with the boyfriend's mother, she flirted with an island stuck out in the Mediterranean...
fields.body:
It must be said that there are things that the English are good at - war and pop music - and then there's things that mainland Europeans are good at: smoking fags and sitting over a drink in shady squares, watching the world go by. On balance, if I had to choose, I'd be good at war and pop - but after a week in Corsica, I concede that there's quite a lot to be said for the other way of doing things, too.

I didn't go abroad until I was 35, when I started going on long-haul holidays like a thing possessed. I did this because one of my jet-setting friends told me, spitefully I now realise, that, having seen the beaches of Antigua and the Maldives, I was officially spoiled for Europe, where the sea was grey and the beaches thick with used syringes.

On a more erudite level, this passage from Kingsley Amis's I Like It Here, as the hero contemplates the horrors of a hot mainland Europe, always stuck in my mind: "All that sun, which made you set out to be colourful and wonderful instead of keeping quiet and getting on with the job. All that geography and biology, which made you behave as if you had invented the country instead of just living in it... All that air of maturity, lack of nervousness and doubt, devotion to serious shouting argument or dedicated gaiety, naturalness which was always an actor's naturalness... All that staring - which in England would be the mindless inquisitiveness of those whose greyly uniform lives were nourished on mere sensation, but in the sunny South was a frank, free, healthy, open, uninhibited curiosity."

But what can you do? When in Rome, eat spaghetti. And when in Corsica, you'd better get used PDQ to a whole wagonload of sun, geography, maturity and the rest of it. You also, in my case, have to get used to the fact that your jet-set friend was lying to you, and that the sea and sand of this island poised between France and Italy is of a standard that makes the Caribbean look positively murky. The weather's better, too; I went in May, and I came back moderately sunburned - it will be two degrees hotter than that in October, however. Whatever you do, avoid July and August, when it's full of Frenchies, too scalding hot to go out before 4pm and prices in hotels and restaurants double - mmm, lovely.

Corsica is 100 miles from France and 50 miles from Italy, which sounds like something God would do on a particularly good hair day. Corsicans are like the French without the ponciness and the Italians without the corniness, and the climate is similarly sweet, though the months from November to April see the island become the wild, untamed place of the popular imagination. When I was there, bright warm sunshine combined with the most impudent and charming breezes, as though someone who likes you a lot was following you around with a big feathery fan and wafting the scent of the lemon trees all over you.

Everything looks lovely in Corsica, even things you wouldn't normally expect anything of, like stations and airports - the airport is like a lido without the water (and as my dad used to say of the Moscow Underground, you could eat your dinner off the floor) while the stations look like something out of Clochmerle.

Corsica does everything well, but what it does best is squares. Big, cool, shady squares under plane trees that are a hundred years old, and loads of tables without ashtrays because you might as well just drop your fag end in the sand on the ground. And the most gorgeous dogs running round everywhere in mint condition, complete with collars and ID, not strays, but obviously out for a constitutional and looking to make a few new friends.

It is this feeling of everything being relaxed and organic that makes our sorry attempts at café society look even more pathetic than usual; all those people sitting under gun-metal grey skies in Soho and Covent Garden, doing their best to trip up the tourists and getting dirty looks if they bring a four-legged friend with them. The only place I've ever seen the alfresco thing work properly here, in fact, is in Torquay.

Frankly, though you're not supposed to say it, I love Torquay, and to a great extent I approve of holiday destinations insofar as they resemble it. I liked Funchal, the capital of Madeira, for this reason, and also Harbour Island in the Bahamas. But the little town of L'Ile Rousse, where we stayed, scored highest of all on my Torquameter.

Founded in 1760 by the Corsican nationalist leader Pascal Paoli, who worked ceaselessly to throw off the yoke of Jacques and Giovanni Foreigner, Paoli predicted that it would be "the gallows on which we hang Calvi" - Calvi still being in the mitts of the Genoese, whose blockade was suffocating the economy of the putative state. Due to the export of wine and olive oil, L'Ile Rousse became a successful port, but now, according to the excellent Rough Guide to Corsica, "The main traffic consists of holidaymakers... That the only town intended to be a Corsican success story makes its living from tourism as a classic French-style resort adds an ironic twist to Paoli's dream."

There's always some misery-bucket who has to spoil things for everyone else, have you noticed? The only twist I was interested in was floating in my Martini as I sat in the square outside the Café des Platanes in the place Paoli, the central square of L'Ile Rousse, thinking that, to judge by the statue there, old Pascal had been quite fit in a depressed done-it-all Jeff Bridges sort of way. I suppose you could call Torquay a French-style resort, too, if you wanted to be rude, but importantly they're both like the Riviera as it must have been in the early 50s, before mass tourism discovered it - more Mr Ripley than Mr Whippy.

Sitting in Place Paoli, you can sip a Suze or a peppermint Get 27 and eyeball the 18th-century French architecture, all balconies and shutters and just a little bit gone to seed and therefore perfect, and fancy yourself as a European something rotten. The Café des Platanes has been there since 1928, serves more than 150 types of alcoholic and/or ice cream cocktails (Turbot Jet: chocolate and peppermint ice cream and Get 27; Barbe Noire: chocolate ice cream and whisky; Colonel: lemon sorbet and vodka) and you can bet your virtue that it isn't owned by some horrible corporation, as is invariably the case with every folksy little joint in Britain.

From your vantage point, you can observe that even in the town centre there are no yellow lines, no parking restrictions and that Corsican cars, like Corsican dogs, appear to be allowed to do what they want, even parking on zebra crossings. Yet somehow everyone seems to rub along.

Maybe this sweet- temperedness has something to do with the restaurants; they certainly put me in a good mood. No cheque had a space for service charge; carafes of the purest Corsican water came to the table unbidden; not one joint tried to charge us for the air that we breathed while on their premises, which so many English restaurateurs seem determined to. The ritziest dinner we had was at Le Grand Bleu in rue Napoleon, which cost Ffr320 (£32) for two people with a gorgeous Corsican wine, Colombo, but there were also Ffr70 and Ffr90 set menus, as there are in most Corsican restaurants. At L'Etoile D'Or, in Place Paoli, I had a seafood salad with a champagne sauce that was unbelievable. I never thought I'd go at a salad like a piggy at its trough, but the lettuce had actual sex appeal. A testimony to the cool and ceaseless smoking of the Corsicans is the huge steel stand-up ashtray right beside the toilet here.

Le Crillon, a hotel and restaurant two minutes away from the main tourist drag, on the avenue Paul Doumer, is the sort of place that, in the 50s, Cyril Connolly would drag his mistresses hundreds of miles to, in search of the perfect tomato salad. High ceilings, glazed windows, a condiments boat and Ray Charles on low, obviously not done up in any way and a lady who looked like Edith Piaf sitting alone at the next table eating fish soup with aïoli; here, you can find heaven for Ffr78. The steak roquefort and potato gratin screamed out for a cigarette afterwards, and I'm not even a smoker.

There's only a few bad things about Corsica, and even they aren't really that bad unless you're working overtime at being a worry-wart. There's not much to do, even in Calvi - you'd better be there with someone you like a heck of a lot. I'm afraid to say that the long afternoons between the glorious beach sessions and the gorgeous dinners did seem to call out for some form of lingering, languorous sexual activity, but as I was on holiday with my boyfriend's mother, romping wasn't really on the agenda, to say the least. Instead, I found myself walking half a mile each afternoon to pick up yesterday's Daily Mail, just for kicks. But Calvi is only 45 minutes on the train, through some of the loveliest scenery you'll ever see.

Don't be expecting to pig out in five-star luxury in Corsica; our hotel, the Santa Maria, was clean and cool but had no suites, no restaurant and the television was entirely foreign except for an American financial channel. In the Caribbean, you get about 16 English channels, many of them devoted to films - but then the price you pay for this is holidaying among masses of North Americans, and, frankly, I don't think I can ever do this again, not at my age. The floor was of the sort of rough rustic matting, a bugger on the bare feet, that would have had Kingsley effing and blinding like a good 'un, but the bathroom was a pristine white temple to dear departed hi-tech.

Whatever shortcomings the hotel had were more than made up for by the pool; one reasonably-sized cold rectangle on an attractive terrace. I've lost count now of the number of Caribbean resorts, some of them very upmarket, which fail to manage this, and now that the sea in so many places is rendered hazardous by wet-biking, it's not much to ask. But no; the pools in such places tend to be tiny, tepid, constructed in such a way that laps are an impossibility and, most annoying, surrounded by sticky-beaked signs instructing one "not to swim unless the lifeguard is present", though how you're supposed to drown yourself in a pool measuring four feet at the deep end, I don't know. Here, the deep end was deep - ie, you couldn't stand up in it - and if there ever had been a lifeguard, he'd gone off and got a life for himself long ago.

As if all this gorgeousness wasn't enough, it only takes one hour 40 minutes to get there direct.

webTitle: Charlie Easmon: Biodegradable soap | Nokia phone | A necklace of Nyame Nyame

fields.headline: Charlie Easmon never travels without...
fields.trailText: Biodegradable soap | Nokia phone | A necklace of Nyame Nyame
fields.body:
A necessity: Biodegradable soap. Avoid disease without damaging the environment.

A luxury: My Nokia phone, because I can e-mail and fax from it wherever I am in the world. I'm the sort of person who wants to be in contact when I'm away.

A memento: A necklace of Nyame Nyame, the Zimbabwean river god.

If only: There is a bag that you just throw into a dirty pool and it filters clean water into the bag. If only all travellers took one with them, then people would not pick up water-borne disease.

 Dr Charlie Easmon is a specialist adviser in travel health at the Hospital for Tropical Diseases Travel Clinic, London. Travellers' Advice Line: 09061 337733.

webTitle: Riots in Charleroi quelled by water cannon

fields.headline: Riots in Charleroi quelled by water cannon
fields.standfirst: Football violence - special report
fields.trailText: English football fans were again involved in  violent disturbances in Charleroi today, before the crucial Euro 2000 match against Germany.
fields.body:
English football fans were again involved in violent disturbances in Charleroi today, before the crucial Euro 2000 match against Germany.

Supporters of both England and Germany threw chairs and bottles at each other in the main square, until driven back by police using horses and water cannon. The trouble started just before 1 o'clock, when English fans charged at a group of chanting Germans.

Police in riot gear moved in to form a cordon between the two sets of fans. At one stage German fans tried to break the line penning them back, hurling missiles at police, but they were forced back by officers on foot and further use of the water cannon.

Three thousand police, including 120 on horseback and 45 dog handlers, were on duty for the "high risk" match in Charleroi's biggest ever security operation.

Meanwhile hundreds of England fans arrested in disturbances in Brussels on Friday were being flown home in handcuffs and under heavy police guard.

The 343 supporters were being brought back on a Belgium military aircraft in batches of 40 a time to Manchester Airport. Another 31 fans were being kept in custody in Brussels, facing charges for public order offences arising from the violence. One possible spark for the fighting in Charleroi was an incident in which an English fan was arrested after apparently snatching a German flag from a rival supporter.

The National Criminal Intelligence Service in London said last night that around 60 Britons had been refused entry to Belgium, Holland and Germany since the start of the tournament. These included three members of Combat 18, a fascist group, who were turned back from Brussels airport yesterday after flying from Heathrow. The Belgian authorities were hoping to quell any disturbances in Charleroi by posting some 3,000 officers - including 600 riot police - on the streets ahead of the game.

webTitle: Are you made of the ride stuff?

fields.headline: Are you made of the ride stuff?
fields.standfirst: A small consolation for a middle-aged woman cycling from London to Brussels in three days is that Belgium is flat, right? Not true, says  Julie Welch
fields.trailText: A small consolation for a middle-aged woman cycling from London to Brussels in three days is that Belgium is flat, right? Not true, says Julie Welch.
fields.body:
Stage 1. Thursday. Dulwich - Dover. 129km

Battling in a brutal headwind up the near-vertical hill that is the old approach road to Dover, it came to me that it might have be easier to reach Belgium by getting called up for the England team. Instead, I was going by bike, along with 57 others who had set off in a tidy peloton that morning from Dulwich College and were now strung out over the clifftops in varying degrees of bedragglement as the unseasonable gusts of early June tried to blow us back to London.

I'd better explain. Bike to Brussels is one of two annual cycle trips organised as fund-raisers by the British Legion. For £350, you get overnight hotel accommodation, meals, outward ferry journey from Dover to Calais, and return fare on Eurostar. I had done the Legion's Pedal to Paris four years back, and retained fond memories of the wine-and-baguette-fuelled control stops in shady villages of the Somme, of the laughs and sense of freedom, not to mention the lasting friendships begun over the borrowing of a tube of Deep Heat. This year, we also had the services of a piper, Duncan, whose plangent tones saw us off through the southern outskirts of London towards the Channel, the battlefields of the Somme and, three days and many litres of sweat later, the heart of Europe.

As with childbirth, of course, one is programmed only to remember the wonderful bits, otherwise one would never reproduce again and the human race would die out. I had forgotten how awful it is to cycle through Kent in wind and rain, through never-ending roadworks, up hills that did not seem to go down again, on a bike that was designed more for the carting home of the weekend shopping than for challenging for kingship of the mountains.

As ever, the organisers were keen to stress that this was not a race, though as we forced ourselves towards the waiting ferry a useful motivation for tired legs and sore knees was to entertain fantasies of being involved in some bitter pursuit match with Richard Virenque.

My fellow pedallers were the usual mixed but delightful bunch. I shared vast platefuls of chips with lean young guys to whom Lycra was a second skin, and blathered about bikes with grizzled veterans in their sixties and seventies who could remember the prime of Reg Harris and who, despite their antique appearance, sped past me on the hills like Marco Pantani while I heaved and puffed on the granny gear. There was an East Devon council chairman who had trained for the trip by riding out with his local cycling club - "After 50 miles I told them I had council affairs to attend to and went home" - a couple of husband-and-wife teams and a man on a pennyfarthing.

There was also a father-and-son team. The father, a distinguished-looking cross between Sir John Mills and Arnold Ridley, went missing soon after we left Dulwich. The police were alerted by his frantic son, who gave them a touchingly filial description of a gentleman on the verge of 70, adrift in the elements in nothing but shorts and a T-shirt saying Bike To Brussels. He was eventually spotted on the outskirts of Dover, having changed his clothes and found his own way there after a wrong turning somewhere near Bromley.

Stage 2. Friday. Calais - Ypres. 94km

In Calais, the dormitory arrangements were on the lines of a moonie wedding - you had no idea with whom you would be sleeping till the room keys were handed out. My room-mate turned out to be an intrepid, Kilimanjaro-climbing 47-year-old, also called Julie. From our window, a marvellous view greeted us at seven the next morning: bits of blue sky.

Piped away from the Hotel de Ville, our peloton headed for Ypres on the potholed but peaceful towpath of the Canal de Calais, where men fished serenely and little boats chugged past. It was the last sliver of France before it became Belgium: the Bonjour Belt, one of those areas so uneventful that people hang around their front gardens all day to say bonjour to passing strangers.

Our lunch stop was in Zegerscappel, Flemish-sounding but still French. We ate home-cured ham and chocolate éclairs, drank red wine, lent each other spirit rub for the knees. We crossed over into Belgium at Houtkerque, where there was no border guard, just an enormous turkey roosting by a pond like a Red Indian chief. But seen from a bicycle, the land was immediately different. The grey and scruffy D roads of France became pale, concrete, backside-unfriendly ribbons on which slimy slicks of mud and cowshit, known by pro cyclists as "Belgian toothpaste", had solidified into natural cobblestones. Twenty-four hours after the dank journey through Kent, the sun was baking our arms brick red.

We were escorted by motorcycle outriders but really there was no need. Fittingly for the land of Eddy Merckx, Belgium welcomes, positively fawns over, cyclists. Belgian drivers, the wild bunch of the motorways of Europe, inched past us as if we were made of spun sugar. Locals smiled and applauded as we clattered past. Where the outriders came in useful was showing us the way. French roads tend to bombard you with more information than you need. Belgium is sparing with signposts. We shot through Reningelst and Hallebast without registering them, and came upon Ypres unprepared.

It was pretty and sparklingly hygienic. We stored our bikes in an empty shop off Grote Markt and strolled stiffly through the town. There were public gardens with wooden benches to sit on, next to troughs of purple and blue flowers. Birds burbled and pudgy citizens sat outside pavement cafés, downing beers in the last of the afternoon sun. At 8pm, the town went quiet, and at the Menin Gate the Last Post was sounded, as it is every night, for the 54,986 Allied dead of the first world war who have no known graves.

Stage 3. Saturday. Ypres - Brussels. 125km

Duncan the piper saw us on our way with a rendering of Hearts of Oak which, after a dinner washed down with enormous amounts of Belgian beer, was less than ear candy. During the 80 miles that ensued, we made an important discovery, which was that Belgium, contrary to popular perception, is not flat. On a bike, after two days in the saddle, it was like taking on the ctes and cols of the Tour de France.

At teatime, on the way into Pamel, a dozen Belgian cyclists rode silently alongside us and escorted us to their clubhouse nestling in a valley. They gave us spice cake, beer, plump crisps, lemonade. We were touched by the hospitality, though somewhat crestfallen by the realisation that every road out of the place was uphill. Only 15 miles outside Brussels, it was hard to believe that the hub of Europe was so near. We cycled through villages where tethered heifers grazed in front gardens, where even the garden sheds had roses round the door. At 5pm, we reached the outskirts of Brussels and what everyone hoped was the last hill.

At the crest, we had our first sight of Brussels. An avenue extended as far as our eyes could see: tall, posh buildings of smokey glass in a city haze, trains, bridges. Tramtracks in the middle of the road brought two tired cyclists crashing to the cobblestones. The journey into the city's heart seemed endless, the noise indescribable after two days of silent countryside. At last it was in front of us: the archway of the Parc du Cinquentenaire. It was at the top of a hill.

Inside the park, we slid off our bikes and drank beers under a thundery sky. The British Ambassador gave out medals saying Bike to Brussels 2000 in gold on a dark blue ribbon. That night we all ate together; awards were given out. The British Legion budget could not extend to yellow jerseys, but Sir John Mills received a special glass paperweight. "Ladies and gentlemen," he said. "I feel very emotional. In fact, I'm pissed."

webTitle: The town that came in from the cold

fields.headline: The town that came in from the cold
fields.standfirst: Emerging from the shadow of Soviet domination, the Estonian capital has joined the café revolution. Daniel Hickey chills out
fields.trailText: Emerging from the shadow of Soviet domination, the Estonian capital has joined the café revolution. Daniel Hickey chills out
fields.body:
You will only need a simple disguise to slip unnoticed past the lonely souvenir hawkers in Tallinn's medieval quarter. Ray-Bans, an Armani suit and the latest mobile phone will easily deflect their wolfish gaze. "Another local who's made it," they'll sniff.

Mercs are in and Ladas definitely out in this laid-back capital. Since independence in 1991, it has turned its back on Moscow and St Petersburg to look squarely at a Western future. In the medieval core, bars and restaurants proliferate, serving young moneyed locals, tourists and Finns on booze cruises. You can be feeling your way along the half-lit corridor of a 13th-century Dominican monastery when you trip over a step and stumble into a busy modern bar.

Winding cobbled streets and stone arches lead into restaurants or craft workshops. In summer, the daylight is almost unending and bathes the city in what can seem, at least at 3am, an almost supernatural glare.

Facing north from Toompea Hill, the Hanseatic Lower Town inclines to the port, with its jumble of spires, fortified buildings and pastel merchant houses. Straight ahead, beyond the ferry terminal and Tallinn Bay, the Baltic meets the sky towards Helsinki, 85km away.

"The Russians came to liberate us in 1944, but forgot to leave," says Anna, our guide, who happens to be Russian. A familiar story in Tallinn's complex history. Waves of Danish, Swedish, German, and Russian invaders have left a cocktail of architectural styles topped up since 1218, when the Danes built a stone castle on Toompea Hill. German merchants soon followed. The rail link to St Petersburg in 1870 brought a Russian influx.

Today, 40% of Tallinn's population is Russian, and the government promotes a delicate integrationist policy. Street posters portray smiling Russian and Estonian citizens.

What to see

The distinctive onion domes of the Russian Orthodox Alexander Nevsky cathedral dominate Toompea Hill. Finished in 1900, but modelled on 17th-century Muscovite architecture, it is provocatively named after a medieval conqueror of Estonia. Its icons, mosaics and 15-ton bell were imported from St Petersburg.

There's hardly a Russian building in Tallinn that hasn't withstood a whispering campaign to have it demolished. But, say locals, "it would take more explosives than we've got", and the cathedral is safe for now.

Up the hill, the Estonian art museum contains unfamiliar names in familiar European styles. Nearby, the terraces at Toom Rüütli and Rahukohtu provide the best views across the city.

Raekoja Plats, the town hall square, has seen festivals, markets, punishments and, in 1444, probably the world's first Christmas tree. Now it's full of restaurants and bars, just the place to loll over a glass of Saku beer.

Vanaisa Juures on Müürivahe sells a bewildering selection of liqueurs and vodkas. Try Vana Tallinn (£4), or the pricier Kannu Kukk with its sugar crystals at the bottom of the bottle (£8). Along the street under the city wall, women sell traditional woollen garments.

The Gothic town hall is bestrode by Old Thomas, "protector" of Tallinn, a suitably tiny, ineffectual-looking figure.

Further afield

Two miles east, around the bay, lie the song grounds, with a 1950s amphitheatre at the foot of a natural bowl. Singing festivals were held to celebrate occasions such as Stalin's birthday, but, in 1988, 300,000 gathered to sing for independence. The venue is still used for huge folk festivals and pop concerts. In winter, locals ski and sledge down the slope.

The baroque palace in Kadriorg Park was commissioned by Peter the Great in 1718, and designed by the Italian Niccolo Michetti. The "mini Versailles" is the president's official residence, but from next month it will host the foreign art collection.

The outlying "bedroom districts", so-called because there's nothing to do except sleep, demonstrate Soviet planning of striking banality. Three-, five-, and 13-storey blocks incongruously overlook rural-style smallholdings, and Trabants pass by hoardings advertising casinos.

Saaremaa and Muhu islands

The "old Estonia" lies an hour-and-a-half's drive and a 30-minute ferry ride west of Tallinn. It too has seen multiple invasions - in 1227 the Teutonic Knights marched 20,000 soldiers across the Baltic ice. It was a spa resort from 1824 until the Soviets built rocket installations and banned foreigners. The hangars now lie empty in the forests.

The population is sparse, even by Estonian standards, and wildlife includes boar and a vast number of birds. Traditionally, the islanders survived on fishing and sealhunting. Now tourists come for the windmills, mud spas and the sandy beaches on the fragmented coastline. There are some interesting restaurants, including one in a windmill (Veski at 19 Parna).

The meteorite crater at Kaali is a source of huge pride to the locals.

On Muhu, joined to Saaremaa by a causeway, the Koguva open-air village museum preserves reed-thatched cottages, a school house and an antique sauna (with birch branches for a post-sweat beating).

5 of the best restaurants

It's easier to eat Italian than Estonian in Tallinn. International restaurants proliferate, and traditional recipes of herring, black or white pudding or pea soup with pigs' trotters are mostly confined to the home. Main courses cost from around £4 in the cheaper establishments to £12 in the upmarket hotel restaurants.

Olde Hansa Vana turg 1, tel: +6279 020. A recreated medieval banquet hall serving wild boar, and even bear.

Vanaema Jüüres (Grandma's) Rataskaevu 10/12, tel: +6313 928. Traditional Estonian dishes in a homely environment.

Mõõkkala Rüütli 16/18, tel: +6313 583. Upmarket seafood restaurant in what, in medieval times, was the executioner's house.

Exit Sauna 2, tel: +6442 031. Authentic, high-quality Caucasian food.

Elevant Vene 5, tel: +6313 132 For a quirky take on Indian cuisine, with an eco-friendly dining room painted with egg, cheese and natural pigments and hung with bizarre animal portraits.

5 of the best bars

Kloostri Ait Vene 14, tel: +6446 887 A large airy bar in a former medieval warehouse. A Bohemian crowd, rather than the more usual yuppies. Live music in the evenings, from jazz to Estonian folk.

Kompressor Rataskaevu 3. Light, airy and industrial, with music videos on a large screen.

Karja Kelder (Cattle Cellar) Väike-Karja 1, in the old city, tel: +441 008. A traditional basement beer cellar.

Nimega Baar (Bar With a Name) Süür-Karja 13, in the old city; tel: +6209 299. Smart bar, often with live bands, run by a Scottish football fan who decided to stay on after a match in 1993.

Roosa Klaver Jazz Bar (Pink Piano) Viru 8, tel: +6448 852. Terrible pink decor, but excellent live jazz.

7#149; Frequent ferries cross from Virtsu to Kuivastu on Muhu. Accommodation is available in hotels, farms and the beautiful 16th-century Pädaste Manor (00 372 4548 800) currently under renovation on the coast at Muhu. Cars are cheaper to rent on the island than the mainland. For details, contact the tourist office (+4533 766).

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Sardinia | New England | Chile & Bolivia
fields.body:
Europe

Sardinia : Seven nights' self-catering in August costs from £449 per adult, £429 per child departing Aug 26. Departures for Aug 12 and 19 cost £475 per adult. The holiday, in the resort of Porto Cervo, is based on four sharing a two-bedroom apartment, and the price includes direct flights from Stansted to Olbia. Holiday Options (01444 244411).

Skiathos : Seven nights' self-catering in Troulos in September start from £279pp, based on three adults sharing. Price includes return flights and transfers. Argo Holidays (020-7331 7070).

Black Sea Cruise : Ten days beginning in Piraeus, Greece, and taking in Turkey, Bulgaria and the Ukraine aboard the Aegean Spirit. April 20-30 2001. Price, including all tours, return flights from Gatwick or Manchester and transfers, starts from £1,299 based on two sharing an inside cabin. Voyages of Discovery (01444 462150).

North America

New England: A 14-night fly/drive holiday staying in historic B&Bs in October and taking in the famous fall foliage costs £1,295pp based on two sharing. Stays can be in Boston/Cambridge, Maine, the White and Green Mountains, Rhode Island and Cape Cod. Price includes return flights from Gatwick or Heathrow, B&B accommodation plus fully-inclusive car hire. Bon Voyage (0800 3160194)

South America

Chile & Bolivia : Save £310 for September departures and £220 for July departures on a 14-night journey across the Atacama desert. The trip starts in Santiago, flies north to the fringes of the Atacama and transfers to a 4WD and crosses into Potsoi, Bolivia. Next departure is July 28-August 13. The price of £1,779pp includes return flights from Heathrow, all transport and accommodation, three lunches and two dinners. Travelbag Adventures (01420 541007)

Asia

Pakistan : 19-day trek in the Hindu Kush, departing August 22, costs £1,950pp. Starts in Peshawar, then flies to Chitral, and the trek starts in Shabronz, heading up towards the base camp of Tirich Mir and later crosses the Ovir Pass. Himalayan Kingdoms (0117 9237163)

fields.headline: Bum bags
fields.trailText: Zipped bags on a belt. Extremely practical.
fields.body:
What are they? Zipped bags on a belt. Extremely practical.

Worn back or front? Front for market traders and pedestrians. Back for cyclists, climbers, fell runners and surfers.

Surfers? There's a waterproof one: so your mobile's not nicked off the beach. Made in Australia, that one.

Good for security? Better than a shoulder bag or ordinary pockets. Not as good as a money belt or a neck pouch worn under clothing.

Cheap and garish? Every merchandising range from the Simpsons to Lord's cricket ground has a tacky nylon bum bag for less than a fiver: best worn with white socks, sandals and a loud baseball cap.

But I want something stylish: Driza-bone do one in leather for £90. Lowe, North Face and Berghaus do well-designed models for walkers, runners and cyclists from £10 to £33.

The latest wheeze? Models that open into a light rucksack. Also bum bag first-aid kits and neoprene bum bags for anglers, worn chest-high above the waders.

Points to look for? Wide belt with secure, adjustable fasten ing. Shaped lumbar padding for cycling and running models. Lined interior, so sharp seams edges don't slip under your finger nails. Internal compartments. Zips that work smoothly. Pouches for drinks bottles, if you're going to be working hard.

So why's it called a bum bag? Something to do with where you wear it: the Americans call them fanny packs, if that's any help.

What's the alternative? Bulging pockets, bouncing backpacks, losing things.

fields.headline: Portugal 1 - 0 Romania
fields.trailText:
Portugal Baia, Costa, Vidigal, Couto, Figo, Pinto, Rui Costa, Dimas, Bento, Secretario, Gomes.
Subs: Espinha, Quim, Jorge, Sousa, Sa Pinto, Conceicao, Xavier, Costinha, Beto, Capucho, Pauleta.
fields.body:
Portugal Baia, Costa, Vidigal, Couto, Figo, Pinto, Rui Costa, Dimas, Bento, Secretario, Gomes.
Subs: Espinha, Quim, Jorge, Sousa, Sa Pinto, Conceicao, Xavier, Costinha, Beto, Capucho, Pauleta.

Romania Stelea, Petrescu, Filipescu, Galca, Popescu, Munteanu, Moldovan, Hagi, Ilie, Chivu, Contra.
Subs: Lobont, Prunea, Ciobotariu, Mutu, Petre, Lupescu, Rosu, Belodedici, Ganea, Hildan, Lincar.

Referee Gilles Veissiere (France)

1 min It's the time of truth - are Portugal really that good? For the sake of England's pride let's hope they take Arnhem by storm. They kick off and knock it about - eventually Constantin Galca brings down Rui Costa. That's put a stop to that.

2 Nuno Gomes latches onto a Luis Figo through ball - he's onside but because he's so far ahead of the last man the flag goes up. A bad, bad decision. Portugal deserved a goal.

5 Figo feeds Gomes down the right - he cuts inside into a bit of space but drags his shot across the front of the goal. Romania aren't exactly rocking, but they're giving the Portuguese far too much space. Ring any bells?

7 Carlos Secretario wins a corner for Portugal. Romania hack it away but the Portuguese just keep coming back. The ball is knocked around for a period until Figo wins another corner. The ball is worked into the box - another bad clearance falls to Rui Costa who sends a soft volley wide.

10 Dorinel Munteanu wins a corner for Romania. It comes to nothing but it's the first bit of pressure from the men in yellow.

12 Gheorghe Hagi swings a high free-kick into the Portuguese box - if Ilie was on his toes there could have been a chance to nick the ball over the advancing Vitor Baia, but the Porto keeper is allowed to claim easily.

15 Christian Chivu lobs in a cross from the left, which Baia drops. Romania don't have a man on hand to take advantage, but that won't do the keeper's confidence any good.

16 Good news for England. Hagi clatters into Joao Pinto and is booked - it's his second caution of the tournament and he won't face Keegan's men in Charleroi on Tuesday.

22 Dan Petrescu is totally diddled by Rui Costa on the edge of the box. You can't say the Chelsea man hasn't learnt from his time in England, though - he hacks the skilful midfielder down. Booked.

25 Secretario flips Viorel Moldovan up into the air. From the free-kick on the left, Ilie curls in a wonderful ball which is heading for the top-right corner of the net - it's tipped away brilliantly by Baia.

26 From the corner, the Portuguese keeper reverts to type. He drops the ball into a crowd of players and is fortunate to see the ball scrambled away by sharp red shirts and missed by extremely blunt yellow ones.

27 Cosmin Contra is booked for weakly dragging back Figo

30 who is in turn booked for softly knocking Moldovan over. My, my, the referee is conscientious.

35 This is turning into a dour midfield battle, albeit with some tricky little cameos.

40 This is now a dour midfield battle with no tricky little cameos.

42 Hagi tries one from nearly forty yards out on the right touchline. No, it didn't go in.

45 Into injury time in the first half. Mr Referee, blow your whistle please.

45 Thank you.

HALF TIME: Portugal 0 - 0 Romania

46 The Romanians restart the game.

46 Popescu lifts a high ball towards the Portuguese goal. There's nobody but Baia under it so it should be claimed easily the ball rolls through his comedy arms, down his amusing torso and along his hilarious legs onto the floor, where it gently rolls, awaiting attention. Luckily for the keeper, who as you may guess isn't playing very well, one of his team-mates is now in close proximity and can clear.

48 Dimas wallops the ball into the stand behind the Romanian goal. The first real Portuguese shot in anger.

50 Jorge Costa fouls Moldovan out on the right wing. Hagi combines with Munteanu and whips a ball in - it's deflected and it's a corner. From it, Hagi finds Moldovan who powers in a header which is deflected past Baia's left-hand post by Jorge Costa. Nearly the opener.

55 Two changes for Portugal. Sa Pinto and Sergio Conceicao replace Gomes and Joao Pinto respectively.

61 Hagi finds room enough to wallop a half-decent cross into the Portuguese box from the left wing. In the context of this match, that's extremely creative. Unsurprisingly, there's no-one there to take advantage of it. This looks 0-0 all the way.

63 Sa Pinto stands on the ball. Romania sweep the ball away, taking it upfield and find Petrescu out on the right - he whacks in a cross which is a bit too strong for Moldovan and Ilie but, ghosting in at the back is Hagi who swings a glory boot at the ball. The volley is well high and wide - a shame, because it would have been a beautiful goal.

64 Florentin Petre replaces Petrescu.

69 Ioan Ganea comes on for Moldovan. Thank god for substitutions, because otherwise there'd be nothing going on.

70 Fernando Couto chips in a ball for Sa Pinto, who is standing on the six-yard box. The Real Sociedad striker's header is straight at Bogdan Stelea, though. Still, something's better than nothing.

72 Portugal have a shout for a penalty - Contra clatters into Sa Pinto, who is chasing after a cross from Conceicao. No dice. But Portugal look like they're belatedly coming to life.

78 Hold on to your hats it's another substitution! Ilie goes off for Laurentiu Rosu. Woo!

80 The game's opening up a bit, but that only goes to show how badly both teams are playing. Sa Pinto is free down the right, but his ball finds Romanian feet. Munteanu and Hagi work some space down the left, but Hagi's cross is easily cleared.

86 Hagi takes another long-distance shot - it's much better than his first-half attempt and Baia is forced to tip it over.

87 Rui Costa is replaced by Francisco Costa.

89 There'll be four extra minutes, which will seem like forty-four.

90 GOAL Portugal 1 - 0 Romania With all four minutes up, Luis Figo sends in a free kick. For some reason, the Romanian defence go AWOL - Francisco Costa ghosts in ahead of the flapping Stelea and heads into an empty net. What a finish - shame about the game.

FULL TIME: Portugal 1 - 0 Romania
