fields.headline: Cup fever
fields.standfirst: Three months after its America's Cup triumph,  Matthew Brace finds that one of the hippest cities on the Pacific rim is still in the mood to party
fields.trailText: Three months after its America's Cup triumph, Matthew Brace finds that one of the hippest cities on the Pacific rim is still in the mood to party
fields.body:
An odd sense of loss pervaded Auckland. The champagne corks and bunting from New Zealand's victory in March in yachting's greatest prize, the America's Cup, were memories.

As if blinking its way through the hazy hangover of a good birthday party, Auckland seemed to be having a hard time coming down from its sporting high.

Everyone still talks about it. Wasn't it exciting? Wasn't Team New Zealand (the winning crew) bloody great? Then their minds wander and they gaze dreamily over the fine, wide harbour of this sea-faring city and sigh as if the two-year wait for the next challenge is a lifetime away. The winners always play host.

Important as the win was for sailing-mad Auckland, it was just one brief chapter in an illustrious career of ocean taming. The Maritime Museum on the harbour front is a must for visitors, even those who couldn't give a fig for jibs and mainsails, as it explains why the Kiwis are such proficient sailors.

Everyone sailed here. The Maoris in vast canoes that rode the currents with the stars and gods for guidance, then Captain Cook who discovered it for the western world on his first Pacific voyage. After him came countless European settlers.

In the last century, ocean liners run by the NZ Union Steam Ship Company must have had the whole town gawping as they cruised stylishly in from trans-Pacific voyages.Now Auckland has joined the hip generation. Who needs to wait two years for the next party?

Cafés

The America's Cup spotlight also picked out a new side to Auckland, a burgeoning café culture to challenge its Pacific rivals, Sydney and Seattle. Scores of coffee bars, bistros and restaurants have opened in the past few years as part of a rejuvenation that has transformed the city into one of the hippest around the Pacific Rim.

Yuppies in expensive knitwear brunch at Gloria under high ceilings and minimalist decor. Families stroll down to Mecca on the harbour for big breakfasts and fruit juice. A supper of bangers and mash and Black Mac dark ale at Deve Brasserie in Kingsland is great value.

In a city where most cafés try so hard to be cool, K Sera manages it with seemingly no effort at all. For insomniacs, clubbers and frustrated poets, Brazil stays open late into the night. The music is funky, the coffee strong and magnificent.

A string of restaurants have replaced the fish- gutting warehouses along the harbour front. It seems over the top for a city with only one million people, but come the weekend they are packed to the gunwales. Euro is especially welcoming and has good venison sausages.

Across the harbour in the suburb of Devonport, more like the English Riviera than the outskirts of Polynesia, the cafés along Victoria Road also hum at the weekend and are worth the 10-minute ferry trip for lunch.

Kawhia

As you drive south from Auckland in comfort, spare a thought for the Maoris, who in the Great Migration around 1350 landed here in the famed Tainui canoe.

Before leaving their homeland in the eastern Pacific, their priests had prophesied that good fortune would be theirs should they land on the western side of New Zealand. Unfortunately, they landed on the east, so they dragged their canoe over what are now called the Bombay Hills, inch by inch, then all the way down to the South Island and north again until they hit the west coast near Kawhia.

Kawhia today plays second fiddle to nearby Raglan, a surf paradise, with some of the best waves on the North Island, notably at Whale Beach, and excellent fish and chips. The picturesque coastline is lined with tree ferns.

On the road from Auckland, look out for signs to Bridal Veil Falls, a glorious 150ft waterfall that thunders with deafening force after a good rainfall.

Rotorua

Rotorua is not like other towns. Jets of steam blow from pavement drains, and clouds billow from beneath the grass in Kurau Park. Sulphur fumes make the place smell like a steelworks but, oddly, the pong grows on you after a day or two.

It is the powerful scent of inner earth, and Rotorua is one of the most active geothermal sites in the world. There are more than 100 tiny earthquakes a day, and all over town the ground has split open to belch boiling water and sulphurous mud.

For a spell last year, residents woke to find that natural hot springs had formed overnight in their back gardens, saving them a fortune in hot-tub installation but also threatening to consume their homes. The Pohutu geyser on the edge of town set a new record for blowing for more than 80 days without pause.

Coromandel

The lush greenery of the Coromandel peninsula is startling. Forget Ireland; these emerald fields shine much brighter. Coromandel is nature gone mad with a paintbrush, so brilliant it looks unreal.

The peninsula has good walking and cycling trails with cabins and bed-and-breakfasts in the main centres of Thames, Mercury Bay and Coromandel Town.

Hot Water Beach on the east coast is famous for hot springs beneath the sand, while the stunning Cathedral Cove boasts a natural rock arch and a stretch of salmon-pink sand.

In a city where most cafés try so hard to be cool, K Sera manages it with seemingly no effort at all. For insomniacs, clubbers and frustrated poets, Brazil stays open late into the night. The music is funky, the coffee strong and magnificent. A string of restaurants have replaced the fish- gutting warehouses along the harbour front. It seems over the top for a city with only one million people, but come the weekend they are packed to the gunwales. Euro is especially welcoming and has good venison sausages. Across the harbour in the suburb of Devonport, more like the English Riviera than the outskirts of Polynesia, the cafés along Victoria Road also hum at the weekend and are worth the 10-minute ferry trip for lunch. Kawhia As you drive south from Auckland in comfort, spare a thought for the Maoris, who in the Great Migration around 1350 landed here in the famed Tainui canoe. Before leaving their homeland in the eastern Pacific, their priests had prophesied that good fortune would be theirs should they land on the western side of New Zealand. Unfortunately, they landed on the east, so they dragged their canoe over what are now called the Bombay Hills, inch by inch, then all the way down to the South Island and north again until they hit the west coast near Kawhia. Kawhia today plays second fiddle to nearby Raglan, a surf paradise, with some of the best waves on the North Island, notably at Whale Beach, and excellent fish and chips. The picturesque coastline is lined with tree ferns. On the road from Auckland, look out for signs to Bridal Veil Falls, a glorious 150ft waterfall that thunders with deafening force after a good rainfall. Rotorua Rotorua is not like other towns. Jets of steam blow from pavement drains, and clouds billow from beneath the grass in Kurau Park. Sulphur fumes make the place smell like a steelworks but, oddly, the pong grows on you after a day or two. It is the powerful scent of inner earth, and Rotorua is one of the most active geothermal sites in the world. There are more than 100 tiny earthquakes a day, and all over town the ground has split open to belch boiling water and sulphurous mud. For a spell last year, residents woke to find that natural hot springs had formed overnight in their back gardens, saving them a fortune in hot-tub installation but also threatening to consume their homes. The Pohutu geyser on the edge of town set a new record for blowing for more than 80 days without pause. Coromandel The lush greenery of the Coromandel peninsula is startling. Forget Ireland; these emerald fields shine much brighter. Coromandel is nature gone mad with a paintbrush, so brilliant it looks unreal. The peninsula has good walking and cycling trails with cabins and bed-and-breakfasts in the main centres of Thames, Mercury Bay and Coromandel Town. Hot Water Beach on the east coast is famous for hot springs beneath the sand, while the stunning Cathedral Cove boasts a natural rock arch and a stretch of salmon-pink sand.

fields.trailText:
Address: Llandudno, North Wales LL30 1RS
Tel: 01492 584466
Web address: www.bodysgallen.com
fields.body:
Address: Llandudno, North Wales LL30 1RS
Tel: 01492 584466
Web address: www.bodysgallen.com

First impressions: Halfway up a mountain, a 17th-century oak-panelled mansion staffed by doormen who bow a lot.

What are the rooms like? Jump on the bed and you can swing from the rafters.

The bathroom test: Crabtree and Evelyn meets Laura Ashley.

The restaurant: Terrific food, chandeliers and more cutlery than Buckingham palace. Three courses for £33.90.

The lounge: Hide in a window seat and read Tolstoy from the bookcase. Total peace.

Other facilities: Health spa, pool, gym, beauty salon, tennis courts, croquet lawn.

What is there to see within walking distance? 220 acres of private woodland paths.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? Three golf courses, the sea, Conwy Castle.

How much a night? Single £109, four poster £235.

Would you go back? When I'm 64.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.standfirst: Pier of the realm
fields.trailText: Pier of the realm | Northern eye | Cove life
fields.body:
Pier of the realm
Century-old Cromer Pier is Pier of the Year 2000. Seaside Special, the last surviving seaside show, opens today at the pier-end theatre.

 Open daily. Free. (01263 513811, box office: 01263 512495).

Northern eye
A 100ft big wheel joins the thrills at Pleasureland, rotating at 2.5 revolutions per minute, faster than the London Eye.

 Opens 11am, closing times vary. Free entry, Big Wheel £2. Marine Drive, Southport, Merseyside (01704 532717).

Cove life
Study the local history, wildlife, flora, geology and fossils at Lulworth Cove Heritage Centre before embarking on a spectacular coastal walk.

 Open daily, 10am-6pm. Free. West Lulworth, Wareham, Dorset (01929 400587).

Cycling circular
A new 75-mile circular cycle route through the heart of Suffolk also caters for people who just want to dip into the route.

 Information booklet with maps £2.50 inc p&p from Heart of Suffolk, Orchard House, Hawk End Lane, Elmswell, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk IP30 9ED or from local tourist-information centres.

Out to grass
HorseWorld is one of Britain's largest equine rescue sanctuaries, complete with audio-visual theatre and heritage museum.

 Open daily 10am-6pm. £3.50/£2, family £10. Staunton Lane, Whitchurch, near Bristol (01275 540173).

Stump up
A behind-the-scenes tour of Lord's Cricket Ground follows in the footsteps of the stars, from WG Grace to Ian Botham.

 Tours at 10am/noon/2pm on non-match days. £6/£4.40, family £18. Grace Gate, St John's Wood Rd, London NW8 (020-7432 1033).

Green peace
Children love the hands-on microscopes in the Exhibition Hall, adults go for the art in Inverleith House, all within 70 acres of lawns, gardens, water features and trees.

 Open daily 9.30am-7pm. Free. Royal Botanic Garden, Inverleith Row, Edinburgh (0131-552 7171).

Downsizing
The Dolls' House Emporium in Ripley sells 1:12 scale houses and miniatures.

 Open daily, 10am-5pm. Free. High Holborn Road, Codnor Gate Business Park, Ripley, Derbyshire (01773-514400).

Off the wall
Segedunum, a new £9m attraction at the eastern end of Hadrian's Wall, includes a replica of a working Roman bath house and interactive displays of everyday life 2,000 years ago.

 Free. Buddle Street, Wallsend, near Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-200 7098/7096).

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Fellow readers offer you the benefit of their experience
fields.body:
Patrick Baughan asked if he would have to know any Spanish if he was spending some time in Buenos Aires before going on to Uruguay.

I have been living in Buenos Aires for two years and have travelled extensively around Argentina and Uruguay. You can get by with English in Montevideo, Buenos Aires and the main tourist spots. As in most major cities, you will always find someone who speaks English in hotels, restaurants and tourist services.

Those who speak English in Argentina and Uruguay often speak it very well, partly because of the British influence in their history (building the railway system, trading) and the bi-lingual school system they established, which is still held in esteem in the higher strata of society. But don't rely on being able to launch into English with taxi drivers, bus drivers, shop workers etc.
Meredith Sweeney

Having travelled to both countries, I would say that a Spanish course is definitely recommended. English is spoken in Buenos Aires and, to a lesser extent, in Montevideo, but in the more rural areas, it is unheard.

As a Spanish speaker, I found my time all the more rewarding because I could speak to anyone I met.
Nicola Pemberton

Berlitz produces a new easy course for learning Spanish called Rush Hour. It's a two-hour tape that will help you get by.
Julia Spence

I would suggest that Patrick Baughan doesn't bother learning Spanish before he travels to Buenos Aires. I would question whether he needs a week there. It's a very European city in style, with great food, gorgeous-looking women and friendly people, but we had done the major tourist attractions in three days and spun it out by a trip to Uruguay.
Dick and Clare Donovan

This week's question

I detest flying, or thinking about it and have not boarded a plane for five years. Has anyone got any unbiased/advice or experience to relate on how they conquered their aversion. I want to go to the Caribbean.
Jennifer Stuart

 If you have questions or advice, please send it to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com. We will publish the answers as soon as we can. We cannot answer questions we do not publish .

fields.headline: The day the earth boiled
fields.standfirst: Chasing volcanoes is a risky business as some tourists discovered at Mount Etna last week. But the thrill of watching the earth move is a powerful draw.  Polly Pattullo  goes to  the edge of the Boiling Lake
fields.trailText: Chasing volcanoes is a risky business as some tourists discovered at Mount Etna last week. But the thrill of watching the earth move is a powerful draw. Polly Pattullo goes to the edge of the Boiling Lake
fields.body:
When Henry Nicholls, a British-born doctor and agriculturalist, claimed to have "discovered" Dominica's Boiling Lake in 1875, he recounted his exploits in the Illustrated London News as if he had just returned from a major imperial expedition to the head of the Nile. The local newspaper made fun of him - for while he was the first person to write an account of his adventure, hunters and map-makers had, of course, long known about this boiling volcanic cauldron in the heart of Dominica's stupendous rainforest wilderness.

Even so, those who these days make the trek to the Boiling Lake might sympathise just a jot with the old colonial's vanity. For to go there -and return - is to feel excitement and a hint of anxiety (before), exhaustion and amazement (during) and exhilaration and more exhaustion (after). So what is it that makes it the stuff of legends (with its own "I survived" site on the internet)?

The world's second largest boiling lake (New Zealand has the largest), its surface churnings hint at an unstable, shuddering earth below. For Dominica, along with many of its eastern Caribbean neighbours, is volcanic. Such a geology gives the island rippling mountain ranges, deep fertile valleys dense with a dazzling greenness, and water galore - streaming from rivers that plunge down waterfalls or ripple contentedly like a Scottish trout stream.

You can know the island backwards but never know it all. The green-blanketed interior invokes an African heartland rather than an island a good deal smaller than the Isle of Wight. Hidden within these forests are sulphur springs, patches of boiling mud, fumeroles, multi-coloured streams, crater lakes, underwater hot springs and, of course, the Boiling Lake itself, deep inside the Morne Trois Pitons National Park, now a Unesco world heritage site.

There are ambitious plans for a great long-distance hiking trail - a tropical challenge to, say, the Pennine Way. But for now, the Boiling Lake is the island's ultimate trial of strength. The one route to the Lake starts from the ridge-top village of Laudat, embalmed in sweet cooling breezes. Leave behind until your return the hot and cold delights of Titou Gorge, a sort of base camp, with its own residents, the eccentric Dr Fix-It and Sulphur, the hiking cat. And set out into the rainforest glades that are the glory of Dominica - tree ferns glittering in sun or rain, the straight-as-an-arrow trunks of the gommier, and chataigners with giant buttresses. Through the green are glimpses of the gaudy yellow-red bracts of the heliconia plant. And yet this is only "secondary" forest - a mere 20 years old, born after Hurricane David blasted its way through the island in 1979 turning green to brown hours.

But Dominica replenishes itself fast, back to a familiar tangled, green warm-wet blanket. As Hagan Dorivea, our conscientious guide, explained, the fertility of the soil, the rain, the heat means that Dominica is a place where "one stop and you grow". So no stopping for the first hour or so until a drink from the waters of the Breakfast River. And then toiling up and up again on to the narrow ridge of Morne Nicholls. Here, the forest gives way to tough, wind-battered vegetation where the cloud cover sweeps down without warning, obliterating a view that stretches back to Laudat and down to the sea and the little coastal capital, Roseau. Then the clouds dissolved and way in front of us, but beyond one more ridge or perhaps even two, was a glimpse not of the lake itself but of steam bursting from within its green-encircled crater.

But before you reach the Lake, you must cross the macabre Valley of Desolation. After a punishingly-steep descent, we reached a flat, bleak basin, stripped of vegetation except for mosses and ferns and surrounded by brown scree. Yet the valley seemed alive: with a whooshing sound from clouds of sulphur that rise from fumeroles; streams come and go, rocks are the colour of stained-glass windows, bubbling waters emerge inky-black or dribble milk, or flow primrose-yellow from sulphur, or orange from iron.

By then, there was a sense of urgency to push on to the Lake itself. Another hour perhaps and then, in a final burst of energy, we reached the cliffs that edge the crater and peered through the sulphurous steam that swirls off its surface. That day, sitting above the steaming crater, I could see that its muddy, milk-white waters were calm at the edges and boiling turbulently at its centre. "Seething like a huge cauldron, so utterly unlike anything I had ever seen in nature," wrote a British visitor in 1900.

Indeed, that is how it has seemed to me the three times that I have made it to the Lake. But not always: it can be pale-green and glassy; or grey and stormy, and despite its "boiling" reputation (people have been seriously burned by its waters and two at least killed by poisonous fumes), a friend of mine, amazingly, once swam in it - on a day when the water had been tepid, almost cold.

But there there was little time for contemplation at the Lake before starting out on the return hike. This included an idyllic rest-stop, a bathe in a tiny, milky, wayside pool with its own warm waterfall. Then the ascents and descents, but by then the narrow green ridges were filled with afternoon sunlight and the peaks on either side rose up like a child's spiky drawing. And eventually (six to seven hours is an average time for the trek), we were back at Titou Gorge, greeted by teenagers having fun jumping into the calm waters of its mouth. Sulphur the cat was still waiting for company or food and there was the self-styled Dr Fix-It tending his vegetable garden. A local farmer locked in some impenetrable battle over land ownership, he is a man of many moods - sometimes angry, sometimes placid. Not unlike the Boiling Lake itself.

Other volcanic hot spots in the eastern Caribbean

This "necklace" of islands lies at the point of convergence of two tectonic plates. There are at least 17 live volcanoes - of which 10 are on Dominica - stretching from Saba, in the north, to Kick 'Em Jenny, the submerged volcano near Grenada, in the south. The first recorded volcanic event in the Caribbean occurred in St Kitts in 1692.

Some of the most intriguing volcanoes in the eastern Caribbean include:

Martinique: The worst catastrophe in the Caribbean's volcano history was in May 1902, when Mont Pelée erupted and some 40,000 people were killed in the coastal town of St Pierre, known as the Paris of the Antilles. The town has been rebuilt, although the ruins of the theatre remain. Visit the fascinating museum about the volcano, and hike to the summit of the now tranquil Pelée itself. Information on Martinique from the French Tourist Office (0906 8244123).

Montserrat: Since July 1995, the Soufriere Hills volcano has been active for the first time in recorded history. Roughly two-thirds of the island remains in the "exclusion zone", although day-time visits can sometimes be made to the abandoned outskirts of the capital, Plymouth, for an awesome view (when the clouds lift) of the volcano dome and the route of the pyroclastic flows that poured into Plymouth in 1997.

On the other side of the island, from a viewing point at Jack Boy Hill, look down to the abandoned airport where flows reached the southern edge of the runway. From there, you can also see the route down Mosquito Ghaut, where the lava killed 19 people in June 1997 after burying several communities. Visitors are welcome at the Montserrat Volcano Observatory (telephone in advance). Montserrat Tourist Board: 020-7242 3131.

St Lucia: The famous Pitons, twin volcanic peaks, south of the village of Soufriere (named after the French word for sulphur) are the most dramatic examples of St Lucia's volcanic past. Nearby is a somewhat over-rated "drive-in volcano", where visitors admire steaming sulphur springs. St Lucia Tourist Board: 020-7431 3675.

St Vincent: The Soufriere volcano erupted twice in the 20th century - in 1902 when 1,500 people were killed and in 1979. Start the hike from the north-east corner of the island, at the Rabacca Dry River. It's about a two-hour hike to the 700ft deep crater, one mile across. The last part involves crunching over the bare upper slopes of rock and ash. Take a guide. No nearby accommodation - the nearest is in the capital, Kingstown. St Vincent and the Grenadines Tourist Board: 020-7937 6570.

Guadeloupe: In 1976, an increase in activity at the La Soufriere volcano on Basse Terre prompted a temporary evacuation of 70,000 people. Photographs and information about that mini-crisis can be seen at Maison du Volcan, on the flanks of the volcano. Then take the trail for a two-hour there-and-back hike to the summit. Best to go on a clear day. Scientific monitoring continues. Contact the French Tourist Office (0906 8244123).

St Vincent and the Grenadines Tourist Board: 020-7937 6570. Guadeloupe: In 1976, an increase in activity at the La Soufriere volcano on Basse Terre prompted a temporary evacuation of 70,000 people. Photographs and information about that mini-crisis can be seen at Maison du Volcan, on the flanks of the volcano. Then take the trail for a two-hour there-and-back hike to the summit. Best to go on a clear day. Scientific monitoring continues. Contact the French Tourist Office (0906 8244123).

fields.headline: Room service
fields.standfirst: www.laterooms.com
fields.trailText: www.laterooms.com
fields.body:
Cheap rooms, or just late rooms?
Let's say that the three- and four-star rooms can be relatively cheap - but not many are going to cost less than £30, unless they're in France.

Give me some examples.
A double at the three-star Birmingham Grand Moat is down from £158 to £35 - just a couple of roundabouts away from the legendary Bull Ring.

Not bad. Is there a catch?
Sometimes breakfast or supper is a compulsory extra, and the site has no maps. Drivers will find full directions, but train travellers usually won't. On the other hand, you have to call the hotel to book, so that shouldn't prove a problem.

It also means I could haggle for a lower price.
Yes - and some of the hotels encourage callers to do so. Laterooms often has links to the hotel's own website. It's a good starting-point for those who are unhappy with the idea of booking online. Bear in mind, though, that some of the money you save on a New York hotel room will be eaten up by call charges, and there is often no guarantee that the French hoteliers speak fluent English.

Any other caveats?
Apart from some atrocious spelling and a touch of glibness (what makes the Wolverhampton Best Western a "hidden gem"?), this is an impressive attempt to break the mould of other travel sites and allow travellers a little more autonomy. Even the smug little badge on every page is a mildly appealing touch.

webTitle: A Traveller's Guide to D-Day and the Battle for Normandy

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: A Traveller's Guide to D-Day and the Battle for Normandy, by Carl Shilleto and Mike Tolhurst  (The Windrush Press, £9.99)
fields.trailText: A Traveller's Guide to D-Day and the Battle for Normandy, by Carl Shilleto and Mike Tolhurst
fields.body:
Imagine! A French party, enjoying a picnic in Normandy, forced to borrow a corkscrew from an English tourist.

They didn't know I was English, of course - until I spoke. But before long, the wine was fuelling a multi-lingual discussion about the Battle for Normandy.

One old lady remembered the invasion. Her father survived, she told me tearfully, but the horror had driven him insane. I was reminded that, for countless thousands of her generation, Normandy will never be about cheese and gtes. And I was painfully aware of my own ignorance.

No excuses now, though. Then-and-now photos and a wealth of practical information make this an ideal compact guide to take along for the ride. But one unusual feature - the inclusion of dozens of eye-witness accounts - sets it apart from similar books.

They serve as more than text-breakers. They are powerful reminders that here was no picnic.

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Chain link | Branson's palace | Eastern appeal
fields.body:
Chain link
Next Wednesday sees the official opening of the first 5,000 miles of the National Cycle Network. Rides from the UK's four capitals will converge in Birmingham. The aim is to have 10,000 miles of routes by 2005.

Branson's palace
Virgin, which last week launched the first scheduled non-stop flights between London and Las Vegas, is negotiating to build a hotel on the edge of the gambling town's airport, only a block away from the strip. Planes from London would be able to park directly beside the hotel, and passengers would step out into it without time-consuming transfers.

Eastern appeal
The Caribbean has lost out to the Far East recently in the list of most popular long-haul destinations, according to American Express offices in the UK. St Lucia has lost its top 10 placing to Thailand. The list (with last year's placing in brackets):

1 California (2)

2 New York (3)

3 Florida (4)

4 Australia (1)

5 Thailand (-)

6 Barbados (5)

7 Canada (7)

8 Hong Kong (9)

9 South Africa (10)

10 Singapore (7).

Veggie Paris
A pocket guide to meat-free Paris has been published by Travelscene (0870 777 4445) listing bistros, museum and gallery cafés and shops where the vegetarian can be happy.

Tourist billions
Britain's tourism industry is now worth £63 billion a year, according to latest figures from the British Tourist Authority. There were 25.7 million foreign visitors to the country last year who spent £12.6bn, with £3bn going to UK carriers. UK residents spent more than £14bn on staying visits within their own country. Day-visit spending in the UK added £31bn. The authority claims that Britain is fifth in the international tourism league, behind the US, Italy, Spain and France.

Pets abroad
It had to happen. Now that pets can travel to Europe, the AA has introduced Five Star Pet Travel Insurance. The cost is £9 for eight days or £15 for more than three weeks. Details: 0800 444 500.

Cats at home
If you don't trust the neighbours to feed the cat when you are away, Cat Calls will do it for you if you live in south London. They can also put you in touch with other cat-sitters in other parts of London and beyond. Details on 020-8761 7907, www.catcalls.co.uk

fields.headline: Heaven on the rocks
fields.standfirst: The spirit of Saint Patrick and the sparkle of the quartzite make the Maumturk Mountains in Connemara a magical place to escape to, says  Mike Harding
fields.trailText: The spirit of Saint Patrick and the sparkle of the quartzite make the Maumturk Mountains in Connemara a magical place to escape to, says Mike Harding
fields.body:
Beneath the southern flank of the Maumturk Mountains in Connemara stands a tiny church that is said to mark the westernmost point of the journeys of St Patrick in the 5th century. He spent the night there before turning back, and a well of holy water sprang up.

The place is called Maam Ean, and Mike Harding's favourite walk takes him there up a mile-long path from the road through the Inagh valley. "The whole area is imbued with a magical feel, and the water from the well tastes absolutely gorgeous," he says. "There's also a wonderful statue of St Patrick, a modern statue that I like a lot. It makes him look almost like a warrior, leaning on his staff and looking out to the west, and there's a little sheep to the side of him."

Harding - a musician, broadcaster, author and dedicated walker - then tackles the sterner part of the day: a 1,100ft scramble up the hillside, across the pale outcrops of quartzite that make these mountains look as if they're always covered with frost. This brings him to the 2,100ft summit of Binn Chaonaigh with its little lake and splendid views eastward into Glean Fada, a six-mile valley so isolated that people would once walk across the Maumturks by moonlight just to get a game of cards.

Six or eight miles due north, you can see a mountain called Devilsmother on the map, but Harding was told by a local that the correct translation from the Irish "Magairli an Deamhain" is "devil's testicles". He checked it in the dictionary - "but you couldn't very well put that on a map, could you?"

His route then goes north-eastwards along the ridge, staying above 2,000ft and moving from summit to summit with wide and exhilarating views. To the west stand another cluster of glittering quartzite mountains, the Twelve Bens of Connemara, and beyond them the wild Atlantic.

In two miles, this brings you to Binn Idir an Dha Log (Mountain between Two Loughs), the highest point of the Maumturks at 2,300ft. Then comes a steep descent to a saddle and another small lake - an ideal place for lunch, and the highlight of the walk for Harding.

"The view of that little lough, and the peace when you sit there, and the views down into Glean Fada - it's like being in another world. The beauty of walking in this area is that it's unspoilt, and hardly anybody gets to it."

From the lough, you can drop steeply back to your starting point in the Inagh valley, or climb to the crest again and continue to a second holy well at the northern end of the range. This would be a complete circuit of the Maumturks, a strenuous 14-mile day.

"It's a great summer walk, and the last time I did it was on a beautiful cloudless day. But you've got some height and there's a prevailing westerly wind there, so you've got to have proper hill gear - it's not a T-shirt and shorts job. And it's tough country."

His preference is to walk alone, or with one or two close friends, and to talk very little. "I find there's so much to see and so much to feel that conversation can get in the way. And it's amazing how quiet it makes people - even my little niece, who's always talking.

"For me, it's completely spiritual. I try not to think about problems or anything, but just go, and be there, you know? It's hard to explain, but I just put my mind into idle and just let it be. And the landscape here is probably more spiritual than anywhere else in Europe."

A walk on the wildest side of Ireland

Connemara is possibly the wildest and most isolated part of Ireland, with more than 50 mountains in four tightly-packed ranges: the Maumturks, the Twelve Bens, the Partry and the Sheffrey. It offers tough walking, with few paths and difficult navigation.

"The mountains have a unique look because they're very bold-shaped, steep-sided and almost barren," says Jim McDonald, who runs the walking company Irish Ways. "And because of the quartzite rocks, they sparkle, especially after rain.

"They're not that high - the highest point is only 2,600ft - but they rise out of the flat, dark bogland, which makes them look twice the size. They feel high when you're climbing them, too, because it's broken country and there's little to help the walker."

Connemara is roughly translated as "the people from the sea". "It's wetter than most places, and it's windy, and life is harsh, and that's reflected in the culture. Life is very physical, and people work hard, drink hard and play hard," says McDonald.

Connemara music is also distinctive, and Mike Harding recommends Newman's music pub in Cleggan, near his holiday cottage. "Connemara fiddlers have shorter bow strokes, more aggressive, and the singing is an amazing sound - it doesn't relate to anything in Europe, it's more like North African."

fields.headline: Home from home
fields.standfirst: Whilst house swapping can be an admirably cheap solution for travellers, it is rarely easy. Ros Taylor takes to the net to find ways of making it less painful.
fields.trailText: Whilst house swapping can be an admirably cheap solution for travellers, it is rarely easy. Ros Taylor takes to the net to find ways of making it less painful.
fields.body:
If you don't object to someone you've never met staying in your home, house swaps are a very cheap way of travelling, particularly to areas where accommodation costs are high. The trick is to persuade an email correspondent - who typically inhabits a San Francisco condo or a skiing lodge in Whistler, Canada - that your property is both "cosy" (nearly all British properties fall into this category) and located near a recognisable town or city. A joining fee is almost inevitable, so choose the site carefully.

HomeLink International
Costing from £12 a year for UK-only exchange listings to £89 for an international entry, HomeLink nonetheless attracts 12,000 members and has been established for nearly 50 years. The clientele is "professional" and visitors can browse the listings before joining. Standards are high.

Holi-Swaps
Plenty of the exchangers here want to stay in Britain, so the prospects of finding a suitable swap are high. Listings can be free, subject to a few limitations; full entries cost £36.

International Home Exchange
A dour but efficient site, established since 1993. Once listed ($30), anyone can contact you to arrange a swap - not just other members.

Green Theme International
A Cornwall-based enterprise, GTI has substantial listings, ill-thought-out web pages and some useful advice.

Latitudes Home Exchange
The range of properties here is wide, but the search facility is very patchy. The fee is $50 and "custom" matchmaking costs substantially more.

Seniors Home Exchange
An American-based service, costing $50 to join, which is available only to over-50s.

webTitle: It's 1984: a nightmare vision of the past

fields.headline: It's 1984: a nightmare vision of the past
fields.trailText: In the first Test of the summer, England turned the clock back 40 years, to the halcyon days when they used to demolish hapless part-timers. In the first real test of the summer, they have turned the clock back 15 years, to the dark days when having a good game against the West Indies meant avoiding an innings defeat.
fields.body:
In the first Test of the summer, England turned the clock back 40 years, to the halcyon days when they used to demolish hapless part-timers. In the first real test of the summer, they have turned the clock back 15 years, to the dark days when having a good game against the West Indies meant avoiding an innings defeat.

At 12.30 on Friday, this game was almost evenly balanced. West Indies were 136 for 4, Darren Gough was on fire and England were only a nick away from exposing a long tail. Or so it seemed. That was the moment when Jimmy Adams came in and showed a grit far beyond any other batsman in the match. By the time he was out, 24 bloodyminded hours later, the game was a horrible mismatch. The last four West Indian wickets added 160 ­ 24 more than the first four. It was hard to say who were more embarrassed, England's bowlers or her bookmakers.

This will be written up tomorrow, or edited up, as yet another England disaster, but it would be more accurate as well as kinder to call it a triumph for the West Indies. Every one of their senior players delivered the goods. First Curtly and Courtney, who have played only three fewer Tests in England than Gough and Caddick, gave a masterclass in the art (once regarded as an English one) of fast-medium seam bowling. Then all four of West Indies' experienced batsmen reached 50. England's old hands reached 50 too ­ 59, between the five of them, on Thursday. Today they managed 35.

England needn't despair, or even panic. They were rolled over here in 1995 and bounced back to win the next Test. In fact, 1996 (when England beat India) is the only time in recent years that the winners at Edgbaston have gone on to win the series. At this stage the patient needs only minor surgery. Ed Giddins was so insipid here that he is now behind at least four others in the pecking order: Dominic Cork, Mark Ealham, Angus Fraser, and Alex Tudor.

Nick Knight and Graeme Hick could reasonably be replaced by Graham Thorpe and Michael Vaughan. Knight top-scored in both innings, but that was saying little except to confirm that he has a good fighting temperament (so does Thorpe). Hick was given out wrongly today, but how long would he have lasted if he hadn't been?

The trickiest decision concerns Andrew Flintoff. Picked as a batsman who bowls, he is currently a bowler who biffs. And not a real wicket-taking bowler either, for all his excellence as Gough's straight man on Friday morning: his strike rate is now 118 balls per wicket, high even by the standards of English allrounders. And as for his batting ­ well, he would be a promising one if he could display an ounce of the nous that seems to come naturally when he has a ball in his hand. Apart from anything else, he is hopelessly unsuited to No 7, a slot that calls for tenacity and short legs. Flintoff should be assured that he remains in the selectors' thoughts, and sent back to Bob Simpson with extra homework.

Use his place to bring back Jack Russell, who is in the form of his life, or to bring in Paul Nixon, and let our best batsman play as a batsman. Nothing was more sadly predictable today than the way Alec Stewart played the ball on to his stumps, like Tony Adams deflecting one past David Seaman, for the second time in the match.

There's just one other serious worry: Nasser Hussain's form. Since that epic 146 not out at Durban, he has made only 110 in Tests for eight times out. In the first innings here he was painfully defensive ­ as he is apt to be in the field ­ and today he only reached eight because he was dropped twice. They say luck deserts those who are out of form, but when you're really out of form, you can't make use of any luck that may come your way. A short selection meeting then Nasser, and a long net.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. Click here for the Test scorecard and Lawrence Booth's Update.
fields.bodyText: In the first Test of the summer, England turned the clock back 40 years, to the halcyon days when they used to demolish hapless part-timers. In the first real test of the summer, they have turned the clock back 15 years, to the dark days when having a good game against the West Indies meant avoiding an innings defeat. At 12.30 on Friday, this game was almost evenly balanced. West Indies were 136 for 4, Darren Gough was on fire and England were only a nick away from exposing a long tail. Or so it seemed. That was the moment when Jimmy Adams came in and showed a grit far beyond any other batsman in the match. By the time he was out, 24 bloodyminded hours later, the game was a horrible mismatch. The last four West Indian wickets added 160 24 more than the first four. It was hard to say who were more embarrassed, England's bowlers or her bookmakers. This will be written up tomorrow, or edited up, as yet another England disaster, but it would be more accurate as well as kinder to call it a triumph for the West Indies. Every one of their senior players delivered the goods. First Curtly and Courtney, who have played only three fewer Tests in England than Gough and Caddick, gave a masterclass in the art (once regarded as an English one) of fast-medium seam bowling. Then all four of West Indies' experienced batsmen reached 50. England's old hands reached 50 too 59, between the five of them, on Thursday. Today they managed 35. England needn't despair, or even panic. They were rolled over here in 1995 and bounced back to win the next Test. In fact, 1996 (when England beat India) is the only time in recent years that the winners at Edgbaston have gone on to win the series. At this stage the patient needs only minor surgery. Ed Giddins was so insipid here that he is now behind at least four others in the pecking order: Dominic Cork, Mark Ealham, Angus Fraser, and Alex Tudor. Nick Knight and Graeme Hick could reasonably be replaced by Graham Thorpe and Michael Vaughan. Knight top-scored in both innings, but that was saying little except to confirm that he has a good fighting temperament (so does Thorpe). Hick was given out wrongly today, but how long would he have lasted if he hadn't been? The trickiest decision concerns Andrew Flintoff. Picked as a batsman who bowls, he is currently a bowler who biffs. And not a real wicket-taking bowler either, for all his excellence as Gough's straight man on Friday morning: his strike rate is now 118 balls per wicket, high even by the standards of English allrounders. And as for his batting well, he would be a promising one if he could display an ounce of the nous that seems to come naturally when he has a ball in his hand. Apart from anything else, he is hopelessly unsuited to No 7, a slot that calls for tenacity and short legs. Flintoff should be assured that he remains in the selectors' thoughts, and sent back to Bob Simpson with extra homework. Use his place to bring back Jack Russell, who is in the form of his life, or to bring in Paul Nixon, and let our best batsman play as a batsman. Nothing was more sadly predictable today than the way Alec Stewart played the ball on to his stumps, like Tony Adams deflecting one past David Seaman, for the second time in the match. There's just one other serious worry: Nasser Hussain's form. Since that epic 146 not out at Durban, he has made only 110 in Tests for eight times out. In the first innings here he was painfully defensive as he is apt to be in the field and today he only reached eight because he was dropped twice. They say luck deserts those who are out of form, but when you're really out of form, you can't make use of any luck that may come your way. A short selection meeting then Nasser, and a long net. fields.headline: Isambard Kingdom Brunel, Robert Howlett (1857)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Robert Howlett, died 1858, an obscure early photographer whose death, shortly after taking this picture, was said to have been caused by the chemicals he was exposed to in his work. The Illustrated Times praised "one of the most skillful photographers of the day".

Subject: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806-1859), the great Victorian engineer who built the Great Western Railway and Bristol's Clifton suspension bridge before spending the last decade of his life on his doomed project, the Great Eastern, a gigantic ocean-going iron steamship.

Distinguishing features: Pictured in front of the giant chains of a braking mechanism used in the attempted launch of the Great Eastern from its dry dock at Millwall in 1857 - an event that attracted thousands of paying spectators, who witnessed these chains whip out of control and throw a worker over the crowd to his death - Brunel is a tower of strength. The massive chains, the stovepipe hat, the cigar - can the photographer really not have known what it all signified? The strap across Brunel's waistcoat belongs to the bag full of spare cigars he always carried. But if this is a study of rampant Victorian manhood, it is also about the birth of photography.

The negative-positive photograph resulting in non-unique prints was invented by WH Fox Talbot in 1841. By the time this picture was taken, fantastic results were being achieved. Yet so many early photographs are airy-fairy fantasies, with everyone in the garden in fancy dress. The excitement in this picture is that of photography recognising itself. This photograph has no medieval disguises, no precedent in the history of art. It represents the self in a new way - it's as if through all Brunel's butch accessories the photograph is trying to give us a physical experience of the man.

The National Portrait Gallery also owns a painting of Brunel from the same year. The painting, by John Callcott Horsley, is a conventional image of the designer at his desk, a represen tation of the intellectual that could have been painted any time since the mid-18th century. This photograph is from a different world. Brunel is not trammelled by tradition. He displays his power to us directly, as he displayed it to the men in the shipyard.

It's a likable picture dirty boots and trousers, hands in pockets, barely contained energy. It looks as if Brunel has his eye on some clumsy subordinate. Yet the chains behind are bigger than he is they are his authority but threaten to overwhelm him. These monstrous chains are excessive, sublime. At his feet they vanish into darkness, as if they might be rattling down into hell or are links in an infernal machine. No wonder the Great Eastern was nicknamed Leviathan when it was demolished decades later it was said the skeletons of two labourers were discovered, sealed between its twin hulls.

Brunel himself was never as confident as this again. Shortly after posing for this picture he tried to launch the ship, only to find it was stuck in its dry moorings. It took several more tries to get it waterborne. On the eve of the first sailing he had a stroke. The ship was plagued by problems and instead of the world's greatest passenger ship it became a cable-laying vessel. This tale of hubris was forgotten 50 years later in time for Cunard to build the Titanic.

Where is it? National Portrait Gallery, St Martin's Place, London WC2 (020-7306 0055)

fields.headline: Car trouble
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I am on the very horns of a dilemma. An insert fell out of my Daily Express today headed "Celebrity Star Match!" and invited me to scratch off the panel on an illustration of a Mercedes convertible, to reveal a picture of a famous star
fields.body:
Friday, June 8, Ashby-de-la-Zouche

I am on the very horns of a dilemma. An insert fell out of my Daily Express today, a colourful shiny piece of A6 paper headed "Celebrity Star Match!" invited me to scratch off the panel on an illustration of a Mercedes convertible, to reveal a picture of a famous star. I did as instructed. Slowly, as a tiny pile of metallic grey dust collected, I began to see features of Cameron Diaz.

Mrs Wormington was looking over my shoulder. "Oos she when she's at 'ome?" she said (the last time she went to the cinema was to see Rock Hudson. I pray she never finds out that Rock had to steel himself to kiss Doris Day, the truth could easily kill her.) I carried on reading the instructions: "Now, one at a time, starting with panel one, scratch the four panels alongside." At this point, Glenn and William begged to be allowed to scratch two panels each. Glenn read further instructions aloud as William scratched. "If you reveal a matching picture - stop scratching - you're a winner!" Alas, his vigorous work with the two-pence piece revealed Tom Cruise and George Clooney. Mrs Wormington peered at these two megga heart-throbs and pronounced them "Nancy boys" who looked as if they "couldn't stuff a lavender bag".

William pronounced himself to be "devastated" at his failure. I must stop him watching so much television, it is having a deleterious effect on his vocabulary. He has no sense of proportion. He fell off his tricycle yesterday. When I asked him if he was all right he said, "I'm cool Dad, I just want to get on with the rest of my life."

The tension grew as Glenn picked up the coin. He took a deep breath and scratched away. The features of Samuel L Jackson gradually took shape. Mrs Wormington confused him with Michael Jackson and seemed to be under the impression that M Jackson had actually married his pet chimpanzee, Bubbles. I tried to explain to her that the ape had, in fact, been the best man at Elizabeth Taylor's last wedding, but I could see that the ways of the modern world were beyond her comprehension.

The atmosphere was now so tense that I could feel the word "palpable" vibrating in the air of the room. Glenn closed his eyes in silent prayer, then scratched at the fourth panel. Unbelievably, incredibly, the smiling face of Cameron Diaz appeared from among the grey filings. Our collective shout of delight brought Vince and Peggy Ludlow round from next door. "I've won a Mercedes, Dad!" shouted Glenn and we had a collective hug, though we didn't include Mrs Wormington, who has brittle bones. I read on feverishly.

"Winners can find out what they've won right now. Just call 0906 551 1020 and listen. Have a pen ready to write down your personal claims number which you will need if you claim a prize."

I turned the leaflet over. Glenn hadn't necessarily won a convertible Mercedes, though for at least 10 deliriously happy seconds, he thought he had. He told me later that he had fantasised in that short time about driving to school in the silver car with the hood down and gangsta rap playing on the in-car stereo. He'd parked next to the headmaster's clapped-out VW and had walked across the playground with the car keys swinging from his index finger. I had to break the news to him that he may have won other, lesser prizes, including: a weekend in Cannes with £500, a dishwasher, a set of hardwood garden furniture, or, even lesser prizes such as key cases, razor sets, kitchen scissors and mixed seed packs.

Peggy read further down the leaflet and pointed out that to discover what Glenn had actually won would cost me £1 a minute, and that the average call lasted longer than 3.5 minutes.

You see my dilemma, diary? Do I fork out more than three quid only to find that Glenn has won a packet of mixed seeds, or do I take a stand against exploitation and risk losing a convertible Mercedes?

webTitle: Caddick in cruise control, Hussain in reverse

fields.headline: Caddick in cruise control, Hussain in reverse
fields.trailText: Good Form
fields.body:
Good Form

Andy Caddick Somerset and England

Andy Caddick is a rhythm 'n' blues bowler. When he's in the rhythm, the batsmen usually end up with the blues. And, after a quiet start to the season, when rain and central contracts limited his appearances, he's been at his clockwork best, for Somerset if not always for England. Twelve wickets in the win against Hampshire were followed by a decisive opening spell (8-3-28-3) in the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's and four cheap scalps in the second innings as Darren Gough threatened to clean up. He was below his best during the second Test at Trent Bridge (when he hadn't bowled for 12 days), but was back in the groove with ten wickets in Somerset's narrow victory over Kent. Along with Glenn McGrath, he's the fast bowler no county batsman wants to face.

At a glance

5-62, 7-64; 3-28, 4-38; 0-57, 1-9; 6-57, 4-40; 2-15

In detail

5-62 and 7-64 v Hants, Southampton, Ch'ship Div 1, May 3-6
3-28 and 4-38 v Zimbabwe, Lord's, 1st Test, May 18-21
0-57 and 1-9 v Zimbabwe, Trent Bridge, 2nd Test, June 1-5
6-57 and 4-40 v Kent, Bath, Ch'ship Div 1, June 6-9
2-15 v Kent, Taunton, NCL Div 1, June 11

First-class record since May 3 30 wkts at 11.83
One-day record since May 3 2 wkts at 7.50
Total record since May 3 32 wkts at 11.56

Bad Form

Nasser Hussain Essex and England

Nasser Hussain's England captaincy has been attracting rave reviews. Some have even drawn comparisons with Mike Brearley. These parallels may be more apt than they know. Brearley averaged 22.88 in 66 Test innings, and Hussain is starting to get used to low scoring too. He's been struggling for most of the season and, in the first Test at Lord's, entered a trough from which he is yet to emerge. He just needs one big score. But as the first innings at Edgbaston showed, when he laboured for 82 balls over his 15, Curtly and Courtney aren't going to make it easy for him.

fields.headline: Those were the deaths
fields.standfirst: David Hess made his name as the Manson-like  anti-hero in Wes Craven's notorious Last House On  The Left, and he's still too scary for the British censors
fields.trailText: David Hess made his name as the Manson-like anti-hero in Wes Craven's notorious Last House On The Left, and he's still too scary for the British censors
fields.body:
Wes Craven's notorious 70s low-budget horror The Last House On The Left is still without a UK certificate - almost 30 years after its initial release. David Hess plays Krug, the head of a gang of escaped convicts responsible for the torture of a pair of teenagers in this grisly reality-nasty, whose advertising told film-goers to keep repeating 'It's only a movie' to avoid fainting. He also wrote the intriguing soundtrack.

What was it like inflicting all that terror and violence?

This was the first film I ever did, and essentially we started out wanting to make 'V for violence', but also to push the envelope to a degree, in that we would present it in this ultra-realistic, hand-held camera fashion.

Did anything get pulled because the cast objected to it?

Wes let us have free rein in the sense that he used the script more as a blueprint than following it line for line. So a lot of what we did was improv because it worked faster; you just keep the camera moving and hope for the best. The camera guy was the first to rig a camera so he could put it on his shoulder, which later became the Steadicam. He was running through the woods with 36kg (80lb) on his shoulders, so he should really be thanked for that.

How did the backlash against the film affect you?

I lost an agent in New York because they thought I was some kind of homophobic crazy and they didn't realise it was an acting job. I look back on it now and really laugh at it. I had a deal on the soundtrack then, and they went and saw the picture on the opening night and cancelled the deal. At the time I didn't think it was so funny.

What do you think of your soundtrack now, looking back?

I was totally pleased with the soundtrack and I think everybody will admit that it had a lot to do with the success of the movie, the way it counterpointed the action, you know. The music was cutting edge, maybe even a bit ahead of its time.

What do you think of the film still being effectively banned in the UK?

Well, I find the English odd. I've been on rugby tours of England a few times and one of the things that English rugby players told me was, 'Listen, if you want to nail an English woman, you have to remember, she's a lady in public but a whore in bed.' I always kept that as a way of relating to English women, and perhaps that's a metaphor for English society.

How do you think it compares to the horror of today?

You know, there are different parameters for the movies now. They're cut faster because of the MTV thing and the speed at which television is cut, which has trickled down into the film industry. So I would say that the film absolutely holds up, and if someone were to go in and do a creative cut on it with today's market in mind I think it could be a blockbuster. The only thing that holds it up is that it was shot 30 years ago, and that was a different time and a different 'eye' so to speak.

So what's your favourite scary movie?

A film by John Frankenheimer called Seconds with Rock Hudson scared the shit out of me.

 David Hess appears with Gunnar 'Leatherface' Hansen at the Prince Charles Cinema, London W2, tonight, then at Newcastle Tyneside Cinema, Wednesday 21; Bradford Pictureville, Thursday 22; Northampton Forum, Friday 23; Birmingham Electric, June 24; Phoenix Arts, Leicester, June 25

fields.headline: Great pecs, but no sex
fields.standfirst: Gay characters are finally muscling their way to leading man roles. If   only they didn't always have to play so squeaky clean, says James Collard
fields.trailText: Gay characters are finally muscling their way to leading man roles. If only they didn't always have to play so squeaky clean, says James Collard
fields.body:
Perhaps it should come as more of a disappointment, but the news that yet another gay character in an American movie or an American TV drama fails to get his end away no longer shocks. I refer, of course, to The Next Best Thing, the movie starring Madonna, the world's most famous woman, and Rupert Everett, the world's most famous homosexual.

The movie, which has more charm than one might expect - more indeed than most of the movies Madonna has made since Desperately Seeking Susan (and certainly more than In Bed With Madonna) - purports to recount the story of a beautiful, quirky, thirtysomething yoga teacher in Los Angeles who, despite possessing an incredible body, a great face and an uncanny resemblance to a huge, international pop music star, can't get laid. At least on a regular basis, by a man she respects. Who loves her. And her handsome, witty, thirtysomething gardener best friend who, despite having a wonderful body (the kind gay men in West Hollywood spend hours at the gym and a fortune on vitamin supplements trying to achieve), a great face and an equally uncanny resemblance to the boy fags the world over fell for, a zillion years ago, when he played Guy Burgess (the spy who came in from the cottage) in Another Country, can't find happiness in the world of 'circuit parties', drugs and body fascism that is WestHo homosexuality, can't get laid... etc, etc.

If we are surprised by this gay boy's dismal sex life, we shouldn't be - and neither should Rupert, who, after all, has been here before. For while in real life Rupe knows that after half a minute in Manto's on Old Compton Street, he'd have more phone numbers than he'd know what to do with (I'm just guessing here), in Hollywood - the city of celluloid, that is, rather than the district of LA that gay folks colonised when the movie stars took to the Hollywood hills - the most a man can hope for is the kind of next-best, best-friend relationship he has enjoyed with Julia Roberts' My Best Friend's Wedding and Madonna's The Next Best Thing.

It would be foolish to hope for more. At least in this, his latest vehicle, it's key to the storyline, about how a gay man and a straight woman seek to build a life out of their friendship, and bring up a child together, that the real drama of this particular gay man should lie outside the bedroom. Or the bath-house. And at least we get to see Rupert, if not so much tripping the light fantastic, then enjoying a warm(-ish) post-coital moment with someone who looks remarkably like (if not enough, for some tastes) Russell Crowe.

But for all the good intentions of The Next Best Thing, this is not going to be the movie finally to dispel our suspicions that gay men aren't accurately portrayed by America's entertainment industry. After all, in real life, gay men are remarkably, outrageously, indeed deliciously, able to get their rocks off. Who's to say if Madonna's conversations with Rupert are really this anodyne, as we have no bigger window on the Madonna/Rupert friendship than they care to give us (and in fairness, this movie gives us a glimpse of their rapport) but I can't help thinking that the relationships between gay men and their heterosexual friends are generally characterised by the sheer, straight wonder that gay men can 'get it' quite so often, even in the face of the most overwhelming odds.

'On the fast train between London Bridge and Lewisham?' they ask incredulously. 'In Pizza Express, between courses?' Gay men rarely hide their light under a bushell, it seems, but they have sex there - more than you'll ever know.

Of course, while Rupert rarely gets to play really gay in the movies - and if we're going to be defined by our sexuality, it seems only fair that we should get some - he certainly seems to go further than your average queer on American network TV.

Jack in Dawson's Creek seems condemned to spend the rest of his life agonising in a way most gay men stop sometime in their teens, when some kind, avuncular figure pours them another drink and takes their cherry. Will of Will & Grace fame, currently eighth in the US ratings and bumping Frasier out off its coveted slot on Thursday night primetime, isn't so much gay - heck, the boy's yet to get his first pair of Helmut Lang jeans, let alone a full-throttle love scene - as not straight. Sadly, in televisual terms, Will plays much the same function as those prosperous, urbane fags in black-tie (please call if there are some of you still out there) whom upper-class women would invite to their dinner parties in the 50s to even up the numbers, sure in the knowledge that jokes would be told, Balenciaga frocks wouldn't go unnoticed, and tricky subjects like rimming or gay lib were sure to go unmentioned.

It's a different story here, of course, in this sceptred - and rather more steamy - isle. Shows like This Life, in which Warren got caught with his willie out (what was it like, a nation asked?) and Queer As Folk, in which we saw (only too clearly) the way gay men really behave, proved that while gay America may have lit the torch of freedom for gay men everywhere, it is in England (that sceptred isle, etc) where we get to use it - give it, take it, suck it, and generally do with it as we please. In America, that still seems to be impossible, on screen at least.

Part of the problem, it seems, is TV and movie executives who are unwilling to face the consequences. These stretch from panicked advertising execs and burning crosses on the studio lawn to 'politically correct' gay viewers who are equally reluctant to see lesbians kiss (that's a whole other subject) and gay men get down to being homosexual.

It's a shame, of course, given the way we feel about Madonna and Rupert, but whatever the reason, it's clear we shouldn't look to Hollywood for portrayals of gay men that go beyond vanilla. That'd be asking for a cherry on top.

 The Next Best Thing is out on Friday
 Dawson's Creek, 12.40pm, Sun, C4 (not showing Jun 18 because of cricket)
 Will & Grace, 7.30pm, Mon-Fri, Living

fields.headline: Posthumous parenting
fields.standfirst: Elaine Showalter  applauds Will Self's weird vision of the afterlife, How the Dead Live
fields.trailText: Elaine Showalter applauds Will Self's weird vision of the afterlife, How the Dead Live
fields.body:
How the Dead Live
Will Self
Bloomsbury, £15.99, 256pp

Ten years ago, in a hilarious short story called "The North London Book of the Dead", Will Self wrote about a grieving son who discovers with shock that his dead mother has merely moved to Crouch End, where she continues to bake chocolate-chip cookies, schlep around with bags from Barnes & Noble and telephone him at the office. Indeed, mum tells him, when people die they all move to less fashionable parts of London, where they keep on doing pretty much what they were doing when they were alive. In a recent interview with Lynn Barber, Self acknowledged the autobiographical root of the story in the 1988 death of his own mother, an unhappy woman who was both "very loving and very aggressive".

In How the Dead Live, Self has transformed one part of this premise into a full-length account of necropolitan London. In his satiric geography, the young dead - the "morbidly mobile" - go to find work in the States or the Gulf, but the older dead simply live on either north of the river in Dulston or south of the river in Dulburb, their placements assigned by the Deatheaucracy Office. Their mornings are busy with the Full Dead breakfast and their evenings filled with the 12-step meetings of PD (Personally Dead). Freddy Ayer, Ronny Laing and Laurence Olivier have Dulston flats; almost all the dead smoke, drink, and sleep around, and all they need to keep up with the urban deathstyle of the rich and famous is Goodbye! magazine.

But for all its one-liners and Jewish-mother jokes, the novel is much darker and weirder than a Woody Allen movie. The other half of the story is the epic of the monstrous mother who haunts her children. This time Self's narrator is Mom - Lily Bloom, an angry, kvetching 65-year-old Jewish-American woman living in London, who dies of breast cancer in May 1988 in the Royal Ear Hospital (don't ask) but immediately finds herself naked on Gower Street with an Aboriginal wizard as her Death Guide and a Cypriot minicab driver ferrying her to her grubby basement flat in Dulston. Never a joiner, Lily has to put up with boring PD meetings and worry invisibly for 11 long years over the fate of her two grown daughters, matronly Charlotte and heroin addict Natasha.

Lily is also saddled with the materialised spirits of two other dead children: Lithy, the fossilised cadaver of an unborn foetus, and Rude Boy, the bratty ghost of her nine-year-old son, who was killed in a car accident. They are noisy, taunting images of her failure as a mother. But Lily is not really dealing with karma or learning what death has to teach her; she spends her posthumous years in a series of annoying deatheaucratic waiting rooms replaying memories of her sexual escapades, unfaithful husbands and ungrateful children. Impatient, restless and controlling even in death, she wants only to be reborn in her children's lives. When the officials finally grant her wish to return in 2000 as her daughter's daughter, the result is futile and macabre.

There is a lot for the reader to sort out in this ambitious but often confusing narrative. The time scheme is so convoluted that even the publisher's press release gets it wrong. And is it all meant to be a dream? Self drops some clues that he intends the vision of London as a city of the dead to be Lily's narcotised deathbed hallucination, a projection of her experiences, memories and inner demons.

Scenes in the hospital such as, for example, Lily's observation of a little boy playing with his toys, recur in Dulston; Phar Lap Dixon, Lily's Aborigine guide, is a figure Natasha encountered on a trip to the outback. But the narrative of the afterlife is also so fully developed and detailed that it seems to be Self's surreal, sci-fi dystopia of urban alienation, global catastrophe, death and recycling. The subplot of Natasha's addiction, recovery and relapse repeats a central theme of Self's fiction and journalism, here starkly deglamorised.

Self is a manic, inventive stylist who can't leave anything out: literary allusions from Goodnight, Moon to Finnegans Wake; discussions of Australian sympathetic magic; a sub-theme about Lily's dentures (dentures also made a cameo appearance in "The North London Book of the Dead"). What with Martin Amis and Zadie Smith, this has certainly been a vintage literary year for teeth, and maybe Self has bitten off more plot than he can chew.

Nonetheless, what How the Dead Live lacks in economy of structure it repays in lavishness of feeling and characterisation. Lily is a colossal heroine, a nighttown Molly Bloom who memorably reveals herself through her furious monologue. What begins as a satiric novel of ideas ends as a surprisingly moving elegy.

fields.headline: Songs of innocence
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Bradbury celebrates Mark Twain's sly exploitation of the lighter side
fields.trailText: Malcolm Bradbury celebrates Mark Twain's sly exploitation of the lighter side in a new biography, Ron Powers' Dangerous Water: A Biography of the Boy who Became Mark Twain, and an anthology of Twain's own work, Cannibalism in the Cars: The Best of Mark Twain's Humorous Sketches
fields.body:
Dangerous Water: A Biography of the Boy who Became Mark Twain
Ron Powers
Perseus, £16.50, 328pp
Buy it at BOL

Cannibalism in the Cars: The Best of Mark Twain's Humorous Sketches
Mark Twain
Prion Books, £8.99, 241pp,
Buy it at BOL

Mark Twain isn't just one of the greatest of American writers - the one from whom, according to Hemingway, all American fiction is reckoned to begin. Along with Walt Whitman, he is also one of the most firmly American: the writer as home-boy, westerner, talisman; a natural, iconic, untainted innocent in the most popular or populist sense. Much of this easy-going status comes from his particular location in 19th-century American culture. Out of Virginia and Tennessee, the Clemens family, like many others, moved west toward the shifting frontier along the Mississippi Valley - which, in the Jeffersonian space between the Louisiana Purchase, opened up the territories, bringing a new idea of America and the national crisis of the Civil War.

These were the new American heartlands, taken away from the Native Americans, grasped from the French and Spanish; and they opened out into the great national artery that gave the States a new axis from north to south. The region took on all the characteristics of American spread and pioneering entrepreneurialism: small sudden settlements, wagon trains, country stores, tin churches, lawyers' offices, print shops, medicine men, property boom and bust, bad investments, sharecropping and, of course, slavery.

But they were also in the process of becoming mythic territory to the East Coast and the European imagination, embodying all the American notions of frontier independence: solitude, pioneering, new territories, fresh lands and fresh opportunities. The day-to-day truths were much grimmer, more complex and corrupt. "Sivilisation" fought with decline, law and lawlessness, and disease was rife. The age of the frontier gave way to growth and expansion, territories became states and the great rivers became war zones. When it was over, the post-bellum world found a new unity in industrialism, entrepreneurship, fast capitalism: it was the age of the locomotive, the telephone and the lightbulb.

Samuel Clemens/Mark Twain - steamboat pilot, silver explorer, newspaper journalist, western humorist gone east - was there to tap into the great transition. And, above all, what he tapped was its voice: the humorous vernacular, the storytelling drawl, the distinctive pace and the unusual narrative speed, the different way of describing things that cast light, shade and emphasis afresh, the innocent-eyed tactic that enabled him to win fame not, at first, by writing about the great river or his Hannibal boyhood, but about a pious trip by American tourists trying to make sense of the cultural sites of Europe.

It was the voice and note that made him a typically American and yet at the same time a world writer, quite as famous internationally as Dickens had been a generation earlier. He was intimately and cleverly aware of his own tactics. One of the famous essays collected in Cannibalism in the Cars - a pleasant collection of, chiefly, earlier humorous pieces in a good cheap-price format called Prion Humour Classics - is "How to Tell a Story". Here, with great clarity, Twain defines the tactical difference between the European comic writer and his distinctive American counterpart, the humorist: "The art of telling a humorous story - understand, I mean by word of mouth, not print - was created in America and has remained at home."

Twain, of course, was more than a humorist, and revising, deconstructing and remonumentalising him are now classic American academic industries. We all know now that there were two Twains: affirmer and dissenter, white-suited comedian and cosmic pessimist, innocent-eyed writer and explorer of deep darkness, cultural conservative and radical. And we know the huge spread of his work; the recent publication of a multi-volume Oxford Mark Twain, with strong new introductions, has reminded us that he was one of the world's most productive as well as multi-purpose writers.

Yet there is profit, and even truth, in the idea of innocence, especially as Twain understood and exploited it. He knew the worth of casting a glow over a world that, as Ron Powers reminds us in his "childhood biography", Dangerous Water, contained some of the more disturbing and critical materials of American culture. "In Mark Twain's dark night lay America's literary dawning," Powers suggests, reminding us that much of the humour in Twain's work did come from strangeness and darkness.

Visitors who today go to Hannibal, Missouri, the riverbank town of Samuel Clemens's boyhood, will find it tacky, the imagery crude; its landscape has been remapped to match the fiction, while the best sights to hand, apart from the raging river itself, are some fine Frank Lloyd Wright homes in the region. But, late settled as a river staging post for the steamboats on which Clemens worked, it was indeed the birthplace of and sourcebook for his writing.

This was because, as Powers rightly says, Hannibal became, for Twain and the American people, a concept of "the past, a concept he had largely created and placed in his boyhood books for preservation". A novelist who was himself born in Hannibal, Powers usefully and vividly explores not just the childhood life in its light, and more often in its darkness, but the process by which Twain exploited, distanced, reworked and refined his childhood material for publication.

The versions varied at different stages of his life, though the sheer tenacity of certain memories and the completeness of Twain's lifelong dependence on them is striking. But the river and the line of settlement went through innumerable meanings. The river of life on the Mississippi is hardly the same river as that of the late, sad, savage Pudd'nhead Wilson. The bright childhood world of Tom Sawyer is not the same universe as the darkened world of Huckleberry Finn, where the place of anarchic moral innocence is also the place of slavery.

Twain was not, in fact, the first great writer of the American frontier; Cooper was. But it was Twain who, completing the journey from frontier to industrialism, journalistic humour to serious narrative, laughter to darkness to satire, fame to bankruptcy and then endurance, anarchistic optimism to moral pessimism, gave the past many of its modern shadings, and the heartland its distinctive voice. These two books, in their different ways, remind us of the freshness of Twain. They make pleasant summer reads, and Powers also offers the Twainian some useful local historical research. And they also light up again, in useful ways, Twain's intricate, complicated, still influential innocence.

And they also light up again, in useful ways, Twain's intricate, complicated, still influential innocence.

fields.headline: Minister accepts compromise over section 28
fields.trailText: The bitter row over the repeal of section 28 which has dogged Labour in Scotland looked finally to be over yesterday when it emerged that ministers had accepted a compromise proposal stressing the importance of marriage.
fields.body:
The bitter row over the repeal of section 28 which has dogged Labour in Scotland looked finally to be over yesterday when it emerged that ministers had accepted a compromise proposal stressing the importance of marriage.

After months of increasingly unpleasant wrangling, the education minister, Sam Galbraith, said he was prepared to accept a report which called for the legally binding guidance issued to local authorities on sex education to contain reference to the responsibilities and importance of marriage.

Mr Galbraith had previously refused to accept any changes in the guidance and opposition parties yesterday accused him of a humiliating climbdown.

The controversy over repeal of the clause, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality, has been furious in Scotland. The Labour dominated Scottish executive - and the prime minister - have been taken aback by the strength of feeling it has provoked.

An anti-repeal campaign run by the millionaire businessman Brian Souter - which included a much-criticised independent referendum - has been backed by most of the Scottish tabloids.

Ministers in Westminster and Holyrood felt it was over shadowing many of the executive's achievements.

A committee set up to look at repeal, which included representatives of the main churches, called on the executive to insert a clause in its guidance which stressed "the importance of family life and relationships including the responsibilities of parenthood and marriage".

Mr Galbraith said yesterday he was prepared to take that recommendation on board.

"There are no hierarchical relationships, no value judgments, what they do talk about is the responsibilities of parenthood and marriage and, as a married parent myself, I fully appreciate these," he said.

Gay rights campaigners also said they were happy with the new wording. Tim Hopkins, of the Equality Network, said: "If marriage is placed above other relationships that would have been discriminatory, but it is not and we have no problem with the guidance."

Mr Souter's Keep the Clause campaigners yesterday refused to comment on the developments, but the indications are that they are prepared to accept the compromise.

Nicola Sturgeon, the shadow education minister, said Mr Galbraith had performed a u-turn, but she hoped the compromise would finally settle the debate.
