fields.headline: An unlikely reading
fields.trailText: Alain de Botton and Front Row take the punishment as Dan Rhodes lets off steam in Borders, plus the long and the short of the Guardian Fiction Prize
fields.body:
 To Borders in Charing Cross Road to hear authors Kevin Sampson and Dan Rhodes read from their new books, in Rhodes's case a selection of the fragmentary mini-stories that make up Anthropology.

Or not. Alas, a lengthy promotional tour had taken its toll, and the audience were treated to what one might call an, um, unorthodox reading. After we'd all listened in silence to a George Jones track (that's Tammy Wynette's ex-husband, in case you didn't know), Rhodes proceeded to play tapes of his book's critical reception on radio's Front Row ("the most inane thing I've ever heard") and finally, in revenge for stealing the media spotlight by having a book published at the same time, to punch a tiny, home-made effigy of everyone's favourite philosophe Alain de Botton.

As if the affable Swiss hasn't suffered enough. A distinctly overshadowed Sampson, who has, after all, written plenty about rock stars behaving badly, took it all in good part, as did the rather bemused book-buying public.

 Nottingham Trent University has been in touch with the results of its survey on writers' experiences online. It yields startlingly predictable insights: women are more sociable, forever popping into chat-rooms and the like, men get straight on with posting their stuff up there for all the world to see.

One respondent confided that "Being online is sometimes like being tickled and sometimes like being rubbed up the wrong way!", a mystifying pronouncement that bodes ill for their future career as a scribbler. The average "wired" writer, apparently, is a woman living in the suburbs aged between 51 and 65. Unfortunately, the survey doesn't reveal how much time writers spend cooking up "customer reviews" to post on Amazon, nor surfing obscure research sites for storylines to plunder. Now that would have made good reading.

fields.headline: The Road(show) to domination
fields.trailText: Have you noticed how anxious Mark Nicholas and Sybil Ruscoe seem every Saturday morning on the C4 Cricket Roadshow? Forget the stress of live broadcasting - we know that they are reflecting the nervous vibes coming from our student flat. Even Dermot Reeve is affected; only Michael Slater, coming from a cricketing culture confident in the knowledge of its international success, remains untouched.
fields.body:
Have you noticed how anxious Mark Nicholas and Sybil Ruscoe seem every Saturday morning on the C4 Cricket Roadshow? Forget the stress of live broadcasting - we know that they are reflecting the nervous vibes coming from our student flat. Even Dermot Reeve is affected; only Michael Slater, coming from a cricketing culture confident in the knowledge of its international success, remains untouched.

You see, our five-strong (all-female) flat is divided on the issue of cricket: three of us can easily spend all day looking forward to the highlights, while another sighs despairingly at the first strains of 'Mambo No.5' (although she can identify more players than she'd perhaps be prepared to admit), and the last cannot understand why anyone should be interested in cricket - and tells us so at every opportunity.

It is the attitude of these two which, I believe, is at the root of our esteemed presenters' anxiety. For us cricket-lovers, highlights-watching has taken on the air of an illicit activity: video subtly set in motion by under-the-table zapping, viewing timetabled with surreptitious meaningful looks, usually for the early (that's 10am) weekend morning. And if surprised by the cricket-hater, we can at least claim we are watching an actual match. The Cricket Roadshow, on the other hand, offers no such excuse, and watching it is much harder to justify.

We desperately hope for action and wit, anything that will justify our lame "because it's cool" replies to the eternal question "but how can you like cricket?!" The reality? We are treated to yet another tableau vivant of press-ganged children, while the cricket-endurer cries despairingly "oh no, it's that man!" at the appearance of Michael Slater and his manic grin.

Yet we keep watching, hoping for the occasional flashes of insight into a player's approach or an aspect of the game. Note to the producers: please repeat Richie and Shane's leg-spin masterclass now that I've bought a tennis ball to use instead of the apple (someone else's at that - which, remember, is of no little importance in a student flat). And Mark and Sybil are, I'm sure, aware that our self-respect is in their hands.

However, perhaps they need not worry for much longer. Dedicated viewers will recall the recent programme which featured Slats quizzing Mark Ramprakash (who once wrote a personalised message on a signed photo for my Mum's birthday at my request - what a man) on the contents of his coffin. True aficionados will remember the grey elastic strap which Marko uses to strengthen his shoulder. Unbeknown perhaps even to herself, the cricket-endurer somehow absorbed this information while making breakfast. She then made us oh so proud the same evening by recounting how she'd informed a friend that Mark Ramprakash used a strap just like his! Maybe the Roadshow is the route to world domination by cricket-lovers after all.

Claire Daniel is a 4th-year student at Edinburgh University. For the previous Punter's Point, in defence of Oxbridge cricket, click here

webTitle: Big friendly giant leaves Northants all in a spin

fields.headline: Big friendly giant leaves Northants all in a spin
fields.trailText:
Warwickshire 568-9dec

Northamptonshire 266 and 160-4
fields.body:
A tale of the unexpected this ain't. On a hazy day, to the cooing of a wood pigeon, Northamptonshire briefly rallied, collapsed, followed on, steadied the ship and then wobbled again against Warwickshire, who have defeated them in their last three first-class matches here.

While Northamptonshire continue to mourn the temporary loss of form of their spin twins, Warwickshire's more senior twirlers, Ashley Giles and Neil Smith, rubbed salt in the wound by taking 10 of the 11 wickets to fall.

They make an odd couple. Giles has the air of the BFG when fielding, but give him a bowl and he becomes scary. Wheeling in wearing sunglasses and a heavy gold chain, he follows through to straddle the pitch and strikes a pistols-at-dawn pose.

Smith is far more unprepossessing, smaller and with a gently pinking crown; he takes his shades off to bowl. But however peculiar a pair, they were too good for the home county. Giles especially found sharp turn. He bowled 23 overs unchanged from the Addington Avenue end in their first innings, finishing with four for 45. He followed this up with 27 overs in the second innings and another three wickets.

There were flashes of resistance from Northamptonshire in the morning, Tony Penberthy and Mal Loye putting on 81 for the fifth wicket. Penberthy lifted Giles high into the guttering of the indoor school, 30 feet up. As it turned out he should have hit it further. That ball, which was returned in the next over, not only had his name on it but those of his five remaining colleagues, including Loye, who was out seven short of what would have been a classy century.

A poster of Matthew Hayden is available from the Northamptonshire shop. You can see why. He may be wearing a maroon helmet but he bats like a man who sees himself back in a baggy green cap. But he was not to be the home county's saviour as they followed on. It is Adrian Rollins who carries their hopes into the fourth day.

Warwickshire indulged in some over-zealous appealing after tea. Neil Smith was summoned over by the umpires and told to pipe down. But the damage was done and the next ball Loye was walking back to the pavilion with his head bowed.

David Sales walked on to the field, head bowed. It was no surprise when Giles outwitted him for four. Somebody needs to teach Northamptonshire positive body language.

fields.headline: The City Brasserie, Norwich
fields.standfirst: Delia has made a fortune out of teaching Britain how to cook. But can she hack it as a restaurateur? Matthew Fort went to her new venture in Norwich to find out
fields.trailText: Delia has made a fortune out of teaching Britain how to cook. But can she hack it as a restaurateur? Matthew Fort went to her new venture in Norwich to find out
fields.body:
Address: The City Brasserie, Carrow Road Stadium, Norwich.
The other Saturday, I took my family to work. We caught the afternoon train to Norwich, pitched up for dinner, ate, and then caught the train back again: that's some six-and-a-half hours' travelling for a couple of hours' eating. It's not something I do every day. In fact, it's not something that I would think of doing at all, had not Delia Smith just opened The City Brasserie at Carrow Road Stadium, home of her beloved Norwich FC, aka, the Canaries.

I take my hat off to her. Our queen of the screen has no need to offer herself up as an Aunt Sally in the real world of restaurants. She, who has millions of devoted followers, who with the merest mention can transform the fortunes of a cranberry producer or a frying-pan manufacturer, who sells books in figures others can only envy, has no need of any eulogistic endorsement or to expose herself to the carping comments of peevish critics. But open one she has, so here goes...

It would take a genius of design and a stockpot full of money to transform this section of the Carrow Road complex into anything other than the corporate dining suite of a middle-ranking first division football club writ large.

Sensibly, the proprietor has chosen to leave it as close to the experience as possible: blown-up black-and-white photographs of heroes past and present cover the walls, football motifs liven up the window blinds, and the baggy trousers of the waiters and waitresses, elasticated at the top, have the same black-and-white colours as a ball, albeit arranged in irregular shapes, which, as my daughter observed, looked like cow pats on snow rather than anything to do with the great game. However, the staff carried the burdens of their uniforms with cheerfulness and obliging energy.

It is tempting to say that the menu is a game of two halves, but it isn't - it's of three courses of Delia classics, and it's all yours for £22. Piedmontese roasted peppers are there, as are: buckwheat blinis with smoked salmon and crème frache; a foaming hollandaise to go with local asparagus; jerk pork with grilled pineapple salsa; confit of duck with a compte of sour cherries; spinach-and-pinenut lasagne with three cheeses; fallen chocolate soufflé with Armagnac prunes and crème frache sauce; banana cheesecake with toffee pecan sauce; and meringue with mascarpone vanilla cream, summer berries and raspberry coulis. That's what you get: the dishes that have brought hope and happiness to millions of kitchens throughout Britain, in a restaurant, at restaurant prices. Indeed, both the blinis and the meringue are preceded with the phrase "home-made". In whose home, I wonder. Delia's, perhaps?

The impression of having stumbled in on some Delia-inspired dinner party - complete with jazz combo to provide the soothing vibe - is increased by the plating of the food, which has the artless quality of domestic arrangement. The cooking, too, has the uncertain ups and downs of the enthusiastic home chef. Ups included sound peppers, velvety, mild smoked salmon, fine foaming hollandaise, and succulent, fat-free duck confit with a properly sour cherry compte. Downs included soggy blinis, tough pork, coarse jerk seasoning that tasted as if it came from a bottle, starchy fresh peas, fallen chocolate soufflé that has fallen so far as to become a too, too solid wodge, and a meringue of death-embracing sweetness.

The question that restaurant goers have to ask themselves is: do they want to pay restaurant prices - our bill came to £89.50, which included a fine bottle of Cypress Shiraz from Oz at £17.50, mineral water and some lemonade - for food that you could reasonably expect to produce in your own home? Such, perhaps, is the power of the Delia Smith legend that, yes, they do. But what do I know? I'm only a peevish critic

Small Helpings

Offshore
15/20
Tel 020-7221 6090. Address Holland Park Avenue, London W11. Food Fish. Price £14.50-£30 a head (excluding drinks).

Clean, clear lines of split-level dining room. Clear, clean flavours. Fish in various shapes and guises, familiar and not so familiar, from Mauritian master Sylvain Ho Wing Cheong. Literate use of chilli, lime, garlic, tamarind, etc, to bring life to fishes and refreshment to tastebuds. Not cheap, but neither is good fish, or the talent to cook it well.

The Vineyard
17/20
Tel 01635 528770. Address Stockcross, Newbury, Berks. Food Modern French. Price £20-£70 a head (excluding drinks).

Southfork on the A4. A place of towering ambition, with taste to match. Shrieks expense account from the rooftops. Food and wine very classy, particularly when matched together, and generously served. Chef Billy Reid has a sophisticated touch and produces big flavours, easy balance, perfect pitch. Almost as many staff as guests. It costs, natch.

RK Stanley's
 14/20
Tel 020-7462 0099. Address Little Portland Street, London W1. Food Sausages. Price £10-£15 a head (excluding drinks).

Sausage Heaven. Bangers in many forms and combinations given a touch of class by 40s (or is it 50s?) retro dining room - booths, banquette seating, bar and brouhaha. Sausages mutate. Most are decently made. Veggies to match. Top-notch chips. Decent mash and onion gravy. Big beer list. Pretty good value for money.

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst: A lot, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: A lot, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
Different strains of plants under the same name umbrella can present many problems and disappointments. It is sad to have to recommend suspicion and caution in respect of every acquisition, but that is my message.

Hydrangea villosa is one of the most delectable of its genus: soft, furry leaves; intense, lilac florets in a ring around a central disc of tiny blue flowers; bees besieging it for pollen. You buy a plant and find, after a few years, that it is nothing like as good as the one you fell for, with wan-coloured flowers, maybe, and coarser foliage. Then, belatedly, you look it up in the RHS Plant Finder and find yourself referred to H. aspera Villosa Group. What do they mean by "Group"? Evidently, that there is no fixed and finally defined clone on which you can rely. Quite right; there isn't. Word of mouth and advice from an expert is (or would have been) the safest recourse.

When there is a reliable cultivar name, seize upon it; if there are several, take advice and buy the best clone. As with Liquidambar styraciflua , for instance. This makes a tall, though fairly narrow, tree with maple-like leaves, but it is chiefly noted for its autumn colouring. Grown from seed, which is the easiest way to raise it, you may get a liquidambar that never colours at all. So you must acquire a named cultivar that has been selected for its fall colour and is propagated vegetatively. There are more than two dozen listed in the Plant Finder, but two of them, 'Lane Roberts' and 'Worplesdon', have the Award of Garden Merit insignia. Buy one of them.

Vitis coignetiae is a vigorous vine that is grown entirely for its large, handsome foliage. That has (or should have) a prolonged crimson colouring season in autumn, but is often a disappointment. The season itself may be the reason, as weather conditions in some years do not promote fall colour, but if a failure to colour up well is monotonously frequent, you are growing a bad clone. There are named clones, such as 'Claret Cloak', but you can more easily buy a good one by visiting a selling centre in autumn and picking out a well-coloured specimen yourself. Some of its high colouring may be attributable to the roots being pot-bound, but at least you can be certain that your plant is capable of putting on a good show if the circumstances are right. I would choose a Virginia creeper, such as Parthenocissus henryana or P. quinquefolia, in the same way.

They seed themselves, and from their look before flowering you cannot tell that the colour will be a quite uninteresting green. Subspecies wulfenii is the one to choose, for size of inflorescence, but it can vary in colouring, from muted green to eye-catching yellow with only a hint of green. Buy your plant on the hoof, so to speak: if you can see that it is of a lively colouring, you don't need to worry whether it has a cultivar name or none.

But there will be some strains within the same species that are far more willing flowerers than others. webTitle: Prospect of another film shoot splits fishing folk

fields.headline: Prospect of another film shoot splits fishing folk
fields.trailText: The tiny Scottish fishing village of Pennan, which was used as a setting for the 1983 film Local Hero, has found itself split over plans to film another TV series on its only street
fields.body:
It has all the makings of a cutesy Hollywood tale - except, this time, another dash of celluloid glamour is at the root of the discord.

A tiny Scottish fishing village has found itself split over plans to film yet another TV series on its only street. In the majority camp lie those desperate to see a share of the £25m that is splashed into Scotland by deep-pocketed production companies each year, and in the other lie those who are fed up having to dodge boom microphones and coach loads of tourists on the way to the pub each weekend evening.

On the surface, at least, it is the familiar fable of the lure of Mammon versus the desire to protect a fragile rural lifestyle; and, in an irony hardly lost on the villagers, it is a big-screen depiction of this very tale that caused all the problems in the first place.

Before Burt Lancaster and his entourage flew in to film Local Hero, a movie about a Texan oil magnate trying to buy over a small village, Pennan was just another pretty fishing village in the north east of Scotland.

But the worldwide exposure given to the white-washed cottages and red phone box still brings thousands of tourists each year to its remote setting.

Although the volume of sightseers has dwindled over the past 18 years - they tend now to come in national clusters dictated by where the film is being revived - their number was replenished last year when the BBC filmed its All Along the Watchtower series there.

The corporation had wanted to exploit Pennan's charms once more in its new 2000 Acres on Skye drama, starring former EastEnder Michelle Collins. The village laird, Julia Watt, however, was having none of it.

As the villagers set about organising a public meeting to discuss the production company's proposals, Mrs Watt contacted the owners of all 37 homes. She said there was an overwhelming majority against more filming in Pennan, though she refuses to make the exact result public.

Brenda Kutchinsky, owner of the Pennan Inn and leader of the pro-faction, was not impressed with Mrs Watt's poll, so she organised a meeting in the village hall - it ended with a motion, passed 50-9, calling for the filming to go ahead.

Rather than resolve the question it has instead led to battle lines drawn.

Mrs Watt, who was not at the meeting, has refused to accept its result. Her husband bought the archaic feudal rights to Pennan in 1948 and, as feudal superior, she can make life very difficult for Zenith, the production company.

With both sides deadlocked, Ms Kutchinsky called in Alex Salmond, the local MP.

Mr Salmond suggested a referendum. "I think that's the only way to prevent ill-feeling from forming," he said. But resentment is already beginning to stain.

"The production company said they would bring £3.5m over three years, we can't turn that down," said Ms Kutchinsky. "But it's not just about money. There are only 18 year-round residents in Pennan.

"The place is dying. If people see how beautiful it is on the telly, they may think they want to give up the rat race and come here. We want to attract more people to live in Pennan."

Mrs Watt, however, believes filming will have the opposite effect. "It causes so much disruption, it is not good for the village," she said. "People do not like to live with all this chaos and they leave."

The referendum is still going ahead and will be supervised by an academic from Aberdeen University. Interested parties - from the harbour master to overseas owners in Oman - are all to be given a vote.

But, no matter the result, the pro-filming faction has two more problems to counter.

Mrs Watt told the Guardian yesterday that she was unsure if she would accept the results of the referendum and, even if she does, time is running out for the villagers: Zenith wants to begin filming in the summer and alternative locations are already being sought.

fields.headline: The waiting game
fields.standfirst:
It is time to open up the euro debate

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The drumbeat is getting louder. Yesterday's announcement of 1,430 job losses by Corus, the company that used to be British Steel, augmented it. Both management and unions there blamed steel's export problems on the strong pound - insisting that things would be easier if Britain joined the single currency.
fields.body:
The drumbeat is getting louder. Yesterday's announcement of 1,430 job losses by Corus, the company that used to be British Steel, augmented it. Both management and unions there blamed steel's export problems on the strong pound - insisting that things would be easier if Britain joined the single currency. The engineers' leader, Sir Ken Jackson, said the high value of sterling was destroying large chunks of British industry. Another Blair favourite, Paddy Ashdown (now Sir Paddy: congratulations) complained that "the country is being left leaderless" on the issue.

And that is only outside the cabinet. Inside there is a split, too. Stephen Byers, Peter Mandelson and Robin Cook want to champion the euro now; Gordon Brown wants to wait till the time is ripe. That difference came to a dramatic head on Thursday when Foreign Office staff cackhandedly distributed a text of a speech Mr Cook was due to make, including several paragraphs the foreign secretary did not then utter, all of them favouring the euro. This enabled the Tory front bench to cast Mr Brown as the wielder of the blue pencil - the monetary union sceptic editing the words of his cabinet colleagues.

As a matter of basic presentational politics, this is bad news for the government. As Michael Portillo gloatingly reminded us yesterday, it was precisely these sorts of visible cabinet divisions which did for the Tories three years ago. Of course things have not yet reached that point for Labour. The prime minister may be deluding himself to describe (as he does privately) the current disagreements as merely a "slight nuance" between colleagues, but nor are they the doctrinal blood feud they were in the last Conservative administration.

The disagreement within Labour is not between those who love the euro and want to join it tomorrow and those who hate it and wish it never to darken our shores. Rather, one camp thinks Labour should start the selling mission now and another wants to wait. The first argues that with 70% of the nation hostile to the euro, according to Mori, the government has its work cut out. To win a national ballot in, say, three years' time would require intense spadework now. That is the Cook-Byers-Mandelson position (though grumpy Treasury officials wonder if the Northern Ireland secretary would prefer to enter straight away, whatever the economics). The Brownite view is that winning the referendum is not the finishing post: rather it is just the beginning of the process. They imagine that slamming the foot on the accelerator now might see Britain vote to join the euro only to experience drastic economic turbulence once we got in. Better to wait and get it right, so that we join and fit, than rush in as a quick-fix, discover that we are not in sync - and then scramble to get out. That kind of repeat of the ERM performance would cast a cloud, say the Brownites, over Britain's relations with Europe not for a year or two, but for decades. They want to wait for Mr Brown's famous five tests to be met and then make the case.

These are arguments worth having - which is all the more reason why they ought to be heard in public. The debate does not have to wait for the passing of the five tests; there can, for example, be a national discussion now over the premise of Labour policy that the euro is right in principle. Officially, all ministers agree on this, even if they disagree on timing. Why then not talk about it? The electorate is grown up enough to understand that this is the biggest decision the country will face in a generation. We are ready to discuss it out loud.

webTitle: Cook vows to fight on for euro

fields.headline: Cook vows to fight on for euro
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, is to spearhead a pro-euro fightback against Gordon Brown after the chancellor attempted to silence cabinet critics of his lukewarm stance on the single currency.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, is to spearhead a pro-euro fightback against Gordon Brown after the chancellor attempted to silence cabinet critics of his lukewarm stance on the single currency.

Angered by the chancellor's declaration in his Mansion House speech on Thursday that he was "guardian" of the government's policy on the single currency, the cabinet's pro-euro camp is to deliver a series of speeches that will unashamedly beat the drum for the single currency.

One Labour source underlined the growing cabinet rift over the euro by saying that Mr Cook would never be silenced by the chancellor. "People are quite mistaken if they think that Robin Cook is not going to speak up," the source said.

As Downing Street sought to play down talk of splits - stressing that the government was united over its euro policy laying down five key economic tests for entry and that Mr Cook was "an able and respected member of the cabinet" - a senior government source highlighted the irritation with the chancellor among some in the cabinet by describing his speech as a disappointing attempt to "isolate and humiliate" the foreign secretary.

The pro-euro camp was infuriated when it emerged that Mr Cook was forced to abandon four key passages of a Commons speech on Thursday, which were strongly in favour of the single currency. Mr Brown yesterday denied having censored the speech, while - as the finger was pointed at Downing Street - the foreign secretary told Radio 4's Today programme that he stood firmly by the remarks dropped from the text.

The senior Labour source said that Mr Cook had made such comments before, including a warning that Britain could soon be the only EU country outside the euro, and would continue to speak in such forthright terms. "Robin is not going to be deflected from saying what he believes. He will continue to do that in speeches and in interviews."

A senior government source said that the pro-euro camp was confident that it had the support of the prime minister to speak out in favour of the single currency. "Tony Blair sees the need to make a strong case for the euro," the source said. "We have to speak up if public opinion is to be kept from sliding over the edge."

However, the source accused Mr Brown of destroying any chance of achieving cabinet unity over the single currency. "Gordon Brown has got himself into the ridiculous position of believing that if ministers are positive about the euro that means they are being negative about him.

"The Treasury is also attempting to undermine Cook, [Peter] Mandelson and [Stephen] Byers by claiming that they want to accelerate British membership. No one is suggesting that for a moment."

While Mr Brown has provoked fury in some quarters with his territorial approach to euro policy, some pro-euro ministers argue that his Mansion House speech - while stressing an unchanged policy on the single currency - in fact contained some of the chancellor's most positive remarks about the euro since he first set out the government's stance in autumn 1997.

Mr Byers, who as trade and industry secretary is under pressure from business claims that manufacturing industry is vulnerable to currency fluctuations as long as Britain remains outside the euro, is understood to have welcomed references to the benefits of a successful single currency, including currency stability and the potential for "more proactive investment in Britain".

The trade secretary is now expected to reassure business that the speech contained the confirmation it sought that a referendum on the euro will take place early in a second Labour term, rather than dragging out until the end.

Few, however, believe that the government can suppress dissent over the euro until and beyond a general election, probably less than a year away. Mr Blair yesterday received further warning that, without a clear lead over the single currency, he was vulnerable to accusations of vacillation and weakness.

The former Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown, who remains close to the prime minister after returning to the backbenches, said Mr Blair was in "exactly the same danger as John Major" over divisions on Europe. He told Radio 4's The World at One: "This country is being left leaderless. This is the biggest decision the country has to take."

webTitle: Quench your thirst for a career

fields.headline: Quench your thirst for a career
fields.standfirst: Jobs on tap at Manchester fair
fields.trailText: Boddington drinkers won't need any incentive to take a trip to the home of their favourite brew, but job seekers should also consider a trip to Manchester this weekend for a graduate fair with one of the highest scores in the exhibitor league.
fields.body:
Boddington drinkers won't need any incentive to take a trip to the home of their favourite brew, but job seekers should also consider a trip to Manchester this weekend for a graduate fair with one of the highest scores in the exhibitor league.

This two-day thrash in the Armitage Centre at the Firs Athletic ground has its own unique selling proposition in that different companies set out their stalls on each day of the event. This means you have choice - and lots of it.

It's also worth knowing that exhibitors can't book space unless they have real jobs tucked in their portfolios, possibly waiting for you.

Manchester University's employment liaison officer Jan Hewitt says that even professional bodies who book space have vacancy lists of jobs in member companies.

Some 180 employers are lined up and they cover a huge range of job opportunities from management consultancy to health clubs with software companies and the Lancashire Constabulary in between.

"There is something for everyone," says Hewitt.

Manchester University's own statistics show that business studies students, science and computing science students have scored best at its graduate fair but percentages in other disciplines have been pretty respectable too.

An unusual feature, says Hewitt, is that last year the number of people already in jobs but looking for a second opportunity by coming to their graduate fair suddenly shot up from 8% or 9% to 19%.

"We don't know the reason why this happened, and we don't know how successful they were in finding employment," explains Hewitt. "But we want to stress that the fair is for first job applicants."

So don't let the thought of all those down-in-the-mouth second time arounders put you off - employers are looking for fresh blood and sparkling new degree certificates, which puts you in pole position.

Graduates from any university are entitled to pitch up at any fair, Hewitt stresses. And while there is a small core of employers who set up stands at all the fairs, each venue has a different flavour.

Variety is Manchester's theme - because of the two-day mix - with large national and international conglomerates, small companies and companies local to the north west. Some will want people with a specific degree but others will be looking for a certain type of person regardless of the subject they studied.

So what's your part in all this? Turn up, smartly dressed and well-briefed about the employers you are interested in - use the website to find out who is exhibiting. Manchester has created a virtual fair on its website so that you can go in ahead of the game and check out the companies in greater detail.

"Make your visit worthwhile," advises Hewitt. "The employers will want to know about you, so you need to be armed with copies of your CV or a standard application form which you can hand in.

"You may, in some cases, find yourself being interviewed on the spot and yes, occasionally jobs are actually offered on the day, although usually you will get called back for another interview at the company's own offices."

There could be queues at the more popular stands which means you will only have a few minutes to sell yourself and this is where your research can help you hit paydirt.

There are a few useful extras at the Manchester fair - seminars giving tips on how to fill in your application forms, tips on going for interviews and job search methods. For individual advice you can ask one of the professional careers advisers who will also be available.

Entry to the fair is free as is the Fair Guide listing all companies and the goodies on offer. Further freebies include a private bus service from the Piccadilly railway station and from Oxford Road railway station to the Firs ground and free parking at the venue.

Exhibitors on the first day include: Andersen Consulting, Egg, Enterprise Rent-a-Car, Ernst and Young, Halifax, Harcourt Publishers, Sun Microsystems, Blackburn with Darwen Borough Council Social Services Department, Marconi, Lancashire Constabulary and Toys R Us.

On day two you will find, among others: The College of Law, Carphone

Warehouse, CanDo for disabled students and graduates, Direct Line, Embedded Solutions, Scottish Power, HM Prison Service, McDonald's, Pink Elephant UK,

Majestic Wine Warehouses and IBM.

Want to know more?

Organisers:University of Manchester and UMIST.

Dates: June 21 and 22.

Times:10am to 4pm

Venue: Armitage Centre Firs Athletic ground

Website: www.netwise.ac.uk

fields.headline: Top rung/ Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Sharon Reed and Michael Davies present the view from either end of the career ladder at Post-production company Framestore
fields.body:
Sharon Reed Aged 44 Chief executive FrameStore

The amazing special effects used in the TV series Walking With Dinosaurs has earned post-production company FrameStore an international reputation. "It was a big hit here and earned the biggest cable audience ever in the US," says Sharon Reed. "It has put British creature animation on the map."

Sharon was a founder member of FrameStore in 1986 - that year it turned over £750,000. Last year this figure has shot to near £20m.

CV to date: History degree (Manchester) was followed by various stints; armed with secretarial training she joined Robert Maxwell's print-and-publishing BPPC, where she became part of a video company start-up.

"At that point I learned selling skills and the video business. I preferred this environment to the print trade as it was more woman-friendly," she explains. A few years on, she and a few colleagues got financial backing and FrameStore was created.

Facts and stats: FrameStore employs 135 people and produces visual effects for TV, films and commercials.

The buzz? "Working with technology and, of course, seeing audiences respond to the pictures."

Must-have qualities: "Graduates must be able to show initiative."

Michael Davis Aged 24 Production co-ordinator FrameStore

Michael Davis always wanted a career in film production: "right from work experience at Shepperton Studios, through to A levels and my degree," he says.

Michael graduated in media arts (Portsmouth) and, after a few fill-in jobs, was taken on by FrameStore as a 'runner' - which means learning the basics by doing everything from tea making to responsible technical tasks. "My job was to be a library runner delivering tapes."

He became a production co-ordinator in 1998. "You act as a lynchpin in the production and post-production process. All shots are logged ready for post-production when special effects - such as 3-D - are added.

"I'm involved in long-form projects which last around six months." Films to date: Arabian Nights, Merlin, Alice in Wonderland and Gulliver's Travels.

Training and progress: On-the-job training ("FrameStore encourages you to find out where your strengths lie") with regular appraisals. Non-specialist and specialist (physics, maths and computer sciences) skills are sought.

fields.bodyText: Sharon Reed Aged 44 Chief executive FrameStore The amazing special effects used in the TV series Walking With Dinosaurs has earned post-production company FrameStore an international reputation. "It was a big hit here and earned the biggest cable audience ever in the US," says Sharon Reed. "It has put British creature animation on the map." Sharon was a founder member of FrameStore in 1986 - that year it turned over £750,000. Last year this figure has shot to near £20m. CV to date: History degree (Manchester) was followed by various stints; armed with secretarial training she joined Robert Maxwell's print-and-publishing BPPC, where she became part of a video company start-up. "At that point I learned selling skills and the video business. I preferred this environment to the print trade as it was more woman-friendly," she explains. A few years on, she and a few colleagues got financial backing and FrameStore was created. Facts and stats: FrameStore employs 135 people and produces visual effects for TV, films and commercials. The buzz? "Working with technology and, of course, seeing audiences respond to the pictures." Must-have qualities: "Graduates must be able to show initiative." webTitle: Sink or swim with an Oxbridge degree

fields.headline: Sink or swim with an Oxbridge degree
fields.standfirst: Rise  sticks its oar in to the Laura Spence affair
fields.trailText: Rise sticks its oar in to the Laura Spence affair
fields.body:
There are two facts that never cease to amaze me around this time of year. Not because they're particularly awesome in their own right, but because so few people seem to be aware of them. And because they're rarely examined side by side.

Fact number one.
A level grade for A level grade, you stand less chance of getting a first or a 2.1 at Oxford or Cambridge than at many other UK universities. In other words, an Oxbridge education doesn't add as much 'value' as a degree from a shiny new university or solid redbrick. Lucky old Laura Spence, then. Just as well she didn't get in.

Fact number two.
Degree result for degree result, you still stand a better chance of getting a certain class of job if you went to Oxbridge. We're not talking fast-stream Civil Service here - or even top-five accountancy firm. The former is now bound by political correctness and the latter by a numbers game. No, the recruiters who remain faithful to Oxbridge are the representatives on earth of big-bucks careers without necessarily a conscience or a quota: investment banking; the London Bar; management consultancy; top City solicitors. It's not so much that these opportunities are denied to you if you got your 2.1 from a redbrick, simply that your chances of getting the jobs are diminished by comparison with someone who 'just missed a first' from Oxbridge. And if you went to an ex-poly - why expose yourself to all that rejection?

Putting one and two together what do we conclude? Perhaps no one told those god-like graduate recruiters about fact number one. Or maybe they know something we mere mortals don't. Isn't it just possible that Oxbridge adds a different kind of value. And one that Laura Spence's much-maligned interviewer may have put his finger on when he dared to utter the "C" word. Could the apparent gap between the two facts be filled by 'confidence'?

Let's give the still-smouldering Laura Spence story a little sequel. Assume for the sake of argument that she did get into Oxford after all, arriving next October with high hopes, her auntie's biggest suitcase and a new toaster. In the porter's lodge, she unwittingly smiles at her new tutorial partner.

He's pushing a little trolley laden with a battered trunk, several sleek pot plants and a large number of alien electrical appliances. His stout leather shoes make a curious clicking noise that somehow reassures the new girl. It reminds her of the sound of stilettos on a Saturday night, outside the clubs back home.

As the first year wears on, though, his presence reassures her less and less. The ex-public schoolboy seems to do little work and yet breezes through their weekly sessions with the don. He asks questions designed to flaunt his knowledge, nods earnestly in the right places, makes eye contact. The comprehensive kid, on the other, spends more and more time in her room, puzzling over why she can't achieve the successes of the past.

In tutorials, she mumbles into her A4 offerings and dares not ask questions about the things she doesn't understand, for fear of looking stupid. As summer finally comes, she succumbs to the vicious spiral of sinking confidence and thinks of giving up. Her tutor suggests that maybe she wasn't suited to university after all.

Of course, this isn't how it would have turned out for Laura. But it's exactly what happened to me - longer ago than I care to remember and still painful after all these years. The story has a happy ending, well, at least a happy middle. I managed to start again in the same college with a different subject and rode the confidence roller-coaster with relative success over the next few years.

Perhaps I'd just learnt how to play the game. Or, maybe, I restarted my degree in a class of students whose confidence levels were even lower than mine. Whatever. You don't ask questions when you're a high-grade junkie.

I wasn't confident enough to apply to an investment bank though, let alone blag my way through the interview. (In truth, I'd never even heard of investment banks until my public school-educated colleagues started getting jobs with them.)

And now, 13 years on I look around at the people I'm still in touch with and what do I see? Those who went to state schools are academics, teachers, scientists, trade journalists, maybe accountants if they're lucky. Those educated in the independent sector have generally reached much loftier heights in terms of salary and status. But is my small sample representative? Is it even surprising?

This time around, I'm brave enough to call the careers service for the answer to my careers question. If 53% of Oxford places are offered to state-school pupils, does that mean they also get 53% of the top-paying milkround offers? The patient careers adviser explains that they don't collect that data. They know roughly where people go, but they don't know where they come from in the first place. He does suggest, however, that 'career success' has more to do with personality type than social background.

I agree with him up to a point (that was always my problem with careers advisers). I can't help feeling that the personality trait in question is confidence, but that it does depend very much - if not on social background - on education. The more you have when you arrive at Oxbridge, the more you accumulate. The more you accumulate, the better you'll do at interview, no matter how humble or how exalted the graduate job in question (and to some extent regardless of your ability to do the job).

The only problem is that students from state schools often arrive at Oxbridge with a low confidence quotient. As one friend puts it: "You don't speak up in comprehensive for fear of getting punched in the face after class." Your confidence can tumble yet further at Oxbridge, resulting in a poorer degree than you deserve and a not-so-happy graduate recruitment ending.

And graduate recruitment is really just the beginning. In ten years' time you could find yourself PA to your old tutorial partner. Take it from me, it'll be too late then to say "Please mister, can I have my balls back?" Learn the confidence trick, while you've still got a chance.

webTitle: Write the CV that portrays you as absolutely fabulous

fields.headline: Write the CV that portrays you as absolutely fabulous
fields.standfirst: It's step two in our graduate starter series
fields.trailText: It's step two in our graduate starter series
fields.body:
A CV, no matter how good, will not get you a job by itself. However, a good CV will attract the attention of the recruiter and, at the very least, secure you an interview. The purpose of a CV is to reveal your accomplishments and qualifications to a potential employer. And of they like what they see, they'll soon be in touch for a face-to face-meeting.

Think of your CV as a promotional brochure about you. You need to show a potential employer what you have achieved so far and where your knowlegde, skills and any relevant experience lies. Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to emphasise the skills and attributes that a particular employer is looking for.

But your CV is also a written example of your communication and organisational skills. A well done CV is a marker of what kind of valuable employee you would be. Likewise, a sloppily-produced CV is the best way to remove yourself from the running before the race even starts.

There's no shortage of books and websites on CVs and CV writing - some of them contradictory, but most of them useful. A fiver on a good CV book will be money very well spent if it teaches you the fundamentals of CV writing.

But try to stay in touch with current thinking in CVs too as CV advice follows trends. The web is home to plenty of free advice and information - much of it is written in the Unitied States, but can be a useful predictor of CV fashion.

With so many different occupations, professions and sectors open to graduates, there isn't a single CV template that works for everyone. There are, however, generally accepted ways to arrange the information on your CV to present it in the best light.

The two styles that you'll come across most often are the 'chronological format' and the 'functional format'. Both have their own advantages and disadvantages when it comes to presenting your information. A third style, the 'combination', is a compromise between the two and has become more popular in recent years.

1. Chronological

This is the most common CV style because it's the one that most employers prefer. In the chronological format, the emphasis is placed on education and employment experience. The applicant's school, university and job history is presented in reverse chronological order, with the most recent placed at the top of the list.

The chronological CV is good if your recent qualifications and experience are relevant to the job. Potential employers can easily see what you have done, and how you have progressed and garnered relevant skills and knowledge.

Despite its popularity, there are some reasons why the chronological format may not be right for you. If you are just entering the workforce from university and have little track record of part-time or summer working, a CV like this may actually highlight your lack of experience. Alternatively, you may have held summer jobs recently that have no relevance to the position you're applying for. If you are re-entering the workforce after a couple of years bumming around, this kind of CV can also highlight your recent inactivity. Any large gaps in your 'learning' history will be evident, and you may be asked about them.

2. Functional

In this non-linear format, your skills and achievements are emphasised. Your employment history is summarized or avoided all together. Your skills and previous relevant experience (including educational experience) are presented at the beginning of your CV. They are organised so the employer can see how your skills relate to the job position you are applying for. (In a chronological CV, employers may simply be looking at any jobs you have held previously to see if you have the experience they are looking for.) It may take more effort to write a functional CV, but you are free to highlight your talents instead of your recent job experience.

The functional CV can be particularly effective if your education and working experiences have been in a similar vein; it will allow you to highlight your skills rather than itemise what might look like a one-dimension history.

But the functional CV may also raise concerns in some employers' minds as to whether you are withholding information. This doesn't mean that functional CVs are ignored or that they can't be effective. But an employer looking for a clear history may be put off by the functional format, especially if you've used it to hide your inexperience or a long period of 'time out'.

If you don't have any problems with the reverse chronological format, use it instead. If you still like the idea of the functional format, you may want to make it more acceptable by combining it with the chronological format and creating a combination CV.

3. Combination

The combination CV is simply a functional CV with a brief employment history added. Skills and accomplishments are still listed first; the employment history follows. You need to reveal where you worked, when you worked, and what your job position was. This will allay an employer's worries about your experience, and it still allows you to emphasise your talents and how you would use them for the job you are applying for. While most employers might still prefer a chronological CV, this is a good alternative to the functional CV.

Whatever style you choose, keep it concise. Employers have lots to do, so don't make the mistake of asking them to read through an unnecessarily long CV. A long, wordy CV will put off someone who is already short on time. CVs should be one page, if possible, and two if absolutely necessary to describe relevant work experience.

A two page CV is no advantage if it's full of information that isn't reasonably applicable to the position you're applying for. Use the space only if you need it to fully describe your accomplishments.

Make every word count. Your use of language is extremely important and ensure the CV addresses your potential employer's needs.

Email your way to the top jobs on the internet

An electronic CV is simply your CV in a format that can be sent via email or the internet. The advantage to having an electronic CV is simple - you can respond instantly to job openings posted all over the world. No need for faxing or queuing at the post office.

If your CV is on a PC hard disk, floppy or CD, you already have it in electronic format; but that's not to say it's in the most useful format. While it's true that most email systems can accommodate document attachments - be they in Word, WordPerfect, Quark or otherwise - it won't be true that every person or organisation to whom you'd like to send your CV is willing or able to receive it in that format. Plain text (also called ASCII text or MS-DOS text and recognised by its three letter file extension '.txt'), however, is universally accessible and, in many cases, required.

To make your electronic CV as readable as possible, follow these simple steps:

 Using a standard word processing application, compose a CV as you would normally. Note that plain text format is very basic - it won't recognise fancy formatting such as bullets, bold facing or italicised text. So consider using asterisks (*), plus symbols (+) and capital letters to achieve similar effects. In any case, make sure your CV is legible in the absence of these formatting features.
 If the word processing application permits, set your margins at 0 and 65 characters. This means that your longest line, including spaces, exceeds 65 characters before wrapping to a new line. This will make your CV easier to read and, just as importantly, safe to print.
 Using the 'Save' command (or, if you're converting a document from another format, the 'Save as...' command), save your document as an ASCII or MS-DOS text document. Remember to add the .txt extension on to the file name, for example 'CV.txt'

When sending an electronic CV, remember to:

 Include a covering letter, remembering to mention where you found the advertisement.
 Send the CV and covering letter in one file. You can do this by writing or pasting your covering letter in the space before your CV. You can also send your covering letter as an email message with your electronic CV as a file attachment.
 Use the job title and/or job reference number as the subject of your message. Cite any relevant job numbers noted in the ad.
 Follow up with an email or phone call a week or so after you submit it.

Even if you are submitting your CV in hard copy form, bear in mind that it might be processed by electronic scanning equipment. More employers are using scanning software to sift through large volumes of applications.

Tips for writing a scannable CV include:

 Using simple fonts, such as Helvetica at point sizes of between 10 and 14.
 Avoiding italics, script, and underlining.
 Using bold face type sparingly.
 Finding an ink jet or laser printer for optimal printing quality.
 Avoiding abbreviations.
 Always using white paper.
 Never folding your CV in order to send it. Use an A4 envelope instead.

fields.trailText:
• Pass masters:
Don't like your degree grade? Sue for a better one. The new law could apply to all university hearings involving student matters.

 Pass masters:

Legal eagles are claiming that under the new Human Rights Act which becomes effective in October, universities could be taken to court by students unhappy with their marks. The new law could apply to all university hearings involving student matters.

 Book of the week:
If Euro 2000 has whetted your appetite for foreign shores, Jonathan Packer's guide to finding a job abroad is a useful jumping off point. Packed within tips on visa-hunting and settling into different cultures, Living and Working Abroad (Staightforward) is available at the special price of £6.99 (plus p&p) from our Cultureshop on 0800 316 6102.

 Feet in mouth:
First impressions are crucial and among the howlers uncovered by a US survey were candidates who: brought lunch and ate it during the interview; flirted with the recruiter; responded "I don't know" to every question; said the recruiter was "a fool" for not hiring him; put his feet up on the interview table and talked about adult entertainment.

 Our survey said:
We'd like a little more money - but don't give us too much! Almost three quarters of the 1,000 people polled in an NOP survey for the New Economics Foundation said they would rather have a pay rise than more holidays from work. Yet a majority of respondents said they would prefer to be remembered as kind than as rich and successful.

 Magazine of the week:
Woolly hats off to Real World for putting Ali G through the application process for a graduate trainee scheme. Among the achievements listed on his CV: "To increase the peace in Northern Ireland I tried to get the Orange boys to get with the drum 'n bass for their marches. fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No 35 Elida Fabergé
fields.trailText: No 35 Elida Fabergé
fields.body:
Open any bathroom cabinet in the land and you're sure to find at least one product in the vast Elida Fabergé range. Britain's top personal care products company, it is home to key global brands like Sure, Lynx, Dove, Organics, Impulse, Vaseline, Physio Sport and Timotei.

Elida Fabergé is the health and beauty products offshoot of the Anglo-Dutch corporation Unilever, one of the world's largest consumer goods companies, serving local markets in almost every country.

Its subsidiary is the 'European Innovation Centre' for deodorants and grooming, accounting for more than half of the total market in the UK. Each of its brands falls into one of six major categories: deodorants, skin cleansing, skincare, male toiletries, haircare and dental.

According to Elida Fabergé, the corporate vision is to make a real difference to how people look and feel, constantly seeking to deliver the "wow" effect to those who use its healthcare products. The corporate culture - which is young, vibrant and open with a passion for winning - is fostered through an enterprise culture where new ideas are given the head and leg-room to grow.

The company is truly committed to unleashing the imagination, individuality, initiative and energy of all its employees. Senior executives recognise that management is more about leading creative people than about setting a bunch of business goals. It also means that people with the right skills, talent and mindset can enjoy themselves at work.

This year, the company launched an employee initiative aimed at creating competitive advantage. The scheme involves working with the arts world, bringing a different and refreshing perspective into business solutions. The scope of the programme includes creative-writing workshops, theatre-based communication, a modern art collection in the building and corporate membership of visual and performing arts.

Graduates are recruited for Elida Fabergé through Unilever's central recruitment process. The Unilever Companies Management Development Scheme (UCMDS) is one of the most highly-regarded training programmes in the country. During the two-year programme, trainees experience several different functions within the business and learn from hands-on experience as well as through skills training and personal development.

Graduates are not selected on academic ability alone - demonstration of drive and energy, proven ability to work in a team and a passion for business are equally important.

 For more information on the UCMDS and an application form, visit its website: www.ucmds.com or call the recruitment hotline on 0541 543550.

webTitle: How to... get through your first day in the job

fields.headline: How to... get through your first day in the job
fields.standfirst: It won't be has bad as your first day at school - it'll be worse
fields.trailText: It won't be has bad as your first day at school - it'll be worse
fields.body:
Just graduated? Time to take off that cap and gown and slip into something a little less comfortable... a new graduate job. Last time you felt like this, your mum was waving you goodbye from the school gates. Don't panic. Here is (just about) everything you need to know to get you through your first day at work.

Your first day will be miserable
You'll stick out like a sore thumb. You'll be the only person wearing a brand new suit with the price tag still hanging from the back. Nobody will show you where the loos are. And when you try to find the loos, you'll walk in on the managing director's most important annual meeting.

Nobody will teach you how to use office computer systems or tell you where the photocopy paper is kept. You'll be screamed at for crashing the central server.

The paper you find will jam the photocopier. You'll be escorted round the office and introduced to at least 500 people. You'll instantly forget the names of all five hundred people ... but, without exception, they'll remember yours.

You'll either be thrown in at the deep end, which will be terrifying, or you'll have absolutely nothing to do (in which case, you'll have to go through it all again tomorrow).

People will treat you like a grown-up

One day you're a 'juvenile' student, taking exams, drinking pints and snogging in the union bar - the next you're a certified "adult" employee.

It's a curious phenomenon, but if you wear a suit and carry a business card people will take you seriously. Your company's clients will want to shake your hand, take you to expensive restaurants and offer to buy you fine wines in plush wine bars.

Suddenly, you'll understand what your gran meant when she said: "I'm 85, you know, but I don't feel a day over 18". Only 15-year olds actually want to be grown-ups.

Accept it - it won't get any better (you'll just get older). Humour people who mistakenly treat you like an adult by smiling sweetly, acting responsibly and referring to share reports in the Financial Times. Then go home, play air guitar, eat pot noodles and trash your living room.

Your boss will be schizophrenic

You thought your boss really liked you. After all, he/she sent you nice letters saying: "I'm delighted to offer you the job" and told you you'd be an asset to their company. Heck, they wanted to work with you so much they even offered you money!

So why, after just a few days, has the person who championed you turned into a morose, petty taskmaster with about as much tact as Liam Gallagher? He/she is human, that's why. "We're all on our best behaviour in interviews," says the Edinburgh-based chartered psychologist Ben Williams. "But even bosses have bad moods and off days. None of us is perfect. You've got to learn to make allowances."

If your boss really is Liam Gallagher, check into the Priory at once.

You're a nobody

So, you've got three A levels. So, you've got a first class degree. That don't impress me much. Qualifications are just a means to an end. Anyone who told you otherwise was lying. The only way to become somebody at work is to prove you're a brilliant team-player and a hard worker. Never blow your own trumpet (or anyone else's, unless you're at the office Christmas party).

You won't have any friends

Then again, you won't have enemies either. Don't worry, there's plenty of time to acquire both ... and you will.

Working with those who resent you

In some industries, graduate trainees are about as popular as an outbreak of legionnaires' disease. "People who've climbed the career ladder are suspicious of graduates," says Williams. "As far as they're concerned, you're a fast tracker with no experience who has skipped the queue." Don't try to argue.

... and you'll have to get on with them

"You're a small minnow in a large ocean and the world doesn't revolve around you," says Williams. "Remember your manners at all times and demonstrate a concern for other people, not just the managing director. This includes the office receptionist, the people wearing dirty overalls and the tea lady. Never, ever be snobbish."

You'll have to set your goals

Until now, your life has been a series of goals, with exams - GCSEs, A levels and finals - the goal posts. Unless you're entering a career which requires professional qualifications (like accountancy), your days of revising, popping pro-plus and wrist-strain are over. Hooray.

The only problem is, if you want to progress and develop you'll have to set out your own aims and objectives (just getting through each day doesn't count).

No long summmer vacations

July to October will never be the same again. If you don't like it, become a teacher.

You're bound to fail

It's the hardest lesson of all for high achievers. "Learn from your failures," says Williams. "Your career won't be all smooth-sailing, but that's how you develop."

There's no escape

Face it, a real job isn't like a holiday job. There are only two ways to leave - get another job or get the sack. You might feel like you're trapped in an episode of The Prisoner , but that's working life. Make the most of it.

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to being a conference delegate
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to being a conference delegate
fields.body:
A. Paper engineering

Conferences have so many uses that it's worth putting effort into finding one your employer could be persuaded to send you to. It provides sanctioned time off work and the status of chosen one for a short period, which gives you instant credibility with strangers. You are all there because you're of value. International conferences have more clout than home-based ones. Aim for any impressive enough to add to your CV.

B. Go for gold

Olympic ideals apply. It's not too important to add to the store of human performance - just attending is enough. The surest way to get noticed is through a 'look at me' question. Asking for clarification is a waste of the limelight; you need to display an insider's knowledge of the jargon or hint at understanding that surpasses that of the presenter. The longer, more involved your question the likelier it is that everyone will lose the plot but be afraid to act other than impressed.

C. The common good

As all delegates share a common expertise and curiosity combined with some self interest, conferences can provide shortcuts to making the right sort of contacts. Make sure any badge you wear and business cards you distribute

reflect future aspirations rather than past achievements. Addressing speakers by their first name should fool most of the audience into thinking you have a working relationship.

webTitle: Help: My talents are being wasted here!

fields.headline: Help: My talents are being wasted here!
fields.standfirst: I feel underused at work. The things I'm asked to do are so basic I'll never get the chance to show what I'm capable of.  Tess D, scientific officer, Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: Everything you do, no matter how menial, is an indication of your potential. You just have to find ways of showcasing it. The mistake many who feel understretched make is to put no thought or effort into tasks they considern beneath them.
fields.body:
Everything you do, no matter how menial, is an indication of your potential. You just have to find ways of showcasing it. The mistake many who feel understretched make is to put no thought or effort into tasks they considern beneath them.

In a perfect world, managers would be sensitive to the fact that sloppy work is often the result of resentment bred by under-use of talents and immediately find you something more stimulating to do. In reality, all they see is poor results and construct their impressions of you accordingly.

Get noticed for inserting something into your work by putting care into its presentation or taking time to discuss ways of extending the scope of projects. Much better to have others thinking "she's too good for this job" rather than "she thinks she's too good".

You can only wait so long for others to provide the stimulus and opportunities you need. Make things happen for yourself. Suggest an enhancement to an assignment or show interest in a training event you've not been nominated for.

Request a mentor to guide your career development. Do something in your own time that will add to your credibility. Don't waste energy on feeling misunderstood. Turn people on to your abilities rather than turning them off with an aura of resentment.

ijk@excite.com

webTitle: Mind tests which can damage your wealth

fields.headline: Mind tests which can damage your wealth
fields.standfirst: Not every applicant likes the role of lab rat
fields.trailText: Not every applicant likes the role of lab rat
fields.body:
Job interviews, as we all know, are a bit of a game. You, the wannabe employee, turn up on time in your best clothes, answer any questions in a confident yet relaxed manner and laugh - but not too hard - when the interviewer cracks a joke. Hopefully, your performance as an intelligent, hardworking individual is so convincing that the company takes you on.

It's disconcerting, then, to go for an interview only to find they want to look behind your carefully- constructed façade to discover what you're really like.

Many employers now use psychometric testing to assess the personalities of potential employees. There are several kinds of test but in most cases candidates have to answer questions on their preferences and interests which are supposed to reveal their aptitudes and how they get on with colleagues.

Understandably, many people are wary of being exposed in this way. Sam Bruce had completed her MA in investigative journalism when she applied for a job as a reporter on her local newspaper in the Midlands. At the interview, she was asked to complete a psychometric test.

"I have a real suspicion of these tests because I don't like being pigeon-holed," she explains, "but I went along with it. I found the questions way too simplistic. There were things like, 'Do you like being with people? - all the time, some of the time or hardly ever?' It was difficult to answer because I'm different at different times."

Bruce didn't get the job and when she received the test results, she was gobsmacked. "It wasn't flattering," she says. "I was described as decisive, aggressive and impatient, among other things. It seemed to be about someone who wouldn't be able to work with other people but I work hard to get on with people. Ironically, I'd applied for the job because I didn't want to work on my own."

Disillusioned and frustrated, she sought help from a professional careers adviser who also used psychometric testing. This time, it was a more positive experience. "I was given a different test which had been designed for professional, highly-educated people," she says. "I was also given a motivational test and asked to trace the course of my life so far.

"The consultant talked about the findings in depth and gave me a lot of useful insights. He confirmed, for example, that I couldn't work alone and that I'm motivated by a need for social change. I came out of it with a new sense of direction."

One of the suggestions made by the consultant was that Bruce might be suited to working in the voluntary sector. She now works as a co-ordinator for community advice centres in the Midlands and enjoys her job.

Sam's experience is a common scenario, says Sophie Rowan of consultancy Career Psychology. "Many people find psychometric testing very useful for careers advice but have had bad experiences with job interviews. The problem is that tests are often used in the wrong way. It can really knock someone's confidence.

"But there's no doubt that it's a valid way of assessing people if it's used in the right way," she continues, "but it should only be part of the whole interview process. You can't tell anything from just looking at someone's profile. Interviewers should spend at least fifteen minutes elaborating on the test results. Feedback is crucial.

"For example, we use psychometric testing here for careers advice," she points out. "We might see two people with identical backgrounds and test results and give them completely different suggestions. It depends on their priorities, their salary requirements and their aims. And a lot of big companies use psychometric testing for graduate recruitment," she adds. "People often find the feedback very useful, even if they don't get the job."

Ideally, says Rowan, you should be warned in advance that you will be tested at interview. The test should be one that is recognised by the British Psychological Society and you can check this by asking the name of the test.

But if you are given a test at interview, don't be tempted to fill in the answers you think the interviewer is looking for, she warns. If you're too perfect, they'll smell a rat. "But if you have to misrepresent yourself, is it really the job for you?" she asks. "If you try and fit the profile of their ideal candidate, there might be problems if you get the job because there could be things you won't be able to do."
