She now works as a co-ordinator for community advice centres in the Midlands and enjoys her job. Sam's experience is a common scenario, says Sophie Rowan of consultancy Career Psychology. "Many people find psychometric testing very useful for careers advice but have had bad experiences with job interviews. The problem is that tests are often used in the wrong way. It can really knock someone's confidence. "But there's no doubt that it's a valid way of assessing people if it's used in the right way," she continues, "but it should only be part of the whole interview process. You can't tell anything from just looking at someone's profile. Interviewers should spend at least fifteen minutes elaborating on the test results. Feedback is crucial. "For example, we use psychometric testing here for careers advice," she points out. "We might see two people with identical backgrounds and test results and give them completely different suggestions. It depends on their priorities, their salary requirements and their aims. And a lot of big companies use psychometric testing for graduate recruitment," she adds. "People often find the feedback very useful, even if they don't get the job." Ideally, says Rowan, you should be warned in advance that you will be tested at interview. The test should be one that is recognised by the British Psychological Society and you can check this by asking the name of the test. But if you are given a test at interview, don't be tempted to fill in the answers you think the interviewer is looking for, she warns. If you're too perfect, they'll smell a rat. "But if you have to misrepresent yourself, is it really the job for you?" she asks. "If you try and fit the profile of their ideal candidate, there might be problems if you get the job because there could be things you won't be able to do."

fields.headline: Petter Lindstrom
fields.standfirst: Brain surgeon whose refusal to divorce Ingrid Bergman enmeshed him in a Hollywood scandal
fields.trailText: Brain surgeon whose refusal to divorce Ingrid Bergman enmeshed him in a Hollywood scandal
fields.body:
In August 1949, headlines around the world revealed a scandal involving a beautiful Hollywood film star, her surgeon husband and her lover, a famous Italian film director.

It was a cause célèbre that whipped America into a moralistic frenzy, and the press heaped vituperation on Ingrid Bergman's head for ruthlessly abandoning her fine husband and defenceless 10-year-old daughter to run off to Italy to join the married Roberto Rossellini, whose child she was carrying. Most people reserved their sympathy for the wronged husband, Dr Petter Lindstrom, who has died aged 93.

The affair even reached Capitol Hill. There, on March 14 1950, Senator Edwin Johnson of Colorado delivered a vitriolic diatribe to the United States senate, denouncing Bergman for "an assault upon the institution of marriage". He considered her to be "one of the most powerful women on earth today - I regret to say, a powerful influence for evil".

In the moral climate of the time, to bear a child out of wedlock was unacceptable, though none of the fuss might have occurred if Lindstrom had granted Bergman a divorce when she asked for it. As for deserting her husband for another man, as Bergman herself reflected, divorces and remarriages in the film community were an everyday occurrence.

Why, then, was she forced to pay such a heavy price? Because, for the American public, the Swedish actress - who had recently played a nun in The Bells Of St Mary's and the heroine in Saint Joan - represented integrity, moral decency and family values, and they could not forgive her for betraying their faith in her perfection.

Bergman had met Lindstrom in Stockholm in 1933, shortly after her 18th birthday, when a cousin persuaded her to make up a foursome for a night out. The son of flower farmers, he was a handsome, hardworking dentist, and, to a naive girl like Bergman, the epitome of worldly sophistication. He was 25, and had dental and medical degrees from Heidelberg and Leipzig universities. He owned a car, was a fine sportsman and an excellent dancer, and had a good sense of humour. Highly intelligent, he was a model of old-fashioned moral virtues.

Three years later, after Bergman had created a stir in her sixth film, Intermezzo, the couple got married. In 1939, their daughter Pia was born, and Intermezzo was shown in New York. When producer David Selznick offered Bergman a Hollywood contract, Lindstrom encouraged her to go, he and Pia following a few months later.

Having settled in Beverly Hills, both Lindstrom's and Bergman's careers advanced. He moved from dentistry to lecturing in medicine, eventually becoming a renowned brain surgeon; she won her first Oscar, for Gaslight (1944). But Bergman was not happy.

For all Lindstrom's virtues, his dominating attitudes curtailed her sense of freedom. He was critical of her, and made her look and feel foolish and inhibited. He was also puritanically frugal, restricting her ability to enjoy the luxuries they could now afford. She suggested divorce, but he refused - and they settled back into a solid, but, for Bergman, emotionally unsatisfying existence.

One evening in 1948, the couple went to see Rossellini's neo-realist masterpiece, Rome: Open City. Bergman was shattered by it. After seeing his Paisa a few months later, she became obsessed with a desire to make a film with Rossellini. She even wrote him a fan letter. "I am ready," she said, "to come and make a film with you."

In 1948, when Bergman and Lindstrom met the Italian director in Paris for the first time, Rossellini suggested she should appear in Stromboli. Her husband was sceptical, but Bergman was carried away with the idea. Rossellini went to stay with the Lindstroms in Los Angeles for further discussions on the film, and it was after the shooting of Stromboli was completed that Bergman told Lindstrom she would not be returning.

There began a tormented and protracted correspondence between them, with Bergman begging for a divorce and contact with her daughter, and Lindstrom refusing both. In February 1950, a week after the birth of Robertino, her child with Rossellini, she obtained a Mexican divorce by proxy. Jean Renoir, a friend of both Bergman and Lindstrom, tried to help them and Pia through the emotional difficulties.

"It makes me so happy to hear that Petter is often with you," Bergman wrote to Renoir. "Take care of him. Maybe you, Jean, whose life, I'm sure, has been difficult, confusing and tossed like a shipwreck, maybe you can explain to Petter that sometimes people leave and they don't go back. The trouble is I don't feel sinful. I'm unhappy so that it almost breaks my heart for what Pia must go through, and also Petter, though he could have helped and finished this thing earlier."

It was not until 1957 that Bergman was reunited with Pia, by then 18, in Rome - and even that meeting was against Lindstrom's wishes. He remained bitter towards Bergman, and told her biographer, Laurence Leamer, that he regretted not telling the world years earlier of an Ingrid Bergman they did not know - a hard-drinking, heavy-smoking, promiscuous woman, who, according to Lindstrom, ignored her children and lived only to act.

Lindstrom taught medicine at the University of Pittsburgh and the University of Utah, and later practised in San Francisco and San Diego. In 1954, he married Dr Agnes Ronavec, who survives him, as does Pia, the four children of his second marriage, Karl, Peter, Michael and Brita, and eight grandchildren.

He was, recalled Brita, a wonderful man. But while Lindstrom achieved fame as a brain surgeon, sadly that never obliterated his reputation as one of the most celebrated of Hollywood cuckolds.

 Petter Lindstrom, brain surgeon, born March 1 1907; died May 24 2000

fields.headline: £4m teacher survey dismissed as waste
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday accused of squandering nearly £4m of taxpayers' money on a 10 month research programme which concluded that good teachers are those who set regular homework and plan lessons well.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday accused of squandering nearly £4m of taxpayers' money on a 10 month research programme which concluded that good teachers are those who set regular homework and plan lessons well.

Teaching unions joined forces with the Tories to protest that its "obvious" conclusions - published in a 234-page report yesterday - could have been learned from any classroom in the country and the money spent instead on teachers and pupils.

But the Department for Education and Employment defended the research, claiming it was the first of its kind to try to identify the characteristics which underpin good teaching.

Ministers want to use the findings to establish the skills teachers need at various stages in their career, as part of the drive to modernise and raise standards in the profession.

The new teaching standards will be part of the new continuing professional development strategy for teachers, running in parallel with the new system of performance-related pay being introduced this September.

The research was commissioned by the department from management consultants Hay McBer and involved detailed analysis of 172 teachers working in a cross-section of schools - in "leafy suburbs" as well as those in inner-cities. The department has refused to confirm or deny claims that the research cost £4m although sources have confirmed it is in excess of £3m. The report found that a combination of teaching skills, professional qualities and classroom 'atmosphere' were key to highly effective performance by teachers. The skills associated with outstanding primary teaching were high expectations, time and resource management, assessment and regular homework.

The skills associated with outstanding secondary teaching were similar; high expectations, lesson planning and setting regular homework. The report also lists 16 profes sional characteristics listed in a "dictionary", which range from teamworking to seeking information.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, yesterday welcomed the findings. "The report identifies the qualities that underpin effective teaching" she said. "I hope teachers will find the descriptions a highly valuable tool for self-evaluation and professional development.

The shadow education and employment secretary, Theresa May, condemned the government for spending £4m "to discover what they could have learnt from any staffroom in the country; £4m just to discover that teachers should plan their lessons well. Brilliant."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the largest teaching union, the National Union of Teachers, was also fiercely critical. "The results of this research will surprise no one," he said.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NAS/UWT described the report as "an expensive exercise in revealing the obvious".

webTitle: Peter Pan refills the piggy bank

fields.headline: Peter Pan refills the piggy bank
fields.standfirst: Children's culture is now being avidly consumed by adults
fields.trailText: As Prince William becomes an adult, there's increasing evidence that many of his seniors are in the process of becoming children. The summer's culture is dominated by the amazingly grown-up commercial performance of products constructed for the young.
fields.body:
As Prince William becomes an adult, there's increasing evidence that many of his seniors are in the process of becoming children. The summer's culture is dominated by the amazingly grown-up commercial performance of products constructed for the young.

An initial print-run of 1m copies of the fourth Harry Potter book by JK Rowling will be released on July 8: a remarkable figure for any fiction, almost sorcerous for a children's hardback. Next week, Chicken Run - the first full-length movie from Nick Park, creator of Wallace & Gromit, and Peter Lord, inventor of Morph - will open in 3,000 cinemas across America: blockbuster coverage for a film made in a shed in Bristol using plasticine. And next week marks the 10th anniversary of The Simpsons, a children's cartoon which has become a billion dollar industry.

The status of juvenile fiction has always been complicated. Although many of the most durable classics were created mainly for the young (Alice In Wonderland, Treasure Island, Peter Pan), contemporary stories for the lunch-box market are usually ranked by critics as a secondary form: like women's football or amateur dramatics.

The cross-over product - aimed at those with pocket money but loved equally by those with salaries - was pioneered in the 70s by two Hollywood directors with the trick of being able to think like big kids: George Lucas (Star Wars) and Steven Spielberg (ET, Indiana Jones). But this summer's Harry Potter 4, Chicken Run and Bart Simpson's 10th birthday celebrations show that it has become routine for class artistic products (the movie Toy Story 2 should also be included) to have been originally intended for classmates. And art for kids has become a financial big boy as well.

The reasons for what can be seen as either the infantilisation of culture or the coming of age of children's entertainment, are artistic and social. Artistically, there is a growing fashion for split-level fiction. Artistic territory has generally been well patrolled by border guards. Pokémon, for example, is a phenomenon tolerable only to children.

In contrast, the six-to-60 hits appeal to two different audiences simultaneously. Nick Park's plasticine movies draw children in with a comic dog and the moon as a cheese shop but have sophisticated cinematic gags for adults: The Wrong Trousers is a film noir parody, Chicken Run a spoof of escape movies. The Simpsons - to its young viewers a story of cool kids and hopeless folks - has jokes and observations on politics, art and even sometimes philosophy. These works are written with double sales potential.

The power of culture for the young can be explained socially by the fact that no previous section of society has taken parenthood quite so seriously as the well-heeled middle classes. This hot-house motherhood and fast-stream fatherhood frequently takes the form of material provision so that books, videos and games sell at unprecedented rates. The market for children's enter- tainment has also benefited (in a way which might seem paradoxical) from the fragmentation of the family. An army of separated parents and step-parents has increased the potential number of entertainment treats per child.

But, crucially, these products sell not just to children and this is the result of another cultural shift. No generation before those now in middle age showed such sheer reluctance to grow old. In the 50s, a couple of 48-year-olds were likely to be grandparents settling towards tweeds and bridge. These days, it would not be unusual to find the man in jeans and the woman pregnant. The advertising industry invented the term "kidult" to describe these age-deniers. The Simpsons, Harry Potter and Nick Park are all beneficiaries of this attempt to make the calendar go backwards.

The infantilism of the kid-ult generation is not just a denial of ageing. As entertainment for adults tends to become bleaker and more distressing - which reflects the lives of many people - there is also a comfort-blanket hunger for lost innocence. Only this could explain the adult audience for Harry Potter (which, unlike The Simpsons and Wallace & Gromit, isn't written on two levels). Publishers must accept that a section of the reading public finds grown-up fiction so off-putting that their book-shelves are regressing. The Potter books offer novels with no sex, violence (although Quidditch is a vicious game) or swearing.

Oliver Postgate - who wrote and narrated childrens' television shows including Bagpuss and The Clangers - has a haunting story about this in his just-published memoir Seeing Things (Sidgwick & Jackson). When he took the original Bagpuss puppet to an animation festival in Cardiff, the fantasy cat was "feted, hugged and cuddled, thrown from embrace to embrace by joyful young executives who shed nostalgic tears for that long-lost haven of warmth, safety and sense - Emily's shop."

A young woman who had suffered much emotionally told Postgate that Emily's shop was the safest place she knew. In offering those safe places, kidult culture is becoming entertainment's fattest piggy bank.

webTitle: Oy Gevalt, says Vini, it's krakh not honey

fields.headline: Oy Gevalt, says Vini, it's krakh not honey
fields.trailText: Winnie the Pooh, the Bear of Very Little Brain, created 80 years ago by AA Milne, has triumphantly crashed a new cultural barrier, being translated for the first time into Yiddish.
fields.body:
Winnie the Pooh, the Bear of Very Little Brain, created 80 years ago by AA Milne, has triumphantly crashed a new cultural barrier, being translated for the first time into Yiddish.

The stories, usually more appreciated by parents than children, have already been translated into 31 languages - including Latin - and have survived a makeover by Walt Disney.

But the honey-loving bear's charms have hitherto left Orthodox Jews cold.

That may now change with his emergence as Vini Der Pu, given to a shout of " Oy Gevalt! " on discovering a new supply of krakh - honey - up a tree or chatting with his friends Kristofer Robin, and with Khazerl (Piglet), Kangus (Kanga), Iyas (Eeyore) and Kinigl (Rabbit).

Even EH Shepard's illustrations have had a transformation. The famous map of Pooh's locality now has the hundert-akordiker Vald and the pu-pastke far hefalumpn instead of the wood where owl lives and the hefalump trap.

The translation, by a New York academic, Leonard Wolf, is faithful but has certain discreet modifications. Pooh's song Cottleston Pie, for instance, has become Varshever, varshever, varshever tort which roughly translated means Warsaw cake.

More striking still are the poems: Do kumen mir hant in hant/Kristofer Robin un ikh Zog, az s'iz dir a khidesh? ( Here we come, hand in hand, Christopher Robin and me tell me what's happening?)

Martin Kaye of the British distributors Kuperard, based in Finchley, north London - which will be marketing the books in the next few weeks - said: "I guess people who would speak Yiddish are not the sort who would be interested in Winnie the Pooh normally but maybe it's the sort of thing you might give Yiddish-speaking parents or aunts and uncles for a joke."

fields.headline: Casarola
fields.trailText:
Cliffs come sheering down into woodland here:
 The trees - they are chestnuts - spread to a further drop
Where an arm of water rushes through unseen
 Still lost in leaves: you can hear it
Squandering its way towards the mill...
fields.body:
For Attilio Bertolucci


Cliffs come sheering down into woodland here:
 The trees - they are chestnuts - spread to a further drop
Where an arm of water rushes through unseen
 Still lost in leaves: you can hear it
Squandering its way towards the mill
 A path crossing a hillslope and a bridge
Leads to at last: the stones lie there
 Idle beside it: they were cut from the cliff
And the same stone rises in wall and roof
 Not of the mill alone, but of shed on shed
Whose mossed tiles like a city of the dead
 Grow green in the wood. There are no dead here
And the living no longer come
 In October to crop the trees: the chestnuts
Dropping, feed the roots they rose from:
 A rough shrine sanctifies the purposes
These doors once opened to, a desolation
 Of still-perfect masonry. There is a beauty
In this abandonment: there would be more
 In the slow activity of smoke
Seeping at roof and lintel; out of each low
 Unwindowed room rising to fill
Full with essences the winter wood
 As the racked crop dried. Waste
Is our way. An old man
 Has been gathering mushrooms. He pauses
To show his spoil, plumped by a soil
 Whose sweet flour goes unmilled:
Rapid and unintelligible, he thinks we follow
 As we feel for his invitations to yes and no:
Perhaps it's the mushrooms he's telling over
 Or this place that shaped his dialect, and where nature
Daily takes the distinctness from that signature
 Men had left there in stone and wood,
Among waning villages, above the cities of the plain.

 Attilio Bertolucci, the Italian poet, died this week aged 89.

fields.headline: An Italian job?
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  hails Tim Parks' Destiny, a novel with disturbing European style
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard hails Tim Parks' Destiny, a novel with disturbing European style
fields.body:
Destiny
Tim Parks
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Well, there I go complaining about the lack of respect or even recognition given in this country to the works of Thomas Bernhard, and it turns out that I haven't been paying attention, Tim Parks has been writing them in English all along.

Now, if you neither know nor care who Thomas Bernhard is, then skip the rest of this review and go and buy Destiny (it may be a week shy of appearing in the shops, but most of them bust publication dates these days), which you will find to be a dense, tough, but beautiful and rewarding, highly intelligent and perceptive, yet at the same time heartfelt and moving, exploration of 72 hours in the mind of a middle-aged man who has just discovered that his son has committed suicide.

But we have to address the question of Parks's style, which here (and in his previous novel, Europa) is so wholly lifted from Bernhard as to be identifiable as Parks only because his novel is set in Italy (his home) and not Austria (Bernhard's), and because the passages of abuse directed against the host nation are not as corrosively vitriolic.

Bernhard's and Parks's narrators are intellectuals or academics or both - for only a certain kind of mind can plausibly sustain such a complex mode - and although the style teeters on the edge of madness, as they say (both are given to putting clichés in scornful italics), so that the very pages sound like sanity disappearing down the plughole, Parks's narrators seem to be more unlikely to commit suicide than Bernhard's. Yet it is interesting that suicide features strongly in both authors, as if the very style demanded it. "Flailing disaster" was the evocative and accurate term Adam Mars-Jones used to describe the life of Europa 's narrator, and the same applies here; but were we to write our own diaries like that, a reader might well conclude that we were going nuts, too.

Parks is at least candid about the influence: Bernhard's style is, after all, highly infectious, and more readily imitated than those of his high-modernist ancestors, Joyce and Beckett. (Or indeed Faulkner.) It involves enormous, seemingly digressive sentences (which are actually cunningly constructed), mostly in the historic present; a time-frame that shifts back and forth beneath a slow forward thrust; and then the artfully delayed revelation or bombshell upon which the whole novel hangs.

On his charming and frank website, Parks says he felt it "possible" to borrow from Bernhard for three reasons. One, because he had only read Bernhard in Italian, whereas Parks writes in English (a reason that does not work for someone practically monoglot like myself, who reads both Bernhard and Parks in English); two, because Bernhard doesn't write about sex; and three, because Bernhard has less plot. Parks also says that he wrote a bit like Bernhard before ever reading him - and this last seems to me the only really convincing excuse.

"Languages talk to themselves, I insist," says Chris Burton, the narrator of Destiny (his name a nod to The Anatomy of Melancholy): "to explain Italian in English, for example, is always to have an English explanation." So it is funny that Parks chooses an Austro-German technique with which to write. The narrator is writing a book on national character, and the predictability of character; and one of the novel's underlying gags is whether Burton himself acts predictably or not. Yet the very style Parks uses tends towards a final point. Perhaps that is why he stuck with it. Still, an extraordinary, brilliant book. Good cover, too.

fields.headline: Growing pains
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  finds Ben, In the World - Doris Lessing's sequel to The Fifth Child - as freakish as its hero
fields.trailText: Alex Clark finds Ben, In the World - Doris Lessing's sequel to The Fifth Child - as freakish as its hero
fields.body:
Ben, In the World
Doris Lessing
Flamingo, £16.99, 178pp
Buy it at BOL

In 1988 Doris Lessing surprised a readership already accustomed to her restless shifts in form and tone with her short, brutal tale The Fifth Child. Defying easy categorisation, it seemed to veer between spare realism and surreal allegory; at times, there were even overtones of her science-fiction writing. It concerned a couple who seek to construct an impregnable edifice of happiness based on having lots and lots of children. Their extended family disapproves of them, detecting in their manic procreation a form of narcissism and recklessness for which others, and by extension society, must pay.

When their fifth child, Ben, is born, the couple are duly punished. He is, almost literally, a monster whose freakishness is characterised by random acts of violence and an utter inability to communicate. He is sent away, but when his guilty mother rescues him from incarceration in a grim, laboratory-style institution, the family is all but destroyed. Ben's unclassifiable otherness, his parents eventually decide, is down to a mad slip in the genes: he is a throwback, a troll, a goblin - even, at one point, an alien child.

The Fifth Child ended inconclusively, with a half-hearted gesture towards Ben's unknowable future in an uncaring world. In this sequel, Lessing attempts to give shape to that future, picking up Ben's story when he is 18 years old, estranged from his family and eking out a miserable existence on the streets of London.

He is taken up by a prostitute perversely attracted to the urgency and rawness of his sex drive; alas, "poor Ben", as he is frequently termed, is the perfect dupe for her unscrupulous pimp, who co-opts him as an unwitting mule in a drug-smuggling scheme. Thus begins Ben's career as a globetrotter, his haphazard travels taking him from the south of France to Brazil, where an American filmmaker seeks to turn Ben's weird appearance and behaviour to his own advantage.

That, roughly, is the plot, an aimless and uninvolving business that cares little whether it convinces or interests. The prose style is similarly careless; often repetitive and turgid, relying on a simplicity that borders on the naive and comes across as shoddy writing. Lessing's pared-down style has, on occasion, functioned well as the vehicle for a teeming cargo of ideas; her priorities, she suggests, are elsewhere. Here, that stylistic inadequacy fails to evoke a sense of great ideas at play, creating instead disappointing longueurs (unfortunate in such a very short book) and an irritating feeling that one is being preached at rather than engaged in a dialogue.

In part, that nagging doubt stems from a disjunction between the earlier novel and its sequel. In The Fifth Child the tension between realism and fable gave rise to a cleverly sustained sense of menace and unease. Like Ben's mother, the reader could experience both terror and pity in the face of this unknowable object, a product of her own body that was unmistakably alien to her and to us. But where the infant Ben suggested unpredictable and uncontainable evil, the adolescent/adult Ben has more of the circus freak about him, something between the noble savage and the wounded, exploited animal. His protectors are good, his exploiters are bad: the analysis rarely gets more sophisticated than that.

If Lessing is trying to create an allegory - and various moralising passages and thinly veiled stabs at polemic hint that she might be - then she is scuppered by her central premise. We are given to understand, over and over again, that Ben does in fact belong to a branch of the species that has long since died out. One notes, however, that he has attained basic language and social skills, and a set of emotional responses.

These are not facts that are easy to absorb, but it is not surprising, in the light of them, that people are both frightened and fascinated by him, and that research scientists wish to perform experiments on him. But it is exactly these facts that undermine Lessing's ability to move the story on, to explore issues of otherness, of difference and oppression. And Ben himself becomes a victim of that double bind, a character whose stalled future prevents him from coming to life on the page, let alone in the world.

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: Graham Tayar's poems are effective and often moving
fields.body:
Not Too Late For Loving: A Lifetime of Occasional Verses
Graham Tayar
(Smaller Sky, £8.99)

Most books of light verse have a terrible Victorian amateurism about them. This has some of the faults of the genre, but overall these poems by former BBC radio producer Graham Tayar are effective, often moving. He follows the line of Gavin Ewart back to Ogden Nash, but crosses this mood with personal lyrics that remind one of Hardy and Housman. Better than much from the established publishers' lists, this would nonetheless have benefited from the eye of a sharp editor.

 For information tel 07050 632277 or email editor@smallerskybooks.co.uk

fields.headline: Original paperback fiction
fields.trailText: Stuart Evers, fiction buyer at Waterstone's Charing Cross store, has picked out for us a list of top-selling trade paperbacks, or paperback originals - the strange designations for books that dispense with hardback publication and make their first appearance in (often jazzed-up) soft covers at between £9 and £11. The price point has been creeping up, prompting one to speculate whether the trade paperback will eventually cost as much as a straightforward hardback - something that would not be in consumers' interests. As for the books themselves, the two to look out for are Chris Paling's Newton's Swing and Andrew Crumey's Mr Mee. Paling never fails to catch the reader in his subtle toils, while Crumey has written a highly sophisticated philosophical thriller about the octogenarian Mr Mee's search for a lost book. This is the kind of writing, dead in the water as a hardback, that makes publication as a paperback original commercially viable.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText:
Can history work on audio? Yes and no...
Hear an extract
fields.body:
Stalingrad
Antony Beevor
(Isis, £21.99, 17.5 hrs)
Buy it at BOL
Hear an extract

The book was garlanded with rapturous reviews, but does it make good audio? The answer must be a qualified yes. The morass of daily advance and retreat at this city that Hitler wanted to grab, and Stalin to hold at any cost, and the apparently endless lists of armies, divisions and commanders are tricky enough for the non-military enthusiast to retain from the printed page. For most listeners, trying to visualise the basic shape of this egregious mess is impossible.

Where audio scores is in uttering aloud the many snapshots of courage, suffering, degradation and incredible endurance which cram the book. For his remorseless trudge through the narrative, Michael Tudor Barnes uses a dour delivery with a sepulchral sheen. Of all the horrors it is the utter contempt that Stalin, his commanders and NKVD bullyboys showed their own troops which tops the lot. If you listen to this in your car you will need to de-mist from time to time - your eyes, not your windscreen.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Two marvellous portraits of children trapped by family expectations, plus Tears Of The Giraffe, Afraid to Death and Southpaw
fields.body:
Fasting, Feasting
Anita Desai
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

An orange, skinned and offered to Papa on the veranda, and a plate of bloody steak cooked in a Massachusetts backyard and shoved into the hands of a nervous Indian student. These images bookend Desai's Booker-shortlisted novel. Mama and Papa form a selfish union that overshadows the futures of their three children.

Uma - slow and bespectacled - is doomed to service and spinsterhood, while Arun is fated to carry the family's academic hopes to America; only Aruna escapes to Bombay with a husband. Desai writes delicately of family unhappiness, and in Uma and Arun she creates two marvellous portraits of powerless children trapped by family expectations.

Tears Of The Giraffe
Alexander McCall Smith
(Polygon, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

Botswana is indeed the land of milk and honey in this second helping of tales from Mme Ramotswe's No 1 Ladies' Detective Agency. Whether it's a case of a disappeared American, Mr Matekoni's troubles with his apprentice car mechanics, a scheming maid, or adopting two orphaned children from the Kalahari, everything finally comes to a happy end. The cynic might catch a whiff of tendentiousness in McCall Smith's fulsome praise of old African ways and the "traditionally built" Precious Ramotswe, but there is much pleasure to be gained from reading a very straightforward narrative written with wit and exuberance.

Afraid to Death
Marc Behm
(No Exit Press, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Chance and travel - two all-American motifs - are bound together blackly in Behm's second novel. Joe Egan is always on the run, taking rooms in anonymous motels with easy escape routes and always on the look-out for a strange blonde who follows him across America. He is a gambler, a poker king driven to spend his money as fast as he wins it. Sure, he would like something more stable but how else can he earn $1,000 an hour and cheat his femme fatale Angel of Death? Afraid to Death is both a thriller and an odyssey through every state in the union - a parable about luck and its downside, written with knowing style.

Southpaw
Lisa St Aubin De Teran
(Virago, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

There are no surprises in this collection of stories, gleaned from the author's years spent on a Venezuelan hacienda and in the Umbrian hills. St Aubin De Teran's own enchantment with odd little stories from the lives of peasants in exotic backwaters is always apparent. The details - food preparation, the complicated relationships of small communities and plants spilling from balconies and back gardens - are neatly realised and pervade each narrative. If you like her brand of simplicity, touched with exuberant quirkiness, then Southpaw will be a welcome reprise, but others might feel St Aubin De Teran is treading water.

fields.headline: White City blues
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit  travels the road of dreams that died in Edward Platt's Leadville
fields.trailText: Chris Petit travels the road of dreams that died in Edward Platt's Leadville
fields.body:
Leadville: A Biography of the A40
Edward Platt
Picador, £9.99, 304pp
Buy it at BOL

The illusion, driving west out of London along the A40, is that conditions have improved over the last 20 years; for the driver, anyway. A stutter of traffic lights has been replaced by a series of flyovers and underpasses and a quasi-motorway that, out of rush hour, offers the fastest of any route out of London - apart from the clog-up between White City and Hangar Lane, the last stretch due for redevelopment until the Labour government scotched it.

Getting in and out of London is a recurring problem in the city's history. Lack of military influence at government level meant that it never acquired the grand boulevards of other European capitals, built to facilitate troop movement. There was a radical highway programme after the second world war, but it fell out of fashion long before completion; its interrupted legacy can be seen in the tower blocks lining the Westway, including the now-fashionable Trellick.

After the rooftop skim of the Westway, something goes badly wrong. A massive flashback occurs and the road reverts to what it was - a classic example of between-the-wars ribbon development, that aesthetically and environmentally deadly combination of dual carriageway bordered by cheap suburban housing, once offered as an ideal alternative to city-dwelling. Most of the houses are now boarded up and abandoned. Dereliction gives a futuristic, post-apocalyptic air, and the bizarre combination of bailiffs' grilles and former tweeness makes the area look like an Ealing Films version of Bladerunner, which is pretty much how Platt's book turns out.

Leadville is not, as it claims, a biography of the A40 (which ends in Wales), but the story of how this particular section got left behind. It is a history of urban and transport planning, of the contrast between the clarity of the drawing board and the muddle of execution, and how that applies to those affected most, the local community.

Five years ago, curiosity led Platt, a journalist living nearby, to start knocking on doors in order to find out the story behind these houses. The road was due for redevelopment and compulsory purchases were in order. Most residents greeted his approach with mild bemusement, but Platt persisted, finding a hypnotic beauty in the desolation. From a journalistic angle, however, he was chasing a non-story. The locals were either too old or resigned, and the squatters too disorganised; there was little concerted opposition beyond the odd individual effort and the occasional fractious housing-association meeting.

This inertia is something of a surprise; from A Passport to Pimlico to EastEnders, the myth of the local community is deeply embedded in the national psyche. Platt's book gradually exposes the illusion of community and the way, as the social infrastructure breaks down, rumour and superstition replace it (ironic, given that part of the point of suburbia was the elimination of uncertainty).

It was fear of political unrest that led to the Western Avenue development in the first place. In the aftermath of the first world war, suburbia was offered as the solution to Britain's housing problem ("Homes for Heroes") and an insurance against Bolshevism. In the inherent conservatism of suburban development, with its mock-Tudor facades and spurious appeal to an imaginary past, lay a political calculation. Lloyd George announced that these new houses - "each with its own garden, surrounded by trees and hedges, and equipped internally with the amenities of a middle-class home" - were to provide "visible proof of the irrelevance of revolution". Platt's book offers a bathetic coda to that vision. Three of the great false dawns of the 20th century - suburbia, modernism and the automobile - are mocked in all their deficiencies in that short stretch between the Westway and Gypsy Corner.

Platt grows increasingly alert to the contradictions on offer. Urban abandon has let nature back in, a reminder that before this was tarmac, known originally as the "road to nowhere", it was allotments. The original policy of losing a returning army in the suburbs has a weird echo in the mindless violence done by bailiffs in their efforts to make the houses unsquattable. Platt writes of rooms looking as though they have been ripped apart by an explosion.

Meanwhile, his own views on the car are as cheerfully muddled as most. The title of his book presumes an environmental stance, and his Peugot 205 seems to empathise (at first refusing to reverse and then, in a burst of eco-mindedness, starting to sprout moss in its interior). But in the end, after a belated acknowledgment of JG Ballard's Crash and the psychosexual pathology of an automobile culture, Platt extols "the lubricious pleasures of driving on the Westway".

However, given the suburban and essentially English nature of his enterprise, perhaps the Ealing comedy analogy remains the most appropriate for Leadville - smug, heartless bureaucrats, lots of squatterspeak (same as it ever was) and a few shell-shocked old dears strayed out of One Foot in the Grave. Given that the BBC is within walking distance, it's a surprise that it hasn't already been turned into a sitcom.

fields.headline: Interrogating the human
fields.standfirst: Val McDermid explains the literary uses of murder to Nicholas Wroe
fields.trailText: Val McDermid explains the literary uses of murder to Nicholas Wroe
fields.body:
Crime writer Val McDermid's literary tastes were formed by the institutional high-mindedness of the Kirkcaldy public library. The cultural commissars of the Scottish mining town where she grew up in the 1950s rigorously enforced a strict lending policy. Readers were allowed to borrow up to four books as long at least two of them were non-fiction.

"It was a very puritanical and Protestant system," laughs McDermid. "Agatha Christie had already been imprinted on me because Murder in the Vicarage was the only book in my grandparents' house, and I read all the classic English writers like Allingham, Marsh and Sayers. As I practically lived in the library, I was therefore made to read a lot of things like poetry and folk-tales that I never normally would have encountered had I been allowed to stay only with detective novels."

With her literary base thus broadened, McDermid won a place at Oxford, where she discovered Hammett and Chandler and found, unexpectedly, that crime fiction received tacit approval. "It wasn't treated exactly like literature, but it was thought to be almost respectable. It was the sort of thing I would see on a tutor's side table."

As a student she did "all the usual stuff; embarrassing poetry and song lyrics". A few poems were published in small magazines, which gave her a taste for seeing her name in print. After university she enrolled on the Daily Mirror trainee journalist course. A year later, she graduated top of her year. She went on to run the Sunday People's northern news bureau in Manchester, and she still lives in the city.

"I was a complete news hack and had a lot of fun in newspapers for a long time," she says. "It's hard to believe now, but we actually used to turn over wicked people and expose wrongdoing. We covered the abuse of old people in homes and the treatment of women in prison. But as the 1980s progressed, the obsession with the sex-lives of soap stars took over and I became very disillusioned."

She says that in the back of her mind, journalism was always a temporary measure until she was able to become a full-time writer. She had a play broadcast on the radio but it was a creative false start. "I didn't really understand what I was doing right with drama. So it was then kind of hard to replicate."

Her continued interest in crime fiction led to a friend sending her Sarah Paretsky's first novel from the states. It was a decisive moment. "I realised a crime novel didn't have to be set in a strange English village with a retired Indian colonel and some spinsters doing their knitting."

McDermid's first novel, Report for Murder, was published in 1987. She drew upon her own life in the creation of lesbian journalist Lindsay Gordon as her central character. The book sold well, two more Lindsay Gordon books followed, and pretty soon McDermid became something of a spokesperson for the lesbian community. But she insisted that her books be displayed on the crime shelves in bookshops rather than in the gay and lesbian section. "People who like crime fiction, whether gay or straight, will always go to the crime-fiction shelves before they go to the gay-and-lesbian shelves," she explains.

When McDermid introduced a new leading character in her fourth book, the straight Manchester private eye Kate Brannigan, it precipitated predictable complaints that she had sold out. McDermid denies the charge but acknowledges an element of pragmatism. "Of course the commercial consideration was there," she says. "I wanted to be in a position where I could write full-time, and I wasn't going to be able to do that through writing lesbian crime fiction. But there were other reasons as well. I wanted to see if the female private eye novel could work in the UK. And there was the challenge as to whether I could write a character so different from myself."

McDermid also knew the mind-set of crime readers. She guessed that if a mainstream audience enjoyed Kate Brannigan, they'd also check out Lindsay Gordon. Every time a new McDermid book has come out since - there have been six more Brannigans and five others - there has always been a kick in sales for the Lindsay Gordon series.

Her latest book, A Place of Execution, is set geographically and chronologically close to the moors murders, which cropped up repeatedly during McDermid's journalistic career. Over the years she has interviewed the investigating police officers, the families of victims and Ian Brady's mother, and she is acutely aware of the sensitivities surrounding the case.

"I thought about it a lot. I couldn't not mention it, but equally I was aware of the charge of exploitation," she explains. "This case still has huge sensitivity in the region, and rightly so. I eventually decided to refer obliquely to the real moors murders at the very beginning and let the readers bring their own resonances to the book."

It is a captivating and emotionally dense read that more than holds its own against much contemporary mainstream fiction. As a critic, as well as a writer, McDermid has championed the literary merit of crime fiction, and she describes the last decade as a golden age. "There has been a tremendous injection of talent and imagination into the genre," she says. "There are novels written from every perspective and about every aspect of society. My own work reflects the level of diversity that is permissible. Quite frankly I don't see any limits and I'm happy to continue working in the genre. I can't think of a single thing I have wanted to say that I haven't been able to say within crime fiction."

fields.headline: Grave robber
fields.standfirst: Julie Burchill  on Paul Morley's memoir of his father's suicide, Nothing
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill on Paul Morley's memoir of his father's suicide, Nothing
fields.body:
Nothing
Paul Morley
Faber, £11.99, 426pp

Death is the pornography of the respectable publisher - or is it cookery? Both, probably; that's what makes John Diamond and Nigella Lawson such a hot, now couple. She cooks and writes about it, he's dying and writes about it. Still, whatever you think about John Diamond turning his cancer into a cottage industry, it does belong to him: it is a resource, if you like, that he has every right to exploit. But what about turning a buck from the deaths of one's nearest and dearest?

Writing about the death of a child is far more understandable than writing about the death of a parent, as for a parent to bury a child goes against the whole grain of life and is, therefore, more puzzling for the bereaved and more interesting to the reader. But what of people who write whole books about their parents' deaths - and, more specifically, their parents' suicides? For me, there is something doubly indecent, while invariably banal, about such efforts. The banality comes about because parents are, by their nature, meant to die; that's what they're here for (and to tell us we can't go out dressed like that). If someone had a parent who didn't die, now that would be a story worth reading.

The indecency crops up because it doesn't behove any of us to look too closely at our parents generally; their final impenetrability is often the only dignity we leave them with after we have trodden their hearts down into dust when the hormones kick in. This is why we all share the same nightmare scenario of seeing our parents having sex; we owe them a bit of me-time, when all they ever seemed to have or want was us-time. In the case of a suicide, this poking and prodding seems especially vulgar; vulgar in the way that only true heartlessness can be. A suicide has simply had enough; he or she has turned away, begged to be excused and moved into another room. To then go rooting about and digging them up seems one step removed from cannibalism.

There will, of course, be the usual whingeing geek chorus writing to point out that when my father died of asbestosis three years ago, I lost no time in writing a column about it. To which I would say that those thousand words or so were nothing more than an obituary for a great man who, because he possessed neither wealth, education or fame, would never have been honoured on the obits page proper. There. Just clearing that one up.

I have always found Paul Morley to be one of the drabbest and silliest of the alumni from my old alma mater - the New Musical Express - and if there was one thing I didn't need on top of his addled musings on music and sex it was a peek at his unhappy family tree. Not much happens; he mithers about in Stockport (lying git told us he was from Manchester), fails to get the job I got at the NME, moves to London anyway, hypes Frankie Goes to Hollywood, does loads of drugs and drink and wakes up in the cold outer suburbs of youth to discover that - gasp! - his father's suicide has wiped out whole chunks of his memory. Excuse me, but might that not have been the drink and drugs?

This book highlights, as none has done so flagrantly since Kathryn Flett's The Heart-Shaped Bullet, all that is worst about such guts-spilling tomes. While pertaining to tell the truth, they are tweaked and spun to within an inch of their lives, so that what you end up with actually bears less resemblance to reality than Jeffrey Archer's autobiography would. Here, on page four, Morley contemplates a dead body and "wonders" what it would sing if it could. "This is the end, my friend"? "It's good to touch the green, green grass of home"? What about Fly Me to the Moon?

As humour, this makes us groan; as pathos, it makes us laugh. And I didn't feel guilty for laughing, because the emotions described are so obviously false; no one, on finding a corpse, wonders what song it might sing. This is just Paul Morley working overtime at being Paul Morley - as if anybody was checking up on him any more! - and, proving that, as the great John Miles once sang, music is his first love and it shall be his last. Music of the future, and music of the past.

But I've tried to be positive, and one thing I did like was the list of records at the back - more than 50 of them, God help us - which were "listened to whilst writing Nothing and music you might listen to while reading it": Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now, Heartbreak Hotel and Boys Don't Cry among them. I admired this little "conceit", as I believe they are known, and just in case any reader would like to duplicate the experience, I read this book and wrote this review while listening to, among others, Is Everybody Happy?, The Laughing Gnome and Don't 'Ave Any More, Mrs Moore! Bonne chance, readers!

fields.headline: Ch-ch-changes
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer laughs out loud at Harland Miller's darkly comic Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer laughs out loud at Harland Miller's darkly comic Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty
fields.body:
Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty
Harland Miller
Fourth Estate, £9.99, 256pp
Buy it at BOL

This novel has been wildly hyped -"one of the great comic novelists of his generation", "right up my strasse", says none other than Jarvis Cocker. Given this, I was rather expecting a load of trendy nonsense - and I certainly wasn't expecting to smile, having read some very sombre, macabre books bizarrely described by their publishers as comic. So I was somewhat surprised when, only 10 or 20 pages in, I found myself head down, absorbed in Harland Miller's eclectic anecdotal style. Dark as it was, I laughed out loud.

Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty is a tale of a northern town in the early 1980s, where the kids are getting out of it when they should really be getting out. Its structure is essentially Arabian Nights: one reminiscence arising from the ashes of another, a complete entertaining story on nearly every page. The narrator - or supposed diarist - is William Glover, aka "Kid", aka Nick Barrel, but the figure who strings the book together is Ziggy Hero (aka several other names), a David Bowie impersonator who faces the serious problem of trying to build a solid identity on the ever-shifting sands of Bowie's public image.

Also featured are: the Undead - the kids who start out fresh-faced and bright as teds, mods, rockers, soulies or punks and end up as toothless alcoholics before they've hit 20; the Coneheads - a violent rabble of vandals identifiable by the inevitable orange traffic cones jammed onto their heads; various family members, including a father who thinks your boss might as well shoot you as retire you; the Yorkshire Ripper (off-stage but omnipresent); the Planet of the Mates - a troubling collection of individuals pally with the narrator who live in the Wigwam, a house-cum-building site.

The theme is change, for and against; those waiting for change, those willing to change and those who vigorously beat up anyone who looks like they might be thinking about change in any shape or form. The chameleon Ziggy, glamorous and tarted up, trailing a gaggle of schoolgirl groupies, is an obvious target for assault. The plot, such as it is, involves the Kid's long wait for Ziggy to play his bound-to-be-amazing gig - a vaguely planned event that is constantly mutating due to Bowie's changing style.

Most of the characters, including the narrator, end up in London, surely the northern tale's equivalent of getting the girl: a hotly desired outcome - but then, what next? The gig does happen eventually, but in another time and another space, when it is no longer clear whether it is a call to the future or a throwback to past times - yet it is a great success, in its own way. By the way, anyone who can guess in advance where that title comes from really knows their stuff.

Given this, I was rather expecting a load of trendy nonsense - and I certainly wasn't expecting to smile, having read some very sombre, macabre books bizarrely described by their publishers as comic. So I was somewhat surprised when, only 10 or 20 pages in, I found myself head down, absorbed in Harland Miller's eclectic anecdotal style. Dark as it was, I laughed out loud. Its structure is essentially Arabian Nights: one reminiscence arising from the ashes of another, a complete entertaining story on nearly every page. The narrator - or supposed diarist - is William Glover, aka "Kid", aka Nick Barrel, but the figure who strings the book together is Ziggy Hero (aka several other names), a David Bowie impersonator who faces the serious problem of trying to build a solid identity on the ever-shifting sands of Bowie's public image. fields.headline: Bomb bay
fields.standfirst: Praful Bidwai and Achin Vanaik argue that the nuclear confrontation in South Asia has wider implications in New Nukes
fields.trailText: Praful Bidwai and Achin Vanaik argue that the nuclear confrontation in South Asia has wider implications in New Nukes
fields.body:
New Nukes: India, Pakistan and Global Nuclear Disarmament
Praful Bidwai and Achin Vanaik
Signal Books, £12.99, 312pp

The nuclear games being played by India and Pakistan are both dangerous and obscene. They are dangerous because there are Taliban-type elements within the Pakistan army (and, I'm sure, their equivalents in India) who could, in extremis, press the dreaded button. They are obscene because both countries are racked by poverty of the most abject sort, illiteracy, mass unemployment and the lack of basic amenities for countless millions. The lack of these necessities of life is not considered to be a denial of "human rights" as far as western policymakers are concerned, a view increasingly contested by the young on the streets of Seattle and Washington.

The figures speak for themselves. Following the nuclear tests of 1998, the Indian government announced an allocation of $9.9bn for defence spending in 1999, an increase of 14 per cent on the previous year. Pakistan mimicked this increase with one of 8.5 per cent, pushing its spending to $3.3bn. South Asia today is one of the world's most heavily militarised regions. The Indian and Pakistani armies form part of the world's 10 largest war machines. There are six soldiers to every doctor. The social cost of arms expenditure is horrendous.

If nothing else, the extension of the nuclear race to South Asia should compel policymakers in Washington to pause and reflect on their own actions since the official end of the cold war. The fact is that the US military budget remains inflated and accounts for over a third of the world's spending on armaments. The old enemy no longer exists, but the Cold-War scenarios remain in place. US military planners continue to target Russia and China. The latest wave of Nato expansion, followed by a Balkan war, only hardened Russian opposition to nuclear disarmament. When Nato patrols the Black Sea, what price the "partnership for peace"?

Herein lies the crux of the problem. Unless the West begins the process of unilateral nuclear disarmament, it has no moral or material basis to demand that others do the same. It is a twisted logic that accepts that while London and Paris can have the bomb, New Delhi and Islamabad, not to mention Seoul and Pyongyang, cannot.

Praful Bidwai and Achin Vanaik are two of India's most courageous radical journalists. Like others who tell the truth, they are sometimes heaped with ridicule, but they remain steadfast. They interrogate power and often venture into dangerous territory. They are immune to the usual pressures and inducements with which governments, eastern and western, seek to intimidate or bribe journalists. Among the most valuable sections of New Nukes is the account of India's previous stance on the question of atomic weapons. Jawaharlal Nehru was a firm believer in nuclear abstinence. "Coming from a warm country," he informed the United Nations in 1960, "I have shivered occasionally from these cold blasts." Now the blasts have overpowered the political elites in India and Pakistan.

Bidwai and Vanaik are in favour of unilateral nuclear disarmament by both India and Pakistan: for them, this is a moral and a political imperative. The case they make is unanswerable, but politicians and generals usually concede only to mass pressure; rational arguments leave them unmoved.

The authors complain that the Indian left (India's two communist parties) is part of the problem: "The socialist bomb has been seen as the progressive weapon against the imperialist bomb. The adjective has been made more important than the noun in perverse understanding of the history and politics of nuclearism. The left's claim that deterrence has sometimes worked is a self-serving delusion." In any event, the conflict in the region is seen by fanatics on both sides as the "Muslim" bomb versus the "Hindu" bomb. The former believe they will end up in paradise anyway, and for the latter there is always the hope of reincarnation, if this time in the shape of ants.

Bidwai and Vanaik argue that unilateral nuclear disarmament in South Asia should not be seen in a national context, but as a stepping stone towards global disarmament. This is an extremely useful book, and not just for India. The projected scenarios in the case of nuclear conflict would not remained confined to South Asia. Nuclear rain is no respecter of frontiers: it will cripple humans and plants alike. Western leaders in the grip of a triumphalist fever appear to have given up on disarmament, blighting the harvest of hopes that arose briefly during the time of Gorbachev. It could turn out to be a fatal error.

fields.headline: Grand design
fields.standfirst: Tim Pears takes on the grand sweep of contemporary British life in A Revolution of the Sun
fields.trailText: Tim Pears takes on the grand sweep of contemporary British life in A Revolution of the Sun
fields.body:
A Revolution of the Sun
Tim Pears
Doubleday, £16.99, 440pp
Buy it at BOL

Tim Pears specialises in grand panoramas of our national life: teeming casts and multi-tracked plotlines heavy with the scent of zeitgeist. For this, and quite a lot more (eagerness to take risks, range of enquiry, specialist knowledge), he deserves the highest praise. The anaemic, boxed-in quality of much contemporary British fiction has long been a critical sore point, and the very idea of a novel that wants to supply "the anatomy of a nation in flux" is enough to put the reader on the writer's side - even if, as in this and other cases, the book itself doesn't quite deliver.

Extending effortlessly beyond its 400th page and clearly anxious not to yield up its ultimate patterns too early on, A Revolution of the Sun begins on the cusp of 1997. The people who wander about in it are not perhaps representative, but they are definitely emblematic: an amnesiac hospital escapee picked up at King's Cross by a rave-fixated Brixton babe; a gang of Manchester towerblock slackers; a soft-shoed female cat burglar; a venal Tory MP.

The same could be said of their adventures. Arms-dealing, pill-popping, vivisection - few of the tics and irritations of recent years fail to acquire an airing here, and the effect can be slightly frictionless, giving the sense of "issues" ticked off on a checklist rather than the real thing (whatever that is) convincingly rendered.

As might be expected, given the riot of characters and events on offer (including an actual riot at one point), some of the serial fragments into which the book straightaway dissolves are better than others. The political stuff - which features a Conservative defence secretary of Spanish origin named Roderick Pastille and a Labour opponent named Edna Wartwhistle - is simply dire. All the more so, in fact, by comparison with some much more appealing character sketches: Solo, for instance, a Manchester lad with fervent dreams for his eight-year-old paraplegic son, or Penny, a cancer-stricken elderly woman.

Pears's prose style, too, has an erratic strike rate. "Kids with gaudy plastic rucksacks burst from the primary school and scattered like Smarties from a tube." Like what? Alternatively, at one of the young persons' sound-drenched drug-ins on which Pears rather enjoys flexing his pen, we come across "music that was a series of interconnected stories in a narrative which built into the story of the night". Yes, indeed.

There is also a great deal of stolid establishing dialogue in which characters prattle on implausibly about their lives to date ("You'd all got milkshakes, taken out the straws and competed for the quickest to down the first in one," haulier Jack Knighton fondly reminds his wife of the girls' night out that sparked their first encounter). The result is a less than even read - episodes of great interest and subtlety undermined by over-reach and overwriting. You get the feeling that Pears's considerable talents might be better served by a narrower canvas.

fields.headline: Essex noir
fields.standfirst: Jason Cowley's debut Unknown Pleasures is set on familiar territory
fields.trailText: Jason Cowley's debut Unknown Pleasures is set on familiar territory
fields.body:
Unknown Pleasures
Jason Cowley
Faber, £9.99, 256pp

Parental mystery is always unsettling, and it makes a dark and edgy starting point for Booker judge Jason Cowley's debut novel. Joshua Winter's father disappeared 12 years ago, and now Joshua has come back to London to find out what happened there. Meanwhile, an intercut narrative reveals the story of his father, who fled to Spain after a bungled porn-video scam led to murder. With its Essex men and its porno pivot, Cowley's book attempts to exploit a familiar patch of well-dodgy novelistic turf.

Joshua is remarkably slow to realise that the people he meets on his quest, such as the charismatic Nicholas Dundee, are gangsters. It was Dundee who lunged out with the fatal knife 12 years before, but now he is a millionaire with a lovely little daughter. Given that his money comes from unspecified business interests in leisure and security, and that he lives in an Essex mansion bristling with surveillance cameras, readers might raise an eyebrow when Joshua innocently wonders, "How could there be darkness in that life?"

Joshua's clumpingly ironic naivety is partly characterisation, but the novel is never as worldly as it would like to be. Small details - descriptions of tart cards or King's Cross street life - don't quite ring true. Nor does the violence. Joshua is followed from a club by three men, who beat him up. Afterwards, he has a flirtatious cup of tea with the woman outside whose house the assault took place (it's "the comfort of strangers"), despite the fact that such an attack would put most of us in casualty.

Later, having inadvertently killed one of Dundee's henchmen, he gets home to find his lightbulbs removed and the dead body in his bathtub. Any normal reaction - the suppressed panic of checking if intruders are still in the flat, for example - is completely absent. Either Joshua has nerves of steel, or he's in a book that just doesn't convey the real bite of trauma.

The book's most striking feature is its slightly bizarre prose style. Portentous and cliché-packed, it drips with ersatz drama. Joshua is back in "a country I once called home. And now? Nothing but the slow desolation of early winter... and the mistakes we repeat". The writing seems haunted by posturing crime cadences, with occasional more ambitious excursions: Joshua's father was "absent without leave; in time, he was metaphysically absent, too, for in their hearts my family had abandoned him as dead". Still, Unknown Pleasures has a functional plot and it works reasonably as a thriller. It's a brave Booker judge who dares to show the world his own book, but Cowley has acquitted himself. Just.

fields.headline: Big in SF
fields.trailText: Jon Courtenay Grimwood rounds up the latest
fields.body:
A new alternative history from Kim Newman is always a treat, and Dracula Cha Cha Cha (Simon & Schuster, £16.99) is no disappointment. Mixing fictional and real-life characters, this follow-up to Anno Dracula and Bloody Red Baron finds il principe in exile in a Fellini-esque Rome of the late 1950s.

Kate, formerly a Victorian vampire, has fallen for Italian journalist Marcello, who specialises in writing about the empty nightlife of the eternal rich. However, Kate is really in Rome to see Charles Beauregard, an elderly British spymaster currently being looked after by a beautiful adolescent called Genevieve Dieudonné who is several centuries old.

Anybody who is anybody in the vampire world is in Rome for the marriage of Dracula to an obscure eastern European princess. Unfortunately, a serial killer with a silver scythe is also in the city, making short work of Dracula's more distinguished guests. And it falls to Kate to hunt down the killer, with help from Genevieve and Charles Beauregard, not to mention Commander Hamish Bond, owner of a rather neat metallic silver Aston Martin.

Few people would or could write a Dracula novel in which Dracula doesn't actually appear, but Newman pulls it off magnificently; although for some readers, playing spot-the-cultural-reference might occasionally get in the way of the narrative tension. Imagine La Dolce Vita with vampires, and you've got some idea of this espresso of a book.

Three times as long as Dracula Cha Cha Cha and not remotely frothy, the 918-page blockbuster that is Cryptonomicon (Heinemann, £7.99) also sees Neal Stephenson mixing fictional and non-fictional characters, to produce an alternative history of the second world war.

The Allies have cracked the Enigma code; the only problem is that if they act on their new knowledge, the Nazis will know the code has been cracked and develop another one. Enter Detachment 2702, an outfit so secret that mathematician and member Lawrence Waterhouse can't get into one base because the level of authorisation he carries is so high that no one else has heard of it.

Along with marine raider Bobby Shaftoe, Waterhouse's job is to justify events as they happen, by manufacturing evidence to be found by the enemy at a later date. Often funny, erudite and staggeringly plausible, Cryptonomicon 's second-world-war "history" is intercut with a near-future tale of dirty tricks and dirtier money as Waterhouse's geekish cypherpunk grandson sets out to establish a data haven in the far east, where he meets up with Shaftoe's granddaughter Amy. Cryptonomicon was expected by many to win last month's Arthur C Clarke award (the SF Booker), but came unstuck because the judges apparently couldn't agree as to whether or not it was actually science fiction. It is, and it should have won.

Equally hotly tipped and also not chosen - but not quite in the same class - is Justina Robson's Silver Screen (Macmillan, £9.99), a first novel in which heroine Anjuli O'Connell copes with a perfect memory, a boyfriend who is turning into a cyborg, a best friend who wants to mesh his mind with a global artifical intelligence and her job with OptiNet (imagine a totally immoral Microsoft).

Robson writes best when she concentrates on tight locations, such as the school at which most of the characters first meet; where Silver Screen finally falls down is in the structure and editing. Ultimately the ending just doesn't satisfy, and there is a whole chapter involving a weapons-grade mecha-suit that belongs in another book altogether. All the same, it promises good things for her next novel.

One of the more interesting trends in SF is the move away from Wasp culture towards novels set outside America and western Europe. Jan Lars Jensen's Shiva 3000 (Macmillan, £9.99) takes place a thousand years from now in an India where the gods have returned to rule the subcontinent.

As the awesome mechanical idol Jagannath rolls across the arid plains crushing believers beneath its vast wheels, a low-caste Indian boy called Rakesh sets out from a shattered city, accompanied by the disgraced designer of a silken airship so large it has offended the gods. Every move the boy makes is driven by fate, and his fate is to fight the fearsome Baboon Warrior, assassin of the gods. More dungpunk than cyberpunk, Shiva 3000 is an ambitious effort and worth reading even if the technology on display doesn't quite stand up to scrutiny.
