For her parents, the image of their daughter's future - wearing a traditional wedding dress - was slowly replaced by that of a tall, slender woman enveloped in a lawyer's robe, or a doctor's white coat. Her parents may have treated her brother preferentially but the favoritism could have been much worse, she says. Her family was educated and her father, a teacher, was broadminded. And yet she felt her brother could move freely while she had to sit politely. Her grandmother would counter her protestations by telling her to control her "long tongue". But what was not said was written. One day her Arabic teacher asked the class to write an imaginative story. She handed in the novel she had secretly written. It tracked a 12-year-old girl's doubts about religious ritual and parental rules. ("The child is myself," El Saadawi says now.) She was 14. Her teacher gave her a zero and scrawled on her story "strange distorted ideas which should never occur to a girl of your age". The zero was to be the first of many rebuffs that El Saadawi has received for her writing. But there have been many accolades too. Since 1957, when her first novel was published, she has written 32 books, including articles, short stories, plays, memoirs, polemics and novels covering Arab women, colonialism, fundamentalism and globalisation - red flags to many bulls. She writes in Arabic and almost all her books have been translated, into more than 30 languages; 27 into English and 14 into Japanese. The novelist and activist, who trained as a doctor, has survived censorship, incarceration and, most recently, exile, for putting pen to paper. Despite the efforts of her teacher, El Saadawi is the leading voice of her generation on the status of Arab women. She compares a pen to a scalpel. "Words should not seek to please," she writes in A Daughter of Isis, the first part of her autobiography, adding that words "should not hide the wounds in our bodies, the shameful moments in our lives." When she was six, she underwent a clitorectomy at the hands of a daya (midwife), who said it was the will of God. Nawal called for her mother to rescue her, only to find that she had been present all along. She later wrote a letter to God saying, "I'm not ready to believe in you if you're not just." Everywhere she looked she saw "double standards, contradictions and injustices. That's why I don't agree with religion," she says. "All religion is political. It's full of war and peace, economics and sexuality." Her father made his children pray, but told them not to believe in God unless they were convinced of his existence. This played a major role in the young El Saadawi's development. "I never feared discussing whether God existed or not," she says. Her first lessons in philosophy, religion and politics were learnt, she says in Kafr Tahla, her father's obscure village on the Nile. Her paternal grandmother, an illiterate peasant would say to the village headman: "We are not slaves, and Allah is justice." Her mother was from an upper-middle class family. Her maternal grandfather's house in Cairo, a villa with a garden was "like a palace" compared to the village home where the family slept on mats laid on the dust floor. Levels of education, "the way they talked," also contrasted. "I was brought up between two classes," El Saadawi says. "Peasant and bourgeois." Physically, she moved between the two houses, but it was the village that she thought of as home. El Saadawi was the second child of nine. Her mother's loving care made her childhood very happy. Her father was a just and kind man who never raised his voice. He was "atypical. I wasn't brought up by a masculine man. That's why I had such problems with men," she says. When he came home from work, he laid the table, prepared food, washed the pots and pans and sewed his own clothes. When Nawal was four the family moved to Alexandria. Her mother became more distant and Nawal became closer to her father. He had marched against the British in the 1919 revolution and was active in anti-colonial struggle. "Because of my father I lived politics every day." In 1938, when she was seven, the government transferred him to the small town of Menouf in the middle of the Nile delta - punishment for his participation in student demonstrations against the acceptance of British rule by the Egyptian king and his government. She loved to listen to her revolutionary father but his words were always addressed to her brother. Her job was to take care of her younger siblings. "A boy's childhood is much longer," she says. Her brothers and sisters were never friends. "Their way of thinking is totally different. They conform." Her sisters cover their heads. Her brothers are very religious. "They never challenged. Maybe they never faced the obstacles I did. " She didn't want to be a doctor, but a girl with good grades had to do something respectable. She won a scholarship and went to medical school "to satisfy my parents" and dreamed of being an artist, a singer, a musician, a painter. "I hated doctors, death and disease." Her graduation from Cairo University's medical school in 1955 left her "more ignorant than when I entered". It began her slow-burning disillusionment with the idea that illnesses could be cured by medicine alone. She had joined other students on the streets in demonstrations against the British occupation of Egypt and began to write articles for Egyptian newspapers about the links she had seen between poverty and disease. Her reading widened to sociology, philosophy, religion and literature. "To see the human body as a whole, to see society and knowledge as a whole," has been her life's work she says. "To break down and analyse, only to build up and synthesise. This was my progression from the particular to the general, from the personal to the political, from one woman to all women, from the individual to the collective." El Saadawi, now 68, is acknowledged as a uniquely powerful voice in the international women's movement. "She's an amazing gift to the movement," says Beatrix Campbell, the writer and broadcaster, who met her in the mid-80s at a rally in Hyde Park in support of the miners' strike. "She was a woman who in that period of British feminism was a remarkable presence. She was one of the first to initiate the engagement between black and white feminists." Women And Sex, her first work of non-fiction, slashed at the mythology surrounding sex, virginity and marriage. Until then she had written novels as well as newspaper articles drawn from her observations as a rural doctor in the 1950s. Women And Sex, published in 1971, when she was Egypt's director general of public health, went much further. El Saadawi became the first Arab woman to write against female circumcision, arguing that it stems from the ancient practice of monogamy for women and polygamy for men. Because of the ensuing controversy she lost her job as well as her seat on the board of the government medical syndicate in 1972. Her writing was banned. The magazine she edited about social influences on health was closed down. "I think women can be easily attacked, " she says. "They said I was promiscuous. Oh yes, they said everything." El Saadawi's own writing is often a form of attack, delivered behind a shield of scholarly authority. She relates the history of Arab women's liberation to the anti-colonial struggle. Her novels veer towards reportage: clear and precise accounts of stories previously untold. "I have my utmost pleasure when I'm writing my novels," she says. "It's the present tense, the here and now, that I enjoy. It's my constitution. I love novels more than anything because they help us to understand." She was cooped-up in Cairo writing from home following her censorship in 1972. While her work was sent to Beirut to be published, she felt isolated. In 1978 she took up a post with the United Nations as an adviser on women's development. The job took her all over the middle east and Africa. In retrospect, she says, it was way of seeing for herself "that the UN was not seriously interested in either development or women". In 1981, a year after she returned to Cairo, Sadat put her in jail along with more than 1,000 others for "crimes against the state". She hid her pen and notes written on toilet paper in a camouflaged hole in her cell. These notes were to become Memoirs From A Women's Prison, an account of the "terrible" months she spent in a jail bursting with prisoners. She shared a cell with 12 others, some imprisoned for their fundamentalism, others for their Marxism, but all facing the grim daily reality of bread and beans with worms, the floor or plank of wood for a bed, the fleas and the bugs. Obedience, El Saadawi says, was the only way to avoid being beaten. Imprisonment accentuated life, she says. "I remember anger and extreme happiness," she says. Simple things such as the smell of tea made her ecstatic. Her release after three months was thanks to Sadat's assassination and the succession of the present Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak. "Hers was a project of social-realism: to speak of all those things that had never been said," says the writer and poet Michele Roberts, who met El Saadawi in London in the early 80s. " Many British women read her books. We shared the ideology of novel writing. We believed in telling the truth and that novels could testify and effect social reality." In 1993, with Muslim fundamentalism growing in Egypt, her name was put on a death-list. Government security guards surrounded her home and a bodyguard trailed her. She believed the government was largely to blame for religious extremism and was suspicious of the guards. With her husband, she boarded a plane for North Carolina in the United States. She watched Egypt from a distance and taught a course at Duke University about the experience - Dissidence and Creativity. Exile made her feel "like a fish outside the sea". She was homesick. "Life became very dear," she says. "I felt death was over my head like a big black cloud. So I wanted to write my life. I became very sensual. I loved food. I loved sex. That's how we survive." In the 80s she had become involved with British political campaigns: the miners' strike, Greenham common, sit-ins against NHS cuts, demonstrations against the National Front, CND.Her position as an eastern intellectual embraced by the west has led her work to be simultaneously used in the west to justify objections to Islam while in the east there are hopes that her writing will serve as an antidote to western misconceptions about Arab women as supine, veiled creatures in need of rescuing. "She had a knowledge and critique of British feminism while British feminism didn't have a confident engagement with African or middle eastern feminism," says Beatrix Campbell. "Here was a woman sustained by feminism and in an argument with it. And while defending her own society in an argument with it and ours." The arguments, when first expressed, were revelatory. It is not Islam, she argued, that oppressed women in the Arab Islamic countries, but the inability of Arab people to take control of their economic potential and resources. "I have never separated women's liberation from the liberation of my country," she says. Economics, she argues shapes the standards and values of all religions. She rails against the prevalent conception of women's liberation as a western invention that has trickled to women in the east. Lives have been changed by El Saadawi. Marlyn Tadros first met her in 1988 at a book fair in Cairo. At the time Tadros was 28 and had worked as an air-hostess, but her husband had confiscated her passport. She had just read The Hidden Face Of Eve, El Saadawi's 1980 work on the status of women in Arab countries. "It was only Nawal who said how I felt was unnatural," she says. "When you live in a mainstream that tells you 'this is natural' it's extremely empowering to find someone out there who thinks differently." Tadros, now the senior director of programmes for a human rights organisation, after a stint as a visiting fellow at Harvard, cites this meeting as the beginning of her own activism. El Saadawi writes in The Hidden Face Of Eve: "There are still so many thinkers . . . who wish to separate the arduous struggles of women for self-emancipation from the revolt of the people everywhere." What we share rather than what separates us interests her. She tells a story about how, when giving a lecture in the States, a woman in the audience asked: "how do you explain why some Muslim women want to wear the veil?" She relishes her reply: "In the same way that I'd explain why you choose to wear make-up. Like make-up, it hides the face of women. They both show conformity to a culture's idea of what is feminine." Her analysis is a series of cultural and political dot-to-dots. "I think clitorectomy is done to all women," she says. "Be it physical, psychological, educational. When Freud said the clitoris is a male organ in a female body and clitoral orgasm is related to childhood he cut the clitoris psychologically because he abolished its function." Unusually for an Egyptian woman, El Saadawi has married three times; the first time, aged 24, to a fellow student two years her senior at medical school. Like her father, he was active in the anti-colonial struggle; a guerrilla fighter against the British military occupation of the Suez Canal. Nationalist sentiment and the humiliation of the Egyptian armed forces during the war against the newly independent state of Israel precipitated a coup, led by Mohammed Neguib in July 1952, in which the ruling King Farouk was deposed. When Neguib's political rival Gamal Abdel Nasser assumed power two years later, El Saadawi's first husband came out of hiding and returned to her. But he had become embittered and disturbed by his enforced self-exile and fled to upper Egypt, racked with depression. "The depression added to his patriarchal tendencies," she says. "I was a successful doctor. He tried to dominate me." The couple had a daughter, Mona, now 44, a writer and essayist living in Cairo. When El Saadawi's salary could no longer stretch to supporting her husband and their daughter, she turned to her father. He helped her get a divorce and she lived with her parents in Giza, a district of Cairo, until they died a couple of years later. Her second husband, a lawyer, hated being married to a woman who ruffled so many feathers, and they divorced within a year. "I didn't love him very much but he said he'd accept my conditions. I needed a partner. A secret love affair would have ruined my career. The social pressure to be married was great." In 1964 she married Sherif Hetata, a doctor, writer and activist. They have a son, Araf, now 39, a film director, who lives in Cairo. Hetata is her English translator and companion. They are a beautiful, entertaining double act: "I wanted to be with a political man," she says. "That's not what you told me," he interrupts. "You said you wanted to marry a man who'd been in prison." They met at the ministry of health, where he was setting up a rural health programme. He had just been released from a 14-year prison sentence for membership of a communist party that had criticised Nasser's regime. Hetata "was sure of himself, thoughtful, calm and serious," she says. "I felt I could trust him." El Saadawi has never belonged to a political party. "I was never a Marxist, never a communist. Why should I belong to Marx, or Nasser or Sadat and abolish my name? Marx is a man who created a theory. We can all be philosophers. I was always just myself." It is an attitude that over the years has made her enemies and brought her criticism. Marlyn Tadros says El Saadawi is a pioneer "but she's a very, very difficult person and I don't want to stay around her. She has to have everything her way. There's often only a semblance of democracy. Her self-confidence goes against her." Recognition for pioneering work, Tadros says, is particularly hard to come by in Egypt and the middle east, and so El Saadawi "has to act up for it. She has been isolated by the women's movement in Egypt - other feminists have not included her in projects." Beatrix Campbell says British feminism "deified" El Saadawi. "There's always a risk that black women are rarefied, exoticised and isolated. It's easier for the white world if there's only one different voice. It doesn't have to deal with the clamouring; all those things that different people have to say. El Saadawi moved very easily in a white woman's world. She was received as a lone star." It is a position that makes Yasmin Alibhai Brown, a commentator on race affairs, uncomfortable. "There was something alarming about the way one woman's life was grabbed and used to simplify all Arab women's lives. She's from that final wave of colonialism where being a member of the international westernised elite was desirable. There are new kinds of writers now." El Saadawi's friend of 20 years, Haleh Afshar, professor of politics and women's studies at York University, says that El Saadawi has been bashed both ways. "In the States she is often seen as an eastern intellectual exotic on the sidelines. She is no longer a prophet in her own land, and she wasn't one in the States." At the beginning of this year, after six years' exile in the United States, El Saadawi returned to Egypt to finish the third and final part of her autobiography. Mubarak's government, itself threatened by the extremist Islamic groups that wanted her dead, is now beginning to tackle them, she says. She feels safer. Part one of her memoir, covering the first 24 years of her life, is a sensuous recollection: the smell of her mother's skin, the pain in her growing bones. Back home in Egypt, other women have been slogging away to change the nitty-gritty details of areas such as the law, health and education to improve women's lives. They are not starry-eyed over El Saadawi. Hala Shukrallah, a member of the New Women Research Centre in Cairo, which campaigns, offers legal support and community-based projects for women's rights, is unequivocal about how El Saadawi's absence from grassroots activism in Egypt has diminished her significance there. "She was important in the 70s but I don't think she's had an influence in the 90s," she says. "She's not here. When you're not here and not struggling on the same level, you're out of it. She's been shaped by her audience and has directed her work to the west when she's there. That's natural." El Saadawi compares herself to a horse jumping over obstacles. "When I clear one jump, the next is higher." She has set herself some tough hurdles. She was among a delegation of nine women to Baghdad a month before the expiry of the UN deadline and the outbreak of the Gulf war in 1991. She met the UN secretary-general in New York and toured the US for two weeks to rally support for peace and an Arab solution to the war. The initiative grew out of the Arab Women's Solidarity Association, the first pan-Arab organisation to be accorded international status at the UN, which El Saadawi founded to counter "the isolation" of writing. The government closed the Egyptian branch of the association later that year. She appeared at the 1985 United Nations women's conference in Nairobi, but did not attend the international debate in Beijing a decade later. Why not? "I received an invitation," she says. "But after the UN's intervention and collaboration with western powers in the Gulf war it became the United Nations of America for me: a tool in the hands of global capitalist powers. I'm wasting my time going. Women will never be liberated if the UN is involved." The world has not turned out in the way that El Saadawi once hoped. "Those countries with global power bring barriers between countries so capital can flow more easily. They speak about diversity, freedom, multiculturalism, and divide people by religion and race in the name of post- modernism. We should be undoing the differences between us." Haleh Afshar detects a lament for lost opportunities in El Saadawi's autobiography. "It's full of bitterness and sadness," she says. "Nawal started in an era where modernity and progress meant that a young woman from a village could, as she did, become a government minister. You can't do that in Egypt today. There is less social mobility. She had a vision that didn't come good. It's so different from the exuberant, lively person she is." El Saadawi's journey between Cairo and the village is all the travelling she wants to do for now. She and Hetata have built a small house in his family village just north of hers in the middle of the delta. They go there two or three times a year to write and relax, she says. The village is "typical - just fields, animals everywhere, small streets and children running around". Every other year she will spend a month teaching at Florida Atlantic University. Dissidence and creativity will still be her subject. Next month she must submit the third and final part of her autobiography to her Egyptian publishers. More meetings are planned to discuss setting up an Egyptian women's union. El Saadawi hopes as always that links will form between the fragments. She's trying to find "a charismatic woman" to lead it. She's very busy with her writing these days. The movement needs someone less controversial, she says. Someone with a clean slate. "I'm arguing," she says, "that it may be better for the union to have a young woman leading it." Will she miss America? "I miss teaching. It allows me to speak my mind but I was always going to be an alien there. I needed to be near my children, my village, my friends. I told Sherif that it's better to die here. But wherever I am I'm criticising the government. Now I feel at home in every country. I feel as if I belong to the world," she smiles. "I don't belong to a certain place." Life at a glance Born: 1931 Kafr Tahal, Egypt. Education: Helwan school, Cairo; 1949-55 Cairo University (doctor of medicine); 1966 Columbia University New York (masters in public health). Married: 1955-57 Ahmed Elmy (one daughter); 1960-61 [name with held]; 1964- Sherif Hetata (one son). Career: 1956-8 medical officer, Cairo Hospital University;1958-9 village doctor; 1966-72 director general of public health, Egyptian ministry of health; 1978-90 head of UN women's programme in economic commission for Africa; 1982- president, Arab women's solidarity association. Some books (English translations): 1972 Women And Sex; 1980 The Hidden Face Of Eve; 1982 Woman At Point Zero; 1984 God Dies By The Nile; 1987 The Fall Of The Imam; 1985 Memoirs From The Women's Prison; 1992 The Well Of Life; 1999, A Daughter of Isis.  The first part of Nawal El Saadawi's autobiography, A Daughter Of Isis, is published by Zed Books at £14.95.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: George Orwell gives a masterclass in clarity, plus Harold Evan's classic Essential English
fields.body:
Essays
George Orwell
Penguin, £9.99

Buy it at BOL

Comprehensive enough a one-vol edition to dispatch copies as tracts, proselytising for more private thought and quiet action and less journalistic, political crap. His observations of Marrakech, of its seen but unperceived toilers, should be sent to those who write of 24 hours in Reykjavik's clubs as if they were overviewing the planet; his brief BritLit history, "Inside the Whale", to those who review fashionable novels as though the present era could never be outmoded. And "The Art of Donald McGill", on the philosophy of the seaside comic postcard, goes to those who analyse pop culture without any real affection for it. No pretensions, no arrogance, just calm clarity. Perfect.

Essential English for Journalists
Harold Evans
(Pimlico, £12.50)
Buy it at BOL

Updated (apart from the cover pic of pen-edited hard copy - now a museum piece); another volume we would like to distribute free to academic authors, Blair's WI speechwriters, the assemblers of television presenter-speak, and anyone who believes that "war-torn" is an exciting, or indeed even an acceptable, adjective. Not sure, though, if our thickening newspapers now really want or understand the brevity, clarity and cogency that Evans promotes. There are now just so many pages to be filled, so many big-type words to be used as design elements rather than as communication, that his crisp precepts might no longer apply.

fields.headline: MBE for England's 'prince of centres'
fields.trailText: Sport
fields.body:
Jeremy Guscott, the supreme centre for the England rugby side for more than a decade, has been made an MBE.

His former international coach Jack Rowell labelled him "the prince of centres" and Guscott established himself - with his pace, effortless style and fierce determination - as the man England could least manage without.

When injury forced him to retire from the England side last year, he had amassed 65 caps and scored 30 Test match tries in an international career that incorporated three World Cup campaigns and three British Lions tours.

He is now preparing for a possible comeback in the next campaign with Bath.

Other sporting celebrities honoured include the former pentathlete Mary Peters, who becomes a DBE for services to sport and to the community in Northern Ireland. The chairman of the McLaren racing team, Ron Dennis, becomes a CBE, as does the jockey turned author Dick Francis. The Radio 5 Live commentator Jimmy Armfield is awarded an OBE as is the chairman of Reading FC, John Madejski.

The City's two most senior figures, the Bank of England governor Eddie George and his former deputy, Howard Davies, now head of the Financial Services Authority, each receive a knighthood in the honours list.

Mr George is a career central banker who started at the Bank of England in 1962 and is serving his second five-year term as governor. He now chairs the nine-member monetary policy committee, which determines the level of interest rates.

Mr Davies, a former director general of the Confederation of British Industry, was Mr George's deputy until leaving Threadneedle Street for Canary Wharf in 1997 to set up the FSA, the City's new super regulator, supervising banks and other financial institutions.

Ian Byatt, director general of Ofwat, the water company regulator, who is due to retire next month after a lengthy civil service career, also receives a knighthood.

fields.headline: Knighted Caine no longer 'ignored'
fields.standfirst: Applause for stars of film, stage, music and TV
fields.trailText: Show business
fields.body:
It is ironic that Sir Michael Caine, who earlier this year claimed he had been ignored by the establishment, has been recognised with the ultimate accolade - a knighthood for services to drama.

The star of Alfie, The Italian Job, Get Carter and The Man Who Would Be King courted controversy when he was presented with a Bafta fellowship. In an outspoken acceptance speech, he claimed that for years he had been shunned by the establishment, which had made him feel like an outsider.

This was all forgotten yesterday when the 67-year-old said he was "ecstatic", describing it as the greatest day of his life.

Caine was born Maurice Micklewhite, the son of a Billingsgate fish porter and cleaner, in south London. His film career spans four decades. He won an Oscar earlier this year as best supporting actor for his role in The Cider House Rules - the film version of John Irving's book.

It comes as no surprise that Sam Mendes, the film and theatre director who won international acclaim (and two Oscars) for American Beauty, the story of dysfunctional family life in suburban America, was once described as "very young, very bright, very talented, very sickening".

Now he has an OBE for services to drama at the age of 34. He started his career straight after university at the Minerva theatre, Chichester, West Sussex, where he was artistic director, at the age of 22.

Two years later he had successfully staged two plays in the West End. His production of Oliver! at the London Palladium caught the eye of the critics and ensured he was comfortably well-off.

In 1992, he was in charge of his own theatre - the Donmar Warehouse, in Covent Garden, London. It was there that he persuaded Nicole Kidman to strip off in David Hare's play The Blue Room.

The television presenter and maths wizard, Carol Vorderman 39, receives an MBE for services to broadcasting. She has appeared on the Channel 4 quiz show Countdown since the early 1980s, but a meteoric rise in her fortunes came quite recently. Ms Vorderman is now the most highly paid woman on television. "These are two consonants and a vowel I am very proud of," she said.

Lulu, the 51-year-old singer and entertainer, gets an OBE for services to music. She was a shy teenager when Shout! hit the charts in 1964. She went on to win the Eurovision song contest five years later with Boom-Bang-A-Bang. To Sir With Love was another of her memorable songs. She later honed her skills as an all-round entertainer.

She enjoyed a renaissance in the 90s with the boy band Take That, when she joined them on the song, Relight My Fire.

Lonnie Donegan, 69, who is best remembered for ditties such as Does Your Chewing Gum Lose its Flavour on the Bedpost Overnight? and My Old Man's a Dustman also gets an MBE for services to music.

The king of skiffle, who brought black American blues across the Atlantic, joined Van Morrison in a series of recent concerts.

fields.headline: Suits you, Sir Paul
fields.trailText: Design
fields.body:
Paul Smith, who has been awarded a knighthood, revolutionised menswear and persuaded British men that even they could look good in designer clothes.

"It's nice for the industry. Fashion is sometimes treated rather flippantly, yet we're a big contributor to the economy."

Mr Smith, 53, left school at 15 to take a warehouse job. He opened his first shop, in Nottingham, with £600 in 1970. His empire is worth about £180m a year. He has more than 220 shops and sells his designs in 42 countries.

Tom Dixon, who receives the OBE, is one of the most successful British designers of the last 20 years. Credited with putting the zing back into Habitat, he first emerged with Creative Salvage, a group that made furniture out of scrap metal.

fields.headline: Bainbridge bathed in glory
fields.standfirst: Awards span literature, TV and sculpture
fields.trailText: Arts
fields.body:
Only the rarest, household-name sporting celebrities get their feet on the rungs of an honours list when they are as young as the author Joanne Rowling, 34, who was yesterday awarded an OBE.

But if her Harry Potter stories continue selling at their present tempo - 30m copies so far - then she can probably count on a grateful book industry lobbying for her to be made a dame within a decade.

Ms Rowling is honoured for services to publishing and bookshop coffers and to young readers with imaginations; and above all for proving, as one critic said, that not every computer games-sodden nine-year-old has attention deficit disorder.

By contrast, Vivien Duffield, Beryl Bainbridge and Anne Evans took decades to achieve their damehoods. Ms Duffield, 54, Covent Garden's legendary fund-raising luncher, has given away £90m. She has said: "I don't eat lunch myself, I'm too fat..."

Ms Bainbridge, 65, has published six plays and 18 novels, almost all successful, but missed the Booker prize five times. She is one of the literary circuit's most familiarly cheerful, rueful voices. When she goes out, she says "I try to find some clothes without fag burns in them".

Anne Evans was acclaimed as the finest singer of Wagner of her generation after triumphing as Brunnhilde for three seasons at Bayreuth. A critic wrote: "She has shed new light on the colouring of the vocal line and the meaning of the text."

The actress Sian Phillips, made a CBE, won a drama student gold medal in 1958, making an immediate and astonishing professional debut as Hedda Gabler and the Duchess of Malfi.

Widely remembered as the empress Livia in the TV adaptation of I, Claudius in 1976, she has recently toured the US as Marlene Dietrich. Her marriage to the actor Peter O'Toole was dissolved in 1979.

Derek Deane, 47, who receives an OBE as artistic director of the English National Ballet, is credited with doing more to bring ballet to the public than anyone else in his field.

Once resented for his firmness with dancers, he recouped the company's finances and had triumphs with Swan Lake and The Nutcracker in the late 1990s.

Another OBE winner, the sculptor Andy Goldsworthy, 43, uses ephemeral natural material such as sheets of leaves stitched together with thorns.

Recently he extended his range with a series of installations, including slate walls, at the National Museum of Scotland.

That, he said, "is as permanent as it's going to get".

webTitle: Chat show legend made a CBE

fields.headline: Chat show legend made a CBE
fields.trailText: Media
fields.body:
Michael Parkinson, the Yorkshire-born chat show host, 65, was made a CBE for his services to broadcasting. After an 11-year stint on BBC1, his show was dropped in the 80s but revived again in 1997.

Guests on the Parkinson show have included Muhammad Ali and John Lennon and there was the ill-fated confrontation with Rod Hull and Emu - during which he was floored by the comic. Last year Parkinson pulled off the coup of having Sir Paul McCartney on his show, fulfilling a pledge that the musician made more than 25 years earlier. He has also worked on radio for many years with an award-winning show on BBC Radio 2: Parkinson's Sunday Supplement, among his many credits.

Parkinson said he was "happy and proud" yesterday and so was his family with the award.

The chat show host grew up in a council house in Cudworth in Yorkshire, near Grimethorpe colliery where his father was a miner. After landing a place at Barnsley grammar school he went on to take his first steps on the journalistic ladder, with local papers in Yorkshire, before moving to Fleet Street and the Daily Express.

He later worked as a producer at Granada TV and eventually moved in front of the cameras.

Throughout his broadcasting his career he has continued to write, penning sports columns and many books.

Another award winner, Tina Brown, the US-based British editor, who launched Talk magazine last September, gets a CBE in the diplomatic service and overseas honours list for services to journalism overseas.

She is one of Britain's most successful journalists, having edited Vanity Fair from 1984 to 1992.

Michael Brunson, who recently retired as political editor of ITN, became one of Britain's most respected political broadcasters during his long career. He gets an OBE for services to journalism.

Will Wyatt, latterly chief executive of BBC Broadcasting and the deputy director general under John Birt, was made a CBE.

fields.headline: Combat 18 men among fans expelled
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Three neo-Nazis were sent back to Britain yesterday and four men were arrested for fighting American tourists on a Eurostar train as thousands of England fans flooded into Belgium for today's vital Euro 2000 match with Germany.
fields.body:
Three neo-Nazis were sent back to Britain yesterday and four men were arrested for fighting American tourists on a Eurostar train as thousands of England fans flooded into Belgium for today's vital Euro 2000 match with Germany.

As security forces across western Europe stepped up their hunt for troublemakers heading for the match, 22 supporters from Barnsley were also turned back. The number of English fans sent home in the tournament's first week has risen to around 50, with 18 arrests.

Last night about 50 riot police moved in to break up trouble between England supporters and local Turks in Charleroi. After being goaded, the England fans chased the locals across the town's square hurling chairs.

Three members of the fascist group Combat 18 were sent back from Brussels after flying there from Heathrow, according to police sources. They were named as Paul Parish, 32, Paul Holiday, 37, and Nicholas Marsh, 34, all from Milton Keynes. They are believed to have more than 60 convictions between them for a variety of public and violence offences.

Another six fans on the same Eurostar train as the four arrested for fighting also face being sent back.

The 22 Barnsley fans were returned from Dussledorf airport, Germany, today. Three Aston Villa fans were sent back from Ostend. Others refused entry included men from Oldham and Bolton with football-related convictions, and two fans from Brighton, one from Oxford, one from Sunderland, one from Swindon and one from Leicester, at undisclosed locations.

Police estimate that up to 10,000 ticketless England fans could be in Belgium over the weekend and the match, which will decide England's Euro 2000 future, is a sell-out. Kevin Keegan's men must avoid defeat if they are to remain in the tournament.

Many England fans are staying in Brussels, 30 minutes away, and will arrive in Charleroi today. About 3,000 officers will be on duty, with another 120 on horseback.

fields.headline: Peerless Blair honours middle England
fields.trailText: Tony Blair offers middle England a Queen's birthday honour's list after its own heart today with awards for soap stars, sports heroes of all ages, best-selling novelists, successful headteachers - and virtually no politicians.
fields.body:
Tony Blair offers middle England a Queen's birthday honour's list after its own heart today with awards for soap stars, sports heroes of all ages, best-selling novelists, successful headteachers - and virtually no politicians.

Today's belated knighthood for the Oscar-winning actor Michael Caine and the designer Paul Smith, plus assorted gongs for the likes of pop veterans Lulu and Lonnie Donegan, writers JK "Harry Potter" Rowling and Colin Dexter, the creator of Inspector Morse, are unusually accompanied by not one peerage.

Paddy Ashdown, the former Liberal Democrat leader and ally of Tony Blair in centre-left realignment, gets one of 25 knighthoods, as do such pillars of the new establishment as the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, the City watchdog, Howard Davies, and the tenacious water regulator, Ian Byatt.

But these honours among the 971 given - a record 40% of them to women - are partly overshadowed by awards to controversial businessmen, which surprised some Labour critics. Not only does the Tory party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, cap his recent peerage with a knighthood, the KCMG, courtesy of the government of Belize, but the Barclay brothers, David and Frederick, also get knighthoods for services to charity.

Famously secretive about their affairs, the fabulously wealthy Barclays have built themselves a fortress in the low-tax Channel Islands. But they are listed in today's Downing Street press release as resident in Monte Carlo.

The latest Ashcroft honour was not one either Mr Blair or Buckingham Palace could reject, coming as it did from the Commonwealth government that his wealth and expertise benefited.

A Labour MP, Peter Bradley, said: "At the rate Ashcroft is going, he'll be a member of the royal family by Christmas." Mr Blair is leaving most peerages in future to the new appointments commission. His priority this summer has been to reward people doing good jobs in health and education, with 11 new knights and dameships between them.

The arts patron Vivien Duffield, a pillar of the Royal Opera House, becomes Dame Vivien. More surprisingly, so does the feisty novelist Beryl Bainbridge. Another new dame is Mary Peters, an Olympic pentathlon gold medallist, like Jim Fox who gets an OBE.

The golfer Paul Lawrie, who won the Open, and rugby's Jeremy Guscott get MBEs, as does Wendy Richard (Pauline Fowler in EastEnders) and Liz Dawn, who is not only Coronation Street's gossipy Vera Duckworth but the campaigning mayoress of Leeds.

Carol Vorderman, said to be the highest-paid woman on television, is awarded an MBE, while the distinguished Welsh actor Sian Phillips gets a CBE, the same award as Sam Mendes of the Donmar Warehouse, fresh from his Oscar for American Beauty.

CBEs also go to Michael Parkinson, the great survivor of the chatshow sofa, and Elizabeth Jane Howard, novelist ex-wife of Kingsley Amis and patient stepmother to Martin. Now 77, she has been writing books since she was nine.

Lulu, who had her first No 1 at 19, gets an OBE, as does the ex-footballer Jimmy Armfield, capped 43 times for England. In another sentimental gesture to a bygone era, an MBE goes to Sidney Wooderson, 86, a legendary miler in his time.

Media awards include Michael Brunson of ITV (an OBE) and the magazine editor Tina Brown (CBE).

Stephen Lander, the new head of the security services, gets the standard Whitehall knighthood for the post. Another goes to Murdo MacLean, the shadowy Mr Fixit between the government and opposition at Westminster.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • Tuesday, and the London Metal Exchange summoned the world's media to a boardroom briefing on plans to turn the mutual marketplace into a go-getting (sort of) private company. Fresh flowers decorated the boardroom table, placed there not, alas, in honour of the fourth estate but of a very important guest due later that day, Alderman Clive Martin, lord mayor of London. His worship, explained chairman Lord Bagri and chief executive David King, has close links with the LME. Indeed, he is one of an ultra-special category of "honorary and individual members". That's tremendous, isn't it? Well, yes and no. Section 2.2 of Tuesday's blueprint makes it clear that this membership category is to be abolished. We wonder which of the LME's high command broke the news that his worship was not wanted on voyage.

 Tuesday, and the London Metal Exchange summoned the world's media to a boardroom briefing on plans to turn the mutual marketplace into a go-getting (sort of) private company. Fresh flowers decorated the boardroom table, placed there not, alas, in honour of the fourth estate but of a very important guest due later that day, Alderman Clive Martin, lord mayor of London. His worship, explained chairman Lord Bagri and chief executive David King, has close links with the LME. Indeed, he is one of an ultra-special category of "honorary and individual members". That's tremendous, isn't it? Well, yes and no. Section 2.2 of Tuesday's blueprint makes it clear that this membership category is to be abolished. We wonder which of the LME's high command broke the news that his worship was not wanted on voyage.

 Should you have thought the single European currency was complex, wait until you clap eyes on the not-so-single European postage stamp. Clock Inf€uro, one of the European commission's many propaganda mags, which features some examples of "stamps relating to the euro ... a useful ... and amusing ... [their dots, not ours] way to get to know the euro!" Yes, it's a barrel of laughs. The French post office has generated something with three sets of numbers on (price in francs, euro price and 2000, lest one has forgotten the date) and five languages, including the hated Anglais. Belgium's offering is a masterpiece of non-clarity, being marked 17/0.42, which reads like one of Captain Kirk's famous "star dates". Ireland's is a little more straightforward, bearing the simple message that 30 Irish pennies equal 38 euro-centimes (Irish inflation permitting). Luxembourg appears to have abandoned dreary old money altogether, marking its stamp simply "A", presumably not a credit rating for the Kleenex currency. But then, as European commissioner David Byrne explains earlier in Inf€uro, we aren't really talking about a currency at all but "a new social bond". Inf€uriating, or what?

 Across the sea, and farewell, then, Joe Stiglitz, who was chief economic adviser to the World Bank until he had the temerity earlier this year to rip into the "stabilisation" policies of the International Monetary Fund, at which point he was sacked at the prompting of Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary. His successor is Nick Stern, who, as the brother of World Bank human resources bigwig Richard Stern, very nearly fell foul of the bank's anti-nepotism policies. Indeed, the staff association was vocal on this point, we hear, but Nick was not only allowed in but turned up to Professor Stiglitz's recent leaving bash in Washington DC. Bank president James Wolfensohn was also there, and expressed his sadness at the prof's departure, not least because he now had to tell two brothers apart. Indeed, he pretended to mistake one of them for the violinist Isaac Stern. At least, we think he was pretending.

 Back home, and another set of findings from the Central Office for Suspiciously Round Numbers (COSRN), the people who routinely announce that "Lloyd's of London is facing a £1bn bill" for whatever is the latest catastrophe. This time it's a more modest £1m-plus, the daily cost to British business, allegedly, of hunting for lost files. webTitle: Kremlin critic freed after tide of protest

fields.headline: Kremlin critic freed after tide of protest
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian authorities last night released the media tycoon and Kremlin critic Vladimir Gusinsky, after three days in jail, bowing to a wave of protest at home and abroad that has severely embarassed President Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
The Russian authorities last night released the media tycoon and Kremlin critic Vladimir Gusinsky, after three days in jail, bowing to a wave of protest at home and abroad that has severely embarassed President Vladimir Putin.

In a move as surprising as the initial arrest on Tuesday, the prosecutor's office in Moscow said Mr Gusinsky, 47, the owner of Russia's sole independent media empire, was being allowed out of Moscow's Butyrka prison after 72 hours in remand that had turned him into a symbol of victimhood in post-Yeltsin Russia.

Mr Gusinsky was released on a pledge that he would not flee the country. Earlier yesterday prosecutors charged him with embezzlement of some $10m of state funds, arising from his company's takeover of a St Petersburg television company in 1997.

Winding up a visit abroad yesterday, Mr Putin, who has been relentlessly grilled over the Gusinsky affair during three days in Spain and Germany, said he did not think the allegations were enough to warrant instant arrest. On Thursday he said the action appeared excessive.

The arrest presented Mr Putin with his biggest political scandal and conflict since he became president, with domestic opponents and foreign critics accusing the Kremlin of reverting to Soviet-era repression and even Stalinism.

fields.headline: Rivals threaten Channel 4 racing
fields.trailText: Horse racing broadcasts on Channel 4 looked to be in jeopardy this weekend after it emerged that a number of proposals are being put to racecourse owners that could see the broadcaster stripped of its rights.
fields.body:
Horse racing broadcasts on Channel 4 looked to be in jeopardy this weekend after it emerged that a number of proposals are being put to racecourse owners that could see the broadcaster stripped of its rights.

The Racecourse Association, which represents the interests of Britain's top tracks, is due to meet in London on Monday to hear rival proposals on how best to broadcast race meetings and maximise the betting revenues likely to be generated through interactive television.

The meeting will be the culmination of months of behind the scenes manoeuvring and comes days after the conclusion of the bitterly contested battle for Premier League football broadcasting rights.

Racing insiders expect Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB, racecourse owner-cum-media company Arena Leisure, and SIS - the current broadcasters of the Racing Channel - to be among those making alternative pitches.

In February, Channel 4, in partnership with the BBC and cable company NTL, thought it had agreed a £225m 10-year deal to broadcast race meetings from Britain's 12 top tracks. However, the agreement, which includes rights to broadcast from courses including Ascot, Epsom, Goodwood and Aintree, remains unsigned.

Racing insiders say the course owners believe the deal does not value their rights highly enough, particularly in light of the £1.6bn secured by the Premier League. They also believe the internet offers significant extra opportunities to generate cash from on-line betting, broadcasting and e-commerce.

Those course owners outside the so-called Super 12, who together account for 65% of annual betting turnover, are particularly angry at the smaller amount they have been offered for their rights and are considering striking an alternative deal of their own.

Channel 4 insiders warned that without the support of most of the 47 smaller tracks it could withdraw its current offer. "Racing has to decide whether it is prepared to go forward with a united front at this crucial point in its future," a Channel 4 source said. "We will only complete the deal as it stands if we have sufficient UK racing to broadcast."

Super 12 sources said they hoped the deadlock could be broken and the racing world would move forward as a united body.

"Everyone is talking to everyone at the moment," one source said. "It's like a game of poker but we're confident all sides will see sense."

However, a source close to one of the alternative bidders said: "The whole thing is a mess. The Super 12 jumped too soon. The value of these rights and the betting turnover that comes with them could be enormous. Only now are the track owners starting to realise that."

The Channel 4 consortium is at best likely to have to sweeten its offer, racing insiders said. At worst it risks seeing a rival like BSkyB re-entering the fray and outbidding it.

webTitle: The heat is on as summer arrives at last

fields.headline: The heat is on as summer arrives at last
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Britain looks set to bask in the hottest weather of the year this weekend as a mini heatwave pushes temperatures as high as 30 degrees celsius (89F) over two sun-drenched days.
fields.body:
Britain looks set to bask in the hottest weather of the year this weekend as a mini heatwave pushes temperatures as high as 30 degrees celsius (89F) over two sun-drenched days.

The eagerly awaited hot weather is expected to hit the whole of England and Wales and continue through the weekend until Monday evening.

There will be few clouds, and forecasters predict that several hours of glorious sunshine should lead to the hottest June day for four years.

The brief outbreak of summer, caused by warm weather blowing in from the continent, will see the mercury fluctuate between 25C (78F) and 28C (83F) on average, soaring even further in parts of the south.

"Temperatures will go even higher than this in a few well-known hot spots," said a Met office spokesman, "with places like London, where the tarmac and concrete attracts more heat, going up to 29 and even touching 30."

Those anxious to escape the heat would do best to flee to the coast, he advised, where sea breezes will cause temperatures to drop by five degrees on average. "It will feel slightly muggy inland but on the coast it should be quite refreshing."

Or they could hurry to Scotland, gripped by gales earlier this week, or Northern Ireland, neither of which is likely to see temperatures rise higher than 20 to 21 degrees and both of which look set to be stricken by cloudy weather.

Or they could just wait until the weather breaks - and the rain returns - on Monday. "There's going to be a build-up of cloud and a greater risk of thunder with storms breaking out on Monday night," said the spokesman. "After that, we will notice a real change: it'll be rather muggy, rather cloudy and with showers."

For today, however, the mercury looks set to rise beyond the previous high point this year, on May 15, when it nudged 28 degrees in London.

The three previous Junes have been predominantly wet and lacklustre, but the heat this weekend could rival that at the start of the long, hot summer of 1996 when, on June 7, London temperatures hit 33C.

webTitle: Energy targets would change face of Britain

fields.headline: Energy targets would change face of Britain
fields.trailText: A British landscape and coastline dominated by wind farms, with turbines on and under the sea and on much of the land, was yesterday sketched out by scientists who recommended a 60% cut in carbon dioxide emissions over the next 50 years.
fields.body:
A British landscape and coastline dominated by wind farms, with turbines on and under the sea and on much of the land, was yesterday sketched out by scientists who recommended a 60% cut in carbon dioxide emissions over the next 50 years.

There would be hardly a stretch of coastline from which a huge green power plant would not be seen as tides, wind, waves and sunshine filled an energy gap left by the shrinking use of conventional fuels such as coal, oil and gas. Swaths of agricultural land would also be turned over to energy crops, such as fast-growing willow, for a new generation of local green power stations.

Prices for electricity and other energy sources would also have to rise steadily - helped by a new carbon tax - to reduce demand, said the royal commission on environmental pollution. It challenged political parties to go much further in helping Britain to give a lead in measures to slow climate change.

Britons would have to change their energy-guzzling lifestyles to make a major dent in soaring carbon dioxide levels, with the money raised from extra taxes being used to provide better insulation in poor people's homes. Businesses might also need subsidies to compete at international level if other countries did not introduce similar taxes, said the commission.

Its report, Energy - the Changing Climate, said that the government's current target for reducing 1990's carbon dioxide levels by 20% by 2010 was welcome but did not go nearly far enough. The commission wanted cuts of 60% by 2050 and 80% by 2100.

Although the amounts of carbon dioxide Britain sends into the atmosphere are significantly lower than 10 years ago, that is largely because gas has replaced coal in power stations. Making further significant inroads will be difficult as car congestion increases.

The commission offered four ways in which its targets could be reached. "All involve substantial changes and impacts. There is no free lunch," it said.

Its chairman, Sir Tom Blundell, said that Britain should "embark now on a pathway that leads to a sustainable energy policy that protects the interests of our children and grandchildren and the generations after them".

But, he said, "changing our production and consumption of energy to protect the environment and climate must also seek to achieve social justice and reduce fuel poverty, to increase the quality of life, and to protect or enhance the competitiveness of industry."

He added: "Recklessly causing large-scale disruption to climate by burning fossil fuels will affect all countries. It is the poorest that would suffer most. We cannot expect other nations to do their part in countering this threat - least of all if they are much less wealthy - unless we demonstrate we are really serious about it."

The commission recognised the value of nuclear power in providing carbon-free energy but did not believe it was indispensable. Most existing plants would have ceased operation by 2020 and no new ones should be built until the problem of managing nuclear waste had been solved to the satisfaction of scientists and the public.

There was an option of using fossil fuel plants, capturing the carbon dioxide and storing it underground. Big new plants would be necessary to fill the gaps when the weather prevented full use of wind and sea turbines or solar power.

The report also said that wind farms must not damage landscapes or wildlife.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said the commission was "right to highlight how enormous the challenge of climate change really is. We must rise to this, but cannot do it alone."

But Stephen Tindale, chief policy adviser for Greenpeace, said: "This report confirms that fossil fuel economies such as the UK's are on the wrong path, but it also shows that wind and solar power can break our addiction to oil, coal and gas. It makes clear that tinkering around the edges, which is all governments are doing now, won't stop climate change wrecking lives and economies in places like Mozambique, or prevent sea level rise flooding large parts of the UK."

2050 The future of power

Scenario1
60% cut in carbon dioxide; no rise in energy demand

Two hundred windfarms Ikm out to sea, 10,000 small wave-power turbines under sea, thousands more in rivers. Barrage across the Severn. Solar panels on most roofs. Windfarms on 1% of land.

Either 46 nuclear power stations the size of Sizewell-B or 46 fossil fuel power stations with equipment for trapping and storing carbon dioxide, 15% of farmland growing crops for thousands of small local "green" power plants. Gradual rise in energy prices, improved insulation in old housing.

More traffic and aircraft with more efficient engines .Cars powered by fuel cells with hydrogen from oil and gas

Scenario 2
60% cut in carbon dioxide; 36% cut in energy demand

Two hundred windfarms at sea,10,000 small wave-power turbines under sea, thousands more in rivers and streams. Barrage across Severn estuary

Wide use of solar panels, but only half of scenario one, windfarms on 0.5% of land, no nuclear power, 15% of farmland growing crops for thousands of green power plants.

Big rise in energy prices. Cars powered by fuel cells. More energy efficient housing

Scenario 3
60% cut in carbon dioxide; 36% cut in energy use

Two hundred windfarms at sea, 10,000 small wave-power turbines under sea, thousands more in rivers and streams. No Severn barrage. Little use of solar panels

Either 19 new Sizewell-B power stations or similar number fossil fuel plants with carbon dioxide put underground. Few wind farms on land, 2% of farms growing crops for 1,000 green power plants. Big rise in energy prices. Traffic and aircraft use falling, cars use fuel cells, energy efficient housing

Scenario 4
60% cut in carbon dioxide; 47% cut in energy demand

Windpower offshore and on land only half levels of scenario one, use of crops for fuel same as scenario three, relatively little use of solar panels. Barrage across the Severn

Wavepower and tidal streams same as other scenarios, no new power stations

Useful link
Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution

fields.headline: NY police 'ignored' park sex attacks
fields.trailText: New York police were in trouble again yesterday - this time for allegedly turning a blind eye as at least 44 women, including a Briton, were sexually abused in broad daylight in Central Park by a rampaging gang of up to 60 youths.
fields.body:
New York police were in trouble again yesterday - this time for allegedly turning a blind eye as at least 44 women, including a Briton, were sexually abused in broad daylight in Central Park by a rampaging gang of up to 60 youths.

"If that's true, that's very, very troubling and that should lead to significant disciplining of the police officers," the mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, said.

The assaults, the number of which have shocked the city, occurred after the annual Puerto Rican Day parade, in which hundreds of thousands of people marched through Manhattan last weekend. Most attacks happened in highly visible parts of the park, and the police have been accused of looking the other way while dozens of women, including an 18-year-old Briton and a French honeymooner, were sprayed with water, had clothes torn off and were sexually molested.

The numbers of suspects arrested and charged with sexual assault reached 13 yesterday, including an 18-year-old alleged ringleader. Manuel Vargas was said by police to have been caught on tape yelling "Get them, get them. Surround them."

Police continued to study amateur and television news videotapes of the attacks and to field calls from witnesses. "It's a very aggressive police response," Mr Giuliani said.

The city has offered rewards of up to $12,000 for tip-offs leading to convictions. Among the men arrested is a minister's son who wants to be a lawyer; a barber; a student; and a father of two described by friends as a good parent.

Victims - the youngest was 14 - said that police in the area failed to react when they reported assaults. The officers allegedly said they had been assigned to specific duties such as traffic and crowd control and could not abandon their posts. Mr Giuliani said yesterday he had seen no evidence of this, but promised to punish any officer who had turned a blind eye.

About 4,000 officers were on duty during the parade, with hundreds in the park area. Police confiscated 2,500 bottles of beer, 100 bottles of spirits and 16 bags of marijuana. "Sometimes, some sick crazy criminal or drunk kids do sick things," Mr Giuliani said.

For more than a year the city's police have been accused of targeting non-whites in the fight against crime as, one after another, three unarmed black men were shot dead by officers. But this time the charge is that they failed to act because of a tacit policy of political correctness. "Last week we were criticised for being the most aggressive police force," said one officer. "Now we're being criticised for being the most passive."

After a bystander was stabbed to death during a St Patrick's Day parade three years ago, a policy of zero tolerance was adopted towards drinking during parades. "You have chiefs and inspectors looking for people drinking," said one police officer.

But others said that the authorities were more concerned that the events should pass off smoothly than they were about making arrests for drinking and smoking cannabis. "Things that would be disorderly conduct on a regular day, we just give a warning," said a policeman who was on duty during the Puerto Rican parade. Another said: "We were told, 'We don't want to see any altercations between us and them.' In other words, 'Leave them alone.' They don't want photos of altercations with minorities."

One of those arrested, John Taylor, a barber, 24, said the assaults stemmed from "an innocent water fight that got out of hand". He had not taken part in the attacks and had told friends: "Somebody's going to get arrested, let's get out of here."

Isaias Lozano, a pastor, said of his 19-year-old son: "He's innocent. He was in the wrong place at the wrong time."

Manuel Vargas was said by police to have been caught on tape yelling "Get them, get them. Surround them." Police continued to study amateur and television news videotapes of the attacks and to field calls from witnesses. "It's a very aggressive police response," Mr Giuliani said. The city has offered rewards of up to $12,000 for tip-offs leading to convictions. Among the men arrested is a minister's son who wants to be a lawyer; a barber; a student; and a father of two described by friends as a good parent. Victims - the youngest was 14 - said that police in the area failed to react when they reported assaults. The officers allegedly said they had been assigned to specific duties such as traffic and crowd control and could not abandon their posts. Mr Giuliani said yesterday he had seen no evidence of this, but promised to punish any officer who had turned a blind eye. About 4,000 officers were on duty during the parade, with hundreds in the park area. Police confiscated 2,500 bottles of beer, 100 bottles of spirits and 16 bags of marijuana. "Sometimes, some sick crazy criminal or drunk kids do sick things," Mr Giuliani said. For more than a year the city's police have been accused of targeting non-whites in the fight against crime as, one after another, three unarmed black men were shot dead by officers. But this time the charge is that they failed to act because of a tacit policy of political correctness. "Last week we were criticised for being the most aggressive police force," said one officer. "Now we're being criticised for being the most passive." After a bystander was stabbed to death during a St Patrick's Day parade three years ago, a policy of zero tolerance was adopted towards drinking during parades. "You have chiefs and inspectors looking for people drinking," said one police officer. But others said that the authorities were more concerned that the events should pass off smoothly than they were about making arrests for drinking and smoking cannabis. "Things that would be disorderly conduct on a regular day, we just give a warning," said a policeman who was on duty during the Puerto Rican parade. Another said: "We were told, 'We don't want to see any altercations between us and them.' In other words, 'Leave them alone.' They don't want photos of altercations with minorities." One of those arrested, John Taylor, a barber, 24, said the assaults stemmed from "an innocent water fight that got out of hand". He had not taken part in the attacks and had told friends: "Somebody's going to get arrested, let's get out of here." Isaias Lozano, a pastor, said of his 19-year-old son: "He's innocent. He was in the wrong place at the wrong time."

fields.headline: Own goals
fields.standfirst:
Politicians play the sporting game at their peril - it can all backfire horribly

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: They think it's all over? It might be before sunset tonight. After the way England played against Portugal, it would be hard to back them with confidence to beat even a weakened and troubled German side, and Kevin Keegan's lads could be home shortly after the Romania match on Tuesday. One person dreading that almost more than Keegan is Tony Blair.
fields.body:
They think it's all over? It might be before sunset tonight. After the way England played against Portugal, it would be hard to back them with confidence to beat even a weakened and troubled German side, and Kevin Keegan's lads could be home shortly after the Romania match on Tuesday. One person dreading that almost more than Keegan is Tony Blair.

His cabinet is riven over Europe, carpers mock the vapid dome and swaying millennium bridge as metaphors for New Labour, the Blairite BBC (or "the people's television company" as a LibDem MP called it on Thursday) has, through its own miscalculation or the skulduggery of others, lost Match of the Day. At Edgbaston, England have resumed normal service, and it seems their best chance of winning a Test is if the other side are paid to throw it. Assuming the Springboks are playing to win, they will likely beat England at rugby. All Blair's summer of discontent needs is for the football team to take a collective early bath from Euro 2000.

If a defeat does have measurable political repercussions for Blair, he will have himself partly to blame. "Keep politics out of sport" was the slogan used by those who wanted to continue playing South Africa in the bad old days, and it always had an unconvincing ring, since apartheid intruded itself into sport. But there was once a line of separation between politics and sport, which has been wilfully blurred by politicians.

Quite apart from the ramifications of international football, our own politicians have taken to exploiting competitions such as the World Cup and European championship for years past. Just as Blair would still very much indeed like to greet a victorious Alan Shearer, in 1992, John Major was planning to fly to join the England team - until they stumbled out of that year's World Cup.

This follows a path pioneered by Harold Wilson. A hardy perennial error - I have seen it several times in print - says that Labour won the 1966 general election on the back of England's victory in the World Cup. In another version, Harold Wilson at any rate believed this to be so. The flaw in that historical theory is that Bobby Moore's team won the final at Wembley on July 30, and the election had taken place on March 31. That strange mistake may have taken root because Wilson was indeed keenly aware of the political importance of football, quite apart from his own genuine interest in the game.

His interest predated the modern convention that politicians must pretend to be sports fans, however implausibly. Kate Hoey really does follow Arsenal, but the prime minister displayed his waywardness with fact when he said that he used to watch Newcastle under Jackie Milburn: that great player retired when little Tony was a baby. As for Peter Mandelson's insistence that the one thing he would choose to rescue from his burning home is his Hartlepool FC scarf...

By contrast, Wilson could reel off the Huddersfield teams of his youth, not just because he was a natural anorak or train spotter. And whatever happened in 1966, he had his eye on the leather ball four years later. Richard Crossman's Diaries describe a meeting at Chequers of Sunday March 8, 1970 to discuss the timing of that year's election. "Harold said one of the problems was the World Cup... he was now trying to find out at what time the match was played, because he felt this was a determining factor." Late in April, the prime minster returned to the subject of the election, in view of "the timing of the South African cricket tour... not forgetting the World Cup at the end of June."

Not that this was the first time a government had found itself caught up in sport. In 1932-3, England played Australia in the notorious "Bodyline" Test series when the fast bowler Harold Larwood was set by his captain, Douglas Jardine, to bowl deliberately, and dangerously, at batsmen rather than wicket. Bodyline seriously damaged relations between the two countries, and after a series of acrimonious cables, JH Thomas, the Dominions secretary, insisted that Larwood should be dropped. As AJP Taylor put it, this was: "the only occasion on which a cabinet minister has chosen a cricket eleven, even negatively".

At least Thomas had a better excuse than our prime minister did when he tried to choose an England football manager, even negatively. Blair's demand that Glen Hoddle should be sacked for his idiosyncratic metaphysical beliefs was perhaps the worst example to date of Blairite demagoguery, a really disgraceful intervention in something which was no concern of the government's whatever.

And yet, although that particular intervention caused some dismay, no one seems surprised when politicians intervene more generally in sport; or not any more. More than 70 years ago, Mussolini created the "Dopolavoro", the fascist institute for controlling sports and pastimes, and liberal Europe laughed. There could not have been a more flagrant demonstration of what was called - with approval by Mussolini himself, remember - "totalitarianism" than that the state should have anything whatever to do with popular recreations.

Before long, the connection between sport and totalitarianism had become all too clear, as Hitler appropriated the 1936 Olympics to turn it into a Nazi propaganda stunt. The British tour by Moscow Dynamos in 1945 inspired Orwell's claim that "sport is an unfailing cause of ill-will". That might be debatable, then and now, but teams such as the Dynamos were unarguably used as athletic agitprop by communist regimes, along with factory farmed East German athletes. Now even in this country we have our own Dopolavoro, with a minister for sport, and no one any longer thinks that odd.

Along with the partial nationalisation of sport has come the rhetorical invocation of sport by politicians. Clement Attlee famously never read the political pages of the papers, only the cricket scores. But for all his love of the game, he didn't try to exploit successes by the England team politically, and even if he grieved in private it was no skin off his prime-ministerial nose when the Australians won the 1948 Test series 4-1.

As for Wilson in 1970, with all his assiduous attention to the footballing calendar, he managed to get the timing wrong. The World Cup final was to be played on June 21, and he called the general election for June 18, relying on England to stay in the competition until the last stages. Alas, England were knocked out by West Germany on June 14. Four days later, the Tories won the election. There is a warning there to politicians who think the beautiful game belongs to them rather than us.

fields.headline: Home from home
fields.standfirst:
It's agreed: we must do something about refugees. Well, it's better than doing nothing

Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: There are, in Britain, Kosovan Albanians who want to stay. This is hardly surprising because, although most are in grim hovels from which slum-lords make a killing, at least they can walk outside without stepping on a Nato cluster-bomblet or breathing uranium dust. Moreover, many Kosovans no longer have homes or relatives to return to. Some do wish to return. Some would just like to return to London, where they had started to make a home before being dispersed throughout the United Kingdom.
fields.body:
There are, in Britain, Kosovan Albanians who want to stay. This is hardly surprising because, although most are in grim hovels from which slum-lords make a killing, at least they can walk outside without stepping on a Nato cluster-bomblet or breathing uranium dust. Moreover, many Kosovans no longer have homes or relatives to return to. Some do wish to return. Some would just like to return to London, where they had started to make a home before being dispersed throughout the United Kingdom.

The same government that spoke so tearfully about their plight while bombing Yugoslavia now wants to round them up again and kick them out. Some people who supported the bombing are appalled by this. There were those who supported the war for genuinely humanitarian reasons. They didn't give much thought to what the government might be up to. If we don't take account of motives, we won't understand what is happening or what will follow.

Those who imagined that Nato was trying to help the Kosovans must either have been shocked when they learned it was showering the area with anti-personnel mines, or have imagined that they are designed to deal with the problem of ugly footwear. Depleted uranium must have been a clerical error or an attempt to have the place twinned with Iraq.

It would follow that the government is forcing Kosovan refugees to return for their own good. Refugees from other parts of the world must either be being expelled for the same good motive or for motives which, although bad, contrast with the benign rationale behind the expulsion of Kosovans.

Of course, some Kosovans arrived before the war started, partly because of violence and partly because the Yugoslav authorities had driven ethnic Albanians out of their jobs. This confuses the issue because, in Home Office logic, employment discrimination is not persecution, and the motive for fleeing it is financial. The same logic is applied to the Roma. The fact that a person is forced to live in poverty means that their flight is based on acquisitiveness and that they imagined any violence because they were faint with hunger.

Furthermore, even if people can prove that they have been persecuted, they must also prove that the state connived in that persecution at high level. One would think all these clever immigration lawyers and traffickers would encourage victims of violence to ask for a receipt. Unlike a government, a refugee has to prove a motive. A Polish Gypsy who has been attacked by neo-Nazis while police turned a blind eye, must establish a motive for telling her story to a British immigration officer. It might be that she has a well-founded fear of persecution, or it might be that she was bored with telling the story to relatives who'd all had the same experience.

If one believes that the British government is doing its best to help "genuine" refugees, a number of things follow. Dispersal to Belfast, for example, must be an effort to find a familiar habitat, a war zone riven by ethnic hatred being ideal. Moreover, since Ann Widdecombe is in almost total agreement with Jack Straw, either her motives are equally honourable or she has arrived at the same humane conclusions by accident. We would have to examine her views in context. Perhaps she finds herself in agreement with Jack Straw by pure chance.

Whereas she agrees with making asylum seekers apply from their home countries because it will reduce numbers and pander to racism, he wants to enable them to plan their move and leave a note for the milkman. He doesn't want to make it harder for refugees to come, or to criminalise those who arrive without the right papers. He wouldn't want people who are already in danger to get arrested after telling their stories to their local British embassy, or simply to be rejected because we get on with their government. He just wants to spare them a pointless journey to Britain and possible travel sickness.

For, surely, "something must be done" about the asylum system. As with the oppression of ethnic Albanians in Yugoslavia, it doesn't matter what is done or what the consequences are, so long as it is something. It would have helped if Labour and the Tories had not whipped up racist hysteria against refugees, just as it would have helped if the west had not crippled the Yugoslav economy, but it's too late now. Some people are whipped-up and something must be done. In the case of Kosovo, the something was to make things worse, which made British liberals feel temporarily better. But that cannot have been the motive for the something, because British liberals rightly feel terrible about the way the government is treating refugees. So what motivates British liberals? The failure to see a pattern.
