fields.headline: Survivors mark forgotten disaster
fields.standfirst: Churchill's delays contributed to the sinking of the SS Lancastria 60 years ago, in which 3,500 died
fields.trailText: Tomorrow a group of nearly 150 people will embark onto vessels of the British and French navies and take a trip into the Bay of Biscay off St Nazaire on the west coast of France. There they will remember the victims of the worst British maritime disaster of the second world war.
fields.body:
Tomorrow a group of nearly 150 people will embark onto vessels of the British and French navies and take a trip into the Bay of Biscay off St Nazaire on the west coast of France. There they will remember the victims of the worst British maritime disaster of the second world war. The SS Lancastria was sunk on June 17 1940 while lying at anchor five miles off St Nazaire. There were fewer than 2,500 survivors from a total of around 6,000 passengers. This was part of Operation Aerial, a desperate attempt by the British to evacuate more than 150,000 men from western France two weeks after the Dunkirk Operation Dynamo had ended.

The story of the Lancastria is one of the worst kept secrets of the war. Churchill slapped a D-notice on the press, fearful that the huge loss of life would damage morale. This was understandable, as British forces had been pushed out of Norway, Dunkirk, then the west of France. The French had surrendered and everyone expected a German land invasion.

However, the New York Press published a report, so the British press thought it was freed of the D-notice and stories appeared in most newspapers around July 26. The D-notice and the fact that many returning survivors were told they must not speak about the incident to anyone created an illusion of secrecy. Some survivors believe that information on the sinking is still withheld, closed until 2040 under the Official Secrets Act. The public records office and admiralty deny this.

The known facts are harrowing enough. Continuing advances by the German army had broken through the French 10th army, and Lt Gen Alan Brooke, who took command of the British Expeditionary Force only on the morning of June 13, proposed plans for the complete evacuation of Britain's remaining forces.

The SS Lancastria, which had been involved in the evacuation of troops from Norway, was sent from Liverpool on June 14 and arrived off St Nazaire on June 17. Between 8am and noon, more than 5,200 troops and civilian refugees boarded it.

Reg Brown, who was with the 633 Artisan Work Company (Royal Engineers), said: "We got on board at 3pm. I was filthy dirty and hungry. I headed below for a wash, but the food smelled good so I decided to eat instead. I had just sat down to eat when there was an almighty bang and the boat rocked like a cradle. The ceiling came down."

The enemy attack that interrupted Reg Brown's meal took place at about 3.45pm. Four high-explosive bombs hit the ship simultaneously. One went down the funnel, exploding in the engine room. Another crashed through the hatch of No 2 hold, where 800 RAF personnel had been sent. The others smashed through the hatches of Nos 3 and 4 holds.

Listing steeply to starboard and sinking at the bows, the Lancastria took only 20 minutes to go down. Many soldiers who could not swim stayed on the ship until the last moment. They were singing Roll Out the Barrel and Rule, Britannia. About 1,400 tons of fuel oil was released. It was to prove more lethal than enemy machine gun fire to many of the Lancastria's passengers.

Other ships involved in the evacuation moved in to help rescue survivors. An armed trawler, the Cambridgeshire, picked up 900. HMS Oronsay, itself hit in an earlier enemy air attack, moved in to help. Private Jesse Fenton from Nottingham was with the Sherwood Foresters. "I was picked up after about two hours in the water by a French soldier and his father who had put out in a fishing boat from the shore."

The Lancastria was overloaded: a liner, its usual complement, including a crew of 350, was 2,180. There was no time for survival drills and many soldiers died as lifejackets bounced up when they hit the water, breaking their necks. Others drowned, there being insufficient lifeboats or jackets. More perished in the burning fuel oil, probably set alight by calcium flares detached from lifeboats, although there were claims that the Germans dropped incendiary bombs onto the floating oil.

Exhausted
Several survivors reported being machine-gunned by aircraft in the water. Reg Brown said: "I was in the water for about three hours before being picked up by a French minesweeper. I could feel the vibration in the water as the bullets hit." Capt WG Euston, skipper of the armed trawler HMT Cambridgeshire, the first boat on the scene, recommended several of his crew for awards, including Stanley Ringett for "making repeated journeys in a lifeboat to pick up exhausted men from the water while under machine-gun fire from enemy planes", and William Perrin for "keeping up continuous machine-gun fire in an attempt to prevent enemy planes machine-gunning men in the water."

Brooke knew little of the Lancastria sinking, but he must have been unsurprised that such a disaster had occurred. For five days he had been involved in a merry-go-round of politics and regulations. Once he had learned that the French 10th Army was unable to continue organised resistance, he contacted Churchill and the chief of the imperial general staff, Gen Sir John Dill, recommending first that Canadian troops newly arrived in Brest be re-embarked and withdrawn to England, and that the other fighting units retreat towards Cherbourg to evacuate. He also sought to set in train the removal of stores and equipment, plus men, from west coast ports including St Nazaire and La Rochelle.

He was thwarted, first by an amazing scheme, that the combined French and British forces should retreat into Brittany and hold a line roughly between Mont St Michel and Nantes. Churchill only learned of the plan - described by one French general as "idiotic" - from Brooke, who both agreed it was impractical and that it be abandoned. Unfortunately, no one told the French and politics took over, as some British troops were forced to remain fighting alongside the French to placate them.

At least a day was lost, with troops preparing to embark at Cherbourg then awaiting further orders. Despite the fact that the French armies had disintegrated, and Pétain was preparing to seek an armistice with the Germans, Churchill still wanted to save face with the French.

Brooke was walking a tightrope, trying to prepare for evacuation, but with no orders to do so. There is no doubt that the delays by Churchill, which stopped the BEF evacuating earlier, created the bottleneck at St Nazaire. If troops had been evacuated from Cherbourg and Brest ear lier, more ships would have been free to evacuate St Nazaire. Perhaps then the Lancastria would not have been kept waiting so long, or been so heavily loaded.

Many troops had to travel across France from near Paris and Rheims to reach St Nazaire. Major Henry Pettit called in several towns and villages picking up Naafi staff and their cash takings en route. He later formed an association for Lancastria survivors. Sadly, all his records were lost in a burglary at his home.

Continuing advances by the German army had broken through the French 10th army, and Lt Gen Alan Brooke, who took command of the British Expeditionary Force only on the morning of June 13, proposed plans for the complete evacuation of Britain's remaining forces. The SS Lancastria, which had been involved in the evacuation of troops from Norway, was sent from Liverpool on June 14 and arrived off St Nazaire on June 17. Between 8am and noon, more than 5,200 troops and civilian refugees boarded it. Reg Brown, who was with the 633 Artisan Work Company (Royal Engineers), said: "We got on board at 3pm. I was filthy dirty and hungry. I headed below for a wash, but the food smelled good so I decided to eat instead. I had just sat down to eat when there was an almighty bang and the boat rocked like a cradle. The ceiling came down." The enemy attack that interrupted Reg Brown's meal took place at about 3.45pm. Four high-explosive bombs hit the ship simultaneously. One went down the funnel, exploding in the engine room. Another crashed through the hatch of No 2 hold, where 800 RAF personnel had been sent. The others smashed through the hatches of Nos 3 and 4 holds. Listing steeply to starboard and sinking at the bows, the Lancastria took only 20 minutes to go down. Many soldiers who could not swim stayed on the ship until the last moment. They were singing Roll Out the Barrel and Rule, Britannia. About 1,400 tons of fuel oil was released. It was to prove more lethal than enemy machine gun fire to many of the Lancastria's passengers. Other ships involved in the evacuation moved in to help rescue survivors. An armed trawler, the Cambridgeshire, picked up 900. HMS Oronsay, itself hit in an earlier enemy air attack, moved in to help. Private Jesse Fenton from Nottingham was with the Sherwood Foresters. "I was picked up after about two hours in the water by a French soldier and his father who had put out in a fishing boat from the shore." The Lancastria was overloaded: a liner, its usual complement, including a crew of 350, was 2,180. There was no time for survival drills and many soldiers died as lifejackets bounced up when they hit the water, breaking their necks. Others drowned, there being insufficient lifeboats or jackets. More perished in the burning fuel oil, probably set alight by calcium flares detached from lifeboats, although there were claims that the Germans dropped incendiary bombs onto the floating oil. Exhausted Several survivors reported being machine-gunned by aircraft in the water. Reg Brown said: "I was in the water for about three hours before being picked up by a French minesweeper. I could feel the vibration in the water as the bullets hit." Capt WG Euston, skipper of the armed trawler HMT Cambridgeshire, the first boat on the scene, recommended several of his crew for awards, including Stanley Ringett for "making repeated journeys in a lifeboat to pick up exhausted men from the water while under machine-gun fire from enemy planes", and William Perrin for "keeping up continuous machine-gun fire in an attempt to prevent enemy planes machine-gunning men in the water." Brooke knew little of the Lancastria sinking, but he must have been unsurprised that such a disaster had occurred. For five days he had been involved in a merry-go-round of politics and regulations. Once he had learned that the French 10th Army was unable to continue organised resistance, he contacted Churchill and the chief of the imperial general staff, Gen Sir John Dill, recommending first that Canadian troops newly arrived in Brest be re-embarked and withdrawn to England, and that the other fighting units retreat towards Cherbourg to evacuate. He also sought to set in train the removal of stores and equipment, plus men, from west coast ports including St Nazaire and La Rochelle. He was thwarted, first by an amazing scheme, that the combined French and British forces should retreat into Brittany and hold a line roughly between Mont St Michel and Nantes. Churchill only learned of the plan - described by one French general as "idiotic" - from Brooke, who both agreed it was impractical and that it be abandoned. Unfortunately, no one told the French and politics took over, as some British troops were forced to remain fighting alongside the French to placate them. At least a day was lost, with troops preparing to embark at Cherbourg then awaiting further orders. Despite the fact that the French armies had disintegrated, and Pétain was preparing to seek an armistice with the Germans, Churchill still wanted to save face with the French. Brooke was walking a tightrope, trying to prepare for evacuation, but with no orders to do so. There is no doubt that the delays by Churchill, which stopped the BEF evacuating earlier, created the bottleneck at St Nazaire. If troops had been evacuated from Cherbourg and Brest ear lier, more ships would have been free to evacuate St Nazaire. Perhaps then the Lancastria would not have been kept waiting so long, or been so heavily loaded. Many troops had to travel across France from near Paris and Rheims to reach St Nazaire. Major Henry Pettit called in several towns and villages picking up Naafi staff and their cash takings en route. He later formed an association for Lancastria survivors. Sadly, all his records were lost in a burglary at his home.

webTitle: Haiti in life and debt struggle

fields.headline: Haiti in life and debt struggle
fields.standfirst:
Impoverished island forced to keep up its loan payments

Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Haiti hopes that six months from now it will have recovered millions of dollars embezzled by the former dictator Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier and secreted in Swiss banks. It may also launch a prosecution against him in France, where he lives in exile.
fields.byline: Owen Bowcott  in Port-au-Prince and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Haiti hopes that six months from now it will have recovered millions of dollars embezzled by the former dictator Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier and secreted in Swiss banks. It may also launch a prosecution against him in France, where he lives in exile.

But it is not the plundered funds that most preoccupy the leader of the poorest country in the Americas. President René Préval - a dapper agronomist with a ready smile - is more alarmed by the sums his impoverished country must disgorge to repay loans from foreign banks.

The fact that 40% of Haiti's debt was incurred under Duvalier family misrule, when loans were regularly skimmed by regime cronies, reinforces the country's resentment.

Last week in a state reception room, where the sound of traffic grinding through the sweltering slums of Port-au-Prince almost drowned conversation, he signed a petition calling on international creditors to annul the country's swelling $1.2bn (£800m) debt.

For a Caribbean nation whose independence was achieved through the only successful slave revolt in history, the current campaign by the London-based organisation Jubilee 2000 to break the shackles of developing world indebtness has a strong political resonance.

Haiti has already signalled its difficulty in meeting interest payments to the World Bank. It is not among the countries to receive debt cancellation under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) initiative.

"They say our debt is not high enough for relief," says President Préval. "But it's one of the reasons for the problems of this country. We need cancellation." Outside the bleached, white splendour of the palace, chickens amble across the presidential lawn. Haiti is a country of desperate incongruities.

In teeming shantytowns, the most basic services do not exist. In the district of Christ-Roi, the body of a middle-aged man lay on a rutted track, face up with a broad gash to the head. People walked past.

Amid such poverty, the need for aid and investment is undisputed, but in its absence millions of Haitians want simply to escape. "We want to do things for the community," said James Joussaint, director of a development association. "But people want to go abroad for economic reasons, for better health, better education, more security, so their children don't have to work ..." His voice trailed off, implying an endless list.

At home, education is seen as one escape route; private primary schools have sprung up all over. Hubert Milhomme, headmaster of Ecole El-Shaddai in Arcachon, looks on as his 18-month-old son, Hubens, plays on the floor and jokes that one day the boy will be a doctor.

But even this pillar of the community is dispirited: "The government pays nothing toward the school. Not even for a piece of chalk. There's rarely any electricity. It gets diverted to the wealthy people in Petionville. Down here we suffer from tuberculosis and malaria." He, too, talks wistfully of a life in the US.

The traditional way out has been over the border to cut sugar cane in the Dominican Republic, which at one stage last year was sending back 600 migrants a day.

The traffic in boat people heading for Miami is reviving - a clear indication of declining living standards.

Four hundred Haitians were found on a Bahamas beach in January after their ship ran aground. More than 1,000 Haitians have been sent back already this year, according to the US coastguard. Thousands more may have made it to Florida - or drowned.

Last month 10 Haitian policemen disguised as missionaries hijacked a local ferry. The catamaran, and its 121 pasengers, was found adrift in American waters after the fuel ran out. "We didn't steal the boat," explained one policeman, "we stole the destination".

Colette Lespinasse runs a group for returned refugees. "Sometime the fishing boats are too full, there's not enough to drink and they have to throw overboard those who become ill," she says.

"One woman tried the journey four times. She had a young baby who died. She was so full of despair, she committed suicide by jumping into the sea."

Attempts by the outside world to relieve the hunger and suffering have been undermined by previous, corrupt regimes, leaving today's inheritance of mounting debt.

Camille Charlmers - who was an adviser to President Préval's predecessor, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and now runs a development organisation - deplores the country's annual repayments of $45m. Jean-Claude Duvalier, he maintains "took $900m with him when he left [in 1986] - that's almost the whole debt".

Trade liberalisation has also done little so far for Haiti. Instability and poor government have discouraged western investment, and cheap US rice imports have been accused of undercutting small farms in the Artibonite valley - the country's traditional rice bowl.

There are historical prece dents for granting relief for what is known as "odious debt". In 1970 Indonesia was rewarded with significant cancellations after General Suharto overthrew Sukarno. Debt repayments strike such a chord in Haiti because, after the slave uprising of 1791, France demanded "compensation" in return for granting independence. It took 100 years to pay off 550m gold Francs.

"Haiti was a financial colony for a century after independence," says President Préval, sitting beneath portraits of Toussaint Louverture and Jean-Jaques Dessalines, the leaders of the slave insurrection.

"That is why Haiti is poor and has borrowed so much money. Within six months we are hoping to liberate some of Duvalier's funds," he adds. "We are also looking at taking legal action in France against him" for human rights offences.

A year of broken promises

 A year ago today in Cologne, the world's seven richest countries, the G7, promised to write off $100bn of the $260bn owed to the west by the most indebted states

 The G7 promised that 25 of the 40 countries identified by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund as the worst affected would receive help by the end of this year - provided lenders were satisfied that the borrowers had policies to ensure use of the funds to reduce poverty

Britain's chancellor, Gordon Brown, promised that 11 would get through the programme's hurdles by Easter

 By mid-June, five countries have received reductions in debt payments and only one, Uganda, is anywhere near having its debts cancelled. The World Bank still hopes to get up to 20 countries through by the end of the year, but debt campaigners think it will struggle to push 15 through

 So far, the west has cancelled $11.9bn worth of debt - most of it under agreements predating Cologne. The only extra debt relief since the west promised "deeper, speedier" debt relief last year has been an extra $629m for Uganda

 Though Britain and most of its G7 partners have promised to cancel 100% of the debt owed to them individually (most of the money is owed to the World Bank and the IMF), Britain is the only one to do so. The other G7 countries are waiting until countries fulfil all the onerous requirements of the overall debt relief programme before getting out their chequebooks

fields.headline: Awesome foursome's Knutsford taken over
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.WILink.com
fields.trailText: A line was yesterday drawn under one of the more extraordinary stock market sagas of the past year when Knutsford, the high-profile bid vehicle, was itself taken over.
fields.body:
A line was yesterday drawn under one of the more extraordinary stock market sagas of the past year when Knutsford, the high-profile bid vehicle, was itself taken over.

The shell company once touted as a possible saviour for ailing retailers Marks & Spencer and Great Universal Stores, announced a £55m reverse takeover by WILink.com, an American investor relations business run by a school friend of Knutsford director Nigel Wray.

Mr Wray's appointment, along with those of former Asda boss Archie Norman, property financier Nick Leslau and hi-fi retailer Julian Richer, sent Knutsford shares soaring last autumn. The men - dubbed "the awesome foursome" - pledged to takeover and revitalise a struggling high street retailer.

Instead Knutsford launched and then abandoned a bid for mini-conglomerate Wassall. Shortly afterwards the entrepreneurs scaled back their ambitions when Mr Norman, a Conservative MP, was promoted to the shadow cabinet. The share price has fallen sharply since.

Knutsford will be renamed WILink.com and will aim to provide individuals with online corporate information, such as company accounts, and other investor services.

Chief executive Peter Wakeham said the group may want to buy a stockbroking firm to give its customers the opportunity to participate in private placings and flotations.

Knutsford's existing shareholders, who number about 1,000, are to be given the chance to take advantage of a 10 for one bonus issue of 10p shares, which Mr Wakeham believes will compensate investors who bought in during the share price's heady days when it traded in excess of 200p.

"It's the right and proper thing to be doing and something we would probably have done anyway," Mr Wakeham said. "Our business will in the future rely on retail investors."

The shares, which were suspended last month at 80p, are not expected to start trading again before July 18.

fields.headline: Keeping a head above water
fields.standfirst: Sir Ian Byatt, director general of Ofwat
fields.trailText: Sir Ian Byatt has the air of a Latin teacher, erudite, precise and patient when explaining complex issues. He quotes Cicero when asked what he intends to do after he steps down as the water industry regulator next month.
fields.body:
Sir Ian Byatt has the air of a Latin teacher, erudite, precise and patient when explaining complex issues. He quotes Cicero when asked what he intends to do after he steps down as the water industry regulator next month.

"The way to deal with getting a little older is a reasonable amount of exercise but above all to keep the mind as taut as a bow."

Sir Ian, 68, is stepping down as director general of Ofwat at a time when the industry is about to embark upon a period of big change. Insiders say that within five years the structure of the industry will have changed beyond recognition.

He is a reserved man, though his management style has been described by some as draconian but efficient. Yet he is admired by colleagues for his razor-sharp intelligence.

On leaving his post, Sir Ian will have enough under his belt for the book he plans to write about regulation of public and private sector industries. The book together with some public service work and some consultancy will leave him with more time to paint and to travel with his second wife, Deirdre Kelly, a reader in paediatric hepatology at the Diana, Princess of Wales, Children's Hospital in Birmingham.

His large paintings, which he describes as "standard 20th century abstract stuff", are much in evidence on the walls of Ofwat's headquarters in central Birmingham.

Pointing to one of the smaller works, Sir Ian said: "I did that at the time of the 1994 price review - you can see there is a certain amount of tension in it."

After graduating from Oxford, he spent a year working in America, widening his horizons. That was followed by four years teaching at Durham University, before a first spell at the Treasury. "I then went to the London School of Economics before being invited to back to government by Tony Crosland," he said.

Industry insiders said that he acquired a new zest for life when he married Dr Kelly in 1997. Sir Ian, who lives in Edgbaston, has one surviving child from his marriage to the author A S Byatt.

He said his interview with the Guardian would be his last as head of Ofwat. "It's rather appropriate. As a lad I used to run home after school to read the Manchester Guardian."

During 11 years at Ofwat, Sir Ian presided over the change from water boards to quoted companies. The companies have become lean and efficient, and have embarked upon huge investment programmes to replace rundown assets and to improve standards. He was knighted yesterday "for services to water consumers and the water industry".

Ground rules

He is proud of his time at Ofwat. His greatest achievement? He answers unhesitatingly: "A much better performance by the water industry in the interest of customers, much better customer service, better environmental quality, greater efficiency and now lower prices."

Now the big privatised water and sewage groups are looking to save money through corporate re-engineering. Kelda's decision on Wednesday to sell its Yorkshire Water assets to a mutual organisation which will contract out the running of the business is a sign of things to come. Sir Ian is seeking to lay down the ground rules for those changes before he goes.

Whoever takes over his job will find Sir Ian a tough act to follow. His understanding of the peculiar nature of regulated industries has long been his metier. When he worked at the Treasury, he played a big part in producing the 1978 white paper on the nationalised industries. Even his Oxford PhD - which followed a first in politics, philosophy and economics - examined the workings of the state-owned electricity industry.

He was to have a baptism of fire at Ofwat. Many regard the 10 big water and sewage companies as being given too free a hand when they were privatised in 1989.

In retrospect, it appears the Conserva tive government was so determined to be rid of the companies - and their need to invest billions of pounds in their long neglected infrastructure - that it virtually wrote them a blank cheque.

To ensure the shares appealed to investors, the government allowed the companies to increase charges by 5% above inflation for their first five years in the private sector and to pay whacking dividends to shareholders.

As water bills soared, gas, electricity and telecom charges tumbled. The public view was that other industry regulators were doing a good job but Sir Ian was being run ragged by the companies he was supposed to be overseeing. Then his first price review led to further rises in household bills and big pay rises for water company directors exacerbated the situation.

Sir Ian insists his own review halted the escalation in prices. He knew there was no quick fix for the water industry's problems and no easy way to cut bills. The industry had to invest huge sums in long term projects to reverse its decline. New European-imposed drinking water and bathing water standards had to be achieved. Not everyone could be pleased.

"We had to stabilise prices and we did, at 1% above inflation," he said. "The environmental programme was very large."

Sir Ian said the companies did little to improve efficiency during the five year regime set by government. His regime, however, forced them to drive out costs. People who claimed his first price review had been too soft because the industry comfortably exceeded his targets and made handsome profits as a result, did so with the benefit of hindsight.

"You had to go through the pain of higher prices to get better water quality and a better environment," he said.

His second and last review, which came into effect in April, proved that he could be tough when he wanted. The industry has been told to cut prices by 12% on average for this year and next and keep them pretty level for the following four years. The companies have responded by axing thousands of jobs and by planning corporate changes to squeeze out new savings.

Key driver

Sir Ian has steadfastly opposed most mergers within the industry and has already indicated that the proposed new mutual and not-for-profit structures raise serious regulatory issues, not least how to replace shareholder power as a key driver for improved efficiency and lower costs.

He, more than any other regulator, has used comparative regulation to simulate competition. By getting companies to provide detailed figures about their operations, he has been able to force the laggards to meet the best performance achieved by their peers.

The industry chiefs praise him for introducing an open methodology into the regulatory process though they criticise his demand for ever more detailed figures about their businesses.

They hope that, as competition is introduced, his successor will drop comparative regulation. Sir Ian believes that would be wrong. Comparative regulation, say experts, should stay until it can be shown that market competition can deliver the same benefits for customers.

He does not foresee an outbreak of mega-mergers once he leaves. "I think there will be more specialisation, with people concentrating on what they do best, rather than companies gobbling each other up."

To ensure the shares appealed to investors, the government allowed the companies to increase charges by 5% above inflation for their first five years in the private sector and to pay whacking dividends to shareholders. As water bills soared, gas, electricity and telecom charges tumbled. The public view was that other industry regulators were doing a good job but Sir Ian was being run ragged by the companies he was supposed to be overseeing. Then his first price review led to further rises in household bills and big pay rises for water company directors exacerbated the situation. Sir Ian insists his own review halted the escalation in prices. He knew there was no quick fix for the water industry's problems and no easy way to cut bills. The industry had to invest huge sums in long term projects to reverse its decline. New European-imposed drinking water and bathing water standards had to be achieved. Not everyone could be pleased. "We had to stabilise prices and we did, at 1% above inflation," he said. "The environmental programme was very large." Sir Ian said the companies did little to improve efficiency during the five year regime set by government. His regime, however, forced them to drive out costs. People who claimed his first price review had been too soft because the industry comfortably exceeded his targets and made handsome profits as a result, did so with the benefit of hindsight. "You had to go through the pain of higher prices to get better water quality and a better environment," he said. His second and last review, which came into effect in April, proved that he could be tough when he wanted. The industry has been told to cut prices by 12% on average for this year and next and keep them pretty level for the following four years. The companies have responded by axing thousands of jobs and by planning corporate changes to squeeze out new savings. Key driver Sir Ian has steadfastly opposed most mergers within the industry and has already indicated that the proposed new mutual and not-for-profit structures raise serious regulatory issues, not least how to replace shareholder power as a key driver for improved efficiency and lower costs. He, more than any other regulator, has used comparative regulation to simulate competition. By getting companies to provide detailed figures about their operations, he has been able to force the laggards to meet the best performance achieved by their peers. The industry chiefs praise him for introducing an open methodology into the regulatory process though they criticise his demand for ever more detailed figures about their businesses. They hope that, as competition is introduced, his successor will drop comparative regulation. Sir Ian believes that would be wrong. Comparative regulation, say experts, should stay until it can be shown that market competition can deliver the same benefits for customers. He does not foresee an outbreak of mega-mergers once he leaves. "I think there will be more specialisation, with people concentrating on what they do best, rather than companies gobbling each other up."

fields.headline: Leaders shun cosy diplomacy
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin last night ended the key visit of his European tour with Russia's relationship with Germany on a firmer, but still far from fully comfortable, footing.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin last night ended the key visit of his European tour with Russia's relationship with Germany on a firmer, but still far from fully comfortable, footing.

Chancellor Gerhard Schröder announced that he had accepted an unexpected invitation from the president to make a private, family visit to Moscow.

And the two men strolled amiably together through the Brandenburg Gate, where the Wall once ran, to underline the point that cold war differences were behind them.

But the overall impression was that they had established a civilised and effective way to communicate, rather than the touchy-feely, bear hugs-and-sauna diplomacy rapport favoured by Helmut Kohl and Boris Yeltsin.

With the Russian leader's troops fighting a persistently indiscriminate war in Chechnya, that is probably the way that Mr Schröder would like it. Indeed, there was a suggestion from one of his top aides that he had given Mr Putin a grilling on his attitude to freedom and democracy in Russia.

The key meeting of the visit took place on Thursday night when Mr Schröder hosted a dinner for the Russian president at his private residence in the fashionable Berlin suburb of Grunewald.

Michael Steiner, his foreign policy adviser, said the chancellor had not held back from frank discussion of the internal situation in Russia, in particular Chechnya.

He said the two men had found "a line to each other" and that the atmosphere at the talks was "very close". But he added: "One must address the issues in a focused way so that they can lead to results."

The fundamental issue of how much Mr Putin grasps western sensitivities remained as open as ever as he flew out of Berlin.

Mr Putin, who served for five years as a KGB officer in East Germany, also seemed to be skating on thin ice when he argued that the Soviet Union's cold war occupation of the country could form the basis for a special relationship. Many older Germans still recall with horror the sack of the east by Russian troops in 1945.

The president recalled that during the cold war up to 11 million Russians had lived within the frontiers of reunited Germany.

"That is a good foundation for building up contacts," he added. "Success would be guaranteed."

He also used the press conference to invite Europe to join a body set up by Russia and the United States to monitor missile launches. He said he had suggested to Mr Schröder that a "united Europe" should be able to send representatives to the Moscow-based organisation, which is designed to prevent a nuclear war starting by accident.

Mr Putin said: "I proposed to the chancellor consulting the European partners and telling them that Russia would be glad to see representatives of united Europe as a third working party in the Centre for Monitoring Missile Launches.

"That is the new Russian initiative and we expect this initiative to get a positive reception. We have no preference at all as to who represents Eu rope in this centre," he added.

Russian officials said European governments could decide how precisely to take up the offer of sending representatives. One suggested the Western European Union - a near-moribund alliance which will soon be replaced by a new European Union defence body - could be the appropriate partner.

Yesterday also saw progress on several trade issues - but no hint of cancelling Russia's debts to Germany, as the Kremlin would like. Germany accounts for half of all Russia's outstanding foreign borrowings.

Mr Schröder said that a dispute over export credit guarantees had been resolved that would clear the way for some £335m worth of new cover for projects in Russia. That in turn could help progress towards an eventual restructuring of Russia's foreign debts.

Both sides, moreover, agreed to set up a high-level working group on economic relations and Russia's gas monopoly, Gazprom, signed four deals with German firms.

fields.headline: Eau, so sparkling
fields.standfirst: Brand values Perrier
fields.trailText: It took an Englishman to turn a spring of bubbling water at Vergeze into one of France's best known brand names - Perrier.
fields.body:
It took an Englishman to turn a spring of bubbling water at Vergeze into one of France's best known brand names - Perrier.

St John Harmsworth was sent to Vergeze, a spa town in Provence, in 1904 to recuperate after being badly injured in a car crash. The naturally bubbling water from Vergeze's spring had been known from Roman times for its alleged health giving properties.

Harmsworth, brother of British press magnate Lord Harmsworth, wanted to bottle it so it could be sent to friends to drink with their whisky. He soon realised its commercial potential and bought control of the spring.

Harmsworth named his new venture after Louis Perrier, the doctor who introduced him to the sparkling water and from whom he bought the source. The distinctive green glass bottles were designed to resemble the indian clubs which Perrier advised Harmsworth to swing for exercise.

The business grew rapidly. Harmsworth, with his family background, used the power of advertising. He marketed Perrier under the slogan "the champagne of table waters".

By 1922, his company was producing 6m bottles a year. By 1933, when Harmsworth died, the annual output had risen to 18m bottles. Perrier became a favourite with the English aristocracy. It received royal warrants from Edward VII and George V.

Perrier disappeared from the British market during the 1930s and 1940s, and, at the end of the second world war, the Harmsworth family sold the business to a group of French businessmen led by Georges Leven.

Perrier flourished under new ownership, with inspired marketing and promotions. Leading poster artists and copywriters were commissioned. In 1969 a full page colour advertisement by Salvador Dali appeared in French newspapers.

By 1984 Perrier was the world's leading mineral water company. It dominated the British market, with sales rising from 30m litres a year in 1980 to 420m by 1990. This year it will be the official mineral water at the Wimbledon tennis tournament.

Disaster struck in 1990 when routine testing in the US found traces of benzene in 12 bottles of Perrier. The company mishandled the situation. It initially withdrew 72m bottles from the US market, but tried to bluff it out in the rest of the world, claiming the benzene levels were not dangerous. At first it blamed the problem on a cleaner's dirty rag, but later admitted that gas filters at the bottling plant had not been changed.

Public pressure and threats of legal action forced the destruction of 280m bottles worldwide - up to five months' stock. In Britain, Perrier drinkers found an alternative as Scottish producers broke into the market in a big way. In the US, Perrier was never to regain its position as market leader. Today it ranks 22nd, according to specialist consultancy Zenith International.

The affair heralded the end for Perrier as an independent company. In 1992 it was taken over by Nestlé, the Swiss food and drinks group.

Nestlé's Perrier-Vittel division is now the world's largest bottled water company, owning 55 brands including Buxton mineral water. But Perrier, the brand created by St John Harmsworth, remains its flagship product.

webTitle: Serb leader accused of murder plot

fields.headline: Serb leader accused of murder plot
fields.standfirst: Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: Serbia's best-known opposition figure has accused President Slobodan Milosevic's secret police of trying to kill him, after his holiday home was sprayed by gunfire.
fields.byline: Gillian Sandford and agencies in Belgrade and Budva, Montenegro
fields.body:
Serbia's best-known opposition figure has accused President Slobodan Milosevic's secret police of trying to kill him, after his holiday home was sprayed by gunfire.

Vuk Draskovic, the head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, was grazed in the head by the shooting, which occurred at about midnight on Thursday at his home near Budva, a coastal town in Montenegro, where he had been staying for two days.

"This was definitely organised by Serbia's state security," Mr Draskovic said yesterday.

Mr Draskovic, with a bandage on his left ear and right temple, claimed Mr Milosevic had transformed Yugoslavia into a "lawless concentration camp" where gangland-style killings have become a means of governance.

"It is also definitely certain that another decision on my liquidation could not have been reached without the knowledge of those who run the country - and in this case it is Slobodan Milosevic and his wife," he added. According to Mr Draskovic's wife, Danica, he had told local police he was in Montenegro but declined their offer of protection.

After the first bullet grazed his temple, Mr Draskovic threw himself on the living room floor, his wife said. One of the bullets hit his earlobe.

The Serbian deputy information minister, Miodrag Popovic, denied that the government was behind the attack.

Montenegro's police chief, Vukasin Maras, said that his force now faced attempts by Belgrade to export "state terrorism" to the Yugoslav federation's junior republic. "This is a monstrous conspiracy," he added, saying he felt personally responsible for Mr Draskovic's injury.

Mr Draskovic's aides said the attack "came as a shock" and grim-faced party officials gathered yesterday at the party's Belgrade headquarters.

It was the latest in a series of attacks against prominent figures in Yugoslavia this year. Mr Draskovic has claimed there was an attempt on his life last October when a car he was in collided head-on with a truck which allegedly swerved out of its lane. He suffered minor injuries but three party associates were killed.

Mr Draskovic and his party are considered key Milosevic opponents, despite their occasional cooperation with him - notably during the Nato bombing campaign last year when he briefly joined the Milosevic government.

The most prominent unsolved murders in Yugoslavia this year:

Bosko Perosevic
Senior official in Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party. Shot dead on May 13 at the Novi Sad fair

Zika Petrovic
Head of Yugoslav national airline JAT. Gunned down outside his home in central Belgrade on April 27.

Mirko Tomic
Also known as Bosanac (the Bosnian). Prominent underworld figure. Gunned down on February 13 from a speeding vehicle.

Pavle Bulatovic
Yugoslav defence minister, shot dead in restaurant on February 8. Officials put the blame on terrorists who had received their orders from abroad. Police have yet to find the killer.

Zeljko 'Arkan' Raznatovic
Feared Serbian warlord indicted by UN court for war crimes during the Croatian and Bosnian wars in 1991-95. Shot dead on January 15 in a Belgrade hotel. Police say they have arrested several suspects but do not have a motive for the killing.

webTitle: Ministers accused of ignoring energy crunch

fields.headline: Ministers accused of ignoring energy crunch
fields.trailText: Ministers have been accused of ignoring official figures forecasting an imminent energy supply crunch that will trigger "drastic increases in oil prices" by 2010.
fields.body:
Ministers have been accused of ignoring official figures forecasting an imminent energy supply crunch that will trigger "drastic increases in oil prices" by 2010.

A meeting between academics backing the "lean economy initiative" last month proved fruitless, and energy minister Helen Liddell has branded their view as extreme.

But supporters of the initiative say their warning is backed by figures from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and a 1976 projection by Mrs Liddell's ministry, the Department of Energy, now part of the Department of Trade and Industry.

Last night the DTI said the North Sea had proved far more fruitful than anyone had imagined 25 years ago, with unexploited reserves proving equal to the amount already extracted, though it added that the half-way point seemed to have been passed.

Roger Bentley, of Reading university, and David Fleming, head of the lean economy initiative, met DTI energy officials on May 23. Dr Fleming said afterwards: "Our group was not persuaded that the response [was]... remotely adequate to the fuel problem which is now looming."

The the spectre of another oil crisis came as all eyes were on the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec), which holds a summit in Vienna next week to decide whether to ease the tough production cuts that have trebled the oil price since January 1999.

On Monday, the price per barrel soared over $30 as Opec decided not to implement an "automatic" production increase after the price topped $28 a barrel. It is currently at about $28 only because of hopes Opec will open the taps.

Dr Fleming said yesterday that, as the energy department had predicted in 1976, a supply squeeze was taking place around the turn of the century. Total world supply, he said - based on 1998 IEA figures - would start to decline after about 2012, but this disguised the fact that non-Opec Middle Eastern production had already started to decline, giving the cartel's core members an increasing grip on the world's fuel pipe.

But even Opecs Middle Eastern production would start to drop after about 2014.In early May, Mrs Liddell wrote to tell Tory agriculture spokesman Tim Yeo - who has an interest in the issue - of the planned meeting to discuss Dr Fleming's paper on looming oil shortages, saying it "clearly represents an extreme view".

The meeting had not changed Mrs Liddell's opinion, said the DTI.

webTitle: War of words and a free pint on Youngs

fields.headline: War of words and a free pint on Youngs
fields.standfirst: Notebook Brewer to face tough questions
fields.trailText: Anyone in search of a bit of cheap entertainment should buy a share in Young & Co, the south London brewer, and head down to next month's annual general meeting at Wandsworth town hall. It is becoming something of a City tradition for Guinness Peat, the active investment group, to engage in a rumbustious war of words with the brewer's septuagenarian chairman, John Young.
fields.body:
Anyone in search of a bit of cheap entertainment should buy a share in Young & Co, the south London brewer, and head down to next month's annual general meeting at Wandsworth town hall. It is becoming something of a City tradition for Guinness Peat, the active investment group, to engage in a rumbustious war of words with the brewer's septuagenarian chairman, John Young.

The fight often gets rough, and Mr Young has in past years brought boxing gloves and a beekeeper's hat to "keep out a few stings" from Blake Nixon, Guinness Peat's executive director.

Mr Nixon believes shareholders are getting a poor deal. He points out that production at the Ram Brewery approached 200,000 barrels in 1982 but is now little more than half that level.

Despite the management's stated ambition of buying more pubs, few significant deals have materialised, and Young shows little sign in taking part in the industry's rapid consolidation.

Mr Dixon believes this lack of dynamism could be corrected by tweaking the share structure to remove the Young family's unyielding control through its hoard of "B" shares, which carry additional voting rights.

He has had little success so far - the Youngs regard the brewery as their business, with outside investors only permitted on their terms. They point out that Mr Nixon knew the rules when he bought his shares. Young's shares have performed poorly, falling from 885p to 462.5p this year. However, Guinness Peat may have a stronger case if it could point to a better record of delivering returns itself - its stock stands at the same level now as in early 1996.

Mr Nixon points out that special circumstances apply - investors have been waiting for the disposal of its biggest asset, a stake in the Australian insurer Tyndall. His own record of success is modest, with victories over such firms as Bluebird Toys and Staveley Industries. Still, next month's battle should be as ferocious as ever, and if it doesn't appeal, shareholders are entitled to a free pint at Young's pubs afterwards.

Cyber loss

The second most popular stock quotation requested by those logging on to Interactive Investor International's web site is listed as iii itself. Which is not surprising, since anyone who bought shares in February's flotation must have spent the past four months clicking furiously as they watched two-thirds of their initial investment disappear.

In fact, after yesterday's news that the amateur punters who make up iii's user base are still suffering from dot.com shock, blowing the company's revenue dreams away in the process, the shares at 56.5p are now almost 90% below their frothy peak in March.

Against its competition in British, iii is a professional financial information product, with relatively rich content - albeit presented in the drabbest of formats. And, with online share trading expected to grow exponentially across Europe over the next three-five years, it should be a viable business.

But yesterday's profit warning hinted at panic. Yes, the company still has £65m of cash. But rather than waxing on about transaction volumes and the like, the talk now is of monitoring expenses, checking the effectiveness of marketing spend and "managing _ available cash resources so as to ensure achievement of our business plan".

This cuts to the chase. While the numbers of individuals playing the stock market is still expected to soar, growth will be lumpy and will take a number of years. And the financial information providers of the old economy will find it that much easier to catch up if the iiis of this world are frightened to spend their cash promoting themselves.

Virgin talk

Some wild speculation was cited here yesterday linking Sir Richard Branson's desire to run the national lottery and the thirst for cash which occasionally grips various Virgin companies. Of course, the notion that this entrepreneur might funnel money from the lottery to other Virgin businesses is exactly that - wild and also unfair.

In fact, Sir Richard is now almost acting like a Footsie boss keeping the market up to date with news on profit expectations.

In the case of Virgin Airways, we had a fully fledged profits warning yesterday, with Sir Richard predicting that due to soaring fuel prices profits at the airline will halve this year.

However, rather than refocusing attention on the finances of the Virgin empire, the corporate confessional (delivered to Reuters) had the immediate effect of getting the market to focus on Virgin's great rival and consider again the size of the job confronting British Airways' new boy, Rob Eddington.

Fuel prices may prove to be the least of this man's problems.

They point out that Mr Nixon knew the rules when he bought his shares. Young's shares have performed poorly, falling from 885p to 462.5p this year. However, Guinness Peat may have a stronger case if it could point to a better record of delivering returns itself - its stock stands at the same level now as in early 1996. Mr Nixon points out that special circumstances apply - investors have been waiting for the disposal of its biggest asset, a stake in the Australian insurer Tyndall. His own record of success is modest, with victories over such firms as Bluebird Toys and Staveley Industries. Still, next month's battle should be as ferocious as ever, and if it doesn't appeal, shareholders are entitled to a free pint at Young's pubs afterwards. Cyber loss The second most popular stock quotation requested by those logging on to Interactive Investor International's web site is listed as iii itself. Which is not surprising, since anyone who bought shares in February's flotation must have spent the past four months clicking furiously as they watched two-thirds of their initial investment disappear. In fact, after yesterday's news that the amateur punters who make up iii's user base are still suffering from dot.com shock, blowing the company's revenue dreams away in the process, the shares at 56.5p are now almost 90% below their frothy peak in March. Against its competition in British, iii is a professional financial information product, with relatively rich content - albeit presented in the drabbest of formats. And, with online share trading expected to grow exponentially across Europe over the next three-five years, it should be a viable business. But yesterday's profit warning hinted at panic. Yes, the company still has £65m of cash. But rather than waxing on about transaction volumes and the like, the talk now is of monitoring expenses, checking the effectiveness of marketing spend and "managing _ available cash resources so as to ensure achievement of our business plan". This cuts to the chase. While the numbers of individuals playing the stock market is still expected to soar, growth will be lumpy and will take a number of years. And the financial information providers of the old economy will find it that much easier to catch up if the iiis of this world are frightened to spend their cash promoting themselves. Virgin talk Some wild speculation was cited here yesterday linking Sir Richard Branson's desire to run the national lottery and the thirst for cash which occasionally grips various Virgin companies. Of course, the notion that this entrepreneur might funnel money from the lottery to other Virgin businesses is exactly that - wild and also unfair. In fact, Sir Richard is now almost acting like a Footsie boss keeping the market up to date with news on profit expectations. In the case of Virgin Airways, we had a fully fledged profits warning yesterday, with Sir Richard predicting that due to soaring fuel prices profits at the airline will halve this year. However, rather than refocusing attention on the finances of the Virgin empire, the corporate confessional (delivered to Reuters) had the immediate effect of getting the market to focus on Virgin's great rival and consider again the size of the job confronting British Airways' new boy, Rob Eddington. Fuel prices may prove to be the least of this man's problems.

fields.headline: First Choice makes Spanish connection
fields.standfirst: Holiday company aims to keep predators at bay
fields.trailText: First Choice Holidays has underlined its ambition to target continental holidaymakers by agreeing a £250m tie-up with Barcelo Group, one of Spain's largest tour operators.
fields.body:
First Choice Holidays has underlined its ambition to target continental holidaymakers by agreeing a £250m tie-up with Barcelo Group, one of Spain's largest tour operators.

Under the terms of the deal, First Choice will pay up to £145m in shares for Barcelo's travel division, which specialises in taking Spanish tourists to Latin American and the Caribbean.

The two groups are also forming a joint venture company to own hotels in Spain, the Balearics and the Canary Islands.

First Choice's chief executive, Peter Long, said the deal was intended to build critical mass, in order to put off potential predators. "What we don't want to do is to become the weak link in a consolidating market. We either need to be a consolidator or we will be consolidated."

First Choice was forced to fend off a takeover bid from Airtours last year and a number of other big holiday companies are looking for acquisitions, including Germany's C&N Touristic, which recently failed to buy Thomson Travel.

Yesterday's deal followed a tough first half for First Choice - the group's seasonal losses jumped 39.5% to £33.9m. This increase was partly due to winter losses from acquisitions made over the last year, and partly because tourists baulked at the high prices of holidays over the millennium break.

Mr Long said: "The millennium was difficult, although we still think we fared better than the competition."

Earlier this month, First Choice bought Ten Tors, a Turkish-based tour operator, for £77m. The group has had cash to spend since it attracted a £200m investment from Royal Caribbean, an American cruise line.

Over-capacity in the European holiday industry has caused a sharp increase in competition recently. The latest battle has been over accommodation. Tour operators have been buying hotels in order to control the supply of beds in popular resorts and exclude their rivals.

First Choice is likely to invest between £100m and £120m in its joint venture company with Barcelo, while the Spanish group will initially contribute 15 three-star hotels.

Mr Long said: "This is partly a defensive move. We're not actively saying we want to be hoteliers but we have to secure our own bedstock."

First Choice's shares rose 2p to 145p yesterday.

Mr Long said bookings for this summer were on schedule, with trips to the Spanish islands, Florida, the Dominican Republic and Mexico selling particularly well.

webTitle: Manufacturers add fuel to the jobs pyre

fields.headline: Manufacturers add fuel to the jobs pyre
fields.standfirst: Dunlop, Corus, C&A, BAE Systems, Rhodia and Dewhirst mark a week of staff-shedding
fields.trailText: Dunlop will add to the mounting gloom in Britain's hard-pressed manufacturing sector next week when it announces 1,100 job losses at its tyre plant in Wolverhampton.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Larry Elliott  and  Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Dunlop will add to the mounting gloom in Britain's hard-pressed manufacturing sector next week when it announces 1,100 job losses at its tyre plant in Wolverhampton.

Coming in the wake of yesterday's decision by steel firm Corus to axe 1,400 job cuts, the tyre manfufacturer is expected to axe 500 workers from its car division and 600 from its heavy machinery division at the West Midlands plant.

Unions will be warned that the rest of the workforce could be at threat unless it agrees to a package of wage cuts and a 25% increase in productivity.

According to sources, the company is not blaming the pound for its problems in Wolverhampton, but is arguing that the plant is less efficient than those elsewhere.

The announcement is certain to add to concerns among union leaders, who yesterday accussed Corus of a "cyncial ploy" to placate the City ahead of what are expected to be a poor set of results next week.

Corus is set to announce mounting losses when it delivers its half year figures on June 26 and yesterday's move was seen as pre-emptive strike aimed at showing investors it was taking steps to maintain profitability.

Coming at the end of a week that has seen 4,800 job losses at retailers C&A and 3,800 at defence firm BAE Systems, the biggest cuts in steel will be seen in Rotherham and Stocksbridge, both in south Yorkshire. The company is also closing its Tinsley Park works in Sheffield and selling a recycling business in Tyseley, Wolverhampton, both by December 2000. A further 230 jobs will be lost with the establishment of a new UK technology centre and closure of the three existing units. Corus will in future run its R&D from two centres - one in the Sheffield area and one in IJmuiden, Netherlands. Staff levels at the Dutch centre will reduce by around 30.

British demand for engineering steels has dropped 18% since 1995 and shows no signs of recovering, resulting in falling margins for Corus, particularly in the motor sector which accounts for 60% of demand.

"Unless we implement this package of initiatives to reduce our cost base and restore competitiveness for our products, we will see this position continue to erode," said Jon Bolton, managing director of Corus Engineering Steels.

"This is the raw meat Corus has to feed the City," said Rotherham's Labour MP, Denis MacShane. "Corus will not be forgiven for taking all of these jobs away."

Government sources said they had not been surprised by the announcement, blaming a combination of under-investment and the strength of the pound for the losses. "It has proved a fatal combination", one said. Privately, the government has sympathy with the union view that the announcement was timed to take the sting out of Corus's poor financial results.

Shares in Corus, which have underperformed the overall market by 36% so far this year, rallied 4.8% to close at 100.5p on the cost cutting moves.

Bob Shannon, an officer with the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said unions would be seeking help from industry secretary Stephen Byers. A meeting is planned for Wednesday.

Mr Byers said: "The government will play its part in helping the people, businesses and communities affected. The key aim will be to provide new job opportunities for the future to replace those lost today."

Mr Byers said the European Union's Objective One programme would inject more than £756m over six years into creating 35,000 jobs in the region.

Further job losses in manufacturing yesterday included 300 split between Whitehaven, Cumbria and Canada by mining company, Rhodia, and 130 by textile firm Dewhirst in Hull.

webTitle: OFT to investigate rum goings-on in student bars

fields.headline: OFT to investigate rum goings-on in student bars
fields.trailText: The office of fair trading is investigate claims thatBacardi, the world's largest rum company, has been abusing its dominant market position by offering exclusivity deals to bar owners.
fields.body:
The office of fair trading is investigate claims thatBacardi, the world's largest rum company, has been abusing its dominant market position by offering exclusivity deals to bar owners.

The allegations centre on a deal that Bacardi made with the National Union of Students reported in the Guardian in April. Nussel, the commercial arm of the NUS, agreed a £625,000 three-year sole supply deal with Bacardi whereby student bars may not stock any other brand of white rum.

A spokesman for the OFT said: "There are reasonable grounds for suspicion that there has been an infringement under the Competition Act".

Lawyers for Pernod-Ricard - associated with the Cuban government in promoting the rival Havana Club brand - are examining whether Bacardi has been abusing its dominant market position by offering exclusivity deals to British bars.

Bacardi admits to giving money to the extreme right wing Cuban American National Foundation, which has been associated with terrorist attacks aimed at destabilising Cuba and its tourist trade, and was at the centre of the political tug of war over Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez. The company supports the US blockade of Cuba, condemned by the United Nations.

The white rum market is worth around £161m a year in Britain.

fields.headline: United on an advertising roll
fields.trailText: United News & Media yesterday painted a robust picture of the health of its ITV franchises as the competition commission delivered its verdict on the consolidation of the network to trade secretary Stephen Byers.
fields.body:
United News & Media yesterday painted a robust picture of the health of its ITV franchises as the competition commission delivered its verdict on the consolidation of the network to trade secretary Stephen Byers.

The media group which owns the Daily and Sunday Express newspapers as well as the HTV, Meridian and Anglia Channel 3 franchises, said advertising growth so far this year was running well ahead of its previous forecasts.

Television advertising revenues were up 13% to the end of May, driven by a "particularly impressive" second quarter, the company said.

If United's planned merger with Carlton Communications is approved, the business will have control over 36% of television advertising.

Mr Byers is considering the implications of United and Carlton's planned £9bn merger as well as Granada's subsequent comments that it was minded to bid for either. He is expected to make an an nouncement on his decision next month.

The contents of the competition commission report are a tightly guarded secret.

The prevailing sentiment however suggests that Mr Byers will allow the mergers through, the key being the conditions.

The independent television commission has made it clear it would be willing to relax the limit on any single company having more than 25% of the advertising market.

The commission's new chief executive, Patricia Hodgson, is known to be sympathetic to consolidation in ITV's structure of ownership.

Sources close to Carlton and United suggest that there are genuine fears that the demands made by Mr Byers, such as the sale of Meridian, might be too difficult to swallow.

In its trading update, United said its business services division was performing strongly, particularly PR Newswire. Circulation and advertising sales at the Express titles "remained satisfactory".

Analysts revised their forecasts upwards by around £10m to £310m for the full year. The company's shares ended the day 5p higher at 880p.

United said that revenue from online-related activities continued to grow rapidly and the company was aiming for online revenues of £350m-£500m by 2004. LineOne, an internet portal shared with British Telecom, has 1m subscribers.

The online businesses together generated around 100m hits per month the company said.

fields.headline: In bondage to summer torpor
fields.trailText: Financial markets worldwide are deep in a midsummer slumber. Trading volumes are low. Economic news comes and goes, barely attracting a glance. It is tempting to assume this catatonia will last through to September. But having bedded down early, it would take little to spark investors to life earlier than that.
fields.body:
Financial markets worldwide are deep in a midsummer slumber. Trading volumes are low. Economic news comes and goes, barely attracting a glance. It is tempting to assume this catatonia will last through to September. But having bedded down early, it would take little to spark investors to life earlier than that.

There is much talk at City summer parties of the lack of liquidity in stock markets. Three anecdotes from my week: One fund manager complained that he's finding it impossible to invest the cash that has built up in his portfolio. There are just no sellers of the stocks he wants to buy - UK technology companies, for the record.

A trader - with no suggestion of clumsy dealing on his part - cited his $50,000 buy order for a major Nasdaq stock that moved the company's share price by a mighty 5%. And the market was falling at the time.

Finally, a dealer at a major City investment house feared terminal boredom. His dealing pad, normally full of instructions from his fund manager colleagues, was simply bare.

These tales are typical of the experience of most market participants. It is not a lack of available liquidity that is the problem, though. It is the collective unwillingness of investors to deploy it in the markets.

The trauma of spring's collapse in technology stocks has jammed the thought processes of the fund management groups. Too late to sell? Time to reinvest? Or time to head for the beach?

At times such as these it is wise to take the opportunity afforded by collective inactivity to reassess one's basic interpretation of the investment environment. Do it on the beach by all means. But don't neglect to do it at all.

Start first with the economic and interest rate cycles. This year began with the economic temperature high. The US economy appeared impervious to the Federal Reserve's attempts to turn down the heat. Europe's recovery trundled on. Even Japan's stuttering economy was once again in forward gear. Interest rates, unsurprisingly, were on the up in the west.

As rates have risen, however, they've begun to reshape the world's economies. Only this week the US Beige Book confirmed a gradual cooling of the economy. The euro is at last responding to higher European rates. British inflation pressures are waning.

Each of these is a positive sign for bond and equity markets. Both can live with rising interest rates so long as their likely ceiling is visible. Through the early months of 2000 this was not the case. Now it is possible that British rates are at their peak, US rates have half a percent or less to rise, and euro rates perhaps only a percent or so.

As the summer progresses, with further evidence of the lagged impact of past rate tightening, so bond investors will begin to speculate about the timing of the eventual downswing in the cost of money.

Such a shift in economic and investment debate should unjam the bond markets, which have traded in a very narrow range this year. If you are looking for a key indicator, focus on 10-year US bonds, currently yielding 6.05%. A decisive break below 6% would signal a major improvement in sentiment.

Equity markets traditionally take their lead from bonds. Falling yields are a good thing. But one can have too much of a good thing. When falling yields reflect waning inflation pressure, and likely lower official interest rates, it is fine for equities. When they spell impending inflation, that is altogether different.

Now, there is no prospect of economic growth falling materially below its long term rate. Equities can therefore expect to celebrate the positive impact of lower bond yields on the valuation of future corporate profits.

My favourite gauge of the relationship between bonds and equities is the prospective bond equity earnings yield, or BEER. This essentially compares the valuation of future company profits with gilt yields. The lower the BEER, the cheaper are equities relative to bonds.

Over the very long run in the US market the BEER has tended to oscillate around a level of 1.0. In recent years it has typically been much higher - either irrational exuberance or a logical reaction to the productivity revolution. Take your pick. Now it is 1.5, down from a high of 1.8. By recent standards equities are fairly valued. If bond yields do fall they will start to look cheap.

Lower bond yields would solve the perceived liquidity problem in stockmarkets. On a stock-by-stock basis, entrenched valuation perceptions would be challenged - just what is needed to quicken the pulse and stir investors from their slumbers.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Yesterday was not a day for those on the make. Despite a rapid rise in the morning, the FTSE peaked at 8.30 in the morning - only to see gains eroded throughout the day.
fields.body:
Yesterday was not a day for those on the make. Despite a rapid rise in the morning, the FTSE peaked at 8.30 in the morning - only to see gains eroded throughout the day.

At the close, the index was 35.2 points firmer at 6,526.0, below its early high of 6,566.7, but above an opening low of 6,474.9.

All the broader FTSE indices were firm, with the TechMark 100 index adding 26.03 points at 3,353.50 despite Nasdaq's decline.

Rationalisation helped Corus - shares gained 2.75p to100.5p as investors welcomed the company's cost cutting exercise. The steel group made a surprise announcement that it is to cut 1,430 jobs in Britain and the Netherlands by the end of 2001.

Corus said the move was warranted by fundamental changes in the market, which have been exacerbated by the strength of sterling.

Elsewhere, BOC moved 26p higher at 932p after a Goldman Sachs upgrade to "market outperform" from "market perform". Land Securities also attracted interest - gaining 14p at 790p - after announcing a £63m property acquisition in the City of London, with recent sector consolidation moves adding spice. WPP was propelled 41p higher to 962p on news that it has acquired a 49% stake in US marketing group UniWorld Group.

Pearson shares advanced by 195p to £22.20 on press reports that the company is to push ahead with flotation plans for the merged television interests it holds along with Bertelsmann and Groupe Brussels Lambert.

BSkyB rallied from early profit taking, adding 16p at £13.20, extending yesterday's strong gains in response to the group's retention of the Premiership TV rights.

Elsewhere, selected technology and telecom issues rallied, supported by Nasdaq's rally: Energis advanced 240p to £30.50, Colt Telecom also gained 240p to £28.00, Logica took on 95p at £16.35, CMG firmed 42.5p at 929.5p, and ARM Holdings added 30p at 690p.

However, Psion - down 93p at 510p, Baltimore - off 75p at 450p, and Kingston Communications - down 21p at 600p missed out - suffering a sell-off ahead of their demotion from the FTSE 100, which took effect at the close.

Among the others, Lloyds TSB was one of the worst off, falling by 13.5p to finish the day at 649.5p.

At the close, the index was 35.2 points firmer at 6,526.0, below its early high of 6,566.7, but above an opening low of 6,474.9. All the broader FTSE indices were firm, with the TechMark 100 index adding 26.03 points at 3,353.50 despite Nasdaq's decline. Rationalisation helped Corus - shares gained 2.75p to100.5p as investors welcomed the company's cost cutting exercise. The steel group made a surprise announcement that it is to cut 1,430 jobs in Britain and the Netherlands by the end of 2001. Corus said the move was warranted by fundamental changes in the market, which have been exacerbated by the strength of sterling. Elsewhere, BOC moved 26p higher at 932p after a Goldman Sachs upgrade to "market outperform" from "market perform". Land Securities also attracted interest - gaining 14p at 790p - after announcing a £63m property acquisition in the City of London, with recent sector consolidation moves adding spice. WPP was propelled 41p higher to 962p on news that it has acquired a 49% stake in US marketing group UniWorld Group. Pearson shares advanced by 195p to £22.20 on press reports that the company is to push ahead with flotation plans for the merged television interests it holds along with Bertelsmann and Groupe Brussels Lambert. BSkyB rallied from early profit taking, adding 16p at £13.20, extending yesterday's strong gains in response to the group's retention of the Premiership TV rights. Elsewhere, selected technology and telecom issues rallied, supported by Nasdaq's rally: Energis advanced 240p to £30.50, Colt Telecom also gained 240p to £28.00, Logica took on 95p at £16.35, CMG firmed 42.5p at 929.5p, and ARM Holdings added 30p at 690p. However, Psion - down 93p at 510p, Baltimore - off 75p at 450p, and Kingston Communications - down 21p at 600p missed out - suffering a sell-off ahead of their demotion from the FTSE 100, which took effect at the close. Among the others, Lloyds TSB was one of the worst off, falling by 13.5p to finish the day at 649.5p.

webTitle: The future in metal drifts away from the banks of the Don

fields.headline: The future in metal drifts away from the banks of the Don
fields.trailText: "This is our Longbridge," said the 45-year-old steelworker, hitching up his haversack for the walk to the bus, in front of a factory billboard reading Corus - the Future in Metal. "We've not been told exactly what's what yet, but there's not many in Aldwarke who think our future's in metal for that much longer."
fields.body:
"This is our Longbridge," said the 45-year-old steelworker, hitching up his haversack for the walk to the bus, in front of a factory billboard reading Corus - the Future in Metal. "We've not been told exactly what's what yet, but there's not many in Aldwarke who think our future's in metal for that much longer."

A third of Aldwarke's workers face losing their jobs as the Rotherham plant applies its specialist skill - scrap conversion - on to 620 employees.

"They called a meeting in our department an hour after we got in," said a white-collar worker. "I think I'm going to be safe, but it's a horrible atmosphere with everyone waiting and no-one really knowing."

The plant by the river Don, with its hundreds of yards of forging sheds and four giant chimneys, has been shedding jobs for a decade through voluntary redundancy, but the scale of these cuts has winded the economic planners.

The director of the government office in Yorkshire will be in town on Monday with a team from development agency Yorkshire Forward to salvage anything they can.

"The economy's just turning the corner here, at last," said Chris Mallender at the council offices in a town that gave Britain the tap and the Bailey bridge. "It isn't the time for Corus to cut and run. They're putting regeneration back several years. It's the worst moment since we had the last of the pit closures."

Aldwarke staff holding lunchtime wakes at the Station Hotel, one of few pubs in a landscape of retail parks, were equally frustrated. The company's blaming of the strong pound prompted ironic memories of Rotherham's lone venture into euroland two years ago.

"Maybe we should have stayed there," said a programmer from Cap Gemini, which operates Aldwarke's computers. Shops double-priced everything in pounds and euros in a one-day initiative prompted by the town's Labour MP, Denis MacShane. He was furiously talking of "betrayal" yesterday, arguing that with the euro strengthening, cutting capacity was "playing into the hands of Corus's competitors".

Across the M1, in the smaller South Yorkshire town of Stocksbridge, a one-third cut at the Corus plant faces 360 specialist steelmakers with the dole. Anne Hudson of the Steel Valley Partnership, a regeneration trust, said: "Steel isn't just a factory in Stocksbridge, it's the heart of the place."

High street butcher John Crawshaw agreed. "It's the men losing their jobs you feel for most, and their families. But this is going to have an effect on all of us."
