fields.headline: Blair 'defies dad's instincts'
fields.standfirst: Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: The many people who pressed Tony Blair to take paternity leave after the birth of his son Leo last month may have misunderstood one of the most basic paternal urges, two American researchers have found.
fields.body:
The many people who pressed Tony Blair to take paternity leave after the birth of his son Leo last month may have misunderstood one of the most basic paternal urges, two American researchers have found.

When men become fathers their instinct is to want to work harder and longer than before, say the University of Washington researchers. And that instinct is particularly strong after the birth of a son, they claim.

So, while Cherie Blair and a whole generation of "new" men and women expected the prime minister to do the right thing and stay at home after Leo's birth, they may have been battling against an inbuilt paternal urge to put in more hours on behalf of his newborn boy.

Shelly Lundberg and Elaina Rose found that, on average, men work 122 hours more in the year following the birth of their first child if it is a boy, compared with 56 hours if the child is a girl.

The survey of 1,200 fathers, based on data from 1968 to 1993, found that it did not matter whether the fathers came from an earlier, pre-1950 generation, or a later one - to which Mr Blair, born 1953, belongs.

In both cases, new fathers responded to paternity by working longer hours and earning more money.

"It's maybe a bit of a wake-up call that fatherhood of a son is something different from fatherhood of a daughter," Professor Lundberg says.

webTitle: Soros rues infatuation with new economy

fields.headline: Soros rues infatuation with new economy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Billionaire financier George Soros, reeling from his funds' losses in technology stocks, said yesterday that new economy stocks remained overvalued and the market chaotic.
fields.body:
Billionaire financier George Soros, reeling from his funds' losses in technology stocks, said yesterday that new economy stocks remained overvalued and the market chaotic.

The comments were a further blow to the hi-tech sector which has weathered the sharp falls and, recently, dramatic rises in indices like Nasdaq.

"I think that the markets have become somewhat chaotic and very few people have been able to make money," Mr Soros said on the BBC's Radio 4 Today programme. "In my opinion, they [technology stocks] are overvalued. There has been a fantastic boom followed by an initial crash. I think there is a long period of drying out to come."

Mr Soros, an elder statesman of the investment world and chairman of Soros Fund Management, recently restructured his firm's flagship Quantum Fund to pursue a less risky investment strategy, stating that he would prefer returns of about 15% rather than 31% if it meant stability.

Additionally $4.5bn of Soros funds are expected to invested in real estate and private equity, where Mr Soros's son Robert has a keen interest. Robert Soros is to take a bigger management role in the family business.

Mr Soros, 70, said his conservative stance towards technology shares was also prompted by his desire to have an organisation that outlived him.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
CBI welcomes tax change

Business leaders gave a cautious welcome to yesterday's announcement by the government of a modification of its plans to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinational companies.
fields.body:
CBI welcomes tax change

Business leaders gave a cautious welcome to yesterday's announcement by the government of a modification of its plans to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinational companies.

"This may be a step in the right direction, but just how far it is not yet possible to say," said Digby Jones, director-general of the Confederation of British Industry.

He was speaking after the inland revenue said it was sticking by plans to take away the tax advantages of offshore mixer companies but would permit their use onshore in cases of legitimate business activity.

Mr Jones said: "This is a complicated issue so we will need to analyse the detail carefully. For businesses across the UK, their shareholders and their employees, this matter is not yet finished."

Switches at Dixons

Consumer electronics retailer Dixons group has promoted Chris Langley from marketing director to managing director of its Dixons division and has made Nick Wilkinson, former managing director of the Link chain, group purchasing director, replacing Terry Greenwood, who becomes managing director of a new company focusing on buying products.

Springboks help profits leap

The Old Monk Company is planning to roll out its Springbok chain of South African sports bars, which offer a combination of Castle lager, biltong beef and large screen televisions.

Chairman Gerry Martin said the group's three Springboks had proved a hit, contributing to a 52% surge in the company's annual pre-tax profits to £1.19m. He intends to open at least six more over the next year, at a cost of about £1m each. Mr Martin is the brother of Tim Martin, the founder of pub chain JD Wetherspoon.

Investors want more beer

Young & Co, the South London brewer, is facing a renewed attack from the active investment group Guinness Peat, which wants an end to family control and measures to increase production of beer.

Guinness Peat, which has a 21% stake in Young & Co, has tabled a resolution for the company's annual general meeting claiming profits are £5m lower than they should be, and demanding a merger with another brewer.

It is the third successive year that Guinness Peat has demanded reform, which has been steadfastly resisted by the chairman, John Young, aged 78.

Recruit a mate and win $1m

High-tech talent is so scarce that Canada's Nortel Networks is offering $1m in cash and prizes to its employees for enticing skilled friends to join the company. And the world's second-largest maker of network equipment said it is prepared to up the ante if it has to to beat the competition in its attempts to fill 5,300 optical internet positions. For every new hire the referring employee gets $2,000 and the chance to enter five draws, each with a prize of $100,000. Some of the jobs are in Britain.

webTitle: Bashar willing to do deal with Israel

fields.headline: Bashar willing to do deal with Israel
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The new Syrian leader, Bashar al-Assad, is keen to reach an accord with Israel and could resume the stalled Middle East peace talks later this year, according to an informed Syrian source.
fields.body:
The new Syrian leader, Bashar al-Assad, is keen to reach an accord with Israel and could resume the stalled Middle East peace talks later this year, according to an informed Syrian source.

Bashar, who is likely to succeed his father Hafez al-Assad as president next month, is prepared to be flexible over the complex issues that have dogged talks over the future of the disputed Golan Heights.

The Syrian plateau, which overlooks northern Israel, has been occupied almost continually by Israel since the 1967 Six Days War.

Western diplomats discount rumours that talks will resume this year, partly because of the domestic problems faced by the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and partly because of the US elections.

The Damascus regime is excessively secretive but the Syrian source, who has proved reliable in past, said he believed Bashar could seek "a resumption of talks to send a positive message".

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, who attended Assad's funeral on Tuesday, is scheduled to return to Damascus next week.

Bashar has made no public statement since his father's death but during the funeral he told the French president, Jacques Chirac that he wanted a resolution of the dispute that has dogged the Middle East for more than 30 years.

The Golan Heights is a confusion of UN observation posts, checkpoints and minefields. The Syrian side is desert-like and almost empty, whereas the Israeli is lush with fruit orchards, grape vines and tomatoes.

According to the Syrian ministry of information, about 500,000 Syrians fled after the Israeli advance in 1967 and are still living in camps dotted round the country, ready to return if a settlement is reached.

The main town of the Golan, Quneitra - divided between the Syrians and the Israelis - is dead. Once inhabited by 50,000 people, it was flattened by the Israelis with dynamite and bulldozers before they handed in back in 1974, an act of vandalism that was condemned by the UN. The Syrians have left the town in its shattered state, a shrine to their grievance against Israel.

Surprisingly, half-a-dozen families live amid the rubble and eucalyptus trees of this ghost town. Nahed Tannous, 48, who has seven children, said she had fled the Golan village of Banyas in 1967, which remained under Israeli occupation. After a stay in Damascus, she had gone to live in Quneitra. Her husband worked at the UN observation post.

If there was a settlement, she said, they would reclaim their land at Banyas. "Of course, we would return." Did she hate the Israelis? "Of course, they took our land."

The border near the village of Majdal Shams is known as the Shouting Valley. On Fridays, Syrians gather with megaphones to yell across the heavily mined valley to relatives on the Israeli side.

In the Syrian village of Hadar, on the Golan, Wassim Tawil, a farmer, said half his family were on the Israeli side. He said that travel from the Israeli side was possible, though expensive.

He admitted that the villages on the Israeli side were relatively prosperous, but added that "their freedom is limited". He predicted: "The land is going to be returned soon."

That requires diplomacy. The final sticking point in the talks between Israel, Syria and the US in Shepherdstown, West Virginia, earlier this year concerned a strip of land that would give Syria access to the Sea of Galilee - referred to by the Syrians as Lake Tiberias - which formed the 1967 border.

The Syrian source said: "There are two main issues. One is territory and the other is water. The land is a non-negotiable issue. Bashar, like his father, will keep demanding that we have access to the lake but he will make a compromise: he will not demand the right to draw water from the lake. Syria will also be flexible about security on the Golan Heights."

The Israelis want to ensure security by having a proper monitoring system to prevent a surprise attack by the Syrians. The source added: "They are very close to a settlement. It is not a question of technical difficulties but politics. If Bashar makes a decision to have a deal, Syria will sign tomorrow."

webTitle: Critics accuse Haider of abusing libel laws

fields.headline: Critics accuse Haider of abusing libel laws
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Some of Austria's most prominent thinkers have launched a scathing attack on the far right leader Jörg Haider, accusing him of endangering the freedom of speech by his attempts to "criminalise" his critics.
fields.body:
Some of Austria's most prominent thinkers have launched a scathing attack on the far right leader Jörg Haider, accusing him of endangering the freedom of speech by his attempts to "criminalise" his critics.

The group, called University and Democracy, is led by one of the country's leading historians of the Nazi era, Gerhard Botz, and is supported by academics and journalists. It claims that while the Austrian government presents itself as a free and democratic country abroad, at home intimidation techniques - notably lawsuits in which the rightwing Freedom party (FPO) sues its critics for defamation - are being used to silence dissenters.

The group has sent an open letter to President Thomas Klestil, calling on him to intervene. "If not forcefully opposed, it [the FPO] threatens to limit freedom of speech and therefore political debate in Austria at a time when it is most needed," it said.

In support, a group of 35 American historians and social scientists, including Jeffrey Herf, a leading expert on Nazi Germany, sent a letter to President Klestil yesterday, urging him to "do all within your power to preserve the widest possible area for political expression in Austria".

During his rise to prominence, Mr Haider gained notoriety for comments which suggested he was sympathetic to the Nazi regime. He hailed SS veterans as "men of character" and praised Hitler's unemployment policy. He has since tried to distance himself from these remarks.

In the past few months he has sued anyone who "defames his character" by linking his name to Nazism, taking to court various publications, political scientists, commentators, and linguists who claim to have found hidden psychological messages in party publicity material.

The most prominent case so far involves the political scientist Professor Anton Pelinka of Innsbruck University. Last month a Vienna court convicted him of defaming Mr Haider in an interview with Italian television in which he claimed that the governor of Carinthia province had made statements "which amount to trivialising National Socialism".

Prof Pelinka, who was fined 60,000 schillings (£3,000) and ordered to pay court costs, is to appeal to the European court of human rights.

In Democracy and University's letter, the signatories express their concern at the "willingness of an Austrian judge to countenance such a transparent attempt by Haider to use the courts to intimidate his political critics".

Another controversy is raging over the involvement of Mr Haider's personal lawyer, Dieter Böhmdorfer, who is now Austria's justice minister. Officially, he no longer acts as a lawyer while being a minister, but his law firm still operates under his name and uses stationery in dealing with the current cases with his name on the masthead.

A Freedom party spokesman, Karl Heinz Petritz, said in a telephone interview that Mr Haider and the Freedom party were "simply defending the right to sue those who speak untruths about us".

He added: "The trouble is the left wing get so confused and upset when they are forced to go to court for spreading nonsense." When asked to elaborate, he hung up.

Mr Haider stepped down as FPO leader earlier this year to reduce the pressure on his party but remains its de facto leader. European Union sanctions in protest at FPO participation in government remain in place.

The Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, has expressed admiration for Mr Haider, called him an ally in the fight against Zionism and promised to protect him against attacks from the EU. Mr Gadafy, whose son is a close friend of Mr Haider, refused to confirm or deny rumours that during a trip to Tripoli last month Mr Haider purchased cheap petrol from Libya which is now being sold in the province he governs, Carinthia.

A Freedom party spokesman, Karl Heinz Petritz, said in a telephone interview that Mr Haider and the Freedom party were "simply defending the right to sue those who speak untruths about us". He added: "The trouble is the left wing get so confused and upset when they are forced to go to court for spreading nonsense." When asked to elaborate, he hung up. Mr Haider stepped down as FPO leader earlier this year to reduce the pressure on his party but remains its de facto leader. European Union sanctions in protest at FPO participation in government remain in place. The Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, has expressed admiration for Mr Haider, called him an ally in the fight against Zionism and promised to protect him against attacks from the EU. Mr Gadafy, whose son is a close friend of Mr Haider, refused to confirm or deny rumours that during a trip to Tripoli last month Mr Haider purchased cheap petrol from Libya which is now being sold in the province he governs, Carinthia.

fields.headline: Island hostages lost in silence
fields.trailText: For over a week now, there have been no fresh pictures of the 21 hostages on the Philippine island of Jolo - not since 11 European journalists bribed their way into the captors' encampment and were forced to pay $25,000 (£16,500) more to ransom themselves out.
fields.body:
For over a week now, there have been no fresh pictures of the 21 hostages on the Philippine island of Jolo - not since 11 European journalists bribed their way into the captors' encampment and were forced to pay $25,000 (£16,500) more to ransom themselves out.

But the word reaching intermediaries trying to resolve the two-month-old standoff is that the captives continue to discover new depths of despair, trapped hellishly between boredom and terror.

Two of them, Renate Wallert of Germany and Stephane Loisy of France, have fallen into a "very serious condition", according to what the Abu Sayyaf rebels who took them hostage have told Philippine authorities. The hostage takers want swift resumption of negotiations on their $20m demand for the captives' release.

The episode began when the heavily armed Islamic insurgents kidnapped Ms Wallert, her husband Werner and their son Marc together with 10 Malaysians, two French, two Finns, two South Africans, a Filipina and a Lebanese from a remote Malaysian resort island on Easter Sunday. They were then taken by boat to the southern Philippines guerrilla stronghold.

"We must accept the reality that this isn't going to be resolved quickly," a Philippine government spokesman said.

Germany's foreign minister Joschka Fischer talked to his counterparts from France and Finland this week to try to work out a common position to present to the Manila administration. The three states signalled their opposition to any direct action, such as a commando raid, to free the hostages.

The German news reports from the camp captured the despondency of the hostages, many in the same clothes they wore when they were seized eight weeks ago and deprived of decent food, enough water and anything to read aside from rebel propaganda.

The hostages have since been separated into two groups and moved from a reed hut to an open camp elsewhere on the island, German government officials in Berlin have been told.

"We are evermore uncertain if we'll ever get out of here," Ms Wallert, who was in a condition near to hysteria, told the German weekly magazine Der Spiegel. She suffers from a circulation disorder that makes it difficult for her to walk. "We are dying here, and there's nothing you can do."

webTitle: Telephone users in India smell a rat

fields.headline: Telephone users in India smell a rat
fields.trailText: India's long-suffering phone users, already used to bad connections and petulant Hindi-speaking operators, were last night coming to terms with a new hazard - rats.
fields.body:
India's long-suffering phone users, already used to bad connections and petulant Hindi-speaking operators, were last night coming to terms with a new hazard - rats.

Telecom company officials yesterday admitted that wild rodents have been eating the country's vast underground optical fibre network, wrecking phone links between major cities.

Last month the lines between Delhi and the city of Patna were devoured by wild mice at Agra, the home of the Taj Mahal, and at Varanasi, India's holiest city. When the affected areas were dug up, hordes of rodents jumped out.

The fibres run through polythene pipes. The rats enter the pipes, lured by a smell emitted by the fibre and then cannot get out so they eat the fibres.

Telecom workers have proposed installing a second, outer tube around the optical fibre in some of the most vulnerable places and have sprayed anti-rodent chemicals on some cabling.

fields.headline: Straw's refugee plan attacked
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: Calls by the home secretary, Jack Straw, for a fundamental revision of the international convention on refugees to reduce smuggling of asylum seekers were yesterday attacked by human rights campaigners and the UN refugee agency.
fields.body:
Calls by the home secretary, Jack Straw, for a fundamental revision of the international convention on refugees to reduce smuggling of asylum seekers were yesterday attacked by human rights campaigners and the UN refugee agency.

The proposals, disclosed in the Guardian, would require people to apply for asylum from within the countries they were fleeing or neighbouring states.

UN figures show that Britain is consolidating its position as the most popular EU destination for asylum seekers. It received 5,910 asylum applications in April, a drop of 11.7% over March. But the decline was slower than the European average fall of 18%.

Under Mr Straw's scheme, requiring a radical redrafting of the 1951 convention, an agreed list of "safe countries" would be set up from which EU states would not generally consider asylum applications.

He told an EU conference in Lisbon yesterday that a quota system, sharing among EU states refugees from countries recognised as abusing human rights, would speed up genuine applications while keeping out bogus claimants.

But the UN high commissioner for refugees challenged his contention that reform of the convention was needed to take account of the realities of today's swift travel, arguing that 99% of refugees "run away" from persecution and stop once they reach safety.

Its spokeswoman, Lyndall Sachs, said it was unrealistic to think that those suffering persecution could apply for asylum from the country they were fleeing. Also unrealistic were "white lists" of safe countries. She pointed to the plight of the Roma in east European countries not regarded as persecutors of their citizens.

Amnesty International's director, Kate Allen, said poor states could be left to foot the bill for those fleeing persecution across their borders. "Jack Straw wants to turn the refugee convention on its head by making it into a charter for governments to bar asylum seekers."

fields.headline: A devil at every door
fields.standfirst:
Panic fears are haunting the Home Office

Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Where New Labour has most cruelly disappointed is the speed and completeness with which it became "executive-minded". That especially marks Jack Straw and his Home Office colleagues.
fields.body:
Where New Labour has most cruelly disappointed is the speed and completeness with which it became "executive-minded". That especially marks Jack Straw and his Home Office colleagues. They slip too easily into the world view of security service directors-general and senior police officers. The state is under siege. Crime, disorder and libertinism are rife. Unless "the authorities" (a satisfying Home Office term, that) are given vast new powers to eavesdrop, discipline and investigate, chaos will ensue.

It is a fundamentally conservative attitude and so by no means new - the only surprise is the shamelessness of Labour politicians who made so much capital out of opposing it when out of office. A novelty is the tone adopted this week by Mr Straw and his henchman Charles Clarke in rebutting criticism of their regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill. It is not far short of hysterical. Unless the UK acts swiftly drug runners and international crime syndicates will flood the country, or at least its communications media with encoded messages which common carriers must now be compelled to decipher.

Mr Clarke has every right to dispute estimates of the cost to internet service providers of compliance with his bill, but his blustering misses the point. Why does the UK government need to rush this fence at all? Internet technology is changing fast, content faster. The United States, to which we are entitled to look for example, is in the throes of a debate about giving government a right to decode. There, would-be intelligence-gatherers are matched by passionate defenders of privacy in communications.

The RIP bill does rationalise the safeguards surrounding interception of communications by the state - though it would be a lot more convincing if there were any lay and external element in the supervision. But it also extends the state's reach. And "the state" we know not just to be Mr Straw or Mr Clarke, who might in theory be hauled before fellow MPs to account for themselves, but a legion of unnameable executive functionaries. The Home Office is saying: trust us . Why should we? Look at the disposition to coerce shown by its pursuit of the press, this newspaper included, in the Shayler affair. On display there is the same mind-set which we are being asked to prize and privilege in this repugnant bid to extend government power over the internet.

webTitle: Panic as rebel stronghold scents battle

fields.headline: Panic as rebel stronghold scents battle
fields.standfirst:
Thousands of Sierra Leoneans are pouring out of Makeni town before the army arrives in force

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of Sierra Leoneans are pouring out of Makeni town before the army arrives in force
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Mile 91, central Sierra Leone
fields.body:
Romatu Konneh decided to get out of the rebel-held town of Makeni as soon as she picked up one of the leaflets fluttering down from the combat helicopter swooping low over the Revolutionary United Front headquarters early this week.

The text was written by a British officer assigned to psychological warfare against Sierra Leone's rebels.

"RUF, this time we've dropped leaflets. Next time it will be: a half-inch Gatling machine gun or 57mm rockets or 23mm guns or 30mm grenades or ALL OF THEM!" the leaflet warned.

Just a few hours later, the threat was followed through with the first of a series of bombing and shooting raids on the strategic town by the Russian-made helicopter gunship, hired by the government and flown by a South African mercenary. The main market and a factory used as a RUF weapons store were hit, killing several people.

"It's impossible to hide from the helicopter," Mrs Konneh said. "You can even be killed in your house because the bombs and bullets go right through the roof. The rebels shoot back at the helicopter and if you get in their way they just shoot you. I think many rebels died but I think innocent people were killed as well."

Sierra Leone government forces have been steadily advancing inland toward Makeni as the rebels have found themselves pushed further from the fringes of the coastal capital of Freetown over the past six weeks.

Makeni has been the rebel headquarters since the peace accord - now defunct - was signed a year ago between the government and the RUF. The town also straddles the main routes east and south to the diamond mines that have funded the rebels' war. Losing Makeni would be a big psychological blow to the RUF.

Some of those who have escaped from the town describe many of the young rebels as exhausted by the renewed war and alarmed at the prospect of an assault on Makeni, and say they recently voted to surrender. But RUF commanders ordered them to fight on.

Nonetheless, the rebels appear to realise they may well be driven from the town before long. Refugees say the RUF is looting homes and buildings previously left untouched, and is snatching young people to act as bearers to carry the booty away. The rebels are also razing parts of the town.

Mrs Konneh fled with her four children three days after the first helicopter gunship attack. She joined about 50,000 people who have tramped 35 miles south this week to the government-held town of Mile 91 in search of safety.

"Everybody in Makeni thinks the government will attack soon and then it will be very bad. The rebels can just kill us any time they want but so can government soldiers if they capture us. They might say we are RUF supporters because we live in Makeni, though we live there all our lives," she said.

Some RUF fighters take futile pot shots at the helicopter and present themselves as targets. Their bodies are left in the streets with those of passers-by caught in the attacks.

The Sierra Leone army's director of operations, Colonel Nelson Williams, said it was "rather unfortunate if a few civilians were around and were wounded".

The rebels decided that the one place a helicopter was unlikely to hit was the refugee camp on the edge of Makeni. So RUF fighters poured in, driving the residents out of their shelters and looting their goods.

The 11-member Conteh family fled after one of its number, Alfred, a renter of bicycles in Makeni, was shot by a rebel. The elderly father, Saidu, was transported in a wheelbarrow clutching the youngest member, a baby three weeks old.

"I am a tailor. I have left all my sewing machines. How am I to survive here?" he asked.

A group of people with leprosy who fled the Stucco Catholic hospital in Makeni has still not turned up.

Mile 91 itself is hardly secure. The rebels attacked the town a month ago, and RUF fighters are moving about 10 miles away burning villages.

The United Nations says it has no intention of moving the refugees even though they could find themselves in the middle of a battle.

While the government is claiming the RUF is on the run, its own forces are looking increasingly factionalised just one day after the British completed the withdrawal of their combat troops, whose intervention last month stopped a rebel push to take Freetown.

In the shaky pro-government alliance, Kamajor militiamen clashed with soldiers loyal to the former military ruler, Johnny Paul Koroma; one of the more colourful factions calling itself the West Side Boys opened fire on members of the government's army in the frontline town of Lunsar.

At least the government appears to be winning the psychological war. On the leaflet warning the RUF and Makeni's residents of a pending attack is a copy of a $500 note and a picture of a man with his arms hacked off. The rebels get the money, the caption notes, while innocent civilians are mutilated by them.

"That is true," said Mrs Konneh. "If we are lucky they only steal our clothes and our food but it is just as easy for them to steal our lives."

webTitle: Court rules truck driver is son of singer

fields.headline: Court rules truck driver is son of singer
fields.trailText: A retired truck driver was $1m better off yesterday after a court finally accepted that he is the son of the mysterious blues singer and legendary Mississippi delta guitarist Robert Johnson.
fields.body:
A retired truck driver was $1m better off yesterday after a court finally accepted that he is the son of the mysterious blues singer and legendary Mississippi delta guitarist Robert Johnson.

The Mississippi supreme court ruled that Claud Johnson, 68, of Crystal Springs, is the blues musician's sole heir and therefore entitled to about $1m (£660,000) in royalties.

Johnson, a primary influence on popular music and whose numbers have been covered by legends such as Muddy Waters, the Rolling Stones and Eric Clapton, is thought to have died in 1938 at the age of 27, possibly poisoned by a jealous lover.

What is known is that Johnson died without a penny.

Interest in his music was revived in the 1960s when the 29 songs he recorded were released as King of the Delta Blues Singers, volumes one and two.

The albums included songs such as Crossroads Blues, Love In Vain, Dust My Broom and Sweet Home Chicago.

fields.headline: EU split by sanctions row
fields.standfirst: Vital reforms may be blocked as Austria threatens retaliation for isolation imposed by Europe after triumph of far-right Freedom party The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: European Union sanctions against Austria are to stay in place during next week's summit in Portugal despite fears that Vienna could retaliate by blocking vital institutional reforms, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and  Michael White  in London
fields.body:
European Union sanctions against Austria are to stay in place during next week's summit in Portugal despite fears that Vienna could retaliate by blocking vital institutional reforms, it emerged yesterday.

With the Vienna government lobbying hard to end the punitive measures, Antonio Guterres, the prime minister of Portugal - which currently holds the EU's rotating presidency - has been unable to close the gaps, diplomats in Brussels said.

Disagreements over the withholding tax and plans for an ambitious EU charter of fundamental rights, which Tony Blair has vowed to block, are also expected to feature prominently at the summit in Santa Maria da Feira, near Oporto.

But failure to resolve the Austrian row, which has overshadowed all top-level EU gatherings since last February, could impede reform and enlargement - key issues for the two-day meeting of the 15-member bloc.

All 14 of Austria's EU partners froze bilateral contacts with Vienna after the chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, led his conservatives into a coalition with Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party. In the last few days Mr Guterres has failed to persuade France, which takes over the presidency on July 1, to drop its tough line.

Mr Schüssel said in Vienna yesterday that he hoped the summit would mark the "beginning of the end" of his government's isolation.

But EU officials said that, at most, the 14 could agree a date to review the sanctions, probably early next year, and then ask the European commission to report on the situation, thus providing an exit strategy.

"The more the Austrians pile on the pressure for a formal decision, the more difficult the problem becomes," said one senior source. "That way does not advance a solution."

The commission president, Romano Prodi, who was not consulted on the sanctions, said in a pre-summit briefing that normal relations would be maintained with Austria.

The situation in Austria, though not formally on the agenda, is one of several items which could be the subject of sharp disagreements.

Much depends on whether finance ministers, meeting tomorrow night, can thrash out remaining differences over the cross-border withholding tax.

Mr Blair and Gordon Brown, the chancellor, believe they have won the argument against the tax, designed to prevent EU citizens - mainly Germans - moving their money abroad to avoid tax.

More ambitiously, heads of government are to discuss the institutional changes left over from the 1997 Amsterdam treaty. The main proposals are to limit the size of the 20-strong commission, alter the weighting of votes among member states and increase the use of qualified majority voting instead of unanimous decision-making.

Without reform, the EU could become paralysed when it starts to take in new members from eastern and central Europe from 2003 onwards.

EU institutions were designed for the six founding members and decisions are already hard to reach now there are 15. Achieving a consensus with more could prove impossible.

For the first time ever at Feira, leaders will discuss "reinforced cooperation" - or flexibility. Britain has signalled that it will not oppose the idea of a new system in principle but wants to know what areas it would be used for. Mr Blair is already nervous about Britain's exclusion from the euro-11 forum of countries, which has adopted the single currency.

Nothing will be decided until much closer to the Treaty of Nice, due to be signed in December. But battle lines are being drawn, with signs that Britain and Spain will seek a trade-off between support for flexibility and retaining national vetoes.

On the charter of rights, Britain hopes to build alliances with the Nordic countries, Ireland and Spain against Germany and Italy, which back a legally binding document incorporating new rights. France's position is unclear.

Conservative politicians fear the proposed charter, the brainchild of federalist minded MEPs, will be the embryo of a constitution for a federal European superstate.

But Mr Blair's spokesman insisted that the document would "bring together existing rights" rather than create new ones.

With battle raging over his "prepare and decide" policy on the euro, the prime minister is grateful to the Portuguese presidency for its efforts to put the wider economic reform agenda on the map at the Lisbon "dot.com summit" in March.

Downing Street signalled last night that Mr Blair's first objective for Feira would be to "maintain the momentum behind economic reform" which has seen moves to increase productivity and encourage flexible labour markets on the continent.

Mr Blair is also expected to use the summit to press the Greek prime minister, Costas Simitis, to help find the killers of the British attache, Brigadier Stephen Saunders, who was killed in Athens last week.

But failure to resolve the Austrian row, which has overshadowed all top-level EU gatherings since last February, could impede reform and enlargement - key issues for the two-day meeting of the 15-member bloc. All 14 of Austria's EU partners froze bilateral contacts with Vienna after the chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, led his conservatives into a coalition with Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party. In the last few days Mr Guterres has failed to persuade France, which takes over the presidency on July 1, to drop its tough line. Mr Schüssel said in Vienna yesterday that he hoped the summit would mark the "beginning of the end" of his government's isolation. But EU officials said that, at most, the 14 could agree a date to review the sanctions, probably early next year, and then ask the European commission to report on the situation, thus providing an exit strategy. "The more the Austrians pile on the pressure for a formal decision, the more difficult the problem becomes," said one senior source. "That way does not advance a solution." The commission president, Romano Prodi, who was not consulted on the sanctions, said in a pre-summit briefing that normal relations would be maintained with Austria. The situation in Austria, though not formally on the agenda, is one of several items which could be the subject of sharp disagreements. Much depends on whether finance ministers, meeting tomorrow night, can thrash out remaining differences over the cross-border withholding tax. Mr Blair and Gordon Brown, the chancellor, believe they have won the argument against the tax, designed to prevent EU citizens - mainly Germans - moving their money abroad to avoid tax. More ambitiously, heads of government are to discuss the institutional changes left over from the 1997 Amsterdam treaty. The main proposals are to limit the size of the 20-strong commission, alter the weighting of votes among member states and increase the use of qualified majority voting instead of unanimous decision-making. Without reform, the EU could become paralysed when it starts to take in new members from eastern and central Europe from 2003 onwards. EU institutions were designed for the six founding members and decisions are already hard to reach now there are 15. Achieving a consensus with more could prove impossible. For the first time ever at Feira, leaders will discuss "reinforced cooperation" - or flexibility. Britain has signalled that it will not oppose the idea of a new system in principle but wants to know what areas it would be used for. Mr Blair is already nervous about Britain's exclusion from the euro-11 forum of countries, which has adopted the single currency. Nothing will be decided until much closer to the Treaty of Nice, due to be signed in December. But battle lines are being drawn, with signs that Britain and Spain will seek a trade-off between support for flexibility and retaining national vetoes. On the charter of rights, Britain hopes to build alliances with the Nordic countries, Ireland and Spain against Germany and Italy, which back a legally binding document incorporating new rights. France's position is unclear. Conservative politicians fear the proposed charter, the brainchild of federalist minded MEPs, will be the embryo of a constitution for a federal European superstate. But Mr Blair's spokesman insisted that the document would "bring together existing rights" rather than create new ones. With battle raging over his "prepare and decide" policy on the euro, the prime minister is grateful to the Portuguese presidency for its efforts to put the wider economic reform agenda on the map at the Lisbon "dot.com summit" in March. Downing Street signalled last night that Mr Blair's first objective for Feira would be to "maintain the momentum behind economic reform" which has seen moves to increase productivity and encourage flexible labour markets on the continent. Mr Blair is also expected to use the summit to press the Greek prime minister, Costas Simitis, to help find the killers of the British attache, Brigadier Stephen Saunders, who was killed in Athens last week.

webTitle: Archaeologists unearth the Roman Las Vegas

fields.headline: Archaeologists unearth the Roman Las Vegas
fields.trailText: A buried amphitheatre discovered near Rome once lured gladiators, gamblers and shoppers to antiquity's version of Las Vegas, British archaeologists have revealed.
fields.body:
A buried amphitheatre discovered near Rome once lured gladiators, gamblers and shoppers to antiquity's version of Las Vegas, British archaeologists have revealed.

The isolated town of Forum Novum had temples, baths and markets but very few full-time residents, suggesting visitors flocked there for the shows. Its previously unknown arena held around 5,000 spectators who were a day's chariot ride from Rome, 45 miles south and connected by the roads Via Salaria and Via Flaminia.

A team led by Helen Patterson, head of archaeology at The British School at Rome, located the tiered stone structure half a metre below the surface.

"We were shocked when we found an amphitheatre. Nobody knew it existed before. It's virtually in the middle of nowhere," she said. "The most likely activity was gladiatorial combat. Fighters would have been brought from Rome. It's quite possible that animals also fought there, but we won't know until we dig."

Forum Novum's market probably sold olive oil, bread, pottery and wine. People also came to pay taxes, enlist in the army and be buried in its mausoleums. Yet there were dwellings only for 50-100 people, suggesting that it survived by persuading visitors to travel across swaths of central Italy.

"People could have come here to do a bit of shopping and then catch a fight or two. It was hugely popular entertainment. That makes Forum Novum extremely unusual. You would expect to find far more villas or blocks of flats in such a town," said Dr Patterson.

A researcher added: "It was like a shopping mall with lots of added attractions. Viva Las Vegas."

There was a campus to exercise troops, fountains, an aqueduct, basilica and temples dedicated to Venus, the Roman god of love. Forum Novum originated as a market centre in the second century BC and had been elevated to a town by the first century AD when Pliny the Younger catalogued Roman settlements.

The 28 sq metre (300 sq ft) arena, about one eighth the area of Rome's Colosseum, lies beneath a gravel car park and hay field in a ghost town known as Vescovio. Its discovery was one of the first successes of geo-radar, ued to detect buried stone structures.

A Romanesque church occupied by two Brazilian priests, occasional wedding parties and a restaurant, Oasi di Vescovio, are all that's left of the town today. Archaeologists hope that the local authorities, who own the car park, will grant permission for excavations to start in August.

fields.headline: Fantastic voyage
fields.standfirst: Icelandic crew follow in the wake of great seafarer
fields.trailText: A thousand years after one of Iceland's favourite sons, Leif "The Lucky" Eriksson, became the first European to sail to North American shores, one of his direct descendants will today cast off from Reykjavik in an elaborate reconstruction of that epic passage.
fields.body:
A thousand years after one of Iceland's favourite sons, Leif "The Lucky" Eriksson, became the first European to sail to North American shores, one of his direct descendants will today cast off from Reykjavik in an elaborate reconstruction of that epic passage.

Gunnar Marel Eggertsson and his crew of seven men and one woman will retrace the voyage in a replica (above) of Eriksson's ship, Islendingur (Icelander). Eggertsson has faithfully recreated the 22.5 metre vessel, using 9th century plans and 21st century skills. Below decks, the oak and pine-built ship is ballasted by eight tonnes of lava rocks.

The 2,600-mile historic voyage will take Islendingur to Greenland and Newfoundland, whose northern tip was known to the Vikings as Vinland and which became the first European settlement in North America.

Islendingur will continue her journey southwards to Halifax, Nova Scotia, and to the US ports of Boston and New York, where the voyage will end in October.

Leif Eriksson's odyssey is vividly described in the Icelandic Sagas known as the Saga of the Greenlanders and the Saga of Eirik the Red. Written by ancient scribes, the Sagas were preserved for future generations of Icelanders.

The Old Norse language has not changed much since the days of the Viking explorers - at least, not in Iceland, where even school children learn to read the original manuscripts describing their history.

webTitle: Villagers back GM crops in referendum

fields.headline: Villagers back GM crops in referendum
fields.standfirst: GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: Opponents of GM crop trials suffered an unexpected setback yesterday when a referendum in a Yorkshire village voted in favour of continuing experiments at a local farm.
fields.body:
Opponents of GM crop trials suffered an unexpected setback yesterday when a referendum in a Yorkshire village voted in favour of continuing experiments at a local farm.

Campaigners in Aldborough and East Newton, where GM oilseed rape and forage maize are sprouting in eroding clifftop fields above the North sea, were shocked by the result and a "don't care" turnout of only 14%.

"Something has gone badly wrong," said Jane Slater, a local schoolteacher whose husband Tony runs an organic vegetable business and helped to trigger the official referendum.

"There is certainly strong feeling on the issue here, but it it hasn't come across," she said.

The biggest official GM test in Britain to date, the poll in the village east of Hull saw just 141 local people bother to vote, out of 999 on the electoral roll.

A parish meeting resolution that "GM crops should not be grown in the parish of Aldborough until they are proven safe" was defeated by 80 votes to 61.

Handbills had been delivered to every house in the village and posters stuck in shops, pubs and the local chip shop, where they shared the window with a text from St Paul's epistle to the Collossians: "Whatever you do, do it with all your heart."

A polling station was opened in the village hall by East Riding district council and Greenpeace sent extra leaflets with details of cross-pollination findings in recent Canadian GM trials. "It is very disappointing," said Mrs Slater, collecting class reading books under a child's drawing of a sprouting bean seed.

"We did get some warnings about a possible 'apathy effect' and I know people don't vote much in local elections. But we did think that an issue like this, right on our doorstep, would get everyone involved, whatever their feelings."

Confusion over the resolution was widely blamed for the unexpected result, with staff and shoppers at the Spar supermarket saying people had been fazed by the fact that opponents of GM crops had to tick the 'For' box on ballot papers, to support the resolution.

"To be honest, you left the polling station still wondering whether you had voted the right way," said one of the staff, restocking a display stand of biscuits. "But that doesn't explain why so few bothered to vote either way."

Across the Hull road, Peter Bettison was equally puzzled at his lawnmower repair shop, which might win extra business if trial crops ever had to be mown. He said: "I have certainly got strong feelings. I think they should stuff GM crops where they should stuff them. We have just had BSE, which has caused devastation round here, and now they are letting another genie out of the bottle. I am not sure how many people realised the vote was going on."

A family passing the shop, newly-moved to Aldborough and just back from a trip to Hornsea for curtains, admitted that they knew nothing about the referendum, while staff at Aldborough Fisheries said that the limited polling station hours - 4pm to 9pm on Thursday - had coincided with non-stop demand for fish and chips.

"I have to add, though," said the proprietor's wife, "that the more you read about this subject, the less you feel you know."

The farmer conducting the trials, Richard Caley, said he believed in what he was doing and had put the case personally to neighbours and at a local public meeting, which was also addressed by Friends of the Earth and the GM seed supplier Juventus. He said: "I don't want to comment about the vote because we get so much media distortion, but a 14% turnout must say something."

The result is likely to lead to a rethink by GM opponents about campaign-planning for local polls, which have been seen as a livelier and more democratic counter to the government's consultation programme of public meetings.

Peter Riley of Friends of the Earth said: "The government process does not deserve the name 'consultation' but the Aldborough result is surprising. It is particularly strange after the Canadian evidence which is really ought to have people worried."

webTitle: On the street where God lives

fields.headline: On the street where God lives
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: I work on the streets with excluded people. That experience has persuaded me that the greatest cause of their disaffection, and the greatest obstacle to their restoration, is self-esteem - or rather the lack of it.
fields.body:
I work on the streets with excluded people. That experience has persuaded me that the greatest cause of their disaffection, and the greatest obstacle to their restoration, is self-esteem - or rather the lack of it.

Social exclusion is generally depicted in terms of violence, abuse and domestic mayhem. But contamination more commonly occurs in a corrosive way - in an accumulation of bad-mouthing, a constant trickle of put-down, the experience of arbitrary disappointment, with hopes ever being raised in expectation of blessings which seldom materialise, or with isolated moments of being loved to bits interrupting the normal experience of being treated as good for nothing.

From infant through toddler, schoolchild to teenager, the excluded are consistently confronted with feedback that focuses on fault, flaw and trespass. These constant reminders of their transgressions aggravate lives already blighted by disadvantage into a sense of disqualification; they are sad going on bad. Beneath every strutting teenager hides a vulnerable, incompetent young person, who has lost all self-respect and is convinced of their inherent badness.

Most Sundays I attend church. At Eucharist, my first prayers are of hand-wringing apology for the things I have done wrong; my last - before receiving the bread and wine - is to acknowledge my unworthiness. In between, I shall probably have been reminded by St Paul of my association with fornication in Corinth or recidivism in Ephesus, and reprimanded in a sermon which emphasises that, while presidents may underperform, injustice create wars and inequity famine, the fundamental cause of the world's problems is my personal frailty.

The doctrine of original sinfulness underpins Christian aetiology, and produces Christian family values which undermine the self-esteem of its children in a manner identical to the persistent put-down at the kitchen table, school gates and shop counter. The alpha of original sin, and omega of apocalyptic intervention, are the theological equivalent of the street message: "You're rotten through and through, just wait till your dad gets home."

But back on the streets, some remarkable processes are underway. We are embarked on an era of empowerment; the victims of disability are being enabled at an unprecedented pace and intensity. It is easy to be cast down by hype of ephemeral outrages, but a broader view shows two centuries of extraordinary progress in manumission, with victims no longer viewed as objects for charitable disposition but as material for positive contribution.

My work is an infinitesimal part of this process, but I encounter substantial opposition. Post-modernism is uncomfortable with the celebration of enablement, while from the saloon bars comes the indignant blatherings of "never had it so bad". But the most unacceptable opponent is religion, and I deeply resent the manner in which holy-ground doctrine interferes with the real work of salvation which God is performing on the streets.

All the world's systems are based on the premise that man is inherently flawed. It pervades every creation myth where man is the construct of corrupt matter; it informs every doctrine - from the original sin of the Abrahamic systems to the elitist ataraxia of Hellenism to the holy resignation of the East. All rely, where they allow it at all, on man's retrieval being undertaken through divine intervention, whether through mystical initiation or technicolour apocalypse. There is no greater contributor to the culture of blame, which persuades my young people of their basic rottenness, than religion.

Religion is profoundly uncomfortable with the new paradigm of empowerment. Yet empowerment was the emphatic focus of the original ministry upon which the Christian system was based. Jesus was unambiguous in His celebration of the excluded, and even more emphatic about the nature of their enablement. He forgave sins.

Freedom does not come more cogent than that, yet the churches persist with the language of the pawnbroker, which leaves humanity deeply in hock to Christ and at cross purposes with His father. If Christianity - and other religions - are to have any constructive impact, they need to extend a sacred endorsement to that gospel of empowerment being enacted on the secular streets.

 Stewart Dakers is a street youth worker

fields.headline: My opinion
fields.trailText: In response to Gerry Abbotts's question to me (Letters, June 8), there can be no ethical involvement in Burma; tourism and investment merely support a junta that would otherwise be forced to the negotiating table with the democratic forces.
fields.body:
In response to Gerry Abbotts's question to me (Letters, June 8), there can be no ethical involvement in Burma; tourism and investment merely support a junta that would otherwise be forced to the negotiating table with the democratic forces. Much of the tourist infrastructure has been built with forced labour and the ethnic minority areas, the scenes of gross human rights violations, are completely off-limits for tourists. The only foreigners that get out to these more remote regions are the oil companies.

Premier Oil has built a pipeline in a consortium with the junta (in the guise of the Myanma Oil & Gas Enterprise). Not only will this project help keep the military in power for the next 20 years through the revenue it will create, but it has also been the scene of major forced relocation and forced labour projects. The pipeline is now the most militarised region in the whole of Burma and the local people suffer on-going abuses at the hands of the troops.

The Burmese know what democracy is, they don't need foreigners to go in and tell them about it. As for Gerry, he must remember that we live in a democracy and everyone is free to voice their opinion.
Rachel Goldwyn
London
khinkhin@breathemail.net

fields.headline: Off the peg
fields.trailText: The Par Garment factory from which Suthasini Kaewleklai was dismissed (Exploitation a world away from the glitz, June 10) has been the subject of international campaigning for several years. Yet working conditions continue to deteriorate.
fields.body:
The Par Garment factory from which Suthasini Kaewleklai was dismissed (Exploitation a world away from the glitz, June 10) has been the subject of international campaigning for several years. Yet working conditions continue to deteriorate, with sub-contracting increasingly eroding whatever rights and benefits workers had fought for. Labour Behind the Label, the UK platform of the Clean Clothes Campaign, has evidence that suppliers of Nike, Adidas and others continue to pay insufficient minimum wages, fail to enforce workers' rights to form, join and be active in independent trade unions and commonly breach national law over the length of the working week. Chantal Finney
Labour Behind the Label
nead@gn.apc.org

fields.headline: Fans of the wobbly bridge
fields.trailText: Lord Foster and Sir Anthony Caro's Millennium Bridge masterpiece has created a superb opportunity for interaction between New Britain, contemporary art and mass culture (Letters, June 15).
fields.body:
Lord Foster and Sir Anthony Caro's Millennium Bridge masterpiece has created a superb opportunity for interaction between New Britain, contemporary art and mass culture (Letters, June 15). Teams of soccer fans could congregate at either end and march across the bridge in time to "Vinadaloo nah nah nah ... England etc" by Fat Les, trying to create maximum millennium wobble.

Of course the £18m worth might just wobble itself into the Thames, a unique exhibit of deconstruction art in front of the Tate Modern and a useful reminder to the custodians of public money that architects design buildings, sculptors sculpt and bridge engineers build bridges. The trick for the marchers will be to get off before the bridge drops. Bit of a lottery really, like the bridge itself.
M Bell
London

 The most awful thing is not the bridge's failure, but the ill-informed admiration with which it was received. This is surely the last resort of a desperate Cool Britannia. The first principle of engineering is that there are no excuses: if it doesn't work, you got it wrong.

The most obvious cause of the excessive movement is the thinness of the structure. Thin blades are flexible - Arup know that, as they do the effects of people on structures. It would be delightful to hear the full story of how this failure came to be, so that I can put it into the education of the next generation of engineers. Unfortunately, issues of liability make this unlikely. A true millennium achievement would be for Arup to be able to put the story on their admirable website without fear of retribution.
Dr Steve Joseph
University of Sheffield
S.Joseph@sheffield.ac.uk

 An elderly Irish uncle used to sing a song that began "We all walk the wibbly, wobbly walk". Does anyone remember it? It would make an apt theme tune for that wibbly, wobbly bridge.
Don Benlow
Wisbech, Cambs

fields.headline: Laughing at our expense
fields.trailText: Why should private hospitals charge for carrying out NHS operations (Milburn lines up private operations to cut NHS lists, June 16)? Every single British doctor and nurse they employ was NHS trained at the taxpayer's expense. It's about time they started repaying their debt.
fields.body:
Why should private hospitals charge for carrying out NHS operations (Milburn lines up private operations to cut NHS lists, June 16)? Every single British doctor and nurse they employ was NHS trained at the taxpayer's expense. It's about time they started repaying their debt. They owe us, we do not owe them.
Myrna Shaw
Hackney Pensioners' Convention

 So the government is going to rent operating theatres in the private sector for NHS operations. When are they going to stop surgeons using NHS operating theatres to do their private patients?
Richard Roques
London

 At least Charlie Chaplin managed four entries (Hollywood's loudest laughs, June 15); Laurel and Hardy didn't even get a mention.
Colin Billett
Bewdley, Worcs
col@dircon.co.uk

 David Kemp (Letters, June 15) cites evidence that Scots will still support anyone against the English. I hope that he will join me in wishing England well in their next Euro 2000 games. Then the Scots will have someone to support in the knockout stages. For a change.
Andy Gardiner
London
andygardiner@hotmail.com

 In most English locals if Scotland were playing in Europe there would be 100% support for them. Why do the Scots think so differently from us about supporting any British team?
H Evans
Warrington, Cheshire

 I suppose it's a compliment for Scots to be so interested in England's games, because when Scotland appear on TV the majority of us just turn it off. Watching paint dry is more exciting.
Clive Partridge
Plymouth
C.J.Partridge@plymouth.ac.uk

fields.headline: Kick out the prima donnas
fields.trailText: I was delighted to read that the BBC has lost the rights to Premiership football highlights, which will mean the end of Match of the Day on BBC1 (Angry BBC priced out of market, June 15).
fields.body:
I was delighted to read that the BBC has lost the rights to Premiership football highlights, which will mean the end of Match of the Day on BBC1 (Angry BBC priced out of market, June 15). How about the BBC acknowledging the other 50% of TV licence payers and showing some women's sport instead? They could promote matches from the first professional women's football side (Fulham), or minority sports, rarely seen on TV, like netball, triathlon, gymnastics, cross-country, squash. The BBC might be surprised how many viewers switch on.

My daughter (aged six) had to sit through a Euro 2000 match last night and said "Why don't we ever see any women playing sport, mummy?" No wonder if, in seven years time, she joins the ranks of anorexics who take up smoking to keep their weight down because there is virtually no coverage on TV (or in newspapers) of women's sport, which at the end of the day is the best route to producing healthy, confident, high-achieving young women.

Come on Greg, you wanted to make a difference as the new BBC director general. Stop pandering to the overpaid prima donnas of football and give some coverage to the deserving amateurs who promote the true values of sporting achievement.
Hilary Baxter
Buckingham
hbaxter@alacrity.co.uk

 The worst part about the BBC losing Match of the Day is that there is no escape from the puerile inanities of Ron Atkinson.
Daphne Romney
London
didi@weststand.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Liberty RIP
fields.trailText: It is very disingenuous of John Abbott, head of the National Criminal Intelligence Service, and home office minister Charles Clarke (Letters, June 15) to argue that the regulation of investigatory powers bill simply aims to increase the accountability of the security services. This is not true.
fields.body:
It is very disingenuous of John Abbott, head of the National Criminal Intelligence Service, and home office minister Charles Clarke (Letters, June 15) to argue that the regulation of investigatory powers bill simply aims to increase the accountability of the security services. This is not true.

The bill will give them new powers and, in the case of encrypted messages, mean that someone asked to produce an encryption key will be regarded as guilty until proved innocent. It will also threaten e-commerce since no company operating in Britain will be sure that its encryption systems are secure. It will not threaten major criminals or those engaged in espionage - they will use anonymous forwarding systems.
Prof Michael Pidd
President, Operational Research Society
M.Pidd@lancaster.ac.uk

 John Abbot tells us that a warrant signed by the home secretary will be needed to read emails. However, a warrant will not be needed to monitor internet traffic - including which websites users visit and who they email. Abbot says that the intelligence services "have neither the inclination nor the resources ... to monitor the massive amounts of electronic communications". What, then, is the point of the listening stations GCHQ and the US base at Menwith Hill?

Charles Clarke's assures us that "Not all internet service providers... will be asked to provide an intercept capability". When will we be informed which ones will?
Nathan Jackson
University of Central England
Nathan.Jackson@uce.ac.uk

fields.headline: Still no justice for some
fields.trailText: Martin Narey's letter, headlined "I try to stop prisoners killing themselves" (June 16) took my breath away. My 22-year-old grandson committed suicide in Wandsworth prison on February 1 this year.
fields.body:
Martin Narey's letter, headlined "I try to stop prisoners killing themselves" (June 16) took my breath away. My 22-year-old grandson committed suicide in Wandsworth prison on February 1 this year.

Keita had a history of suffering from schizophrenia, he attempted self-harm by hanging on a previous occasion and had begged to be saved from his own overwhelming fear that he might kill himself. Yet it was felt that there was no need to continue a 15-minute suicide watch on Keita. His trainer laces were returned to him, which he subsequently used to hang himself.

There have been 39 suicides in prisons in this country already this year, how dare Martin Narey write a mewling, puking letter in the Guardian trying to justify his role in the epidemic of vulnerable people driven to kill themselves while most of them are on remand? Unless and until prison governors in this country band together and tell Jack Straw that they refuse to act as dumping grounds for the National Health Service, mentally ill patients like my grandson will continue to die while in the "care" of the prison service.
Erin Pizzey
London
pizzey@pizzey1.freeservice. co.uk

 The investigation by the police into the shooting of Harry Stanley is yet another illustration of the need for fundamental reform of the current system for investigation of complaints against the police (Why was Harry shot? G2 June 14). There appears to be widespread consensus that the police investigating the police, albeit from an outside force with supervision from the PCA, should not continue in the most serious cases.

However, the concern is that any reforms allowing for independent investigation will only concentrate on these most serious, high-profile cases and that the vast majority of cases will continue to be investigated by the police, some under supervision from an independent body. Independent investigation of all complaints against the police is neither practical, nor desirable. However, it is many of the less serious complaints, for example in appropriate use of stop and search powers, that cause the most concern to both individual complainants and communities.

Experience has shown that supervision of police investigations has not increased public confidence -investigation of the police by the police, however well carried out or well supervised, will always be vulnerable to criticism and suspicion. The government is now considering options for independent investigation of some complaints against the police, following the publication of two feasibility studies, one commissioned by the Home Office, the other by Liberty.

The Liberty report recommends independent investigation of all serious complaints (such as deaths, or racial incidents), plus a selection of all other complaints equal to at least 25% of all complaints. It is only by independent investigation of a significant proportion of all complaints, rather than of the few high-profile cases, that pubic confidence in the police in this area can be restored.
Mary Cunneen
Associate director, Liberty

 I was truly heartened to read Geoffrey Gibbs's article (Death in the shadow of race fears, June 16) reporting the tragic consequences of the demonisation of asylum seekers by politicians and sections of the media. Jack Straw and Barbara Roche share responsibility with Hague and Widdecombe for the appalling rise in racist violence and the death of Mr Pasalbessi. I, for one, will be on the demonstration in defence of asylum seekers in London next Saturday.
Anna Chen
London
a.chen@virgin.net

webTitle: Rural revolt over asylum seekers' hostel

fields.headline: Rural revolt over asylum seekers' hostel
fields.standfirst:
'There are going to be so many, and a lot are going to be young men'

Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The B-word has been much in use in Over Stowey this week. Not bogus, as in asylum seekers. But, but - as in "I have nothing against asylum seekers, but ... "
fields.body:
The B-word has been much in use in Over Stowey this week. Not bogus, as in asylum seekers. But, but - as in "I have nothing against asylum seekers, but ... "

To their evident discomfort, residents of this normally peaceful corner of rural Somerset have found themselves under the media spotlight in a row about a religious charity's plans to house up to 74 asylum seekers in a former boarding school on their doorstep.

The proposal has bitterly divided this ancient parish, a clutch of hamlets spread along the eastern edge of the Quantock hills near Bridgwater.

The area, whose beauty and tranquillity once attracted Coleridge and Wordsworth, remains a highly sought after place to live, the sort of place young locals can no longer afford.

A cottage requiring £20,000 spent on repairs was recently snapped up for over £130,000 - more than 50% above the expected auction price. The Daily Mail pundit Paul Johnson has a rose-covered country bolthole here.

With their neatly mown lawns and polished Range Rovers in the drive, the small number of historic houses clustered around the 14th century church exude affluence.

Crime is low, the pace of life slow and untroubled. And that is the way most villagers would like to keep it.

For two days this week they have been reliving their worst fears. Kaleidoscope, a Baptist charity that wants to house asylum seekers in the dormitory blocks once occupied by the boys and girls of Quantocks school, has been appealing against the local authority's decision to block the plan.

Sedgemore district council rejected the proposal in January on the grounds that the site did not meet Home Office criteria for asylum seeker accommodation. Because of the remote rural location difficulties were likely to be encountered in providing support services.

Opponents - a large majority of the 314 members of the parish - agree. They must now wait until the government appointed inspector, Philip Wilson, gives his ruling later this summer.

Under the Kaleidoscope plan, asylum seekers would have access to the former school's swimming pool and sports hall - now run as a club for local people - and be provided with a regular minibus service to Bridgwater.

But those fighting the scheme say they will soon become bored. Pubs and shops are a two-mile trudge away in Nether Stowey.

For some, though, nimbyism runs deeper. There is resentment that money is being spent on asylum seekers at a time when the rural economy is on its knees. There are those who are by nature suspicious of outsiders. Over a drink in Nether Stowey, a few from the surrounding area denounce all asylum seekers as scroungers who should be sent "home" without more ado.

Mike Lampson, 63, a retired company director and farmer who chairs the parish council, said villagers had been unfairly portrayed as having a "lock up your daughters" view.

"If we are landed with them they will be given hospitality and every consideration given to any other person that lives here. But if common sense and logic prevails they will turn the plan down for the good of the asylum seekers themselves.

"If you shut 50 young men up in a school for six months or even longer they are going to get fed up. What are they going to do?

"I think what people are worried about is the fear of the unknown. There are no ethnic people in the village and all people have to go on are press accounts of what has happened over the last year in places like Dover. You can understand people's fears."

Joan Watson, who has lived in the village for 20 years, said: "There are going to be so many of them in such a small community and a lot of them are going to be young men. I have nothing against refugees or asylum seekers. If it was only a dozen it would be wonderful because we could absorb them into the community. But you can't absorb that many."

Margaret Swords said people were worried they would "get up to no good" one way or another. But she was also angry that money could be found to provide them with transport in a community where bus services for local people barely exist.

"The money is there to fund the asylum seekers, but it's not there to look after the countryside people of this area, and people are cross," she said. "It's not because people here are not sorry for asylum seekers, we are. But don't we count for something first?"

Gloria Goddard, 34, whose house is next to the grounds of the former boarding school, said she did not like the idea of large numbers of single men being housed there.

Clutching 20-month-old Harry, she said they should be placed in a city where there were facilities for the men to go out and enjoy themselves.

"At the moment there is no crime here at all, or very little, and I am worried that crime will go up. With 50 single men in an area where there are no single women they will get bored and frustrated. What will they do all the time? One or two families up there would be al right, but I don't like the idea of there being lots of single men."

Retired GP Philip Jago and his wife are among the few to have spoken out strongly in favour of the idea.

The local vicar, whose home is in Nether Stowey, has also given strong backing to the proposal. But opponents claim many of the 80 signatures he gathered on a petition supporting Kaleidoscope were those of people outside the parish.

"It is a perfect use for the school. It's absolutely tailor-made for the job and I think the asylum seekers would fit in well here," Dr Jago said. "There was a school there before that had far more people and the village seemed to survive. Asylum seekers will have a lovely home here. Of course there will be problems, but they are all things that can be sorted out. The overall vision is a lovely one. I think they will find more of a welcome here than might be thought."

Not from one member of the local branch of the Women's Institute, however. The woman, who refused to be identified, insisted she would have nothing to do with them.

"They could cause disruption. I go walking up on the hills and if I thought they were up there I wouldn't want to go because I have heard of them being a bit of a nuisance even in town centres."

webTitle: 55 cancer patients get wrong test result

fields.headline: 55 cancer patients get wrong test result
fields.standfirst:
Colleagues spot doctor's errors
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The NHS was at the centre of more allegations that patients may have died as a result of medical errors as it emerged yesterday that cancer patients in Aberdeen received wrong diagnoses.
fields.body:
The NHS was at the centre of more allegations that patients may have died as a result of medical errors as it emerged yesterday that cancer patients in Aberdeen received wrong diagnoses.

Up to 55 people attending Woodend Hospital, Aberdeen for treatment for bowel tumours and disorders may have been wrongly given the all-clear.

The alarm was raised after colleagues raised doubts about the work of Frank Smith, a consultant radiologist. Hospital managers do not know how many of the affected patients may have died, but 16 of those given the all-clear by Dr Smith are currently receiving treatment at the hospital - some for cancer.

The Royal College of Radiologists will begin an investigation by the end of the month and will report by the end of August.

This latest revelation follows sharply on the heels of the case of James Elwood, the Swindon pathologist found to have an unacceptably high rate of error in lab tests he did to confirm diagnoses of cancer.

In this case, colleagues of Dr Smith - a radiologist with an international reputation - raised doubts over the standard of his interpretation of X-rays used to monitor barium enemas. In February, checks began on almost 300 cases carried out over the past three years, revealing the 55 discrepancies.

Dr Smith, 54, who is currently on holiday in the United States with his wife, had interpreted the 55 cases very differently from colleagues who re- examined his work. He was immediately stopped from such work, although he is still carrying out other duties.

A spokesman for Grampian University Hospitals NHS Trust, which runs the hospital, said efforts to trace the 39 patients not currently receiving treatment were under way. No figure could be given for how many might have died, but the spokesman said many of those involved were elderly and might already have died of other natural causes.

The hospital needed to know if anyone had died prematurely because of a misdiagnosis, and that was what the Royal College's investigation would decide, the spokesman said.

Patients suffering from diseases of the bowel are often given barium enemas, which are monitored using X-ray examination. They are considered an essential part of clinical investigation of diseases such as bowel cancer.

Dr Smith has more than 20 years' experience as a radiologist and he is considered to be an expert in magnetic resonance imaging and whole-body scanning techniques. He worked exclusively in these areas between 1989 and 1997 and the trust said this may have led to a "diminution" in his X-ray skills.

Donnie Ross, the trust's clinical director, said Dr Smith was horrified at the discovery of the discrepancies and had expressed great regret about the situation.

All other aspects of Dr Smith's clinical work have been examined by the trust and found to be satisfactory. He is continuing to carry out other work, including his duties as team doctor to Dundee United football club.

A Scottish executive spokesman said the health minister, Susan Deacon, had pledged to act on the outcome of the inquiry.

Earlier this week a report by Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, revealed that one in 10 people attending hospital were damaged by medical errors.
