fields.headline: Happiness is ... lots of cash
fields.trailText: It's official - money buys happiness. That is if you are to believe the findings of the John Charcol Happiness Index out last Wednesday. The index specifically found that money buys happiness in the home.
fields.body:
It's official - money buys happiness. That is if you are to believe the findings of the John Charcol Happiness Index out last Wednesday. The index specifically found that money buys happiness in the home.

John Charcol, the independent mortgage adviser, commisioned Mori to compile the index which aims to track levels of homeowners' happiness. It also attempts to find what makes us happy and in what area the happiest homeowners live.The index found that an astonishing 35% of homeowners give the maximum 10 out of 10.

But happiness comes with a price tag. People in expensive houses are happier than those in lower-value homes. Forty five per cent of people living in homes worth more than £250,000 scored full marks on the happiness scale. They find their homes more affordable because mortgage payments as a percentage of take-home pay are now historically low. Some 75% of the rest of us are seeking properties worth up to £150,000 to ascend the scale of homeowner happiness.

There is hope for us all yet, however. The research revealed that homeowners become happier the older they get. Only 26% of 18-34-year-olds gave top marks for happiness compared to 44% of the over 55s. It seems that the young, for once, don't have it all. And 41% of women claim to be happy in their homes compared to 28% of men.

Happiness is highest among those who are retired with high incomes. If you are among these you might be eternally happy. Or you could move up north - 43% in the north of England are smiling compared to just 26% in the south-east.

webTitle: On a mission to make major conversions

fields.headline: On a mission to make major conversions
fields.standfirst: Green types are adapting all sorts of unusual buildings to create their dream houses. Elizabeth Langton looks at the market
fields.trailText: Green types are adapting all sorts of unusual buildings to create their dream houses. Elizabeth Langton looks at the market
fields.body:
On an island in the middle of the river Frome in Somerset, Lynne Curry and Martin Whitfield have lived like derelicts for 13 months. Stuck without a bathroom or running water for eight weeks, they were reduced to taking showers at a local leisure centre.

Yet they are very, very happy, and, in their own words, on a mission to create the perfect life. They are part of a band of intrepid homeowners who have set about overhauling tumbledown buildings in a bid to create unique and interesting homes.

The couple are in the process of converting two grade II listed former animal feed mills that sit on an island in the middle of the town. They hope to live in one mill once it is completed, work in the adjoining buildings and run a bed and breakfast from the second.

Homebuyers' enthusiasm for converting everything from old pubs to signal boxes shows no sign of waning. In the 70s, idealistic souls in search of the Good Life, scrambled to convert disused agricultural buildings such as barns. More recently, loft dwellers have rushed to buy homes in factories and warehouses. The closure of rural pubs, banks, churches, and schools has also resulted in a wide range of interesting buildings coming on the market.

The Ecology Building Society counts a signal box and cemetery gate building among properties purchased with the help of one of their mortgages. "We try to be a flexible lender and help fund renovation or conversions if the building is no longer used for its original purpose," says spokesman George Penaluna.

Buyers who want to change a building's use need to apply for planning permission. Some older buildings will be sold with planning permission thrown in. If not, check with the local authority how the land lies before making an offer. But there is much more to converting older buildings than sticking in an Aga stove and mezzanine floor, warns Stephen Boniface, a surveyor who specialises in historic buildings.

Mr Boniface says he has seen an alarming number of "atrocious" conversions. "It depends on whose funding it is and the attitude of the builder or developer. If they can't see the profit margin in making the effort you can get a poor job," he says.

For Lynne Curry, making a profit on the project is the furthest thing from her mind. In fact, she says they're not even sure whether they will recover the costs of the refurbishment, an estimated £300,000. The property cost the couple £100,000 and the purchase was financed with the help of a £70,000 loan from the Ecology Building Society.

"We are not attempting to recreate the Mill on the Floss," she says firmly. "We want to create a perfect lifestyle but this is not a rural idyll, this is an industrial town and there are things like electricity stations nearby."

Ms Curry says the project is driven by their ideology. Her husband's company publishes city cycling maps and they run a car-less business. There's no car parking at the site and visitors have to cross a footbridge to get to the island. The building will be environmentally friendly, using the watermill to generate electricity. Ms Curry praises the architects, Bruges Tozer of Bristol and local builder KFG House, both essential to the smooth running of the project.

But not everyone is so lucky. Mr Boniface says too many builders and developers don't understand the construction of older buildings and make the mistake of applying modern solutions to properties constructed very differently.

I'm dealing with a brick-built Tudor barn that has been converted to residential use and they're having damp problems. I can solve them for the time being but I know they're going to reappear a few years down the line. The problem has been caused by their failure to understand the sort of building they're dealing with."

Although listed buildings are governed by restrictions, this is no guarantee that the job will be done properly, he says. "Listing does place restrictions but once you've passed the aesthetic or technical minimum standard it can be hit-and-miss whether the job is a good one."

Robin Chatwin, of the Wandsworth branch of FPD Savills, says buyers get very excited about living in a building that had a former life. An old courthouse in Clapham Old Town, London, has attracted a lot of interest.

Buyers willing to take on a conversion can earn a premium when it comes to selling, says Mr Chatwin. FPD Savills is handling a former electrical distributors' warehouse in Shelgate Road, SW11. Converted five years ago by the artist owner into a four-bedroom live-work space, it has gone on the market for £1.5m.

"As a warehouse I doubt it would have cleared much more than £500-600,000," he says. In London it is increasingly difficult to find interesting buildings to convert into homes, says Mr Chatwin. Further afield, in Scotland, FPD Savills is selling Woodston Fishing Station, perched on a cliff-top at St Cyrus, Kincardinshire. Offers above £135,000 are invited for the Victorian villa, paddock and cliff top (3.3 acres) and above £35,000 for Woodston Bothy, icehouse, outbuildings and clifftop.

Buyers who do find a gem should tread carefully when looking for professionals to undertake the conversion, says Mr Boniface. "Make sure that anyone involved has a track record in conservation. This may mean interviewing several professionals before you find the right one.

"All these things point to someone with experience in historic building conservation who knows the pitfalls," says Mr Boniface.

Next week: where to find an unusual home and how to raise the money to buy it.

webTitle: Rug dealers are hitting a new high

fields.headline: Rug dealers are hitting a new high
fields.standfirst: The market for rare carpets has traditionally been small in the UK. But the Antique Carpet and Textile Art Fair, currently on at Olympia, is bigger than ever
fields.trailText: The market for rare carpets has traditionally been small in the UK. But the Antique Carpet and Textile Art Fair, currently on at Olympia, is bigger than ever.
fields.body:
Carpet and rug dealers in this country have always considered themselves poor relations to dealers in paintings or antique furniture. As one carpet trader puts it: "Carpets have never been considered fine art. They seem to come in the category of traditional art or even crafts."

This is not strictly true. At an auction at Christie's last year a 16th century Tabriz medallion carpet from north west Persia sold for just under £1.6m, beating the world record for a carpet.

But the market for Persian and 17th century Mughal carpets from India is small, partly because they are so rare. A number of wealthy collectors and museums in the US buy and there is interest in Germany and Switzerland, but the UK is not a country where these items are collected.

But there is great demand here for what are known as nomadic carpets. These are tribal rugs from Persia, Turkey, particularly Anatolia, the Caucasus and the central Asian countries - Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. These are usually pile or knotted carpets, characterised by bright colours and patterned with geometric shapes or arabesques or, in the case of Caucasian rugs, "guls"or stylised flower heads.

French Aubusson and Savonnerie and British William Morris carpets are also sought after. They can cost anything from hundreds to thousands of pounds. But again, there is a feeling among dealers that they are bought as classy commodities and often not properly aesthetically appreciated.

Jill Tilden, deputy editor of Hali Magazine (Hali means rug or carpet in Turkish) says: "Time and again you would get dealers displaying the most beautiful old furniture but on indifferent carpets." To counter this rather second-division image a group of traders set up the Hali Antique Carpet and Textile Art Fair in 1988 as the UK's only specialist fair for the textile arts. The aim was not only to build mainstream recognition but also to break out from the narrow confines of purely Islamic carpets and show what a great wealth of world textiles are on offer.

This year's Fair, on at Olympia from June 15-19 is the third, and is bigger and more international than previous ones. There are 75 exhibitors, with 50% coming from abroad; Germany, Austria, Italy, Turkey, France, Lebanon, Sweden and the US.

To be sure, there will be some interesting carpets. An important Joshagan carpet, made between 1893-1900 for then Prime minister of Iran, offered by Swedish dealer JP Willborg , is expected to fetch between £30,000 and £38,000.

The emphasis at the Fair will be on unusual textiles. Last year there was a preponderance of central Asian pieces. This year there are some far-eastern pieces and African artefacts. Molly Hogg, an up-and-coming London dealer, will exhibit a 3m long Balinese tie-dyed silk breast wrapper from the late 19th-early 20th century. It is expected to realise in the region of £3,000.

Joss Graham, who specialises in heirloom textiles from India, Asia and Africa, will be showing works from Cameroon including a fine collection of hats. These crochet cotton hats were worn by African nobles and chiefs on formal occasions and date from the early 20th century.

Clive Loveless is a carpet dealer of 30 years' standing who has specialised in North Africa. He says: "Places like Algeria and Morocco were not on the Silk Road, or the Middle East highways. You never know what you can find amongst the tribes in the Atlas mountains."

He has some very fine and rare textiles from Africa on show. There are some "haigs" from Morocco which are 11feet long - shawls of ivory-white mountain wool with bright embroidery around the edges. These are offered from around £1,000 to £2,000. There are also some henna-dyed veils for around £1,000- £1,800. And Hijiras, which are five to six foot mantles, again of white wool but with brocaded strips, rather like South American pre-Colombian cloaks. They cost from £500-£1,500.

Most exquisite of all to my mind are the beadwork aprons from north Cameroon. These are ceramic and glass pieces of great complexity. One of them is like a pointillist painting. They come from the Baana Guili and Kirdi tribes and have rarely been seen in the west. They are 21 cms by 41cm and quite extraordinary. They are priced at £250-£800.

 For further information telephone Cawdell Douglas on 020-7 439-2822.

webTitle: How to drive Avis bills down

fields.headline: How to drive Avis bills down
fields.trailText: Last week Jobs & Money deputy editor Patrick Collinson wrote of how Avis, having promised to hire him a car in Barcelona for around £120, increased the charge on his credit card to £247 when he returned the vehicle. This would seem to be a credit card bill crying out to be challenged.
fields.body:
Last week Jobs & Money deputy editor Patrick Collinson wrote of how Avis, having promised to hire him a car in Barcelona for around £120, increased the charge on his credit card to £247 when he returned the vehicle. This would seem to be a credit card bill crying out to be challenged.

Avis sought to justify doubling the charge on the basis that Mr Collinson had been told that a "small sum" would be added for insurance and tax.

But £127 is neither small, nor does it bear any resemblance to the real cost of insuring a small car for four days.

When hiring the car, he had been required to sign an open credit card slip. Although he did protest to Avis here and in Spain about the charge, the company would not budge on its intention to use that slip to claim the entire £247.

The initial conversation was conducted in Spanish and Avis believes that Mr Collinson may have misunderstood the agreement he was signing. However, so long as he was told that there was only a small charge, that signature and hence the entire contract was obtained by a misrepresentation. Avis could not force a customer to pay in these circumstances.

In a statement prepared by Avis's lawyers, the company says: "We cannot agree with the contention that there could be any misunderstanding as to the charges for the optional coverages. These charges are itemised on the front of the rental agreement signed by the customer, and the customer is required to initial a box against each of the itemised charges to confirm acceptance... we do not consider that there could be any misrepresentation as to the charges payable."

But what can Mr Collinson, or for that matter anybody, with a bill where the charge has been deducted from a credit card, do if they adamantly believe that the money has been taken unfairly?

The frequently overlooked Consumer Credit Act 1974 has the effect that so long as the transaction is over £100, the card company is in no stronger a position than the retailer where where is a misrepresentation or breach of contract. When Mr Collinson gets his next bill, he should write a polite but firm letter to the credit card company declining to pay the extra.

There is a tenuous argument that the misrepresentation releases him from all liability to the card company, even for the initially agreed amount.

When such a letter is received, most card companies will contact the retailer's bank asking for an explanation. If there is no reply within about two months, the charge is reclaimed from the retailer. In all probability Avis or the bank's bureaucracy will be defeated by this requirement and Mr Collinson will simply escape liability that way.

However, Avis in its statement says: "We do not believe that there are grounds for a claim of this kind. Presumably the terms of issue of the credit card to the consumer will determine whether he has a right to refuse payment of his credit card bill if such a claim did exist, and we are not therefore in a position to comment further on this aspect."

Even if Avis tried to persist with its claim, it would be uneconomic to prove in an English court what actually happened in Barcelona, and the bank would bear the loss. In practice they are most unlikely to take legal action over a small disputed debt.

Reporting Mr Collinson to a credit reference agency without making it clear the debt was disputed would be libellous.

Some banks claim that the Consumer Credit Act does not apply to transactions outside the UK, but as they have assiduously shied away from test cases on the point, the argument can safely be disregarded.

For transactions, British or foreign, the Act is a safeguard consumers are entitled to rely upon by refusing to pay disputed bills rather than waiting for banks to refuse to reimburse them.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

We reserve the right to make you pay - and keep on paying

Shocks on car hire bills can come months after the original hire, as Londoner Darren Dodd found after renting a car in February from Avis in Glasgow.

The car was scratched while it was parked and he was told he had to pay to repair this. Although it hadn't been made clear to him when hiring the car, the written agreement did suggest he was responsible for such damage. Reluctantly he paid £122, thinking that was the end of the matter.

However, without any warning last month Avis helped itself to another £400 from Mr Dodd's credit card. He was told the repair had proved more costly than expected.

Mr Dodd was told that Avis' standard terms entitled it to take further money, despite his liability being settled by the £122 payment.

This would seem to be a credit card bill crying out to be challenged. Avis sought to justify doubling the charge on the basis that Mr Collinson had been told that a "small sum" would be added for insurance and tax. But £127 is neither small, nor does it bear any resemblance to the real cost of insuring a small car for four days. When hiring the car, he had been required to sign an open credit card slip. Although he did protest to Avis here and in Spain about the charge, the company would not budge on its intention to use that slip to claim the entire £247. The initial conversation was conducted in Spanish and Avis believes that Mr Collinson may have misunderstood the agreement he was signing. However, so long as he was told that there was only a small charge, that signature and hence the entire contract was obtained by a misrepresentation. Avis could not force a customer to pay in these circumstances. In a statement prepared by Avis's lawyers, the company says: "We cannot agree with the contention that there could be any misunderstanding as to the charges for the optional coverages. These charges are itemised on the front of the rental agreement signed by the customer, and the customer is required to initial a box against each of the itemised charges to confirm acceptance... we do not consider that there could be any misrepresentation as to the charges payable." But what can Mr Collinson, or for that matter anybody, with a bill where the charge has been deducted from a credit card, do if they adamantly believe that the money has been taken unfairly? The frequently overlooked Consumer Credit Act 1974 has the effect that so long as the transaction is over £100, the card company is in no stronger a position than the retailer where where is a misrepresentation or breach of contract. When Mr Collinson gets his next bill, he should write a polite but firm letter to the credit card company declining to pay the extra. There is a tenuous argument that the misrepresentation releases him from all liability to the card company, even for the initially agreed amount. When such a letter is received, most card companies will contact the retailer's bank asking for an explanation. If there is no reply within about two months, the charge is reclaimed from the retailer. In all probability Avis or the bank's bureaucracy will be defeated by this requirement and Mr Collinson will simply escape liability that way. However, Avis in its statement says: "We do not believe that there are grounds for a claim of this kind. Presumably the terms of issue of the credit card to the consumer will determine whether he has a right to refuse payment of his credit card bill if such a claim did exist, and we are not therefore in a position to comment further on this aspect." Even if Avis tried to persist with its claim, it would be uneconomic to prove in an English court what actually happened in Barcelona, and the bank would bear the loss. In practice they are most unlikely to take legal action over a small disputed debt. Reporting Mr Collinson to a credit reference agency without making it clear the debt was disputed would be libellous. Some banks claim that the Consumer Credit Act does not apply to transactions outside the UK, but as they have assiduously shied away from test cases on the point, the argument can safely be disregarded. For transactions, British or foreign, the Act is a safeguard consumers are entitled to rely upon by refusing to pay disputed bills rather than waiting for banks to refuse to reimburse them.  Richard Colbey is a barrister We reserve the right to make you pay - and keep on paying Shocks on car hire bills can come months after the original hire, as Londoner Darren Dodd found after renting a car in February from Avis in Glasgow. The car was scratched while it was parked and he was told he had to pay to repair this. Although it hadn't been made clear to him when hiring the car, the written agreement did suggest he was responsible for such damage. Reluctantly he paid £122, thinking that was the end of the matter. However, without any warning last month Avis helped itself to another £400 from Mr Dodd's credit card. He was told the repair had proved more costly than expected. Mr Dodd was told that Avis' standard terms entitled it to take further money, despite his liability being settled by the £122 payment.

webTitle: The pleasure of flying with strings attached

fields.headline: The pleasure of flying with strings attached
fields.standfirst: As 15,000 people gather this weekend for the London Kite Festival Eileen Sheridan offers a handy guide to the thrills and spills
fields.trailText: As 15,000 people gather this weekend for the London Kite Festival Eileen Sheridan offers a handy guide to the thrills and spills
fields.body:
A decade ago kite flying became deeply trendy among metropolitan media types for its environmental friendliness. Opinion formers wrote endlessly about flying their kites on Parliament Hill Fields. Then they moved on to some other wholesome activity and left kite flying up in the air.

But the sport carried on regardless and now, thanks to space-age technology, has reached another dimension, of which more later. This weekend sees the seventh London Kite Festival at Hackney Marshes where an expected 15,000 enthusiasts and spectators will get the chance to see what variety kiting has to offer.

This is a pursuit for everyone, from child to grandparent. It can cost as little or as much as you like and involves manual dexterity and, sometimes, brute force. London Festival organiser Andy Phelps says: "Kiting is a unique combination of flight and art. You need a lot of skill to fly a kite properly."

If you have Blue Peter talents you can, of course, make your own kite for a few pounds but as the sport grows in popularity so do the choice and price range. The simplest are the single string variety. These are usually made of synthetic fabrics and are often used as art forms. Some are tiny but there will be giants measuring 50 feet or more at Hackney.

Two-stringed kites are where the action is at - "the Red Arrows on string" is how Andy Phelps describes them, and range in price from around £10 to £100.

The Highwaymen kite retailers, who have a website and mail order, sell items like a cube-shaped single-line kite at £14.50, a triad from Prism Kites at £22 or a Pop Kan kite from Goodwinds at £19.99. Their entry level section offers a diamond stunt kite at £10.99 and ranges up to a Phaser at £59.99. For people at the intermediate level there is the Poker from Kite Kitchen at £51.99 and a Reflex from Benson at £100.

Some of these kites come without strings, which you have to buy separately for up to £20. They are made either from nylon or polyester. The American version is Spectra and the European Dyneema.

Similarly, you have a choice in the material your kite is made of. Fibreglass is flexible and tough and will withstand crashes but needs more wind to fly. The alternative is carbon, which is stiffer and lighter.

Other accessories you are likely to need are wristbands starting at £9.99 and kite holdalls, from £19.99 to £39.99 from The Highwaymen. Other retail suppliers are Dunstable Kites, Tradewind Kites, Bristol Kitestore, Mullin Kites and the Kite Store, Covent Garden. Most have websites and do mail order.

Paul Thody of Airborn Kites has two stores, one in Brighton and one at Bluewater in Kent. "I lost a stone in weight when I started kite-flying," he says. "It's a good physical workout . In a force five wind a power kite will drag you across a field."

He is a big fan of two-stringed kites because they help a learner understand how to steer and manipulate a kite and make the most of air currents. "A single-line kite is more twitchy; two-line kites are actually easier to fly," he explains.

Cambridge-based company Flexifoil, which claims air supremacy since 1972, has a wide range of two-line kites starting with the Stacker 6 at £69.95.This is an entry-level kite which helps you through the basics. The Stacker has a 70-inch wingspan and has achieved speeds of 110mph. The best-selling power kite is Flexifoil's Super 10, which tests your muscles to the max at a cost of £129. 95. It is recommended only for fit people over 16.

The big development in kiting is a result of modern fabrics and the space-age kite-lines. Kiting has also moved into the realms of Action Man with kite-surfing and kite-buggying, where wind power is used for cutting edge sport. Kite-surfing, says Mr Thody, is going to get really big. If a force five wind can make a power kite drag a grown man across a field, traction kites are even more powerful. You will pay £149 for a Skytiger 18 from Flexifoil to £499 for a Blade 7.2.

These are four-line kites in Chikara rip-stop nylon. You buy the lines separately but they can cost up to £44.95 a pair. If you don't fancy being pulled across water by kite, you can do the same on land by kite-buggying. You can spend around £300 for a three-wheel buggy with a stainless steel frame and pneumatic tyres.

Like kite-surfing, kite-buggying has become a competition sport. Kite-surfing has its own organisation, the British Kite Surfing Association, which offers free safety guidelines, news updates, events and training dates, third-party liability insurance and other benefits.

At the fun end of kiting are dart-shaped sports kites, which are three dimensional and used for aerobatic displays. Flexifoil's range includes the Psycho and Erazor. Prices are £79.95 and £69.95.

London Kite Festival: www.netspaces.com/londonkitefestival. Kite Store, Covent Garden: 0207-836 -1666 Dunstable Kites: www.dunstable.kites.co.uk. Tradewind Kites: www.tradewindkites.co.uk. Bristol Kite Store: 0117-974-5010 Mullin Kites: www.mullinkites.co.uk. Airborn Kites: www.airbornkites.co.uk. Natural Heights (Kite Flying Tuition Holidays): www.naturalheights.co.uk/km. The Highwaymen: www.highwaymen.demon.co.uk.

webTitle: Get ahead with the spread on Euro 2000

fields.headline: Get ahead with the spread on Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Bookmakers boast that £100m will be staked on Euro 2000, by far the largest sum ever on a sporting event. While publicity hunger, rather than accuracy, prompts the size of this claim, it is certain that the tournament provides more chances for punters to add to bookies' profits than ever before.
fields.body:
Bookmakers boast that £100m will be staked on Euro 2000, by far the largest sum ever on a sporting event. While publicity hunger, rather than accuracy, prompts the size of this claim, it is certain that the tournament provides more chances for punters to add to bookies' profits than ever before.

Walking into a betting shop is still the most popular way to bet, and there will be no shortage of people putting their fivers on an England win. That somewhat unlikely outcome was originally being offered at 9/1 by Corals and only rose to 12/1 after the defeat by Portugal.

In fact, the 9% deduction bookies make from winnings, partly for betting levy but also as a crude device to bump up profits, means that the odds expressed as 9/1 are really 8/1. This price is influenced by sentiment as much as a realistic appraisal of England's chances.

The bias towards England should, in theory, be less prevalent on internet betting sites where there is a more internationally based clientele. Coral's internet arm, Eurobet, cut the pre-tournament price on Slovenia from 150/1 to 50/1 after a large number of bets were placed by punters in that country.

So far, though, even cyber-gamblers can't hope to get much better than 14/1 on England. Unsentimental punters could do worse than to put a few bob on Portugal, who, despite their obvious superiority and better prospects, are now being of fered at around the same price as England: 11/1 with Hills.

Account betting, by phone and internet, is gradually taking over from the traditional betting shop. Much the same odds are offered to those who trade this way, though some offer reduced "tax". Most, like Victor Chandler's Gibraltar operation, are set up so the company escapes tax altogether, leaving punters who find themselves facing any deduction with a justified grievance. Many companies are currently offering new accounts free bets. Among the most generous is the Tote's (0800-825-825) £20.

Spread betting is a better bet - literally - for punters. The range of markets, including bookings, time of goals, corners and even streakers, is much greater and profit margins lower. The spread firms don't attempt to pass taxes - real or invented - on to clients. Spreadex (08000-526575), the newest firm, offers one of the best ranges of markets. Among the most in triguing is the number of converted shoot-out penalties. While the 37 in the 1996 tournament may have been freakishly high, its quote of 15-17 looks a little on the low side. Buying at £5 per penalty at 17 would yield a £100 profit if the 1996 figure were repeated, with an £85 loss if there were no shoot-outs.

Punters determined to back England might find Spreadex's spread on the goals they score, 5.1-5.7, reasonable value.

Those who want to try spread betting might do well to contact Sporting Index (08000-96-96-45). It has a wide range of prices, including 54-56 on the number of times a stretcher comes on the pitch, and offers a free £200 bet on supremacy in any Euro 2000 game to those who opens an account in June.

However, for all the innovative markets and special offers, the message from the founders of new website playfair.com, launched with a great fanfare last week, is that bookies can be cut out altogether. Playfair members will be able to lay their own bets at any price on any event they choose.

Some might offer 20/1 on England winning Euro 96. For 5% of the winnings, Playfair will publicise the bet and hold the stake and even act as arbitrators.

Indeed, members will be able to bet on events such as the Queen Mother's birthday parade having to be cancelled, or Jonathan Aitken returning to gaol by the end of the year, which conventional bookmakers might regarded as being in rather too poor taste.

webTitle: Red tape as a way of life... tied oh-so-charmingly in a pretty bow

fields.headline: Red tape as a way of life... tied oh-so-charmingly in a pretty bow
fields.trailText: Curious about the state of Rome's wheezing economy and infamous bureaucracy? Undecided whether the natives are mind-blowingly rude or friendly? Impatient to test the stereotypes? Buy an ice cream.
fields.body:
Curious about the state of Rome's wheezing economy and infamous bureaucracy? Undecided whether the natives are mind-blowingly rude or friendly? Impatient to test the stereotypes? Buy an ice cream.

The Canova Bar at Piazza del Popolo is a tiled, air conditioned emporium of good taste. Waiters in white shirts and black waistcoats glide out to its terrace beneath silver platters of iced coffee, sundowners and almonds.

Inside there is not one customer to disturb the serenity, save me. Fourteen flavours of ice cream are on display. Attempts to intercept waiters are indignantly rebuffed. The scooping of ice cream is a specialised task way down the pecking order.

Eventually the specialist arrives. He fills the carton but refuses to give it to me. A colleague must now take over.

Together we wait. The cash register girl summons an older waiter, who deposits the carton on another counter. I try to pay but the girl's head shakes. I don't know the price, she smiles. Nor do I, let's ask the waiter, I say. He doesn't know either, she smiles, that's Lucia's job.

We wait for Lucia. The terrace has gone quiet so waiters drift inside and they wait with us. I start flicking through a magazine on a rack. Seconds later a small woman in a smock barrels from a storeroom. Stop smudging it, no reading until you buy, she hisses. Well I wouldn't have been reading except you kept me waiting, I reply, but she is gone.

Again we wait. Lucia returns after a few minutes. Melting ice cream trickles from the carton. She puts it on a weighing scale and scribbles a figure on a scrap of paper. I take this to the cash register girl, her smile broader now, and pay. She issues a receipt.

Lucia is now wrapping my dessert in red paper, festooned with ribbon and bow. Now I need your receipt, she says. I fumble and find it. A rip and she hands it back. Without it the police could arrest me for fraud and tax evasion within 200 metres of the cafe.

Emerging from the counter, Lucia hands over my prize. She shakes my hand, grins and wishes good health. It is her way of forgiving me for the magazine. All the staff bid farewell.

Infuriating, baffling and generous, such is Rome.

The state says it is busy trying to slash the red tape that strangles the economy and, according to a recent survey, is the single biggest deterrent to foreign investment.

Rules, procedures and systems that serve no purpose sprout everywhere: it is a cliche and very, very true.

Romans are supposed to be chaotic yet they submit to the endless queues and most social restrictions, probably because they created them.

They try to make up for it in many ways. They vow to reform, turn on the charm. Compensation comes in many guises, including red wrapping paper, ribbon and bow.

webTitle: Timer rejected by Libyans 'set at Lockerbie moment'

fields.headline: Timer rejected by Libyans 'set at Lockerbie moment'
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Swiss company alleged to have supplied the electronic trigger for the PanAm 103 bomb received an urgent order for timers from the Libyan army just a few weeks before the explosion, the Lockerbie trial heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The Swiss company alleged to have supplied the electronic trigger for the PanAm 103 bomb received an urgent order for timers from the Libyan army just a few weeks before the explosion, the Lockerbie trial heard yesterday.

Irwin Meister, one of two men who set up the Mebo electronics company in 1972, said the rush order was received in November 1988. By then the firm had been doing business with the Libyans for years, supplying communications equipment and 20 of its own-design MST-13 electronic timers.

But Mr Meister told the court that when the order for more timers came in before Christmas 1988, Mebo did not have the right materials to produce its own type in time.

Instead it bought Olympus timers for delivery to Libya by Mr Meister's business partner, Edwin Bollier.

The court heard that Mr Bollier brought the timers back to Zurich the night before the Lockerbie bombing because the Libyans had rejected them as unsuitable.

At the time they were left on a shelf. But then in January 1989, he looked at them again.

Mr Meister said: "Mr Bollier called me and said: 'Look what I've discovered'. He had one of the Olympus timers in his hand. He asked me to look at it - it was programmed for 7.30pm and the day of the week was a Wednesday."

The Lockerbie explosion occurred shortly after 7pm on Wednesday December 21 1988.

Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44, deny charges of murder, conspiracy and breaching an aviation security act.

The court has already heard that a tape recorder packed with Semtex attached to an MST-13 timer was placed in a suitcase on a Frankfurt-bound flight from Luqa airport, Malta.

From there it was put on PanAm Flight 103 to Heathrow, exploding on the plane's next leg, from Heathrow to New York, above Lockerbie.

Mr Meister, 62, had told Alan Turnbull QC, prosecuting, that Mebo first established commercial contacts with the Libyan army in about 1980.

He said it was not like doing business with army purchasing offices in the west. They were passed from one contact to another, and his contacts were sometimes in uniform and sometimes in civilian clothes.

Mr Meister named his contacts as Ezzadin Hinshiri and Said Rashid - both identified in the Lockerbie indictment as a link between Mebo and the two accused men.

On several occasions he met a man called Abdelbaset, one of the defendants. Mr Meister pointed him out and said that at one meeting there was a dispute between Mr Bollier and Mr Ezzadin about an unpaid invoice. "Mr Abdelbaset intervened and arranged for payment of the invoice."

Mr Meister said he got the impression that Mr Abdelbaset was "on the same level or higher than" Mr Ezzadin in the Libyan army hierarchy.

The Libyans were Mebo's biggest customer in the mid-1980s, but Mr Meister acknowledged that another key Mebo client was the Stasi, the former East German security police. He confirmed that the Stasi had been supplied with timers, radios, pagers modified to act as remote switches, lie detectors and miniature listening devices.

The hearing was adjourned until Monday.

Irwin Meister, one of two men who set up the Mebo electronics company in 1972, said the rush order was received in November 1988. By then the firm had been doing business with the Libyans for years, supplying communications equipment and 20 of its own-design MST-13 electronic timers. But Mr Meister told the court that when the order for more timers came in before Christmas 1988, Mebo did not have the right materials to produce its own type in time. Instead it bought Olympus timers for delivery to Libya by Mr Meister's business partner, Edwin Bollier. The court heard that Mr Bollier brought the timers back to Zurich the night before the Lockerbie bombing because the Libyans had rejected them as unsuitable. At the time they were left on a shelf. But then in January 1989, he looked at them again. Mr Meister said: "Mr Bollier called me and said: 'Look what I've discovered'. He had one of the Olympus timers in his hand. He asked me to look at it - it was programmed for 7.30pm and the day of the week was a Wednesday." The Lockerbie explosion occurred shortly after 7pm on Wednesday December 21 1988. Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44, deny charges of murder, conspiracy and breaching an aviation security act. The court has already heard that a tape recorder packed with Semtex attached to an MST-13 timer was placed in a suitcase on a Frankfurt-bound flight from Luqa airport, Malta. From there it was put on PanAm Flight 103 to Heathrow, exploding on the plane's next leg, from Heathrow to New York, above Lockerbie. Mr Meister, 62, had told Alan Turnbull QC, prosecuting, that Mebo first established commercial contacts with the Libyan army in about 1980. He said it was not like doing business with army purchasing offices in the west. They were passed from one contact to another, and his contacts were sometimes in uniform and sometimes in civilian clothes. Mr Meister named his contacts as Ezzadin Hinshiri and Said Rashid - both identified in the Lockerbie indictment as a link between Mebo and the two accused men. On several occasions he met a man called Abdelbaset, one of the defendants. Mr Meister pointed him out and said that at one meeting there was a dispute between Mr Bollier and Mr Ezzadin about an unpaid invoice. "Mr Abdelbaset intervened and arranged for payment of the invoice." Mr Meister said he got the impression that Mr Abdelbaset was "on the same level or higher than" Mr Ezzadin in the Libyan army hierarchy. The Libyans were Mebo's biggest customer in the mid-1980s, but Mr Meister acknowledged that another key Mebo client was the Stasi, the former East German security police. He confirmed that the Stasi had been supplied with timers, radios, pagers modified to act as remote switches, lie detectors and miniature listening devices. The hearing was adjourned until Monday.

fields.headline: Nagako, Dowager Empress of Japan
fields.standfirst: A last link to old Japan, she stood loyally by the emperor through 64 years of war and peace
fields.trailText: The Dowager Empress Nagako, who has died aged 97, lived through the greatest trauma that ever happened to Japan and to the Japanese imperial line. When she married Emperor Hirohito, he was the Son of Heaven, the 124th direct descendant of the Sun Goddess. When the imperial procession travelled the streets, shutters were closed and onlookers bowed their heads; no one was allowed to look on the imperial face.
fields.body:
The Dowager Empress Nagako, who has died aged 97, lived through the greatest trauma that ever happened to Japan and to the Japanese imperial line. When she married Emperor Hirohito, he was the Son of Heaven, the 124th direct descendant of the Sun Goddess. When the imperial procession travelled the streets, shutters were closed and onlookers bowed their heads; no one was allowed to look on the imperial face.

But after Japan's defeat in the second world war, the emperor was forced to renounce his divinity. As a mere mortal, he toured the country wearing an ill-fitting suit in the full gaze of his curious subjects. Throughout, Nagako remained the epitome of the ideal Japanese wife - a smiling silent presence, always in the background. Theirs was the longest imperial marriage in Japanese history, lasting almost 65 years.

Nagako was, nonetheless, a woman of strong character. As the eldest daughter, and third child, of Imperial Prince Kuniyoshi Kuni, she became the last Japanese empress to be chosen from the princely families which traditionally provided brides for the imperial line.

Counter to tradition, Hirohito was allowed to choose his own bride - though Nagako herself had no choice in the matter. At the age of 14, she was summoned to the imperial palace, where, along with other eligible young noble women, she took part in a tea ceremony - while Hirohito watched unseen through a peephole.

The then Japanese prime minister, who came from a rival clan, was horrified at the future emperor's choice, and set about plotting to make him change his mind, amidst claims that, on her mother's side, Nagako had colour-blind relatives. But Hirohito was adamant; Nagako was certainly not the most beautiful, but she was the one he wanted.

The betrothal was announced, and she left the Joshi Gakushin school to begin the six-year training in the accomplishments necessary for an empress. The couple were married with enormous pomp on January 26 1924 and, in 1926, Hirohito, who until then had been technically the regent, became emperor on the death of his father.

As empress, Nagako's prime responsibility was to produce a son and heir. No previous emperor had left this to chance. All, including Hirohito's father and grandfather, had had bevies of concubines. Hirohito, however, made the extraordinary decision to limit himself to his wife, and dismissed the 39 court concubines.

But after nearly 10 years of marriage, there was still no son, though Nagako had produced four daughters - one of whom died in infancy. Outside the palace gates, the country was becoming more and more unstable. Among the military, there was talk of overthrowing Hirohito and replacing him by his more aggressive brother, who had plenty of sons.

Courtiers pressed the emperor to bring back the concubines. They drew up lists of suitable young women and submitted photographs, while the court ladies took to wearing their finest dresses and perfumes. Hirohito remained unmoved. Then, in 1933, Nagako became pregnant again and, on December 23, gave birth to the present emperor, Akihito. There were celebrations throughout Japan. A second son followed.

During the second world war, Nagako took on the role of devoted mother to her people. Locked away in the imperial palace, she spent her time rolling bandages and knitting scarves for generals, or writing personal letters of condolence to bereaved families.

With the end of the war, the imperial house of Japan was thrust abruptly into the 20th century. Under the orders of the American occupation forces, Hirohito announced that he was no longer to be considered as divine. An American governess came to teach Crown Prince Akihito, and Nagako herself took English lessons.

Nagako was to be the last empress of noble blood. When Akihito chose to marry a commoner, Michiko Shoda, the daughter of a leading industrialist, the Japanese people were charmed. But Nagako disapproved and, according to rumours, made life in the palace difficult for the young crown princess.

Nagako spent her last years cloistered in the imperial palace. To older Japanese, she was a figure akin to the British Queen Mother - plump, warm-hearted, smiling and much loved. As she grew older, her health declined. She became wheelchair-bound, and was unable to attend the funeral of her husband in 1989. Rumour had it that she suffered from Alzheimer's disease.

While Hirohito's death in 1989 marked the end of an era, his widow represented the last link with the old Japan. Five years ago, she became the longest-living dowager empress, breaking the record of Empress Kanshi, who died 873 years ago. Nagako is survived by her elder son, the present emperor, three other children and 10 grandchildren.

webTitle: 'Giggly' Hague's debating style fails to impress women voters

fields.headline: 'Giggly' Hague's debating style fails to impress women voters
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's point-scoring at the Commons dispatch box is turning off women voters, who dismiss him as a "cheeky schoolboy" with a "giggly voice", according to new a study.
fields.body:
William Hague's point-scoring at the Commons dispatch box is turning off women voters, who dismiss him as a "cheeky schoolboy" with a "giggly voice", according to new a study.

Research on focus groups over the past fortnight shows that, far from being impressed by the Tory leader's forceful debating style, female floating voters see him as self-satisfied and uncaring about the concerns of real people.

The criticisms are bad news for the Conservatives, who lost their traditional hold on women voters at the 1997 general election after a push by Labour to close the long-established gender gap in its own support.

But there will be only small comfort for Labour in indications that the Tories are failing to win back women's support. The same research suggests that female voters are increasingly dissatisfied with the lack of perceptible improvements in health and education.

A Fabian pamphlet to be published tomorrow calls on Labour strategists to try harder to direct policy and style towards women, citing focus group evidence of a 13 percentage point "dissatisfaction gap" between men and women.

The research, by Deborah Mattinson, director of Opinion Leader Research and co-author of the pamphlet with the former social security secretary, Harriet Harman, indicates that women are frustrated at government pronouncements of "telephone number" public-sector spending figures when they have seen no real change in schools and hospitals.

Mr Hague, however, is a much bigger target of criticism than Tony Blair, according to the study. One floating voter dismissed him as "awful - out of touch, pompous - terrible".

Amid general criticism of the "jumping up and down, shouting and yelling" in the Commons, women say Mr Hague seems interested only in childish point-scoring, while the prime minister is seen as taking a more measured and consensual approach.

"I can't stand him [Hague]. He's just like a cheeky schoolboy - dead pleased with himself because he's pulled one over on the other side. It's pathetic," one woman observed.

"That giggly voice - he doesn't care about us or take us seriously," said another.

Conservative strategists, buoyed by opinion polls showing the gap between their party and Labour narrowing, dismiss suggestions that their leader is a liability

"We think William's robust approach, speaking out candidly on issues that affect ordinary people, is getting through, whatever Harriet Harman might say," said one.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Vale of Llangollen
fields.trailText: The steep flanks of the Vale of Llangollen were illuminated by the usual late May extravaganza of blooming hawthorn as we looked down from the limestone heights of Eglwyseg. Every small sheep pasture, each woody corner, was decked with white ribbons of blossom, underlined   with more brilliance where blooming cow parsley swayed in the breeze. May and early June is a white time. All the way along its course from Llyn Tegid, the Dee traverses country shining now in pale and pristine garb.
fields.body:
The steep flanks of the Vale of Llangollen were illuminated by the usual late May extravaganza of blooming hawthorn as we looked down from the limestone heights of Eglwyseg. Every small sheep pasture, each woody corner, was decked with white ribbons of blossom, underlined with more brilliance where blooming cow parsley swayed in the breeze. May and early June is a white time. All the way along its course from Llyn Tegid, the Dee traverses country shining now in pale and pristine garb.

We looked up the valley towards Corwen; green and packed, it seemed, with burgeoning nature and quite unchanged (when seen from our rocktop eyrie) since the days when George Borrow found the vale so attractive. The Pillar of Eliseg that still stands near the ruins of Valle Crucis Abbey was raised over the body of an ancient British chieftain in the 9th century. Borrow observed that these rocks and the pillar derived their names from association with this Cistercian establishment of Valle Crucis Abbey. As we walked northward along the crest of these pale crags the dark, heather-clad summit ridge of the crumpled country lay stretched out across the green valley to the west.

Here is old rock, rearing as the sombre backbones of the Maesyrychen and Llantysilio mountains, both rising somewhat higher than the crag-tops of Eglwyseg but not so high that we couldn't see beyond them towards the pale blue summits of Snowdonia proper. In certain conditions this westward view brings to mind the sentiments of Gerard Manley Hopkins when he gazed across the Vale of Clwyd into Denbighshire. He lists the natural glories - "woods, waters, meadows, vales" - and considers them the ingredients "that build this world of Wales".

By pressing on to the north along this limestone crest we come, eventually, to the area where plantations climb high on the wild slope. This is World's End, where the ghosts of the second Duke of Westminster's shooting parties linger in the heather expanse behind, up on to Ruabon mountain and away to the north again.

webTitle: Murdered girl was on council's at-risk register

fields.headline: Murdered girl was on council's at-risk register
fields.trailText: Laura Kane was on her local authority's child protection register when she was raped and murdered by a trusted family friend, Sunderland city council admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Laura Kane was on her local authority's child protection register when she was raped and murdered by a trusted family friend, Sunderland city council admitted yesterday.

The nine-year-old's six siblings - several of whom are also believed to have been on the register - are now all in care.

Last night the authority admitted that a multi-agency review of her death - standard practice after a child on the register dies - had identified failings in the system and "lessons to be learned".

But it could not pledge these lessons would be made public and stressed: "No procedure could have anticipated the brutal murder of a child by a family friend."

Laura, of Penshaw Village, on the outskirts of Sutherland, was raped and murdered in August last year by Colin Bainbridge, a 35-year-old handyman who was a close friend of her mother, Carol.

Newcastle crown court was told Bainbridge had gained the trust of Mrs Kane by doing repair work for her, and even took her for a drink hours after killing her daughter and burying her under the floorboards of his home in Murton, Co Durham.

He is to be sentenced on Monday after the trial judge said the case was one in which he would have to consider setting a recommendation of the time to be served before being considered for release.

Yesterday Laura's mother, who is separated from her husband, refused to discuss her daughter's "at-risk" status, claiming she was gagged after having spoken to a Sunday tabloid.

But a council spokesman said: "We can confirm that Laura Kane was on the child protection register and that the surviving siblings are in care. But we are not prepared to discuss confidential information about Laura or her siblings." An injunction, forbidding information about her siblings being published, was still in force, he added.

Following the youngster's murder, a "rigorous and comprehensive" review into whether she could have been better protected had been carried out by an independent expert from the Sunderland area child protection committee, a multi-agency body, the council spokesman said.

And he admitted: "The review does identify lessons to be learned and ways in which work to safeguard children can be improved. At the next meeting in July, the ACPC will give serious consideration to the next steps and to making public details of the review process and its recommendations - something which could not be done while criminal proceedings were in progress."

But he stressed that the decision to release such recommendations was purely at the body's discretion, and that it was unlikely to divulge specific details of Laura's case.

As Sunderland social services department pledged to "look very carefully at its own child protection practices", pressure mounted for the review findings to be made public.

"It is really quite difficult to know whether our social services department is fulfilling all its obligations," said Margaret Forbes, leader of the Tories on Sunderland city council.

She added: "I would like to have an inquiry on what went on. That is some way of establishing accountability."

And health campaigners questioned whether the local authority could have done more to safeguard the girl.

"Surely they should have been alerted to the fact that Laura apparently liked playing games where she was tied up?" asked Chris Close, of the charity Action in Mental Health. "That is abnormal behaviour which would have surely sent alarm bells ringing."

webTitle: Life forces to be rebalanced at holistic hospital

fields.headline: Life forces to be rebalanced at holistic hospital
fields.trailText: The first charitable Ayurvedic hospital outside of India and Sri Lanka will open in west London next month, offering free treatment for sick people wishing to try one of the oldest medical systems in the world.
fields.body:
The first charitable Ayurvedic hospital outside of India and Sri Lanka will open in west London next month, offering free treatment for sick people wishing to try one of the oldest medical systems in the world.

The 30-bed Ayurvedic charitable hospital will open on July 1 in temporary premises in Hammersmith before moving to its permanent residence in central London.

Ayurveda is an ancient Indian treatment system that has recently become fashionable. The hospital's backers hope to eschew this glamorous image and demonstrate that Ayurveda is a serious practice that can cure illnesses where conventional medicine fails.

A holistic system, involving meditation, diet, exercise, massage, and herbal cures, Ayurveda - the name is derived from the Sanskrit for knowledge of life - is offered in Britain by around 50 qualified practitioners who are monitored by the Ayurvedic Medical Association UK.

Fears have grown that charlatans will exploit the fact that the treatment is now in vogue - its healing effects have been espoused by Madonna, Cherie Blair, Naomi Campbell and others - and set up clinics and offer herbal products that falsely purport to be Ayurvedic.

The hospital's chairman, Gopi Warrier, had been concerned that Ayurveda's image could become spoiled. He said: "Ayurveda treatment is serious treatment to cure a serious ailment. Some of the therapies, such as enemas and blood-letting, could be dangerous in the wrong hands."

Ayurveda treats the patient and not the illness and aims to prevent disease and promote health. Ayurvedic philosophy believes that we are all composed of various combinations of five elements: space, air, fire water and earth and that there are three forces, vata, pitta and kapha through which these elements are manifested. In order to stay healthy, we must maintain the natural balance of all these elements.

People can be one of vata, pitta, or kapha or a combination of vata-pitta, pitta-kapha, vata-kapha. Vata types tend to be thin with dry, rough and dark skin. They speak quickly, sleep little, can be emotionally insecure and can have an unpredictable temper. Pitta types are usually of medium height and build with soft, fair skin. They speak clearly, are intelligent but often aggressively so, love to eat and tend to be emotionally intense. Kapha types are usually big-built, can tend to be overweight, they speak slowly and need a lot of sleep. They have a long memory but are slow to learn and they are very loving and emotionally secure.

Ayurvedic treatment helps to iron out imbalances of vata, pitta or dosha by a series of treatments that include laxatives, enemas, massages, saunas, oils being dripped on the forehead (particularly effective for those suffering from psychological problems), medication, meditation and yoga.

Mr Warrier, who believes that many are guilty of intellectual pilfering of Ayurvedic principles, explained: "We decided that we have to have a hospital because a lot of the treatment requires residential care. There has to be very rigorous restrictions on diet, temperature in rooms and to keep control of that it has to be in a hospital environment."

He added the hospital would be funded by a trust for the first six months. He and his two fellow trustees, David McAlpine and Lady Sarah Morritt then hope to raise funding from elsewhere.

"Ayurveda is not simply for celebrities. I am not interested in the transitory fame of celebrities. We are interested in people who have illnesses or problems," he added.

The hospital's chairman, Gopi Warrier, had been concerned that Ayurveda's image could become spoiled. He said: "Ayurveda treatment is serious treatment to cure a serious ailment. Some of the therapies, such as enemas and blood-letting, could be dangerous in the wrong hands." Ayurveda treats the patient and not the illness and aims to prevent disease and promote health. Ayurvedic philosophy believes that we are all composed of various combinations of five elements: space, air, fire water and earth and that there are three forces, vata, pitta and kapha through which these elements are manifested. In order to stay healthy, we must maintain the natural balance of all these elements. People can be one of vata, pitta, or kapha or a combination of vata-pitta, pitta-kapha, vata-kapha. Vata types tend to be thin with dry, rough and dark skin. They speak quickly, sleep little, can be emotionally insecure and can have an unpredictable temper. Pitta types are usually of medium height and build with soft, fair skin. They speak clearly, are intelligent but often aggressively so, love to eat and tend to be emotionally intense. Kapha types are usually big-built, can tend to be overweight, they speak slowly and need a lot of sleep. They have a long memory but are slow to learn and they are very loving and emotionally secure. Ayurvedic treatment helps to iron out imbalances of vata, pitta or dosha by a series of treatments that include laxatives, enemas, massages, saunas, oils being dripped on the forehead (particularly effective for those suffering from psychological problems), medication, meditation and yoga. Mr Warrier, who believes that many are guilty of intellectual pilfering of Ayurvedic principles, explained: "We decided that we have to have a hospital because a lot of the treatment requires residential care. There has to be very rigorous restrictions on diet, temperature in rooms and to keep control of that it has to be in a hospital environment." He added the hospital would be funded by a trust for the first six months. He and his two fellow trustees, David McAlpine and Lady Sarah Morritt then hope to raise funding from elsewhere. "Ayurveda is not simply for celebrities. I am not interested in the transitory fame of celebrities. We are interested in people who have illnesses or problems," he added.

fields.headline: Plying the mountains of youth
fields.standfirst: Scientists in Azerbaijan say rare herbs and clean living are increasing local life spans
fields.trailText: You can see for miles from the steep mountain meadow where Allahverdi Ibadov herds his small flock of sheep amid a sea of yellow, red and purple wild flowers. The view towards the Iranian border is spectacular, but Mr Ibadov barely gives it a second glance.
fields.byline: Chris Morris  in Amburdere, southern Azerbaijan
fields.body:
You can see for miles from the steep mountain meadow where Allahverdi Ibadov herds his small flock of sheep amid a sea of yellow, red and purple wild flowers. The view towards the Iranian border is spectacular, but Mr Ibadov barely gives it a second glance.

Why should he? He's been coming here nearly every day for 100 years.

According to his carefully preserved Soviet passport, Mr Ibadov, whose birth was only registered when he was a toddler, is at least 105 years old. His wife, who died two years ago, was even older. They are among the dozens of people in this beautiful, isolated region who live extraordinarily long lives.

A century of conflict and upheaval has made little lasting impression on the tough way of life in these mountains, but the memories of great events quickly come flooding back. "I remember the battles between the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks," Mr Ibadov said. "I was in my late 20s when the Russian revolution began. Eventually, the Tsar's supporters around here had to run for their lives."

Mr Ibadov married late in life and his eldest son has just turned 70. He lost count long ago of the number of grandchildren he has. "I'm an old man now," he cackles. "I look after the sheep and I prepare the wood for winter. I still have something to do."

A lifetime of unforgiving toil, it seems, takes only a very few people to an early grave in this region.

During Soviet rule, Shirali Muslimov, a man from a nearby village, was said to have lived to the very ripe old age of 168. He was made a hero of the Soviet Union, although doctors insist that his achievement had more to do with propaganda than with fact. No one, the experts say, can live that long.

The woman officially recognised as the oldest human being, Jeanne Calment, died in France in 1997 at the age of 122. But doctors admit that there appears to be something in the Azerbaijani mountains which gives local people a longer, healthier life than most.

Miri Ismailov's family in the tiny village of Tatoni are convinced that they know what it is. Mr Ismailov is 110, his great-great-grandson is four year old. Across the generations they share one proud boast - neither of them has been to a doctor. "There are hundreds of herbs on the mountains, and we use them all in our cooking and for medicines," explained Mr Ismailov's daughter, Elmira. "We know exactly what they can do. We are our own doctors."

There is, for example, one herb for high blood pressure, another for kidney stones and a third for a hacking cough. They are carefully collected from the steep, green slopes that surround the village.

Experts from the Azerbaijan Academy of Science believe the herbs may indeed provide part of the answer. They have been studying longevity in this region for years. It began as a rare joint Soviet-American project in the 1980s, but most of the funds have long since dried up.

In tests on animals, Azeri scientists have isolated a type of saffron unique to the southern mountains as one plant which seems to increase longevity. Another plant, made into a paste, dramatically increases the amount of milk animals are able to produce.

"Now we have to examine these plants clinically to find out which substances have this effect," said Chingiz Gassimov of the academy.

The theory that local people have also developed a genetic predisposition to long life has been strengthened, the scientists say, by their study of a group of Russian emigres, whose ancestors were exiled to the Caucasus 200 years ago. The Russians' life span is much shorter than the indigenous mountain folk, but it's appreciably longer than that of their ancestors left behind in the Russian heartland.

"Over the decades, I believe the local conditions have begun to have a positive effect on the new arrivals," professor Gassimov explained. "It's been slowly transferred down the generations."

In an age when many people in the west are turning to alternative medicines and therapies, it is an intriguing prospect. But Mr Ismailov, his hand gripping a stout wooden cane, has been around too long to get over-excited.

"There's no secret," he shrugged dismissively. "I pray, I look after the cattle and I eat well. Life goes on."

webTitle: 240 arrested as US targets heroin ring

fields.headline: 240 arrested as US targets heroin ring
fields.trailText: United States officials were elated yesterday after more than 240 alleged members of a Mexico-based heroin smuggling network were arrested in two days of intensive raids by federal agents in 22 US cities.
fields.body:
United States officials were elated yesterday after more than 240 alleged members of a Mexico-based heroin smuggling network were arrested in two days of intensive raids by federal agents in 22 US cities.

Seventy arrests were made on Wednesday, followed by at least 176 more on Thursday, as the nationwide operation continued deep into the night. Agents searched more than 60 locations as part of the offensive, and seized more than 29kg (64lb) of unusually pure heroin, said to be worth up to $1,500 (£990) an ounce.

"We dismantled them from top to bottom - from their smuggling operation, to their distribution sales and all the way down to their street-level dealers in many American neighbourhoods," claimed Donnie Marshall, an administrator for the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA).

The raids - codenamed "Operation Tar Pit" - were targeted on the Nayarit drug trafficking organisation, named after the area of Mexico in which the opium - from which heroin is processed - was cultivated. Officials believe that the ring was distributing more than 36kg (80lb) of heroin each month - worth around $7m (£4.6m) - through its US network, said Joe Keefe of the DEA.

The Nayarit ring specialised in the production of an unprecedentedly pure form of the illegal drug, known as Mexican black-tar heroin. The ring undercut more expensive Colombian variants of the drug and gained a major share of the heroin market in several US cities, ranging from Honolulu to Atlanta. Nayarit heroin was marketed at $800 to $1,000 (£530-£660) less an ounce than the heroin marketed by Colombian dealers, officials estimated.

The Narayit ring became the focus of investigators' attention following a sharp upsurge in heroin overdoses in New Mexico and other parts of the south-western US, an indication that users were underestimating the potency of the drug they had bought.

The ring smuggled heroin across the Mexico-US border concealed in the dashboards and fuel tanks of cars, officials said. Their main distribution centre was in Los Angeles, from where couriers - and even overnight delivery parcel companies - took it to the cities in which the ring had established its foothold.

Among those arrested in the swoops this week was Issas Hernandez-Garcia, one of the two main alleged leaders of the group. Mr Hernandez-Garcia was arrested by Mexican agents near his home at Tepic, along with his wife Marina, and is expected to be the target of extradition proceedings by the US. The other alleged leader, Angel Hernandez-Ibarra, remains at large.

webTitle: M25 verdicts still safe, appeal court hears

fields.headline: M25 verdicts still safe, appeal court hears
fields.trailText: A breach of the European human rights convention should not lead to any presumption of an unsafe verdict, the court of appeal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A breach of the European human rights convention should not lead to any presumption of an unsafe verdict, the court of appeal heard yesterday.

David Perry, for the crown, was opposing an argument on behalf of Michael Davis, Randolph Johnson and Raphael Rowe - convicted of a murder and a series of robberies around the M25 - that a decision of the European court of human rights in February had delivered a "knockout" blow to their convictions.

The court held that the appellants' trial had violated article six of the convention as the prosecution had used public interest immunity certificates to deny them evidence.

Patrick O'Connor, for Rowe, has told Lord Justice Mantell, Mr Justice Blofeld and Mrs Justice Rafferty that "in such a case the impact of the violation is that there must be a strong presumption at least that the conviction is unsafe".

The three men have had their case referred back to the court of appeal by the criminal cases review commission. They were jailed for life in 1990 for a series of attacks in December 1988, including the murder of hairdresser Peter Hurburgh.

The case was based on the evidence of three suspects who turned prosecution witnesses and the three - all black - argue that four of the six victims referred to at least one of the offenders being white.

The case continues.

fields.trailText:

Two more members of the Falun Gong sect, which China is desperate to crush, have died in custody in Beijing in recent weeks, bring ing to 21 the deaths since China banned the movement last July, a Hong Kong group said yesterday.
fields.body:
Beijing deaths
Two more members of the Falun Gong sect, which China is desperate to crush, have died in custody in Beijing in recent weeks, bring ing to 21 the deaths since China banned the movement last July, a Hong Kong group said yesterday.

The Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy named the two as Wang Xiuying, a hunger striker who died on May 22, and Tian Shiqiang.

Verdict on mob

A Turkish court yesterday sentenced 33 militants to death for their role in Islamist rioting and burning in 1993 in which 37 people - many from a moderate Muslim minority - were killed in the central town of Sivas. Turkey retains the death penalty but has not executed a convict since the mid-80s.

Empress dies

The dowager empress Nagako, widow of Japan's late emperor Hirohito, died yesterday aged 97, officials finally confirmed after persistent news reports.

fields.headline: Shipman 'honed killer skills' in 1970s
fields.standfirst:
MP wants inquiry into deaths in Yorkshire practice
Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman, the GP convicted of murdering 15 patients, "honed his skills" as a killer in a Yorkshire town, a Labour MP claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman, the GP convicted of murdering 15 patients, "honed his skills" as a killer in a Yorkshire town, a Labour MP claimed yesterday.

Chris McCafferty, MP for Calder Valley, is calling for a public inquiry into Shipman's activities in Todmorden, West Yorkshire, almost 25 years ago.

An investigation has revealed that despite his inexperience he signed 22 death certificates, considerably more than his colleagues in a group practice, over a 16-month period.

Ms McCafferty said there were 30 to 40 more deaths than usual when Shipman was there. When he left, the death rate dropped again.

"I believe he was honing his skills in killing in Todmorden," she said. "I am greatly concerned by the implications of these figures.

"There is no doubt that Shipman was and remains an evil man. He could end the uncertainty of countless relatives by making a full confession, but it is apparent that he will not do this.

"Under these circumstances, we may never know the full extent of his actions, but it is important that every lead is investigated."

She is writing to Jack Straw, the home secretary, and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, calling for further investigations into the higher death rate at Todmorden.

She also wants the Laming inquiry to be held in public. The inquiry was set up under the chairmanship of Lord Laming, after Shipman was convicted in January, to examine the case and the issues thrown up by it.

"A thorough and open investigation is needed to seek to establish what happened while he was was working in Todmorden," said Ms McCafferty. "This can be best achieved by making all the existing information available to the Laming inquiry."

During his time in Todmorden Shipman was addicted to pethidine and had to be driven around by his wife, Primrose, because he suffered from blackouts.

A former patient, Elaine Oswald, nearly died after he gave her an opiate-based drug in 1974 when he was supposed to be taking a blood sample.

Mrs Oswald, now a professor at Tennessee University in the US, said Shipman told her that she had had an allergic reaction to a painkiller.

Shipman, 54, was given 15 life sentences in January for the murders of women patients in Hyde, Greater Manchester.

Police said that his final death toll might be as high as 192 patients.

The relatives of some of his victims will seek a judicial review on Monday of the decision to hold the inquiry in private.

Lord Laming is expected to report to Mr Milburn by the autumn.

webTitle: Long-running battle of the Scottish titans

fields.headline: Long-running battle of the Scottish titans
fields.trailText: It has been described as one of the greatest feuds in British politics, rivalling the 30-year tiff between Lady Thatcher and Sir Edward Heath. Gordon Brown and Robin Cook, who are at the centre of the cabinet split over the euro, have barely been on speaking terms since they fell out in the early 1980s.
fields.body:
It has been described as one of the greatest feuds in British politics, rivalling the 30-year tiff between Lady Thatcher and Sir Edward Heath. Gordon Brown and Robin Cook, who are at the centre of the cabinet split over the euro, have barely been on speaking terms since they fell out in the early 1980s.

The mutual hatred is so deep that their camps are divided as to exactly when the two titans of Scottish Labour politics fell out.

The Brown camp points to an awkward meal at a Chinese restaurant in Soho in 1982. Mr Brown, not yet an MP, had travelled to London to ask Mr Cook, a rising star at Westminster, for support in his campaign to become chairman of the Labour party in Scotland.

Mr Brown was incensed when Mr Cook rebuffed him, saying: "I am sure you will do very well."

Mr Cook's friends do not recall the Soho meal, but they admit that relations were strained by 1983, the year of Mr Brown's election as an MP, when Mr Cook snubbed him at the launch of an updated edition of Mr Brown's book, The Red Paper on Scotland, to which Mr Cook was a contributor.

The publisher, Bill Campbell, recalls the event. Mr Cook turned up first. "He breezed in and started saying: 'We might as well just start.' When Gordon got there, it felt as if Robin had hijacked the show."

All sides agree that Mr Cook has been jealous of his rival, his junior by five years, since the early 1980s, when Mr Brown started to outshine him in Scotland and Westminster. Until the 1997 election Mr Cook regarded himself as leader of the Labour left and has never forgiven the chancellor for snatching the Treasury.

A public reconciliation last year, when the chancellor was guest of honour at a dinner to mark Mr Cook's 25th anniversary as an MP, did not heal the rift.

webTitle: Hampden Park cleared to stage Tyson fight

fields.headline: Hampden Park cleared to stage Tyson fight
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: Boxer Mike Tyson's controversial fight in Britain cleared its final hurdle yesterday after the venue for the bout was granted a safety certificate.
fields.body:
Boxer Mike Tyson's controversial fight in Britain cleared its final hurdle yesterday after the venue for the bout was granted a safety certificate.

After fending off a legal challenge from anti-rape campaigners, speculation about his mental health and the fatal shooting of a close friend, Tyson will arrive in Britain on Sunday evening in the knowledge that the fight against Lou Savarese in Glasgow the following Saturday will go ahead.

A Glasgow city council licensing sub-committee yesterday took 50 minutes to decide to approve an application by Hampden Park stadium for a special safety certificate to stage the event.

The decision was greeted with boos from about 25 protesters who attended the meeting.

During the discussions it emerged that promoters had reduced the stadium capacity for the fight to 51,800 after failing to sell all 60,000 tickets.

The stadium safety director, Tom Onions, confirmed that the seating would be cut back.

The application was granted by a vote of 10 to one, with Scottish National Party councillor John Mason the only dissenter.

fields.trailText:
Now it's cool to be a geek
Computer geeks are now the coolest kids in class, according to a new survey. The NOP poll found that the internet had transformed views of computer-mad teens. Once labelled geeks, they are now seen as "friendly and fun". The survey also revealed that the number of 7-16 year olds using the internet has doubled in 18 months, reaching 4m this month.
