fields.headline: As real as it gets
fields.standfirst: If you think white men can't sing the blues, you can't have heard the North Mississippi All Stars.
fields.trailText: If you think white men can't sing the blues, you can't have heard the North Mississippi All Stars
fields.body:
The North Mississippi All Stars' titanic bass player, Chris Chew, appears to be troubled by an object hanging high around his neck - a cumbersome badge or pendant. You study him, onstage at London's Borderline, for a moment or two, wondering why he doesn't stop fiddling with it and cast it aside, then it dawns on you that his lower torso is bereft of an instrument, yet there are bass sounds emanating from his general area. The object in question is actually his guitar.

You might say that Chew - a 6ft 7in, 300lb-plus part-time truck driver and gospel singer - is the North Mississippi All Stars' token authentic blues component there to counter potential cries of "faker" directed at the somewhat goofy singing white brothers, Luther and Cody Dickinson, who are the band's creative core. You might say that, but only if you'd looked at the band without hearing the intensity of Luther's vocals, the proficiency of his open-tuned, bottleneck guitar manipulation, the vengeful thunder of Cody's drumming.

Of all current postmodern bluesmen, the North Mississippi All Stars sound the least gimmicky. This isn't blues for indie noise terrorists (Jon Spencer) or students (Gomez). Their only equal for deep-rooted authenticity is Alvin Youngblood-Hart. The effect is astonishing: not just "Look how good those skinny white kids are at pretending to be black!" but "I can't believe they're not black!" It is Luther's pasty student looks that seem incongruous, not the lascivious grunts emanate from his microphone and guitar. Shut your eyes on Shake 'Em on Down and it's the Allman Brothers produced by Kool and the Gang, or Fred McDowell and Jimmy Castor gatecrashing Hendrix's Band of Gypsys.

The songs, from the forthcoming Shake Hands With Shorty debut album, would work well as a protest package about supermodel body fascism: hardly a sliding, steaming, silty riff goes by without a groin-felt plea for a "big woman". The three of them communicate wordlessly, exchanging a series of lusty grins, erectile eyebrows and Neanderthal grimaces. Unlike Gomez, the North Mississippi All Stars aren't shaking up the blues by projecting their life experiences on to the intrinsic sounds of poor, southern, post-Depression America. Or perhaps they are. Perhaps their life experiences are "sitting on a hollow log" (Drinking Muddy Water) and lazing around on porches, drooling at chunky women. Whatever the case, they sound so hardcore, so nasty, you're forced to believe them.

The story goes that Luther's first word was "studio". His (and Cody's) dad is the legendary deep south producer Jim Dickinson (Lucinda Williams, Big Star), and the All Stars are a new kind of sprog-rock - less self-conscious than the plague of pop spawn that occurred a couple of years back, and more effective. The saga of your upbringing, in this case, is not so intimidating as to put pressure on you to live up to the family name, yet rich and eclectic enough to ensure that music pumps through you like second blood.

fields.headline: Swiss roll
fields.standfirst: How do you sell dance when there's so much competition? Luxury works for the Kirov - but Zurich Ballet is gambling on giant rubber balls.  Judith Mackrell judges the results
fields.trailText: How do you sell dance when there's so much competition? Luxury works for the Kirov - but Zurich Ballet is gambling on giant rubber balls. Judith Mackrell judges the results
fields.body:
The summer has unofficially become London's ballet season, which means that we are currently watching the Kirov and Zurich Ballet vying for the dance pound alongside the resident claims of English National Ballet and the Royal. The programmes being danced by these four companies are of course a pot-luck assortment. But looked at overall, they present an interesting Polaroid of the state of ballet today.

One thing they tell us for sure is that the 19th-century classics have lost none of their appeal. ENB is currently hoping to net over 50,000 viewers for its spectacle-driven version of Sleeping Beauty in the Royal Albert Hall; the Kirov at Covent Garden is presenting the same ballet alongside other familiar classics. The strategy behind ENB's mass-scale Beauty is unabashed populism: the company has beefed up the ballet's glitz and sex appeal and is counting on the familiar Tchaikovsky score to lure the punters. Meanwhile the Kirov, which has lost much of its generous state subsidy, is fighting to build a mass audience with a staging driven by scholarship. Its four-hour Sleeping Beauty reconstructs the original 1890 production, complete with elaborate mime, processionals and historic costumes. The production sounds like only a balletomane's idea of fun, but the rapturous response with which it has been greeted suggests the public likes the real thing as much as the lite version.

But companies also need new works on which to stake their futures - even though the cost of making them has spiralled scarily and the box office gamble has become more intense. The Royal Ballet is thus lucky to have the new, small scale facilities of the Opera House's Linbury Theatre, where it can stage programmes of new works. This quasi-laboratory situation is a rare luxury, allowing choreographers to play outside of the pressured environment of the Opera House, and hopefully attract a more adventurous public than the traditionally conservative ballet crowd. The classics of the future may well come from here.

Zurich Ballet, under the rejuvenating direction of Heinz Spoerli, already performs a largely contemporary repertory - but it does so in part by maintaining a canny element of name recognition. The title of its London debut production Mozartina says it all: if there's any composer other than Tchaikovsky to snare the public, it's Mozart.

Spoerli's ballet is a kind of encounter between Mozart, his music and the 20th century. There isn't a narrative as such, although at its heart is a Mozartian figure (Michael Revie), who moves through the dancers with a quizzical detachment and an assortment of gimmicks, and may be supposed to offer an oblique comment on history. The dancers regularly change from 18th to 20th-century costumes and at one point Revie looks appropriately startled as huge rubber balls bounce around the stage with images of Mozart's face stamped on them. Frequently, a moving walkway delivers the dancers on and off the stage. Grinning and posing, they look like prizes displayed in a TV game show.

These are irritating distractions from Spoerli's choreography, which has some appealing features. His characteristic lines are lean, stretched and disciplined, yet they are punctuated by moments of unpredictable abandon when dancers skid joyfully on their own momentum and reinvent classical lifts with an acrobatic flourish. The choreography looks particularly good on Revie, who, with his clever, secretive face and dynamic intensity, is a figure of considerable charisma.

The ballet is, however, two hours long, and its length exposes its weaknesses cruelly. Spoerli may create interesting individual moves but they do little other than skim over the surface of the medley of Mozart's scores. There is no counter-argument in the dance's structure that would allow us to hear the music freshly, nor is there any emotional engagement with it. The steps just keep coming, regardless of what is being played.

Mozartina may flourish its lack of sentiment and clutter like a badge of modernity, but the fact that many of its devices are raided from ballets which were voguish a generation ago makes it look, actually, rather old-fashioned. It certainly doesn't look as if Spoerli created it because he had something urgent to say about the music or the subject. And without that urgency, an art form can never be renewed.

 English National Ballet's Sleeping Beauty is at the Royal Albert Hall, London SW7 (020-7589 8212), till Tuesday. The Kirov's Sleeping Beauty is in rep at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), till August 10.

fields.headline: Only here for the beard
fields.standfirst: He looks like Frank Dobson and sounds like he's been pickled in booze. John Martyn is one of a kind, says  Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: He looks like Frank Dobson and sounds like he's been pickled in booze. John Martyn is one of a kind, says Adam Sweeting
fields.body:
Stomping about the stage of the Shepherd's Bush Empire, muttering incomprehensible asides to his band, John Martyn sometimes resembles an amiable nutter basking in the glow of a gallon of Guinness. From other angles, when the lights change colour, he labours under the burden of being the first rock'n'roller ever to resemble Frank Dobson. It is only when he steps to the microphone that you start wondering whether Martyn is a misunderstood genius or merely a musical eccentric who offers flashes of brilliance.

On this showing, I'd incline towards the former. You can tell a lot about a performer from the company he keeps, and years could pass before you stumbled across a band as good as Martyn's. It is not easy to make his easy-riding pieces sound unhurried while retaining their coherence, but this lot did it effortlessly. Drummer Arran Ahmun turned the temperature up and then lowered it again so intuitively that you noticed the effect, but not how it was done. But to single him out would be to belittle the contributions of Spencer Cozens on keyboards, or John Giblin's rubbery gymnastics on the bass, or Jim Lampi's skittering forays up the neck of his mysterious Chapman stick.

Most of the band also appear on Martyn's recent album, Glasgow Walker. It is an evocative collection, but somehow it doesn't compare to their sound on stage. It's as if freezing the songs on disc reduces them to a sample of the real thing. The hints of trip-hop that now underpin Martyn's recorded sound may indicate a willingess to embrace pop's relentless forward motion, but they're too circumscribing for his music.

The difference was evident in the band's performance of So Sweet. On disc, it's a nifty little slice of ambient pop, ticking along over Ahmun's imperturbable beat while Martyn doesn't so much sing the words as allow them to escape gently from his throat. On stage, the song suddenly became fleshed out and three-dimensional, Martyn swapping guitar lines with Lampi and treating the lyric as a starting point for vocal experimentation instead of a fixed and unchangeable text.

Which merely means that Martyn is more inclined to approach his music in a spirit of jazz-like exploration, than as an exercise in pop craft. His musicians understand him perfectly, and frequently stretched out into instrumental passages which, for all their freedom, never damaged the collective fabric. Sometimes there were echoes of the shimmering spaciousness of In a Silent Way, elsewhere hints of reggae or snapping funk syncopations.

Meanwhile, Martyn continued to test the possibilities of his idiosyncratic vocal technique. In Rock Salt and Nails, he rasped and roared like a whisky-soaked gold prospector. He turned Cry Me a River into an echoing void of loss, while Sweet Little Mystery was all the more affecting for the way he kept it dangling just out of reach. "There's a place between words and music, and my voice lives right there," is how Martyn explains it. Who could express it any better?

 John Martyn is on tour till June 29, including June 24 at Glastonbury.

Who could express it any better?  John Martyn is on tour till June 29, including June 24 at Glastonbury.

fields.headline: Desert island risks
fields.trailText: Rough Science | Real Gardens
fields.body:
Primo Levi, writer, chemist and Auschwitz survivor, once tried to synthesise high-price lipstick from low-price sources. No problem. You want that Hollywood gloss, you want to make alloxan, so you start with uric acid. And which products are rich in uric acid? Chicken shit and reptile excrement. So, if you must, head for the nearest hen-house, or the zoo.

New science is always rough science, improvised with materials nearest to hand. Last night, on a Mediterranean island populated only by a television crew and a suite of rueful boffins, Rough Science (BBC2) took the raw materials and improvised some old science.

Presenter Kate Humble demanded a banquet, followed by toothpaste, soap and record player. She got the first from seaweed with a crab on the side, she got the second from seaweed and a squeeze of mint, she got the third from olive oil and ashen water, and she got the fourth from a few bits of wood, a rope and a plastic cup.

She paid for them handsomely in a coin all of her own: the cliché. Vanessa wasn't just a marine biologist, she was an "intrepid marine biologist." Jonathan was "in thinking mode, brainstorming ideas for our record player". Jonathan brainstormed. "I think you have to be quite naive really," he said. "You mustn't worry about whether the ideas are right or wrong. You just put as many ideas as you can down."

Mike ("our chemistry wizard") got as many ideas down as he could, too: he tried conjuring up sodium hydroxide by the electrolysis of seawater (the carbon cathodes were two pencils) but the makeshift generator collapsed in the wind. "It's no use crying over a spilled windmill," said Kate helpfully. He tried getting lime from baked shells, but the aluminium saucepan melted before the shells did. "Proof that even scientists get it wrong sometimes," said Kate. He tried mixing water soaked with wood ash (it turns into potassium hydroxide) and oil from pulped olives, but it took a while and if soap happened, it didn't work up to much of a lather.

Anna the ethnobotanist pounded seashells to make her toothpaste suitably abrasive. "I took the big bits out because I think they might be a little bit too abrasive," said Anna moodily. "Abrasive is one thing and pulling your gums off is another."

The improvised rod and reel looked great but caught nothing. The longbow fired but the arrow got lost. The improvised lobster pot remained stubbornly empty. The banquet was elegantly presented, and ideal for people on a diet, involving a tiny crab in nettle soup, an even tinier fish, seaweed jelly with tree strawberries, crispy-fried seaweed, myrtle berries to provide spice, and pine nuts as appetisers.

The gravity-powered turntable turned at a steady speed, but you'd have needed good ears to pick up much of the tune from a needle stuck in a plastic cup. The rough scientists encouraged each other. "You can hear it!" cried Kate Humble. "That is brilliant!" said one of the scientists. "But will we really want to listen to that during our meal?" continued Kate.

The science was rough, but instructive, if you felt like being instructed. Not everybody did. "This is the maddest thing I have ever been involved in," said one of the team, gloomily. "I don't know how I got talked into doing this."

Meanwhile, in Real Gardens (Channel 4) Ann-Marie Powell struggled to plant a huge trunk of Dicksonia antarctica from Australia in an Islington garden, already stuffed with palm trees from Guadeloupe and Portugal. Monty Don deadheaded roses. Carol Klein used rough science to conjure up a whiff of the Med on a Devon slope.

Scrape away all that well-rotted horse manure, she advised, and dig in some builder's rubble instead. It's the heat and the dry, impoverished soil that makes an aromatic Mediterranean herb explode and fill a patio with perfume. Heat and dust are converted by a chemical plant - a little green factory - into the smell of heaven. "Matter is matter, neither noble nor vile, infinitely transformable, and its proximate origin is of no importance whatsoever," wrote Primo Levi in The Periodic Table.

But he failed to make kiss-proof lipstick from python poo. And what alchemy is it that can take chickenshit ideas and turn them into watchable television?

webTitle: Are you now or were you ever... ?

fields.headline: Are you now or were you ever... ?
fields.standfirst:
The McCarthy era's anti-communist trials destroyed lives and friendships. Arthur Miller describes the paranoia that swept America - and the moment his then wife Marilyn Monroe became a bargaining chip in his own prosecution

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The McCarthy era's anti-communist trials destroyed lives and friendships. Arthur Miller describes the paranoia that swept America - and the moment his then wife Marilyn Monroe became a bargaining chip in his own prosecution
fields.body:
It would probably never have occurred to me to write a play about the Salem witch trials of 1692 had I not seen some astonishing correspondences with that calamity in the America of the late 40s and early 50s. My basic need was to respond to a phenomenon which, with only small exaggeration, one could say paralysed a whole generation and in a short time dried up the habits of trust and toleration in public discourse.

I refer to the anti-communist rage that threatened to reach hysterical proportions and sometimes did. I can't remember anyone calling it an ideological war, but I think now that that is what it amounted to. I suppose we rapidly passed over anything like a discussion or debate, and into something quite different, a hunt not just for subversive people, but for ideas and even a suspect language. The object was to destroy the least credibility of any and all ideas associated with socialism and communism, whose proponents were assumed to be either knowing or unwitting agents of Soviet subversion.

An ideological war is like guerrilla war, since the enemy is an idea whose proponents are not in uniform but are disguised as ordinary citizens, a situation that can scare a lot of people to death. To call the atmosphere paranoid is not to say that there was nothing real in the American-Soviet stand-off. But if there was one element that lent the conflict a tone of the inauthentic and the invented, it was the swiftness with which all values were forced in months to reverse themselves.

Death of a Salesman opened in February 1949 and was hailed by nearly every newspaper and magazine. Several movie studios wanted it and finally Columbia Pictures bought it, and engaged a great actor, Frederick March, to play Willy [the central character].

In two years or less, with the picture finished, I was asked by a terrified Columbia to sign an anti-communist declaration to ward off picket lines which the rightwing American Legion was threatening to throw across the entrances of theatres showing the film. In the phone calls that followed, the air of panic was heavy. It was the first intimation of what would soon follow. I declined to make any such statement, which I found demeaning; what right had any organisation to demand anyone's pledge of loyalty? I was sure the whole thing would soon go away; it was just too outrageous.

But instead of the problem disappearing, the studio actually made another film, a short to be shown with Salesman. This was called The Life of a Salesman and consisted of several lectures by City College School of Business professors - which boiled down to selling was a joy, one of the most gratifying and useful professions, and that Willy was simply a nut. Never in show-business history has a studio spent so much good money to prove that its feature film was pointless. In less than two years Death of a Salesman had gone from being a masterpiece to being a heresy, and a fraudulent one at that.

In 1948-51, I had the sensation of being trapped inside a perverse work of art, one of those Escher constructs in which it is impossible to make out whether a stairway is going up or down. Practically everyone I knew stood within the conventions of the political left of centre; one or two were Communist party members, some were fellow-travellers, and most had had a brush with Marxist ideas or organisations. I have never been able to believe in the reality of these people being actual or putative traitors any more than I could be, yet others like them were being fired from teaching or jobs in government or large corporations. The surreality of it all never left me. We were living in an art form, a metaphor that had suddenly, incredibly, gripped the country.

In today's terms, the country had been delivered into the hands of the radical right, a ministry of free-floating apprehension toward anything that never happens in the middle of Missouri. It is always with us, this anxiety, sometimes directed towards foreigners, Jews, Catholics, fluoridated water, aliens in space, masturbation, homosexuality, or the Internal Revenue Department. But in the 50s any of these could be validated as real threats by rolling out a map of China. And if this seems crazy now, it seemed just as crazy then, but openly doubting it could cost you.

So in one sense The Crucible was an attempt to make life real again, palpable and structured. One hoped that a work of art might illuminate the tragic absurdities of an anterior work of art that was called reality, but was not. It was the very swiftness of the change that lent it this surreality. Only three or four years earlier an American movie audience, on seeing a newsreel of Stalin saluting the Red Army, would have applauded, for that army had taken the brunt of the Nazi onslaught, as most people were aware. Now they would look on with fear or at least bewilderment, for the Russians had become the enemy of mankind, a menace to all that was good. It was the Germans who, with amazing rapidity, were turning good. Could this be real?

In the unions, communists and their allies, known as intrepid organisers, were to be shorn of membership and turned out as seditious. Harry Bridges, the idol of west coast longshoremen, whom he had all but single-handedly organised, was subjected to trial after trial to drive him back to his native Australia as an unadmitted communist. Academics, some prominent in their fields, were especially targeted, many forced to retire or fired for disloyalty. Some were communists, some were fellow travellers and, inevitably, a certain number were unaffiliated liberals refusing to sign one of the dozens of humiliating anti-communist pledges being required by terrified college administrations.

But it is impossible to convey properly the fears that marked that period. Nobody was shot, to be sure, although some were going to jail, where at least one, William Remington, was murdered by an inmate hoping to shorten his sentence by having killed a communist. Rather than physical fear, it was the sense of impotence, which seemed to deepen with each week, of being unable to speak accurately of the very recent past when being leftwing in America, and for that matter in Europe, was to be alive to the dilemmas of the day.

As for the idea of willingly subjecting my work not only to some party's discipline but to anyone's control, my repugnance was such that, as a young and indigent writer, I had turned down lucrative offers to work for Hollywood studios because of a revulsion at the thought of someone owning the paper I was typing on. It was not long, perhaps four or five years, before the fraudulence of Soviet cultural claims was as clear to me as it should have been earlier. But I would never have found it believable, in the 50s or later, that with its thuggish self-righteousness and callous contempt for artists' freedoms, that the Soviet way of controlling culture could be successfully exported to America.

Some greatly talented people were driven out of the US to work in England: screenwriters like Carl Foreman and Donald Ogden Stewart, actors like Charlie Chaplin and Sam Wanamaker. I no longer recall the number of our political exiles, but it was more than too many and disgraceful for a nation prideful of its democracy.

Writing now, almost half a century later, with the Soviet Union in ruins, China rhetorically fending off capitalism even as in reality it adopts a market economy, Cuba wallowing helplessly in the Caribbean, it is not easy to convey the American fear of a masterful communism. The quickness with which Soviet-style regimes had taken over eastern Europe and China was breathtaking, and I believe it stirred up a fear in Americans of our own ineptitudes, our mystifying inability, despite our military victories, to control the world whose liberties we had so recently won back from the Axis powers.

In 1956, the House Un-American Activities Committee (Huac) subpoenaed me - I was cited for contempt of Congress for refusing to identify writers I had met at one of the two communist writers' meetings I had attended many years before. By then, the tide was going out for Huac and it was finding it more difficult to make front pages. However, the news of my forthcoming marriage to Marilyn Monroe was too tempting to be passed. That our marriage had some connection with my being subpoenaed was confirmed when Chairman Walters of the Huac sent word to Joseph Rauh, my lawyer, that he would be inclined to cancel my hearing if Miss Monroe would consent to have a picture taken with him.

The offer having been declined, the good chairman, as my hearing came to an end, entreated me to write less tragically about our country. This lecture cost me $40,000 in lawyer's fees, a year's suspended sentence for contempt of Congress, and a $500 fine. Not to mention about a year of inanition in my creative life.

My fictional view of the period, my sense of its unreality had been, like any impotence, a psychologically painful experience. A similar paralysis descended on Salem. In both places, to keep social unity intact, the authority of leaders had to be hardened and words of scepticism toward them constricted. A new cautionary diction, an uncustomary prudence inflected our way of talking to one another. The word socialism was all but taboo. Words had gotten fearsome. As I learned directly in Ann Arbor on a 1953 visit, university students were avoiding renting rooms in houses run by the housing cooperative for fear of being labelled communist, so darkly suggestive was the word cooperative. The head of orientation at the university told me, in a rather cool, uninvolved manner, that the FBI was enlisting professors to report on students voicing leftwing opinions, and - more comedy - that they had also engaged students to report on professors with the same views.

In the early 50s, along with Elia Kazan, who had directed All My Sons and Death of a Salesman, I submitted a script to Harry Cohn, head of Columbia Pictures. It described the murderous corruption in the gangster-ridden Brooklyn longshoremen's union. Cohn read the script and called us to Hollywood, where he casually informed us that he had had the script vetted by the FBI, and that they had seen nothing subversive in it. But the head of the AFL motion picture unions in Hollywood, Roy Brewer, had condemned it as untrue communist propaganda, since there were no gangsters on the Brooklyn waterfront. Cohn, no stranger to gangsterism, having survived an upbringing in the tough Five Points area of Manhattan, opined that Brewer was only trying to protect Joe Ryan, head of the Brooklyn longshoremen (who, incidentally, would go to Sing Sing prison for gangsterism).

Brewer threatened to call a strike of projectionists in any theatre daring to show the film. Cohn offered his solution to the problem: he would produce the film if I would make one change - the gangsters in the union were to be changed to communists. This would not be easy; I knew all the communists on the waterfront- there were two of them (both of whom in the following decade became millionaire businessmen). So I had to withdraw the script, which prompted an indignant telegram from Cohn: "As soon as we try to make the script pro-American you pull out." One understood not only the threat but also the cynicism: he knew the mafia controlled waterfront labour. Had I been a movie writer, my career would have ended. But the theatre had no such complications, no blacklist - not yet - and I longed to respond to this climate of fear, if only to protect my sanity. But where to find a transcendent concept?

The heart of the darkness was the belief that a massive, profoundly organised conspiracy was in place and carried forward mainly by a concealed phalanx of intellectuals, including labour activists, teachers, professionals, sworn to undermine the American government. And it was precisely the invisibility of ideas that was frightening so many people. How could a play deal with this mirage world?

Paranoia breeds paranoia, but below paranoia there lies a bristling, unwelcome truth, so repugnant as to produce fantasies of persecution to conceal its existence. The unwelcome truth denied by the right was that the Hollywood writers accused of subversion were not a menace to the country, or even bearers of meaningful change. They wrote not propaganda but entertainment, some of it of a mildly liberal cast, but most of it mindless, or when it was political, as with Preston Sturges or Frank Capra, entirely and exuberantly un-Marxist.

As for the left, its unacknowledged truth was more important for me. If nobody was being shot in our ideological war but merely vivisected by a headline, it struck me as odd, if understandable , that the accused were unable to cry out passionately their faith in the ideals of socialism. There were attacks on the Huac's right to demand that a citizen reveal his political beliefs; but on the idealistic canon of their own convictions, the defendants were mute. The rare exception, like Paul Robeson's declaration of faith in socialism as a cure for racism, was a rocket that lit up the sky.

They wrote not propaganda but entertainment, some of it of a mildly liberal cast, but most of it mindless, or when it was political, as with Preston Sturges or Frank Capra, entirely and exuberantly un-Marxist. As for the left, its unacknowledged truth was more important for me. If nobody was being shot in our ideological war but merely vivisected by a headline, it struck me as odd, if understandable , that the accused were unable to cry out passionately their faith in the ideals of socialism. There were attacks on the Huac's right to demand that a citizen reveal his political beliefs; but on the idealistic canon of their own convictions, the defendants were mute. The rare exception, like Paul Robeson's declaration of faith in socialism as a cure for racism, was a rocket that lit up the sky.

fields.headline: The pioneer of sartorial vulgarity
fields.standfirst: 'I don't think many British businessmen would ever be caught wearing an Aloha shirt - their womenfolk would surely prevent it'
fields.trailText: 'I don't think many British businessmen would ever be caught wearing an Aloha shirt - their womenfolk would surely prevent it'
fields.body:
The death in Honolulu of a 91-year-old tailor called Ellery Chun received a lot of media attention around the world last week. For Mr Chun, although not exactly a celebrity, had earned himself a special place in history as the man who invented the Hawaiian Aloha shirt. This was an unforgivable thing to do, but its importance is undeniable. The Aloha shirt, made of crumpled silk or rayon, and decorated with garish pictures of palm trees, pineapples and hula girls, is probably one of the most offensive garments known to man. But its invention in 1931 in the midst of the Great Depression had a catastrophic effect on how men dressed from then on.

For more than 100 years before that, male fashion had conformed to English standards of decorum and restraint, as promoted by Beau Brummel in the 19th century. But the Aloha shirt marked the birth of the loud and sloppy American leisurewear that has since taken over the world. "His shirts will live for ever," said the Washington Post in an obituary of Mr Chun. "Or at least as long as men dream of tearing off their ties, ceasing their senseless labours, and partying down."

Aloha shirts were instantly popular with Americans visiting Hawaii, especially with US servicemen passing through the island during the second world war. For them, they represented the perfect antithesis to military uniform. They were also popular with Hollywood stars such as Bing Crosby and Montgomery Clift. President Harry Truman wore one on a famous 1950 cover of Life magazine. Elvis Presley wore one in the film Blue Hawaii.

Such endorsements guaranteed their respectability among male Americans, who seemed unaware of - or, at least, unconcerned by - the embarrassment they inflicted on their wives, and even more acutely on foreigners when they wore them on their holidays abroad. The Aloha shirt did untold damage to the reputation of Americans in Europe, especially when it was worn inside churches and art galleries, but it remained immensely popular at home as a symbol of a leisurely, convivial, easy-going attitude to life.

One of its most enthusiastic contemporary advocates is Neil Abercrombie, a Democratic congressman from Hawaii, who calls it "the ultimate expression of delighted creativity". "You can't help feeling good when you're wearing an Aloha shirt," he says. "It makes you feel free and at ease with the world. It's difficult to get upset with people when you're wearing an Aloha shirt." That sounds plausible. It is hard to imagine somebody getting road rage in one.

When Mr Chun created the first Aloha shirt by combining the styles of the loose checked shirts worn by Hawaiian sugar-plantation workers and the bright silk children's shirts made out of leftover kimono material by Japanese mothers, he wasn't indulging in a flight of fancy. He had already obtained an economics degree from Yale, and was only looking for some new product to sell in his family's clothing shop as a hedge against the Depression. ("I am sure he had a good business instinct," said his widow, Mildred.) Later in life, he got rid of the clothing shop and embarked on a successful second career as a banker.

But his most important legacy has been the lifting of a long taboo against casualness, ostentation and effeminacy in male dress. It is not yet as acceptable for men to wear skirts (unless they are Scottish soldiers or Fijian politicians) as it is for women to wear trousers, but the time may come when it will be. For the barriers between the sexes are being steadily dismantled, vanity is now as permissible in men as it is in women, and comfort is now widely regarded as the paramount requirement in clothes.

The other day a niece of mine celebrated her 40th birthday by giving a party at which guests were invited to appear in "60s/70s dress". It was a splendid affair, in which the women were very colourfully attired, many of them in miniskirts and bouffant hair-dos reminiscent of Mandy Rice-Davis. But the men, on the whole, were more colourful still, several of them in gaudy wigs and what looked like women's dresses (though they may have been kaftans).

I don't think many of these respectable British men - businessmen, most of them - would ever be caught wearing an Aloha shirt (their womenfolk would surely prevent it), but they may all the same owe more than they realise to Mr Chun. Without his pioneering efforts to encourage sartorial vulgarity in men, they would probably never have had the courage to wear such exuberant and sexually ambiguous attire. Now no man is frightened of looking like a peacock. And maybe Mr Chun bears some responsibility for the fact that my two-year-old grandson insists, despite all my efforts to correct him, on addressing me as Grandma.

fields.headline: How to queue
fields.trailText: In the noble art of queuing, Britain stands first, second and third among the nations of the world, principally because the other nations of the world don't really do queuing.
fields.body:
In the noble art of queuing, Britain stands first, second and third among the nations of the world, principally because the other nations of the world don't really do queuing.

To join a queue, you need to judge distance very accurately. Allow the same amount of space as you would to dance with your Great Aunt Hildegard at a wedding - leave too much space, and you'll become that horrible chink in the queue through which people pass.

If you're in a long queue, you must all look in the same direction. It simply isn't done to face backwards, as this is tantamount to an invasion of privacy. If people can't see the back of your head, they won't know you're in front of them. Let's face it, we would never have got off the beaches at Dunkirk if our lads had all been facing different directions.

Long queues inch forward, and it is vital that you take every inch when presented with the opportunity to do so. You can't wait until a couple of feet have opened up and then make a big leap forward, because the person behind you will immediately ask, 'Are you in the queue?' by which they mean, 'Don't you even know how to queue properly?'

Queues edge forward even when the front isn't going anywhere. When you're in a queue, it's advisable not to lean or tilt forward, because the 300 people behind you will all budge up into the vacant inches and you'll never get them back.

There is a hierarchy in queues. Being first in the queue is next to godliness. Being able to see the front of the queue is excellent. Being able to see people who can see the front is not bad. Seeing nothing but queue is not good. And being at the very back of the queue is dreadful. The only thing that'll make you feel better is when some poor loser joins the queue behind you.

Some queues get a little bit messy, so much so that, to an outsider, it may not be immediately apparent who is in front. However, every single person in the queue has a mental photo-finish picture of exactly who is where. That's why queue-jumpers are the lowest form of life, as they offend our deep sense of fair play. People who lead crushingly oppressed lives will stand for just about any indignity, but God forbid if any-body should push in a queue in front of them.

Queuing is a serious, skilled occupation, and you'll notice that loving couples never claim to have met in a queue. So, unless you've got a back of the neck to die for, you shouldn't expect to score there, either.

fields.headline: Self indulgent
fields.standfirst: 'It was horribly vulgar for me to fall for Will Self, like saying your favourite film is Casablanca or your favourite Opal Fruit is strawberry'
fields.trailText: 'It was horribly vulgar for me to fall for Will Self, like saying your favourite film is Casablanca or your favourite Opal Fruit is strawberry'
fields.body:
I don't know if you saw The Observer last weekend, but there were the most gorgeous photos in the colour supplement of Will Self, his three children and his wife, the journalist Deborah Orr. Taking a tip from Tony Blair, perhaps, this was a serious re-branding: no more the junkie stud, instead the funky dad. Rugged Will, blonde Debs, sun-kissed boy and girl kiddies, and gorgeous, bouncing baby - they resembled what an advert for Sunny Delight might look like if Sunny Delight decided to aim itself at people who holiday in Kerala and know what "frottage" means.

I felt there was something odd about these photos, and I kept gazing at them looking for clues. It took two days of puzzling over them before I tumbled: though he looked as certifiably, teeth-grindingly sexy as ever, I was free. For the first time in 10 years, I didn't fancy Will Self!

To get the full clout of this, you've got to understand what Will Self represented, sexually, in the 90s. Despite his drug and alcohol intake, to us London media babes he was a sexual icon packing the oomph of Jimi Hendrix, Robbie Williams and Gordon Brown all rolled into one. Every man wanted to be him and every woman wanted to have him. They usually did, too. At one time, I had three different friends whom he slept with for the first time on the same day. To add insult to injury, they all then proceeded to ring me up and tell me that they were having a passionate affair with him, he was The One, it was true love - the whole works. I soon put those bitches right, let me tell you - in a caring way, of course, as Dame Edna would say.

So it was horribly vulgar and predictable for me to fall for Will, like saying your favourite film is Casablanca or your favourite Opal Fruit is strawberry. For years, I just looked at him across crowded rooms - you couldn't miss him; he was so tall and prehistoric-looking - until one night he followed my husband and I home, and showed us how to smoke crack. I'll never forget what a thrill it was being bossed about by him - now cut a hole in the Evian bottle, now stick the straw in there; like some depraved Blue Peter presenter - and I'll never forget how he looked when it hit him: slumped on my black leather sofa, with just one big juicy tear coursing down his left cheekbone. I was lost.

Sad, sad, sad; I took to calling his home when I knew he was out, just to hear his voice on the answerphone - sometimes, and this is really weird, I'd call his answerphone from my bedroom when he was sitting drinking vodka in my front room. The reality of him seemed too much to grasp; I was happier with the unreal thing. I was so chronically embarrassed by the predictability of my crush that I even took to inventing false crushes to put people off the trail. But I'm sure I didn't convince anyone. It's the name-dropping that does it, I always think. The search-engine of my mind was primed, and from that moment any word typed in, from AZTEC to ZEBRA, would have come up with one answer: WILL SELF. I had a truly amazing capability to turn any subject of conversation around to him - even with my parents, who, of course, didn't know him from Adam. My mum would be talking about the dog's flatulence problem - and I could turn it on a sixpence right round to Will. No problem.

After a couple of years, I felt I had to tell someone, so I went to my best friend's school at 10 in the morning, saying that I was her aunt and that there had been a death in the family. I dragged her to the Groucho, and told her everything while she sat there in her school uniform with her mouth open, the two of us looking like some corny Hogarthian print about innocence and corruption, as Jeffrey Bernard told me later. Three hours later, I staggered from the bar into the foyer where I walked slap-bang into Will, who gave me the biggest hug and the saddest smile I've ever seen. Somehow, I walked out the door and round the corner into Old Compton Street, where I fainted, and I'm not the type who faints. When I woke up, I burst into tears. In the taxi on the way home, I realised I was becoming a mentalist. Truly, this is the nearest I think I've ever been to going nuts.

So perhaps a life without crushes won't be such a bad thing, and no one can say that it's not about time. I did notice while on holiday with my boyfriend's mum last month that, though the Corsican men were well fit, I wasn't interested in any of them. I thought this was really good of me, and I told Mrs Raven about my lack of reaction, thinking I'd get praise. Instead, she laughed scornfully and said, "I should hope not, at your age!" That hurt. So at least I'll be able to do dignified now. But, on the other hand, being a crushee is one of the few ways I can access my essential self, and it's not as if there are so many that I can afford to lose them.

I've always had crushes on people, really big bastards of crushes. I still remember the first crush I had, when I was four, on my friend Joy (an unexceptional lump, as I recall, whose miserable aspect chronically contradicted her given name), who I would prevent from leaving my house by lying across the threshold and crying. When I was 10, I had to stop watching Dad's Army because I had crushes on three of them - the spiv, the toff and the virgin - and found it too confusing. One reason I've always enjoyed the prospect of falling in love and getting married is because the dull routine of marriage lends itself so perfectly to the agony of the illicit crush. I got through the sexual side of my first marriage - for six years! - by pretending that my husband was my friend Peter York. And people say I don't have any imagination! For those of you outside the slimy boundaries of Mediaville, who can't conjure up either image, let's just say it was a lot like pretending Arthur Mullard was George Sanders.

My second husband was a really popular guy - which was great, because he had loads of friends who I could conceive huge crushes on. And often they had lovely girlfriends, who I could get gay crushes on, too! The Modern Review, my little magazine, provided endless crush fodder in the shape of young would-be writers - most of whom thought I was a stuck-up bitch because I wouldn't speak to them from one year to the next, lest my crush be detected. But still, Will loomed over my second marriage, lurked throughout my very enjoyable six months of lesbianism, and has seen considerable active service in my rich and strange inner life over the years since then.

And now? Nothing. I know it's a good thing, growing up, but I shall miss being crushed. Still, like Will himself, I'm taking it one day at a time.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Trevor Baylis
fields.trailText: Trevor Baylis
fields.body:
Trevor Baylis, 62, was born in Middlesex. He swam for Britain at 15 and, after National Service, worked as a stunt man, circus performer, escapologist and swimming-pool salesman. In 1991, he saw a TV programme about the Aids epidemic in Africa, and was inspired to develop a clockwork radio to broadcast health information. It was launched in 1995, and in 1997 he was awarded an OBE for humanitarian services to Africa. His autobiography is called Clock This!

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Being free from stress, and healthy.

What is your greatest fear?
Being hit by a truck.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Frank Whittle - he struggled for so long against indifference.

Which living person do you most admire?
James Dyson - he showed the big boys how to suck eggs.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
My distrust of others.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Greed.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Pipe, tobacco, matches.

What makes you depressed?
Feeling isolated.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My age.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Picking my nose.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
No.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
For certain offences.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My dog and my current lady friend.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Modesty.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
No.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
'What's going on?'

What is your greatest regret?
Failing to swim in the 1956 Olympics.

When and where were you happiest?
In my youth as a circus performer.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
An E-Type Jag.

What would your motto be?
I don't mind anyone looking down on me, as long as they don't expect me to be looking up.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a guy who made the most of life.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Never to give up; hang on by your teeth.

I don't mind anyone looking down on me, as long as they don't expect me to be looking up. How would you like to be remembered? As a guy who made the most of life. What is the most important lesson life has taught you? Never to give up; hang on by your teeth.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: DI Why?
fields.standfirst: 'I would rather undergo colonic irrigation on a plinth in Trafalgar Square'
fields.trailText: 'I would rather undergo colonic irrigation on a plinth in Trafalgar Square'
fields.body:
There are a few short phrases that can strike fear into the soul. My favourite is "simple self-assembly required". Self-assembly of a computer work-station from the cheaper end of the market is such ingenious torture, I'd rather undergo colonic irrigation on a plinth in Trafalgar Square.

"Come on, Mum!" cries Harriet, wielding the drill with the intensity of PMT. "Don't give up! Pass me that screw!" That drill she's waving is my very own new one. I am going to take control and assemble myself. It's my Vita Nova. However, have never liked carpentry too near tender young flesh. All that sawing, hammering, hacking. No wonder Jesus grew up a pacifist. "Be careful!" I shriek, grabbing the safety instructions ("Sicherheitshinweise"). "Keep children away... Maintain order in your working area... stay alert..." There are 20 safety instructions, and we are flouting most of them. "Stop, Harriet! Turn it off!"

Her father should be helping us, but he is downstairs watching cricket. A huge, hot hatred of DIY surges up from my aged loins. Strange how the menopause disinclines one to screwing. But what does Ex-Spouse care? For him, the end of the over transcends The End Of The Ova. Harriet, though once an egg of mine, seems doggedly intent on continuing. I am uneasily aware that she should be completing her project on social change in the 60s, and that the only aspect of the 60s that she has embraced so far is the mini-skirt.

"You must get back to your history homework in a minute!" I nag.

"Wait, Mum! Locate fittings A and B on panels 5024, 5026, 5020 and 5157... to tighten, simply turn fittings B through half a turn."

"Simply!" I groan. "That's a bloody joke!" Coax panels into faint shape of box, but they collapse loudly on to the floor - bare boards, of course - hard, deafening and trendy. Sink down on to what used to be my haunches and plunge into orgy of regret. Why did I ever start on this? The PC was all right as it was, sitting on a little Victorian table. Okay, I did bark my shin on it constantly, it did shake whenever I walked past, but so what? Endure brief urge to chuck PC, chipboard, flimsy plastic whatsits, drills, screws, bits, awls, rawlplugs, and little envelopes of glue right out of the window.

"What does it say next?" ponders Harriet. "Push the draw runners into the pre-drilled holes."

"The what?" I grab the paper. "The draw? It's a drawer, for God's sake! Bloody illiterates!"

"Oh, shut up, Mum - it looks really good." Harriet steps back on to the little envelope of glue, which, of course, spurts.

Since the self-assembly will clearly take forever, I decide we must discuss social change in the 60s as we go along.

"The cold war was the worst thing," I recall.

"What's the cold war?" asks Harriet, intrigued - for it sounds like some zany new ice-cream experience.

"You mean you've never heard of it?" She shakes her head. "When I was your age," I recollect, searching the while for screw A, "the nuclear arsenals of Russia and the US were pointed at each other and the world was within minutes of meltdown. In Cuba..."

"Cuba?"

Cuba possibly now a chocolate bar or brand of self-assembly furniture. "An island, not far from Florida - well, there were these missiles - Russia was sending shipments of missiles - my parents took us to Aberystwyth and we sat in the car on the sea front, listening to the news and wondering if we were going to be blown to smithereens. I was your age, and I remember thinking, I'm too young to die. I want to fall in love and have a baby."

Ex-Spouse puts his head round the door. "Shall we have a cup of tea?" It must be the tea interval, then. He is hoping I will make it for him. Still expecting the traditional wifely role, even though he hasn't lifted a finger to help us with the DIY. Never mind! I flee from the wretched chipboard monstrosity. Tea, yes sir! Bread and butter, willingly! Compared with the glorious dreams on the seafront at Aberystwyth, my life has turned out to be something of a botched-together chipboard monstrosity, but who cares? At least I can boil a kettle.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck remembers a sleepless night in Coonawarra
fields.body:
oonawarra, the south Australian wine region, boasts the most hospitable hotel in the world. It's called the Bushman's Inn. You share your room, whether you like it or not, with vast numbers of flying beetles. Indeed, on the evening I signed in, there were scores of them actually crawling over the reception desk, computer terminal, and telephone.

'A real computer bug,' I remarked cheerily to the receptionist, and beat a hasty retreat to my room, only to discover, to my disbelief and gut-wrenching horror, that several thousand were beating on the door and several hundred had already made themselves extremely comfortable in every crevice of the room. It was midnight. It was the only bed in Coonawarra.

I slept but little as my companions flew all-night kamikaze bombing missions, crashing into the walls, the light fittings and the bedhead. I got off lightly. Not more than half-a-dozen actually landed on me, but the effort to effect sleep with the mouth closed is not conducive to a peaceful night, let me tell you.

For this poor traveller, then, the word Coonawarra no longer summons up lush, south Australian sunshine and the tang of limestone that haunts the wines of the region. The word Coonawarra when glimpsed on a wine label makes my skin crawl. The very wine in front of me as I write, Tesco's own-label Coonawarra Cabernet Sauvignon 1998, is parked out of sight behind my computer so that can I relish the elegant, elongated liquid in my glass without having to catch sight of that word.

Beetles aside, Coonawarra is one of the very few wine regions in the world where the make-up of the sub-soil, the aforementioned limestone, has a dramatic, if subtle, effect on the wines. The Tesco's Coonawarra (16 points, out of 20, £6.99) is an exceedingly elegant example, offering exceptional balance with refined yet deliciously crunchy tannins. Tesco's non- vintage Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon (16 points, £3.99), on the other hand, parades chocolate with raspberry, a hint of earth and a flourish of blackcurrant - and that's just the climax. And Tesco's Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon Reserve 1999 (16 points, £4.99) is compellingly teasing with its hint of coffee and cream to the blackcurrant richness of the fruit, while Tesco's Chilean Merlot Reserve 1999 (16 points, £4.99) has that give-away leathery softness of merlot plus a savoury undertone.

Tesco also has a marvellous pinot noir from Chile, but it is not an own-label wine: it is Cono Sur Pinot Noir 1999 (16 points, £4.99), and what a racy, rich, stylish, thorny wine it is, with typical, heart-warming, Chilean extra-richness and a texture that is unusual, but deliciously welcome, in a pinot. This wine is also at Asda and Somerfield. I daresay it is the best pinot it is possible to salivate over for less than a fiver - it has more excitement and considerably more textured energy than many a much-vaunted, pricier Burgundy

At the CWS, there is an interesting bunch of wines on special offer until July 2. Vin de Pays d'Oc Syrah/ Malbec is a non-vintage Co-Op own-label wine. On offer at £3.29, it is juicy yet characterful. Ripe, but not over-baked, it has fullness yet still manages some delicacy of purpose. It rates 14.5 points. Marques de Grinon Malbec 1997, a compellingly quaffable tippling from Argentina, has soupy, spicy, graduated fruit that develops on the tastebuds with lingering finesse. On offer at £4.99, it rates 16 points. Star Mountain Touriga Nacional 1997, from Portugal, has invigorating tannins with ripe, raw, plummy fruit. It's on offer at £3.49 and rates 14.5 points.

Two splendid whites at the CWS, also on offer until July 2, are the own-label Australian Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, £3.29) and Fairview Chardonnay 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99), from South Africa. The Aussie has restrained richness and dry fruit, and is not only rather refined for the price but absurd. Cynics will suspect (as will snobs and know-alls) that many corners have been cut to turn out a chardonnay such as this for such a measly sum, but I can only say suck it and see. The Cape wine, to be found at Co-Op Superstores only, is more concentrated and more complex, offering, as it does, hints of woodsmoke, oak, yoghurt and fresh, under-ripe melon. It's a classic new-world chardonnay.

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: De Koninck
fields.trailText: De Koninck
fields.body:
De Koninck means 'the king', and many consider this russet Belgian ale to be worthy of such a crown. The name hails from Joseph De Koninck, whose small brew tavern has now grown into a substantial, but still independent, Antwerp brewery; the only one left in the city, in fact. Available at Safeway, for £1.05 for a 33cl bottle, the beer is 5% alcohol and is brewed from a blend of pale Pilsner malts and a darker Vienna 'red'. It's an all-malt beer, made without cheaper cereals or sugars, and only one hop variety, the aromatic Saaz from the Czech Republic. It is a complex ale, with a peppery-spicy aroma, an orange citrus palate, and a hoppy finish.

One thing you won't find in Safeway, however, is the traditional glass used to serve the beer in Antwerp. The Flemish name for it, bolleke, means 'little goblet', which causes great hilarity to British visitors. So much so that Antwerp waiters will urge you, with perfectly straight faces, not to drop a bolleke when they serve you.

fields.headline: Shack of the new
fields.standfirst: Beach houses Down Under are not the ramshackle, timber constructions of the past, says Stephen Crafti. In fact, modern Aussie architects use them to create an entirely new way of looking at the living space
fields.trailText: Beach houses Down Under are not the ramshackle, timber constructions of the past, says Stephen Crafti. In fact, modern Aussie architects use them to create an entirely new way of looking at the living space
fields.body:
The magnificent beaches of Australia and New Zealand feature prominently on all the postcards and brochures: the sight of some bronzed Aussie or Kiwi lying on the sand or braving the surf is the standard image used to entice tourists "Down Under". But, while the white sand will undoubtedly create a lasting impression on anyone who makes the journey, the fine contemporary beachside architecture will do much the same - as long as you take the time occasionally to glance in your rear-view mirror or up towards the embankments above as you make your way to the beach. For, nestled in the scrub or perched above the road, you will find some remarkable beach houses that bring new meaning to the term "beach shack".

Take the small beach-side resort of Somers, for example, on the Mornington Peninsula of Victoria. There, among the traditional homes with white picket fences, is one such beach house, designed by the architects Robinson Chen. What sets it apart, first and foremost, is that the front facade, with its deep-charcoal angled walls, lacks any of the usual features we associate with a house - there are no windows or doors. But then, says Kai Chen, "when you're designing a beach house or weekender, there simply aren't as many rituals that have to be followed. The kitchen can be much simpler, the laundry more minimal, you need fewer wardrobes, and there is less pressure on facilities in general. The spatial issues, and capturing the special qualities of the site, become more important."

Yet, while a house that is so at odds with its neighbours might be cause for concern in the city, on the beach everyone enjoys the novelty it brings to the street. "Occasionally, we get the odd bloke driving past who screams out his opinion, but the house generally brings a smile to those who pass by," says Denis Hildebrand, who owns the house with his wife, Janice. "Great design will stand on its own two feet, and will complement the surrounding buildings, whether they're located in the city or along the coast."

Further around the Mornington Peninsula, there is another house that shouldn't be missed: designed by architects McBride Charles Ryan, it is constructed from Mount Gambier limestone, and designed over three levels: the lower tier provides space for guests, the middle encompasses the living areas, and the top floor is given over to the leisure areas.

The core of the house is the spine-like staircase that follows the building's curvilinear form. "The stairs are one of the most important aspects of the home," says its architect, Rob McBride. "Two-thirds the gradient of the usual rise, one has the feeling of simply gliding into the next level, rather than being aware of climbing."

The entrance to the house, with its full-length porthole window, is as transparent as the steel front-gates to the property, which are also punctuated with portholes. The storage and display unit on the middle level, constructed from spotted gum, cuts a swathe across the room and echoes the lines of the bay. "The kitchen could be read as a large chopping block," says Debbie-Lyn Ryan, the practice's interior designer, "but it can also be seen as the layers of wood that have developed over time in the trunk of a tree."

Further north, at Palm Beach in New South Wales, the coastline hides many similar gems. One house, designed by architect Alex Popov, is connected to an existing house on a steep site. The new three-storey home - designed around a central void, with a dramatic pyramidal skylight - is cleverly nestled under the roof of the original residence, and features a roof-top observation deck. "The weekender is usually a much lighter building than the permanent residence in the city," explains Popov, "so it's also not as formal as the city abode."

While the structure can be far more relaxed by the beach, however, "one 'loose room' isn't enough", says Popov. "Many of my clients expect the larger bedrooms in the beach house, and many of the features that would be appropriate for eventual retirement."

This sense of "lightness" is one of the hallmarks of Queensland architects Gabriel and Elizabeth Poole, who are mindful of the change in attitude between city and beach. "Clients usually leave the fortress mentality behind when they head towards the beach," says Gabriel Poole. "It's a chance for them to have some fun with architecture. We try and introduce some of these more playful aspects into their city abodes. I think that, when they come to the beach, they have a freer spirit, and the outside walls disappear."

The Pasternak House, on Queensland's Sunshine Beach, characterises the Pooles' lighter approach. Overlooking the Pacific Ocean, the three-storey building nestles into a sloping site, so that the generous space within emerges only once you pass through the front door. The steel stairway not only creates a transparency inside the home, but echoes the shape of the horizontal glass louvres that provide essential ventilation in this tropical environment. Likewise, the playful geometric shapes, such as those that frame the window on the top level, are as functional as they are aesthetic.

In contrast to the strong geometric feel of the Pasternak house is the smaller yet equally impressive Mooloomba House on North Stradbroke Island, off the south-east Queensland coast. Here, the architects Peter O'Gorman and Brit Andresen have built a beach house that challenges the normal parameters of architecture.

According to Andresen, they had two key design requirements: "One was to fix its location in the landscape by designing as much as possible of its small site as outdoor rooms. The other was to explore the use of local hardwoods in domestic buildings in Queensland." They eventually decided on hardwoods as part of a stud-framed system, with 18mm waterproof ply sandwiched in between.

The result is a house that is delicately woven together within the larger context of its site and surrounds. Rather than the standard house, which appears to be rigorously controlled and manipulated, this home's major appeal is the very informality of its construction.

The Moolomba House, like all of these homes, shows that the once-humble beach house may just be the voice needed to steer our architecture in a new, freer direction, not least as city architecture is more often than not forced to conform to existing structures. One thing's for sure: they all guarantee that you'll never think of a beach shack in the same way again

 Beach Houses of Australia and New Zealand, by Stephen Crafti, is published next month by Images Publishing Group Ltd, priced £35.

Here, the architects Peter O'Gorman and Brit Andresen have built a beach house that challenges the normal parameters of architecture. According to Andresen, they had two key design requirements: "One was to fix its location in the landscape by designing as much as possible of its small site as outdoor rooms. The other was to explore the use of local hardwoods in domestic buildings in Queensland." They eventually decided on hardwoods as part of a stud-framed system, with 18mm waterproof ply sandwiched in between. The result is a house that is delicately woven together within the larger context of its site and surrounds. Rather than the standard house, which appears to be rigorously controlled and manipulated, this home's major appeal is the very informality of its construction. The Moolomba House, like all of these homes, shows that the once-humble beach house may just be the voice needed to steer our architecture in a new, freer direction, not least as city architecture is more often than not forced to conform to existing structures. One thing's for sure: they all guarantee that you'll never think of a beach shack in the same way again  Beach Houses of Australia and New Zealand, by Stephen Crafti, is published next month by Images Publishing Group Ltd, priced £35.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: It's crunch time: courgettes
fields.trailText: It's crunch time: courgettes
fields.body:
The subject A member of the endlessly varied grouping Cucurbita pepo . And summer's favourite vegetable.

The basics Courgette (known as zucchini to Italians and Americans) is the diminutive of courge, squash or pumpkin. That tells you almost everything you need to know about it. It's a bundle of seeds encased in a packet of water-rich cells, which in turn are encased in a water-proof skin. In this case, the skin is edible - only fools peel courgettes, though fancy-dan restaurants are permitted to score them with a canelling knife for decorative purposes.

The details The perfect courgette has smooth, shiny skin, often with its tiny bristles still intact. It does not squidge when squeezed at either the stalk-end or the flower-end - make these your essential tests before acquisition. It measures between six and nine inches in length (bigger specimens may be watery, marrow-like beasts). It is of roughly uniform circumference. If you're very lucky, it will still have its flower attached, which you can use for stuffing, coating in batter and deep-frying. Courgettes need to be washed, topped and tailed. After that, your options are sadly limited. Steam, boil, sauté, deep-fry. Oh, and I forgot to add that they are heavenly on the grill or barbecue. And if I forgot that, then maybe I didn't say that you can purée them for soup - if you don't bake them, that is, with tomatoes and onions. And did I mention that they are marvellous when stewed gently in olive oil and garlic? Or grated, with all the excess water squeezed out, and then fried in pancake form? Oh, yes, just one more thing: the courgette reaches its apogee in ratatouille (as if you needed to be told). Ratatouille is often ruined, but not by people who own Julia Child's Mastering The Art Of French Cooking.

Where to buy In summer, courgettes are as ubiquitous as, well, as courgettes. For flower-retention, grow your own.

The easy way out And did I mention that raw courgettes are revolting?

fields.headline: Follow the yellow brick road
fields.standfirst: Want your cooking to cut it? Then crack open the mustard, says Jeremy Lee. After all, generations of cooks have turned to it in times of need.
fields.trailText: Want your cooking to cut it? Then crack open the mustard, says Jeremy Lee. After all, generations of cooks have turned to it in times of need.
fields.body:
It is hardly surprising that a great feeling of satisfaction, even relief, tends these days to prevail over any gathering at table that is presented with a great roast, be that a rib of beef or a belly of pork.

Folk who have been on the receiving end of the foods of whim and fancy - which, to make matters worse, are more often than not cooked with enthusiasm rather than ability - can all too quickly become irascible malcontents. But hand them a slice carved from a joint that has been cooked with sound judgment and sure touch, and they will smile radiantly. Add to the equation some proper roast potatoes, a bowl or two of well- chosen vegetables and a bottle of Burgundy's finest, and your guests will be overcome with a feeling of utter completeness. The only thing missing from this spread, the very essence of British cooking, is, of course, mustard (horseradish being another story for another time).

The application of mustard to slices of roasted or boiled foods is a tradition that hails from way back when. So far back, in fact, that we now use mustard almost intuitively - it was much enjoyed by the ancient Greeks, while the Romans used it in a none-too- dissimilar fashion to the way we do today.

Even so, mustard's introduction to the foods with which we are now familiar, both those from home and abroad, did not really take place until rather more recently - in the early 18th century, to be exact. Alan Davidson, in his majestic Oxford Companion To Food, names a Mrs Clements of Tewkesbury in 1720 as the first to dry mustard seeds and then mill them into a powder; and reveals the inspiration for the phrase "as keen as mustard" as being a famous brand of mustard made by Keen & Sons of London.

Today, it is the mustard of Dijon - the strongest and most pure in flavour of all French mustards (the mildest being the seed mustard from Meaux, which is sold in those distinctive pots plugged with a cork and sealed with red wax) - that receives such plaudits. The most famous mustard of France, and rightly so, is the Grey Poupon from Dijon, created by Maurice Gray in Dijon in 1853, and sold in the most charming and distinctive blue-and-white china pots.

In England, meanwhile, was created a much fiercer powdered form of mustard that became just as popular - perhaps even more so on this side of the Channel - as these "made" mustards of Dijon. This powdered mustard was the creation of one Jeremiah Coleman, whose surname in the realm of condiments has since become as famous as Heinz, though probably not quite as far-reaching.

But then, the British have always held their relishes and chutneys in the highest esteem. Not without good reason, either, for their flavours marry so well with the fine, though simple, foods of our heritage, such as roast or boiled meats, and cheese. Mustard is, in fact, just the simplest and easiest of all such condiments - as exemplified by Coleman's production of a small tube of mustard that was of a handy size for the pocket.

One curiosity with mustard is that people who do not enjoy the feisty quality given off by its heat when eaten straight from the pot rarely like it even when it has been cooked. This reaction is difficult to explain, as mustard loses its heat dramatically when cooked. Within a sauce, say, it imparts a comforting warmth that goes very well with ingredients such as bacon, thyme, white wine and cream (all of them flavours that are hardly contemporary, true, but all are eminently delicious).

Mustard also graces one of the all-time great condiments, and a personal favourite, that regrettably does not seem to travel well out of its homeland: mostarda di Cremona, from the Italian town of the same name. This delight is made by crystallising whole fruits in a sugar syrup that has been made fiery with mustard essence, and the end-result is not only quite gorgeous to look at, but fantastic to eat with all manner of cold meats and cured sausages. The commercial varieties, however, tend to lack the zing of the original recipe, and are all too disappointingly predictable, so I'd steer clear of them if I were you.

As with all ingredients and condiments that are the backbone of any store cupboard, it is all too easy to overlook an old trusted ally; even to take it for granted, God forbid. Mustard has been with us for too long to fall victim to the fickle fancies of food fashion. Here's to its continuation as the cook's good friend.

All recipes serve six.

Mesclun

A salad of gathered leaves from the smallest and most tender lettuces.

A beautiful selection of the very best salad leaves you can get hold of (lamb's lettuce, baby spinach, endive, baby beet leaves, oak leaf)

5 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil

1 tbsp walnut oil

1 tbsp red-wine vinegar

1 tbsp Dijon mustard

Sea salt

Freshly-milled black pepper

In a clean bowl, whisk the salt and pepper in the vinegar until the salt is completely dissolved. Now whisk in the mustard and, when the mixture is smooth, pour in the oils in a fine, steady stream. Only dress the salad immediately before serving, giving the dressing another whisk before doing so.

To devil a chicken

6 little chickens (poussin or coquelet), spatchcocked

100g unsalted butter

Sea salt and freshly-milled black pepper

110g unsalted butter

2 very generous tbsp Dijon mustard

2 big handfuls picked flat-leaf parsley

3 cloves garlic

70g fresh white breadcrumbs

Juice of lemon

Pre-heat the oven to 225C/425F/gas mark 7. Lay the birds breast-side up and smear them with 100g butter, then move to a roasting pan. Season with sea salt and freshly-milled black pepper and place in the oven. Cook for 10-12 minutes and, when beginning to brown and the birds are almost cooked, reduce the temperature to 175C/350F/gas mark 4 for a further five minutes or so.

In a heavy frying pan, melt the rest of the butter, add the peeled cloves of garlic then pour into a liquidiser, along with the parsley. Remove the tray of roasting birds from the oven and drain off all the juices that have collected in the bottom of the tray. Spoon off the excess fat, then pour the cooking juices into the liquidiser.

Turn on the liquidiser to slow, and start to pulverise the parsley. Keep the machine on low until all the parsley is chopped small, then raise the speed and reduce the mixture to a smooth paste.

Add the mustard and lemon juice, then pour over the birds and return them to the hot oven for five minutes. Remove again from the oven, strew over the breadcrumbs and return to the oven until they have turned golden (around a minute or so). The birds will rest happily for half an hour before eating, and they taste even better when barely warm.

Rabbit in mustard, tarragon and green peppercorn sauce

I use very little cream in my main courses these days, preferring to save it for puddings. But, as always, there is an exception, and this sauce is it. Very good it is, too, with rabbit or chicken.

6 rabbit legs, skin on (or chicken breasts, wings attached)

Sea salt

A fully-charged pepper mill

100ml white wine

100ml chicken stock

400ml whipping cream

tbsp tinned green peppercorns

1 big tbsp good Dijon mustard

1 tbsp picked tarragon leaves, roughly chopped

Warm a heavy-bottomed frying pan over a medium heat. Season the rabbit. Pour a little oil over the bottom of the pan and lay in the meat. Leave to cook slowly, undisturbed, until the skin has crisped and coloured well. After 10-15 minutes, turn the legs and cook for just a few minutes more. Transfer the rabbit to a warm dish, and cover.

Increase the heat beneath the pan and pour in the wine. When it has bubbled down to just a spoonful of liquid, add the stock and simmer until reduced by half. Turn down the heat, tip in the mustard and cream, and whisk until the sauce is quite smooth. Add the peppercorns and a little of their juice, bring to a boil and add the tarragon. Stir well and serve over the rabbit at once.

Mustard and dill sauce

I never make gravadlax these days, as the sad affair that is the salmon fisheries of Scotland makes a decent fish virtually unattainable. The farmed matter is diabolical and not to be encouraged. However, I do love this sauce, and find it goes mighty well with herrings, mackerel and the like. I served it once with some baked hake and it was most agreeable.

3 level tbsp Swedish mustard (or Dijon mustard)

2 level tbsp caster sugar

2 tbsp good white-wine vinegar

150ml peanut oil

Sea salt

Freshly-milled black pepper

1 small handful picked dill

Put the vinegar in a bowl, and dissolve a little salt and pepper in it. Add the mustard, along with the sugar, and mix well. Slowly pour on the oil, whisking all the while (as when making a mayonnaise) and stir in the dill. (Some recipes include an egg yolk, but I think the sauce is all the better without)

 Jeremy Lee is chef at the Blue Print Cafe, London SE1

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Getting away from it all
fields.body:
Sir K's yacht in Monte Carlo, the waves of North Africa with Ricky, angst in Soho with Migraine Alan... I was considering my options on what to do, and about to check my e-stocks in the FT, when Mum dropped in. 'You have to look after Redwood. I'm off for a week,' she announced. Dog-sitting a feisty Doberman was not part of my weekend plans, but she's been through so much recently: marriage, Mike's cruel betrayal...

'Where are you going?' I asked her.

'I don't know; wherever passion is these days - please find it for me, darling,' she sighed.

I entered 'passion.uk' on the Mamma.com search engine, and found 42 sites. Most of them were about Celine Dion or unspeakable habits; in fact, the only site that combined both words was Passion Auto UK, offering 'webcam views of French motorways'. 'That's the British male for you,' Mum hissed. Next, I tried 'passion.spain', where the top five sites included 'Color, Friends, Passion', 'Flamenco, San Fermin, Bulls' and 'Almodovar'. 'passion.germany' produced 'Passion Play 2000 in Oberammergau - Christian Tours' and 'BMW (No summary available)', while 'passion.italy' came up with 'Ethnic cuisine' at www.sallys-place.com, and www.ukprivateinvestigators.com. 'I think I'll go to Madrid,' Mum said.

I checked lastminute.com. Their best price was £104 return. 'Try www.easyjet.com' Mum suggested, 'I like that guy Stelios.' His price was £85. 'I wonder if he's married,' she said dreamily.

So, Mum has gone to Madrid, and I'm stuck with Redwood. I checked www.petspark.com, a site that features an animal behaviourist who looks exactly like Anthea Turner (a woman I greatly admire), but sadly they don't have dog-minders. I'll just have to go back to www.dogsonline.co.uk.

www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk
